PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows, and copies will be referred to the appropriate ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the House of Representatives ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Andrew (from 19 citizens), Mr Hawker (from 60 citizens) and Mr Taylor (from 125 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of the undersigned parents and friends of childcare centres draws attention to the House that the Federal Government is seeking to link accreditation to eligibility for Childcare Assistance and in the opinion of your petitioners this link will only lead to higher fees for parents and no guarantee for improvement in quality of care for children. We know that quality care cannot be legislated for—it comes from the heart. Please help us to help our children.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to reject accreditation being linked to Childcare Assistance.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Chynoweth (from 27 citizens), Mr Snow (from 71 citizens) and Mr Snowdon (from 78 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Sex and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
We, the undersigned, are concerned about the escalation of sexually explicit and gratuitously violent material on television.

We do NOT believe that the Australian Broadcasting Authority is, to use its own terminology, `in tune with current community attitudes.' Over 100,000 Australians have expressed their concern relating to violence and pornography on television to the ABA, with no apparent effect. Dozens of major national companies have refused to associate their products with pornographic programs. `Blasphemous, indecent or obscene' material, which is PROHIBITED by ABT standards, continues to be broadcast on television regularly.

In addition, we are concerned that the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Station's Codes of Practice seem designed NOT to protect impressionable children, immature adolescents and adults from offensive television BUT to protect networks from prosecution.
We urge the Parliament to investigate the escalation of gratuitous violence and sexually explicit material on television and to institute appropriate measures to lift television standards.
And we will, as in duty bound, ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Filing (from 1,332 citizens) and Mr Williams (from 971 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Off-road Diesel Fuel
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Government's proposal to charge users of off-road diesel fuel a tax equal to one per cent of the amount rebated to them through the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme under the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Users of off-road diesel fuel currently receive a full or partial rebate of fuel excise paid in recognition that they should not have to contribute to road funding and maintenance in the same manner as on-road users of diesel fuel;
2.We object to being forced to pay fuel excise on diesel fuel and then being charged a tax, which the Government is calling an `administration fee', to have that money returned to us as a rebate;
3.This tax sets a dangerous precedent and could lead to governments charging similar taxes on rebates, such as those for personal income tax.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Forrest (from 174 citizens) and Mr Hawker (from 101 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the increase in excise of 7 cents per litre on leaded petrol and 5 cents per litre on unleaded petrol resulting from the Budget. This rise in petrol tax:
(1)discriminates against low income families and those living in rural areas
(2)increases business costs and will cause further unemployment
(3)adds further to the price of an already heavily taxed product
(4)breaks Mr Keating's election promise not to put up tax.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the House oppose these increases in petrol excise.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Kemp (from 499 citizens) and Mr Slipper (from 79 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Wine Wholesale Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned citizens respectfully ask the House to ensure that the Government's proposals to increase the level of wholesale sales tax on wine from 20% to 31% be abandoned. The Petitioners note particularly that:-
(1)At least $500 million in investment in the wine industry is threatened by this proposal.
(2)The implementation of this proposal could force more than 500 grape growers from the industry and threaten the jobs of hundreds of employees in wineries and other associated industries.
(3)The proposed tax increase will accentuate the current decline in domestic wine sales.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House the Government's proposals to treat unrealised capital gains and losses on listed securities as income under the Social Security Act 1991 and the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986. The petitioners note particularly that:
1.the majority of Australians regard the proposed method of calculating unrealised capital gains and losses as unfair and inequitable;
2.the implementation of this measure will have a deleterious effect on national savings and investments of pensioners and veterans;
3.we regard the Government's estimates of cost saving as spurious.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to abolish such legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Republic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia calls upon the House to:

PETITION.PARA: 1.Ensure its members cease promoting Australia to become a Republic and to firmly uphold and maintain the existing Australian Constitution 1901 in its entirety and
2.Oppose any move to remove the Queen of Australia as the Head of State.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tariffs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House

that with more than 10 per cent of Australians out of work, the concept of a level playing field and zero tariffs is rejected by Australian families who can see no evidence of benefit but substantial losses from the arguments put by economic rationalists.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to

act to ensure that Australia maintains a viable processing industry based on our Primary and Secondary Industries and that tariffs remain in place as long as other nations use non-tariff measures, tariff protection, etc.;
stop imports of goods that are supported by subsidies and other non-tariff or dumping measures to Australia; and
restore profitability to our farms and factories, employment opportunities to our citizens and to provide a future for our youth.

PETITION.TITLE: Queensland University of Technology Campus
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain residents of the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House the support of the residents of the Sunshine Coast to have the new campus for the Queensland University of Technology on the Sunshine Coast situated at Nambour such campus to share the site and facilities presently enjoyed by the Nambour T.A.F.E. College.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Government to consider the wishes of the petitioners as representatives of the residents of the area and to fund the proposed university at the above site.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Age for Men and Women

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain electors of the Division of Swan points out to the House their objection to proposed increase in the retirement age for women.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House not increase the retirement age of women and men above 60 years.

PETITION.TITLE: Higher Education Contribution Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

This petition of citizens and residents of Australia draws to the attention of the House the importance of the principle of equality of opportunity in higher education provision, and accordingly supports the progressive expansion of public funding for education programs, and opposes any increase in present levels of fees or payments levied upon participants in education.
Specifically, we the undersigned oppose:
(i)any increase in the basic rate of HECS debt accumulation;
(ii)any move to impose different rates of HECS debt accumulation proportional to cost of course provision; and
(iii)any move to reduce the income level of the initial repayment threshold for HECS.
We strongly urge the Government and the House to focus upon the importance of free, public, accessible education to a just and democratic society.

PETITION.TITLE: Retirement Age for Men and Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Swan shows:
Their objection to the proposed increase to the retirement/pension age of women from sixty years to sixty five years.
Your petitioners pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, should

PARA.TAB: (a)not increase the retirement/pension age of women above sixty years, and
(b)reduce the retirement/pension age of men to that of sixty years

PETITION.PARA: and your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled—
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:
1.Optometry has been covered by Medicare since its inception in 1975, and currently provides eye care to over 2.4 million people each year.
2.Removal of optometric benefits from Medicare will increase Government expenditure on eye care, as people will instead obtain their care from a more expensive source.

3.The cost to the public of eye care will increase, both through the removal of benefits for optometric consultations and the shift to ophthalmologists who generally charge well over the schedule fee.

4.The visual welfare of the community will suffer as people are discouraged from seeking eye care. Many eye diseases, such as glaucoma, do not produce symptoms until they are in an advanced stage. Any discouragement from seeking regular eye care will increase suffering from these diseases.
5.The removal of benefits for optometric examinations will disadvantage children, as undetected visual disorders will adversely affect their development and school performance.
6.Access to eye care will be reduced, particularly in rural areas, as part-time and visiting optometric practices will no longer be economically viable, and alternate care is not available.
We therefore request that the Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal health insurance system and that all eye examinations by optometrists are covered.

PETITION.TITLE: Wongaburra Nursing Home
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain electors of the Division of Rankin draws to the attention of the House the plight of the elderly in the shire of Beaudesert who face the prospect of having to leave Beaudesert to obtain nursing home care, which because of the lack of transport would isolate them from family and friends.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to persuade the Minister for Health (Brian Howe) to consider favourably the submission of Wongaburra for extra nursing home beds.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows
That the majority of Australians clearly stand united in satisfaction with their existing Australian National Flag which reflects their values, history, and heritage,
And that they condemn unwarranted attacks on their historic Australia Flag, whenever or wherever made by any Australian citizens.

So therefore we call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that the Australian National Flag, as publicly acclaimed in 1901 and confirmed under the Flags Act (1953), is not changed, replaced, or diminished at any time, or in any manner whatsoever, without such a proposal being first voted upon and approved by a majority of Australian citizens in a national referendum.

PETITION.TITLE: Leaded Petrol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled:

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes the reduction of octane quality of leaded petrol from January 1994, resulting from the Government's `Lead Roundtable' meeting. The petitioners note particularly that this reduction in petrol quality:
(1)Jeopardises the use of vehicles made prior to 1986 for operation on high octane petrol and could lead to many of those vehicles suffering serious engine damage;
(2)Will result in worse vehicle operation, higher emissions and greater fuel consumption for up to three million vehicles;

(3)Will have negligible benefit to the community, through reduced lead emissions, because the oil industry proposes to leave lead levels in petrol unchanged in Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia, and because the use of leaded petrol already is rapidly decreasing;
(4)Will disadvantage vehicle enthusiasts and low income members of the community.
And your petitioners therefore pray that the House take action to ensure the continued availability of high octane petrol for Australian motorists.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare Benefits for Optometric Examinations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws the attention of the Houses to the abolition of Medicare benefits for eye tests performed by Optometrists and Ophthalmologists on all members of the community except pensioners and Health Care Card Holders.
We request Parliament take steps to ensure that Medicare continues to be a universal health insurance system and that all eye examinations be covered.

PETITION.TITLE: 1993-94 Budget
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: that pensioners, the unemployed and low and middle income Australians will be worse off if the Government's 1993-94 Budget is passed unchanged by the Parliament;
the increase in the rate of wholesale sales tax will add to the tax burden on basic household goods;

the increase in petrol excise—in particular the excise on leaded petrol which is overwhelmingly used by low income people and farmers—will significantly add to the costs of operating a vehicle in Australia;
the increase in the tax on wine from 20 to 31 per cent immediately and 32 per cent next year will do serious damage to one of this nation's most successful industries;
the increase in the tax on lump sums received from unused leave is retrospective and unfair.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will reject these measures on behalf of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Free the Bears
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain residents of the State of Western Australia draws to the attention of the House that approximately 8,000 bears are being kept in cages in China for the purpose of extracting bile for medical purposes and that the cages are so small the bears cannot move, which results in some of them going mad. It is further brought to the attention of the House that the Chinese plan to increase the number of bears, for these purposes, to 40,000.
Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to object most strongly to this horrendous and tragic practice and ask that steps be taken to stop it immediately.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
(1)We the undersigned wish to signify our strong opposition to any change in the design or colour of the Australian National Flag.
(2)We believe that the current flag has served Australia well and will continue to do so in the future and represents a true manifestation of the Nation's history.

PETITION.TITLE: Petrol Excise
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully submit that:
The 1993 Federal Budget announcement by the Keating Labor Government to increase the excise on leaded fuel by 7 cents per litre,

PARA.TAB: is a selective, discriminatory tax on owners of older cars;
discriminates against lower income earners and country people who own most of these older cars;
will make it more difficult for people to save to purchase newer, more fuel efficient, less-polluting vehicles;
is therefore counter-productive to reducing lead pollution in the air.

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject this increase in fuel excise and that the House of Representatives will urge the Government to take initiatives to reduce the cost of manufacturing cars in Australia, thereby making new cars cheaper to buy.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of residents of the electorate of Indi draws to the attention of the House:
1.Overwhelming evidence is now available in Australia to indicate breast cancer can be treated and many deaths can be avoided if screening takes place early enough.
2.Many Australian women, particularly those in the country, are finding it increasingly difficult, if not impossible, to be able to undertake mammography screening.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House requests the Federal Government to undertake an urgent review of the present policies with the view to introducing expanded mammography screening services and including them in schedules to attract medical benefits.

PETITION.TITLE: Democratic Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note that our Constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:
ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners therefore request that:

PARA.TAB: Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia, as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Genetic Engineering
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: We citizens of Australia and custodians of the Earth draw to the attention of the House, our concern at the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods. Along with the unknown consequences to the Earth's natural life forms and environment, in order for Individuals and Multi National Companies to patent and own the food resources of the world.

We request you to pass laws prohibiting the continued use of genetic engineering and cloning of human beings, animals, plant life, microbes and foods. We want you to protect Humanity from the patenting and owning, by Individuals and large Corporate Bodies, of unnatural life forms.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House our strongest support for the existing National Flag.
The Australian National Flag is the most important symbol of the Australian nation and our national unity, and has evoked deep feelings of honour and respect from many generations of Australians.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully ask the House of Representatives to preserve our current Australian National Flag and to ensure that its design is not changed without the support of a referendum carried by the majority of Australians in the majority of States.

PETITION.TITLE: Unrealised Capital Gains and Losses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:

PETITION.PARA: (a)There is widespread concern and strong objection to the Government's proposal to treat unrealised capital gains on pensioners' and veterans' share investments as income.

(b)Savings in Australia are at a record low level and the implementation of the above measure is likely to encourage pensioners to cash in their share portfolios or divert them to less productive areas.

(c)Older people place great importance on achieving certainty and security in their financial dealings. This proposal will remove all certainty from share investments for pensioners and veterans and will significantly affect their investment decisions.

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled require the Government to repeal those sections of the Social Security Act which treat unrealised capital gains on shares as income under the social security income test for pensioners.

PETITION.TITLE: Mabo High Court Decision
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws attention of the House to the confusion over the Mabo High Court Decision and calls on Members to require the conduct of a Referendum to amend the Australian Constitution to reaffirm beyond doubt the rights of State Governments alone to define and issue land title.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will give this matter earnest consideration and your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek indulgence to raise briefly a matter relating to the broadcast of parliament last Tuesday, today being the first live broadcast day of parliament since. It is a matter which I wish to bring to your attention.
—The Leader of the National Party may proceed.

—On Tuesday, 23 November, in accordance with the procedures, a nationwide live telecast of the chamber was proceeding. After question time the telecast was to proceed until 3 o'clock, which is the arrangement that now applies, and at your call the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) moved a special motion. He was halfway through his speech when the telecast was interrupted by the announcer who controls those programs, who said, `We have a problem if we allow the telecast to continue until 3 o'clock. Because of the particularity of this motion there will be the rest of the speech by the member for Higgins followed by the member for Ballarat's speech. Then the telecast will cut out and we will not have the balancing item of a government minister's response. Therefore, we propose to end the telecast at this moment'. So, in mid-sentence, the speech of the poor young honourable member for Higgins was chopped off the nationwide telecast. However, this is in slight contrast to the guidelines, which are such that although now question time often goes only the exact 45 minutes the ABC has indicated that it will in fact allow the coverage to proceed for the full one hour. That is important on days when we have condolence motions, because quite often a condolence motion covers the first 20 minutes and question time then follows.

PARA.TAB: I ask, Mr Speaker, whether you could examine exactly what happened on Tuesday, 23 November, to see whether it was in accordance with the guidelines, for which you have custodian supervisory duties, and whether the right thing was done. I point out that in fact, in terms of balance, perhaps the ABC got it wrong. Ministers have 30 or 40 minutes of question time—naturally, as they are answering the questions—and time is virtually unlimited for them, whereas the coalition has much less time during question time. Therefore, the real balance over the course of an hour was not necessarily achieved by the action taken by the controller of that live broadcast to the nation. I will leave the matter in your hands, Mr Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Briefly, I say to the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) that the live telecast of question time—and, indeed, the proceedings of this House—has been the subject of some examination, as he is well aware. Indeed, a joint committee of both Houses has only recently been given a reference to examine the broadcasting generally of the parliament, both radio and television. This will be a matter which we will be able to pursue during that inquiry, in a broad sense, but I will have a look at the specifics of last Tuesday. I can say to the honourable member that the comment we have received in the past from the ABC is that, come 3 o'clock, it pulls the plug because it does not want people to be inconvenienced and not be able to see Sesame Street. However, the issue is something that we will pursue.

—On behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities, I present the following reports: The role of audit committees in corporate governance: a progress report; Trading of shares in Jupiter's Ltd; and Committee exchange with the New Zealand Parliament.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities entitled Trading of shares in Jupiter's Ltd, came about through motions moved in another place and followed complaints and allegations of irregularities in trading of shares in Jupiter's Ltd. It also came about because of general concerns about casinos and the creation of the casino on the Gold Coast in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: However, in undertaking that inquiry with the reference from the Senate, the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities found that there was nothing which it could pursue. The report covers that and says that the committee could find no irregularities at all. It recommends that no further inquiry take place.

The progress report entitled The role of audit committees in corporate governance is part of an ongoing matter for the committee. Many honourable members will be more than interested in the way that our major public companies are audited and the accuracy of those audits. It is pleasing to note that a large number of our major listed companies are now setting up internal audit committees. The committee is very pleased with that change of attitude.

Finally—and I know my colleague the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) will expand on this—the committee visited New Zealand shortly after the new parliament met. The committee members met with a large number of groups in New Zealand, including the comparable committees of the New Zealand parliament, the New Zealand round table and various other groups within New Zealand.

We were looking at the way New Zealand undertakes its corporate regulation and control. It was a very interesting visit and I think all members of the committee came back with a much deeper understanding of New Zealand, its role in corporate governance and the way its securities industry is going. I came back even more firmly convinced that the so-called fuzzy law area of company law did not exactly turn me on.

It is interesting that some countries in the world, including New Zealand, are taking the view that industry should be allowed to regulate itself more and government should tend to move away from that area. New Zealand's company law—fuzzy law, as I describe it—tends to be broad in compass and short on detail. That is a matter which I suspect we will debate down the track in this parliament with the Attorney-General's review of company law and corporate law in Australia. I commend these three reports to the House. They make good reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland). I would like to add to his comments on these three reports from the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities entitled The role of audit committees in corporate governance: a progress report, Trading of shares in Jupiter's Ltd, and Committee exchange with the New Zealand Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I think the remarks made by the honourable member for McEwen in respect of audit committees are worth noting. I commend to persons interested in this the addendum to that particular report of the committee. That addendum was prepared by Arthur Andersen. I am disappointed that there are still a number of public corporations which do not have audit committees.

Given the excesses of the 1980s and the problems with entrepreneurs, it seems to me that audit committees are a very good form of protection, not only for the companies and the shareholders, but also for customers, the public at large and certainly for the directors. I commend that practice which, although it does now extend to an increasing number of major companies, has still not been universally adopted.

I say nothing on the report on Jupiter's Ltd trading of shares, but want to make a few remarks about the exchange with New Zealand. There are three aspects of that. First, although the honourable member for McEwen has said that he does not take to fuzzy law with respect to corporations, my attitude is directly the reverse. The background of the committee's discussions with New Zealand was quite intriguing. It was pointed out that, whereas we have been priding ourselves on the introduction of the new Corporations Law here, in fact New Zealand has gone way beyond the concepts that we have pursued. It has looked at the Canadian precedent. We have spent years trying to resolve within our federal system the commonality of our Corporations Law. There is much to be said, I think, for our now looking to what New Zealand has done.

I see that legislation is going to be introduced by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General, the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan), later this day, regarding evidence and procedure in the New Zealand bill. There are observations in our report with respect to the increased commonality of our taxation law. We would now do well to turn to our Corporations Law and try to advance to the point New Zealand has already reached. The law New Zealand has adopted is significantly ahead of the one in Australia in a range of areas including, as I see it, the application of fuzzy law rather than black-letter law.

With respect to the comments of the honourable member for McEwen—and he did say that the debate would ensue—it is interesting that a justice of the New Zealand court with whom we discussed the issue said that, in his view, as indeed in the views of members of the New Zealand round table and others, there is little doubt that the courts will interpret fuzzy law with the same measure of responsibility on the members of the board of a company and the executive of a company as they would black-letter law. Indeed, they suggested that, to a greater degree, responsibility and commonsense would be achieved by the fuzzy law rather than our legislation. So I believe that there is much to be gleaned from that New Zealand precedent and that it is now time for us to follow it.

There are two other issues I briefly wish to address. Firstly, out of this committee there has been a further recommendation made to the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) with respect to what are now known as super shares and matters now before the Australian Stock Exchange. I would like to commend the Attorney-General on the correspondence he has entered into with the Chairman of the Australian Stock Exchange. I do not believe that introducing changes to the ASX listing requirements with respect to super shares on a subjective one case only basis is appropriate. I believe there does need to be appropriate time within which those matters can be considered, and I commend the Attorney-General for that correspondence and trust that the members of the Australian Stock Exchange will agree that there should be a reasonable extension of time before any new listing requirements are gazetted.

The final matter that I wanted to raise was that I note that there has been a very public debate between the Prime Minister of Australia (Mr Keating) and the Prime Minister of Malaysia with respect to a number of matters which are outside this particular field. One of the concerns I have had is that there is a field for us to apply in our region the same relationship we have in the CER. Within APEC, one of the difficulties and one of the barbs of Prime Minister Mahathir's argument is that APEC now is far more embracive than originally intended.

There is reason for us in our region to look not just at New Zealand but to look at Papua New Guinea and to look at the ASEAN countries and to try to establish some commonality in Corporations Law, in tax law and particularly in the normal practices of commercial law. I would trust that, in looking at where APEC is now headed, we do not forget that there are enormous advantages in conducting with countries in our region, particularly the ASEAN countries and PNG, negotiations that lead to the sorts of relationships that we have with New Zealand in respect of corporate law.
Motion (by Mr Cleeland) proposed:
That the House take note of the report on trading of shares in Jupiter's Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with standing order 102B, the debate is adjourned. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Banking, Finance and Public Administration Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, I present the report of the committee entitled Focusing on fraud: report of the inquiry into fraud on the Commonwealth, together with the minutes of proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the final report of the committee's inquiry into fraud on the Commonwealth. I am pleased to be able to indicate that the committee's report is a unanimous one and, given that you are in the chair, Mr Speaker, let me say that it continues the fine traditions of the committee's inquiry work. The inquiry was initially referred to the committee in March 1992 and referred again on 26 May this year by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch). In association with the general reference on fraud, the committee also had referred to it four audit reports related to fraud issues. The report addresses all the terms of reference of the inquiry. These are very wide ranging, covering such diverse matters as risk assessment to whistleblowing. Six years ago, the government changed its fraud management policy in response to the recommendations of the 1987 report on the review of systems for dealing with fraud in the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: My committee has essentially looked at the adequacy of that policy and how well it has been working since its introduction. The committee's work is the first major external review of the policy for the Commonwealth as a whole. The committee supports the basic thrust of the policy which gave managers responsibility for dealing with fraud against their programs. This approach, however, has created a more dispersed system for fraud control at the Commonwealth level than in other jurisdictions. This means that more attention must be given to ensure that there is consistent minimum duplication of effort and accountability in the way in which fraud management strategies are implemented.

Despite the committee's general support for the policy, we believe sections of it need to be revised to achieve a clearer definition of the roles of all agencies involved and to provide more guidance on how some strategies are used. As well, there is a need to redirect the policy and to achieve a more appropriate balance between agency independence and a Commonwealth-wide approach and more emphasis must be given to developing a picture of overall performance on fraud at the Commonwealth level.

The outstanding achievement of the policy to date has been to put forward control on the agenda of managers. The significance of this achievement should not be underestimated. All agencies that are required to do so are meeting their obligations to prepare risk assessments and fraud control plans or statements on an ongoing basis, albeit the quality of the documents prepared is certainly variable. To enhance performance in this area, the committee believes agencies would benefit from assistance from both the Attorney-General's Department and the Auditor-General.

The committee recommends the Attorney-General's Department develop and provide agencies with advice and guidelines on the preparation of risk assessments and fraud control plans and the Auditor-General review agency risk assessments and fraud control plans on a two-year cycle. In undertaking these tasks, the emphasis of both agencies is on providing agencies with constructive feedback.

The focus for the 1990s is to ensure that fraud control plans are actually implemented. The committee is looking for improved performance in this area. To facilitate this, it supports the improved accountability arrangements for fraud control proposed for the new audit legislation, whereby it would be a statutory requirement to prepare and implement plans and heads of agencies would be held accountable for the efficiency, effectiveness and ethics of their agency. Internal audit and the Auditor-General also have crucial roles in evaluating the effectiveness of the strategies introduced.

One of the most contentious issues which the inquiry addresses is the impact of the policy change which gave all agencies responsibility for investigating routine instances of fraud, thereby drawing them into the law enforcement process. The Australian Federal Police have been required to focus their resources on the more complex or larger scale frauds. There was some mutual suspicion between internal investigation units, which want to get into the really interesting fraud work, and the Australian Federal Police, which want a much greater role and involvement in internal agency fraud investigations.

To make the policy work more effectively, as well as efficiently, the committee recommends the role statements on investigation work of both the Australian Federal Police and agencies be strengthened. Standard criteria for the referral of fraud cases to the Australian Federal Police for investigation are recommended. These include, as a general rule, Crimes Act investigations being carried out by the Australian Federal Police, with the exception of investigations by those agencies which can satisfy both the Australian Federal Police and the Director of Public Prosecutions that they have the capacity and capability to undertake criminal investigations. A benchmark figure for fraud above which the matter should be referred to the Australian Federal Police for a decision on whether to investigate is also recommended.

The committee also recommends that the Australian Federal Police have an enhanced role in trading and coordinating fraud investigation work. Under the new policy arrangements, there is a need for the Australian Federal Police, the Director of Public Prosecutions and the Australian Government Solicitor to accept that agencies have an ongoing responsibility for the cases of fraud which agencies refer to them. Accordingly, the level of client services offered by those agencies is an important issue. While the Director of Public Prosecutions has done well in this area, there is considerable room for improvement on the part of the Australian Federal Police. Improved service standards are recommended for the Australian Federal Police.

Greater emphasis has been placed on the use of administrative remedies for dealing with offenders who commit minor frauds. The major problem is that disciplinary measures are not always implemented effectively. To redress this, the committee recommends that the Public Service Commission give a high priority to training managers in the understanding and formal use of the measures under the Public Service Act. An unwanted consequence of relying more on administrative remedies is that some serious cases of fraud are being dealt with inappropriately by using administrative remedies rather than prosecution. Heads of agencies must ensure that this does not happen in their agencies. If managers take up the offer of the Director of Public Prosecutions to provide advice in an early stage in cases, this would certainly help.

Under the new arrangements, substantial emphasis is placed on enhancing ethical behaviour in organisations. It is self-evident that this is directly affected by the attitude and behaviour of management. While developing codes of conduct, guidelines for companies doing business with the Commonwealth and post-separation guidelines are important, the critical issue is that staff are aware of them, understand their importance and conduct themselves accordingly. The committee stresses the Public Service Commission's important role in training in this area.

From the foregoing discussion, it is clear that the range of skills required to deal with fraud control is diverse. It encompasses audit, legal, investigative and administrative expertise. The committee strongly supports the use of multi-disciplinary teams in undertaking fraud investigation and control tasks where possible. Unfortunately, the adequacy of the new policy arrangements is difficult to assess since basic information on the extent and nature of fraud is frequently not available at agency level, let alone at the Commonwealth level. Accordingly, the committee recommends enhanced data collection and analysis systems for both policy and program evaluation and criminal intelligence purposes. Information technology would also facilitate this occurring.

Another key aspect of the inquiry relates to whistleblowing. Whistleblowing on serious fraud and maladministration is a necessary activity in the public sector. Support for whistleblower legislation was much greater than anticipated. With the basic theoretical work already completed by Finn and the Gibbs committee, a three-tiered approach to whistleblower reporting and protection is recommended in our report. It is recommended that all agencies nominate an appropriate high-level officer to receive complaints from whistleblowers. As well, it is recommended that the Ombudsman be the independent reporting and protection agency.

Legislation is not the panacea for dealing with whistleblower complaints and protection. Changes in community attitudes to whistleblowing and whistleblowers are also needed. I believe the committee's recommendations on whistleblowing are comprehensive, groundbreaking and particularly significant reform recommendations for public administration. The committee does not support the Department of Finance proposal for a formal reward system for informants.

While the committee is supportive of the critical role which advanced information technology can and does play in combating fraud, it remains concerned about a number of facets of the law enforcement access network, LEAN, project. The committee reiterates the need to put this project on a sound legislative footing as a matter of priority. In this dispersed fraud management system, coordination is essential if it is to work efficiently and effectively. While the committee recommends that the Attorney-General's Department retain responsibility for this task, it believes that this decision should be reviewed in the light of the recommendations of the Steering Committee on Commonwealth Law Enforcement Arrangements for a new law enforcement agency which could take over this role.

Despite the scope for improvement which the committee found in the Commonwealth's approach to fraud assessment prevention and control, when the Commonwealth's achievements are compared to those of other agencies, generally I think we can feel that those achievements have been quite substantial.

The further recommendations of the committee's work go to the very nub of ensuring the fundamental philosophy that some in the committee characterised as wanting to ensure that we have fences at the top of the cliff rather than ambulances at the bottom—effectively a system of prevention rather than cure relating to fraud control. I think that is a particularly important focus as to the way we would like to see fraud control management be undertaken into the future.

The recommendations relating to whistleblowing are particularly significant. We propose that there be a three-tiered process relating to whistleblowing. Fundamentally, in cases where people have used—or have lacked the confidence to use—established reporting mechanisms when they do go public, they will be entitled to protection from disciplinary procedures if they reasonably believe the allegation was accurate, notwithstanding their failure to avail themselves of alternative procedures, if the course was taken in excusable circumstances. Such a reporter should not be given any special protection regarding defamation or other laws; but rather there would be protection through the system, using the ombudsman arrangement, as we outline in the report.

I believe that the recommendations, when studied in detail, do achieve objectives that many in the community have felt have been particularly significant in many areas of the public sector across this nation. Certainly, there are examples at the state level where if those sorts of protections had applied in the past we would have had more effective and open public administration, with the right sort of public confidence maintained in the integrity of people and in their reporting arrangements. Clearly, the confidence that people have, because of the establishment of ethical behaviour throughout agencies, is crucial. The report goes to great lengths to talk about those issues and to provide the focus that fraud control should have in such circumstances.

I take this opportunity to thank the members of the subcommittee and the committee at large for their work. In particular, I thank the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) for their work in this parliament as members of the subcommittee. I also thank the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), who was a member of the subcommittee for part of the time. I pay tribute to the members of the subcommittee in the last parliament—the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) and the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear)—and to the committee as a whole for the support it has continued to give and the cooperation it has provided.

I also pay tribute to the staff of the committee: our advisers, Peter Bell and Bert Johnston from the Australian National Audit Office; the support staff, Amanda Garlick and, in the final stages, Denise Picker; the committee secretary, Chris Paterson; and especially the subcommittee secretary, Bev Forbes, for the magnificent job she has done in putting together very major elements in this report and for the tireless energy she has given to that task. I commend all of those people and thank them for their cooperation in maintaining the very important contribution that our committee has established over a period of time in the reports it presents to the parliament. I commend the report to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly support the comments made by the chairman of the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott), on the committee report, Focusing on fraud, which he has just tabled. While I was only a recent appointment to the fraud subcommittee when the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay) became ill, I found the work in preparing the draft report interesting. I also wish to pay tribute, as the chairman did, to the original and continuing members and to the staff—particularly Bev Forbes—who performed their work so magnificently.

PARA.TAB: Fraud is an important issue. None of us likes to be ripped off, as taxpayers or as individuals. To ensure that this does not happen, it is critical that the Commonwealth have in place an effective and efficient policy to deal with fraud and that the policy be effectively implemented. As the chairman has told the House, the committee supports the basic thrust of the policy. We support the emphasis on assessment and prevention as well as the decision to give managers more responsibility for dealing with fraud perpetrated on their organisations. However, the results of the committee's work have revealed some shortcomings in the way in which this policy is being implemented. I would like to address just two of the more significant problems.

Firstly, we are concerned that the Commonwealth's fraud control policy has been introduced without a clear picture of the nature and extent of the fraud problem that confronts the Commonwealth. Without this basic information it is difficult to assess the adequacy of the approach adopted. Unfortunately, to date, few strategies have been put in place to address this information deficiency. This is true at both a policy and a strategy level. Furthermore, the data which is available is mainly at an agency level and is not easily collated at a Commonwealth level.

To redress this deficiency the committee has recommended that all agencies improve their data collection and reporting activities. This includes all agencies which are not already doing so advising the Australian Federal Police of action taken on all fraud matters identified by an agency but not referred to the Australian Federal Police. It has also been recommended that the Australian Federal Police be responsible for collating this information to maintain a national criminal intelligence capability. Further, it has been recommended that the fraud control section of the annual reporting guidelines be revised to improve the relevance and consistency of the data reported by all agencies on an annual basis.

Secondly, the clear focus of the government's policy on fraud control has been to place the onus of responsibility on the management of agencies and to make fraud control a much wider issue than just law enforcement. This means that there are a large number of agencies involved in the fraud management process. Coordination is essential in this dispersed system to ensure that the full range of fraud management strategies are effectively and consistently implemented to ensure any lessons learnt in one area are passed on to other agencies and to maintain a Commonwealth-wide perspective as well as develop a comprehensive picture of overall performance in fraud control at the Commonwealth level.

Responsibility for coordination currently resides with the fraud policy and prevention branch of the Attorney-General's Department. Its focus is policy, setting standards, quality control of fraud control documents and exchange of information. The committee is concerned about the department's performance in the coordination role. It is concerned about the `let the managers manage' approach that the Attorney-General's Department has adopted to the coordination task and the limited resources it devotes to coordination. It is concerned also about the overshadowing of this work by the department's focus on the development of the LEAN system, and it is concerned about the time it has taken the Attorney-General's Department to prepare and distribute basic documents such as guidelines on handling fraud cases and a best practice guide, which are important tools to assist agencies in their handling of fraud cases.

As the chairman has just said, while the committee has recommended that the Attorney-General's Department retain responsibility for this task at present, we believe this decision should be reviewed in the light of any recommendations of the Steering Committee on Commonwealth Law Enforcement Arrangements for a new law enforcement agency which could take over this responsibility. In the interim we are looking for a significant improvement in the performance of the Attorney-General's Department in the coordinating role.

Finally, I would like to comment on an issue covered by the inquiry which is of particular interest to me, and that is the need for whistleblower protection. I believe whistleblowing in the public interest should be recognised as a necessary and lawful activity. It is a means of identifying and remedying illegal and improper conduct in the public sector.

Whistleblowing can save taxpayers' funds. I believe there is an obligation on the part of the Commonwealth government to provide a measure of protection to those who expose fraud and malpractice. From the committee's work it is clear there is a need for a comprehensive scheme to deal with whistleblowing. This is required both to provide a measure of protection for those who blow the whistle and to make it easier to deal with those who knowingly make false or misleading reports. There is burgeoning literature on the subject with several major studies undertaken at the Commonwealth level. The most notable are the work by the Finn and Gibbs committees.

In reviewing this issue the committee concluded that the three-tier approach, outlined by both the Finn and the Gibbs committees, is the most effective way to proceed regarding reporting of whistleblower complaints. The aim is to have a comprehensive scheme with the emphasis on in-house reporting and if, for whatever reason, the complainant is unwilling to say in-house the facility exists for making serious complaints to an independent external body. There should be a strong emphasis on confidentiality in those first two stages. If these systems work credibly and effectively there should be little or no need to go public. However, we do see this as necessarily being a sequential approach.

Much of the debate on whistleblowing surrounds the choice of an independent agency for both reporting and providing protection. I believe there are significant advantages in building on existing institutions to deal with this matter rather than creating a completely new structure, and fortunately the committee and I agree.

Given the ombudsman's ability to investigate and redirect for investigation a wide range of complaints raised by whistleblowers, the committee has recommended the ombudsman's office as the most appropriate agency to receive whistleblower complaints. I fully support that recommendation. The committee looked at a number of agencies which could perform the protection and counselling role including, in particular, the Merit Protection and Review Agency and the ombudsman.

The sorts of reprisals which whistleblowers may be subjected to are wide ranging and go beyond employment related matters. Accordingly, the ombudsman is the agency best placed to deal with such a variety of situations. The committee has recommended that the ombudsman should also be responsible for the protection scheme and for providing counselling for whistleblowers.

The committee has also made recommendations that it be both a disciplinary and a criminal offence to harass or discriminate against a whistleblower. It has recommended that there be similar offences for making reports which are known to be false and misleading. Appropriate accountability mechanisms for all agencies involved in the whistleblowers scheme have been recommended.

For this scheme to be effective, it is vital that agency officials have trust and confidence in the proposed lines of communication. This would be achieved only with time and through use of the scheme. Accordingly, to ensure that the scheme is working efficiently and effectively, the committee has recommended that it should be reviewed after two years of operation. Legislation is not the panacea for dealing with whistleblower complaints and protection. Changes in community and agency attitudes to whistleblowing and whistleblowers are also needed. We are looking for these to occur as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price The Hon L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments on the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, entitled Focusing on fraud. Before I do that, I would like to thank the secretariat staff, particularly Bev Forbes, the subcommittee secretary. I felt a little disadvantaged coming into this inquiry late; nevertheless I very much appreciated the opportunity afforded to me by the chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr Elliott).

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that the previous report presented to the House was from the Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities. One of my areas of interest is the consistency of treatment of criminal activity. Let me give an example. Does the House really believe that someone who commits a white-collar crime stealing $60 million will get the same sentence as someone who, for example, in my electorate holds up a bank and robs it of $6,000 or who holds up a service station and robs it of $1,000? There is something very wrong with our society when we treat white-collar crime—and that is what fraud is—as being somehow a nicer type of crime and somehow less injurious than other forms of crime.

I am pleased to say that one of the areas the Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration report picks up is this issue of consistency of treatment of offenders. On page 77 of the report it says:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no simple solution to trying to achieve consistency. Awareness and acceptance of the objective, however, is the first step. Many of the recommendations made in earlier sections of the report, such as the removal of anomalies in legislation dealing with fraud, improved guidelines on how to handle fraud cases, improved training in the use of disciplinary measures, better definition of the roles of various participants in the fraud and control process and improvements in the standards of service from the AFP and the DPP, will assist in achieving consistency.
The recommendations about reporting, thereby leaving us a trail so that in the future we can examine or revisit consistency, are going to be most helpful.

PARA.TAB: Both the chairman and the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) have commented on public interest. That is the area of whistleblowing that may attract the widest public attention. As a member of the subcommittee and the committee, I am delighted at the strong stand that the committee has taken in its recommendations on whistleblowing. Whistleblowers are nothing more than upright people coming forward and doing their duty. That takes a great deal of courage, and so-called whistleblowers in the past have been poorly served by the system for their acts in the public interest.

As the honourable member for Dawson pointed out, if we have an effective mechanism then potentially the Commonwealth purse can be saved considerable amounts of money. I do not want to go over again the three-tier system recommended or reinforced in the committee's report but I would like to highlight the fact that the committee has taken the issue very seriously by recommending that serious harassment or discrimination against a person who has blown the whistle be made a criminal and disciplinary offence.

A committee cannot signal its intention in a more serious way about an issue than by making such a recommendation. Importantly, the emphasis of the recommendations is that agencies should develop internal mechanisms that facilitate whistleblowing and allow the agency itself in the first instance to deal with it. We provide, of course, fall-backs. I am particularly pleased that, even where a whistleblower does not avail himself of the avenues that the committee recommends for developing his or her concerns and goes public, we still recommend a measure of protection for that person.

As the honourable member for Dawson has pointed out, the committee is signalling its very serious concern about this issue of whistleblowing by suggesting that its recommendations should again be reviewed after two years. I think we should be pleased about that recommendation. It signals that the committee's intention would be that if there are any deficiencies, if there needs to be further strengthening of these measures, then we will have the opportunity in two years time to revisit it and again recommend it.

I acknowledge that I have only spoken on two very small areas of the report. The chairman and the honourable member for Dawson have spoken in a much more comprehensive way. I commend the report to the House.

That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the Selection Committee for the opportunity to further debate this report which was tabled in this House one month ago. Unfortunately, I could not be in Canberra that day and so did not have the opportunity to speak on that occasion and I welcome the opportunity to speak today.

PARA.TAB: Before proceeding to the substance of the report and my comments on it, I would like to place on record my appreciation of the work of two people in relation to this report. One is the committee secretary, Robyn Webber, who worked diligently and professionally at all times and was of considerable assistance to the committee. The other is the chairman, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), who also worked very hard as the chairman. He obviously took on the task of chairmanship as a real job and worked very diligently indeed.

The committee was anxious to get this report into the parliament in a reasonable time before the end of the parliamentary session. We were very keen to have a proposal with respect to sitting hours considered by the government before the end of this session, in the hope that we might get proper reform of sitting hours for the autumn session next year. There is virtually unanimous agreement within the parliament, and with those associated with it, that there is need for a reform of sitting hours.

I must say I feel a slight sense of deja vu on the issue. Whilst I think it is very important, it nevertheless took me back to a previous incarnation I had in this parliament and 1981 when a very substantial move was made within the parliament to reform the sitting hours. In those days I was in the Senate and I worked then with a group of people, Liberal, Labor and National Party members, who made a very thorough effort to try to reform parliamentary sitting hours.

I was working with the then deputy leader of the Labor Party in the Senate, Senator Don Grimes. We were able to achieve a reform of sitting hours in the Senate. It was unfortunate that the matter became derailed in the House of Representatives and the reform did not flow on into here. I well remember the frustration of members from the House of Representatives back in 1981 at the fact that it had been derailed.

The then Manager of Opposition Business in the House, Mick Young, had much to say about that and, between then and the 1983 election, he had a great deal indeed to say on the subject of parliamentary reform including reform of sitting hours. In the event, when the government was elected in March 1983, we moved to an even worse pattern of sitting hours than we had previously. I had many conversations in 1981 with those who had been involved in this chamber with the attempt at reform, very notably, the former member for Robertson, the Hon. Barry Cohen. Labor members freely said that we got the worst of all possible worlds—whilst they thought they had complaints under the Fraser government, the situation was much worse all around when Mick Young moved to change our hours in 1983.

Having said that, there is of course a dissenting report, co-authored by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) and me, on the subject of sitting hours and on the subject of the second chamber. Because time is short, I am going to have to be very brief indeed. The contents of the dissenting report outline our concerns. I want to place on the record that, in the discussions that were held by the chairman, the honourable member for Bonython, and me with the leadership group of the opposition on this subject, the proposal that in the event ended up being the committee recommendation was one that was never discussed with that leadership group. It was a proposal that came forward within the committee after those discussions and was not one that was considered in those terms.

I have some criticisms of them which are obvious from the dissenting report, but one that I will place on record is that I do not believe that the proposed early adjournment on Thursday is practical as it stands. There are only two capital cities that are served by air flights that would get members home on a Thursday night. No other capital cities are served by air flights out of Canberra after the adjournment time proposed in the committee's report. This would require nearly everybody to leave during the adjournment debate. That would be a nightmare all around—for whips, for honourable members and for those who are trying to run the House's business. Effectively, either we would not go home on Thursday nights, or the House would have to adjourn somewhat earlier. That is a matter which needs to be considered further.

Obviously this is something that both the Leader of the Government (Mr Beazley) and the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Howard) will have to negotiate further. It is important, if we reform the sitting hours, that there be a consensus and that both opposition and government needs be met, otherwise we will get the worst of both worlds, a la 1981. The issues of question time and MPIs are of great concern to the opposition and I do not believe that the government can ignore them. As a postscript, it is quite important that there be some coordination with the Senate in this matter.

With respect to the second chamber, I have a view that a great deal more consideration needs to be given to all the ins and outs of what that proposal is meant to address. It is meant to address the speaking time available for honourable members. I think this issue needs to be treated properly. If we are going to move to two chambers of the House of Representatives, a lot of thought has to be given to it and a lot of input needs to be made. For example, input needs to be made by people such as the Hansard staff. There are all sorts of logistical issues that have to be raised. I think all honourable members ought to have a chance to think about this and make their input.

Of course, I am more aware of the details of this issue than most other members because I was a member of the committee. I have taken out some information that I think would reinforce the apprehension that I have in relation to a proposal of a second debating chamber running concurrently with this main House of Representatives chamber. Many members of this parliament who have been around for a while fear that the House of Representatives is rapidly sliding into irrelevance. Indeed, there was an article in one of our newspapers recently by a political journalist saying that he does not even know why the opposition turns up for question time because it is irrelevant and not what it is supposed to be. That is the perception of parliament at the moment. Question time is what most people see as having greatest relevance and, in comparative terms, it probably does. To go to two debating chambers and to have to choose between them, with all the conflicts and possibilities that will arise, would be a very serious move to make indeed.

I would have liked the committee to have taken some more time to look at potential ways of organising the parliamentary sessions so that, for example, the flow of business might be more even and we do not have fill-in debates at the beginning of a session followed by the horrendous use of the guillotine that we see now, which truncates everyone's rights. I also make the point that one of the bases for proposing that the second chamber would be acceptable is that there is a large number of bills that do not ever attract a division. The proposal is, of course, that the divisions would come back here.

I place on record the fact that the extraordinary and wide ranging use by this government of the guillotine means that the opposition does not call divisions when it would otherwise want to. By calling a division, it would be using up, say, 15 minutes of the very limited time allowed under the guillotine for the bills that follow. It is felt that that is not fair. If honourable members are to have any sort of opportunity to contribute to debate under a guillotine, limited though those opportunities be, opposition managers of business are loath to cut into that time by the amount of time that a division takes up. That in itself means that we are not getting the proper opportunity to express our view here.

There are matters that have arisen before in relation to the truncation of opportunities for honourable members to properly participate here that I would also like to mention. This week, the manager of government business in this place withdrew 155 orders of the day from the notice paper. They are all reports that this parliament has had no opportunity to debate.

We have had in this place a most dramatic decline in ministerial statements, which were once important. I apologise for not having had the opportunity to speak in advance to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Snowdon), who is at the table, about this—

SPEECH.PARA: I was considering dashing across the room a few minutes ago, but then I thought I might miss the call, because I was a bit unsure of when the previous debate was going to end—but I want to have incorporated into Hansard a table which shows the pattern of ministerial statements in the House of Representatives from 1970 to 1993. It details the number of statements made, the amount of time spent on them, and the percentage of House debating time spent on each statement. The table shows that the number of statements in 1970 was 63, and that that has declined to four this year. The total time spent on such statements in 1970 was 11.58 hours, this year it was 1.22 hours. The percentage of total House time spent in debating ministerial statements was 2.1 per cent in 1970, and that has declined to 0.4 per cent this year.

PARA.TAB: I also refer honourable members to a statement made by the Leader of the Government in the House on 15 October 1992, at page 2309 of the Hansard. It deals with the reason that he gave then for truncating that sort of debate in this House. I feel that this reason is totally spurious.

To say that, because the Senate follows a particular pattern of behaviour, we cannot debate ministerial statements in the House of Representatives is a real abrogation of this House's duties and responsibilities. (Time expired).
