TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the report of the procedure committee, About time—bills, questions and working hours. I take the opportunity at the outset to commend the chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett), for his diligent work in getting this report through for consideration in this session. I also thank the committee secretary, Robyn Webber, and the staff of the committee for the effort they put in to what I believe is an important report. It is one that is designed very squarely to ensure the continuing relevance and dynamic role of this House as part of the parliamentary process.

PARA.TAB: Having listened to the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan), I do not want to dwell too much on what was said. I would have to say that when the committee deliberated on these issues there was a very strong attempt to achieve consensus across the whole range of issues. Indeed, the majority report has the support of opposition as well as government members.

It was not a case of the committee undertaking a task designed to be beneficial to the executive; it was about trying to ensure that all of us, as members of parliament, had the most productive role possible in the parliament. It took account of many of the criticisms that are raised not just by members of the House but also by people outside the parliament as far as the operation of the House of Representatives is concerned.

The report has to be viewed as a package. I do not think the opposition can say, `We would like to see these reforms because they might be beneficial to the opposition', or that we on our side can say, `We would like to see certain reforms because they might be advantageous to the executive or to the government'. Rather, what the report should be about is ensuring that the House of Representatives continues to have a productive role and that all those who have the privilege to serve here in the future can be part of a productive process as well.

We had regard to some of the experiences of parliaments in other parts of the world relating to parliamentary proceedings. The practice in the Australian parliament is to have a very strong legislative framework compared to many other parliaments around the world and we wanted to ensure that we could make the most productive use of the time that honourable members spend here.

As well as that, many people raised their legitimate concern concerning the reform of sitting hours. That concern is shared across the community. Many people believe that our sitting hours are a relic of past times and that members now need to be treated in a contemporary way given the range of responsibilities that they have.

It is disappointing therefore, having tried to achieve those objectives, and in large measure fulfilling those criteria, that we now have a view expressed that there was not enough attempt at consultation. The chairman did consult and the committee tossed ideas backwards and forwards and compromised on certain matters. Many of us probably had other things we would have liked to see happen but the dialogue worked effectively in the committee. So to come here and hear others suggest that there are elements of substantial division is not a correct reflection of the committee's deliberations.

An important matter that I would like to refer to relates to the use of the second chamber that is proposed in the report. The honourable member for Moncrieff and all of us are concerned about the time we have to speak and deliberate on matters. There are many bills that come before the House because of our practice of having a very strong legislative framework to what we do. That means that there is desirability for discussion on legislation that is introduced but in many instances there is no division. Certain bills do not have contentious aspects that lead to a division in the chamber.

Because of criticism of the use of the guillotine and the belief that there is little chance for people to deliberate fully on many of the bills, this led us to recommend the creation of a second chamber where those non-divisive issues could be discussed. We believe it would be productive to have detailed discussion in such a chamber.

That is something that should be welcomed because that would give many, particularly backbenchers, a chance to make a real contribution in debates. They can develop expertise in an area. The second chamber would not always be governed by the time constraints that the present chamber is now governed by. There would not be the contention that some of the bills that come before the House have where there are predetermined views and positions that automatically lead to that process that would need to be pursued in this chamber.

If one looks at the proceedings of this session of parliament one can point to bills that would have been just as effectively debated through that second chamber process. Equally, a bill like the Native Title Bill would remain as part of this chamber because of the nature of the discussion and because of the position that the government and the opposition have adopted. So members would have had a chance to not only have that bill debated but others that might be less contentious would be debated thoroughly and constructively in another chamber.

When one amalgamates that proposal with the amendments that the committee proposes relating to the use of standing committees and so on, which has been one of the successful reforms of recent years of the parliament, there is then a process which gives all honourable members a chance to have a far greater input into the parliamentary process. Also, it provides the community at large with a chance to see, more precisely, the sorts of endeavours that members of parliament are undertaking.

It is a recommendation that is advantageous to the House and to its members. I do not think it is one that is going to be disadvantageous to the opposition in any sense, but it is certainly a recommendation that is helpful to the whole House and, particularly, to the 147 members here with the limitations we all have on the time we can speak on many important issues. The contribution that honourable members make can then be enhanced.

On the criticism relating to question time, the opposition should be prepared to acknowledge what the committee proposes in relation to question time. It proposes to address many of the criticisms that not only the opposition but others in the community have raised about the role that question time should play in the parliament. Specific requirements are included about the number of questions. An important reform is that it would enable a broader range of issues and a broader range of portfolio areas to be covered by all members. That is proposed in the trial measure of rostering arrangements for each sitting Monday.

Those changes will ensure the relevance of question time. They will ensure that members obtain the detailed information they seek at question time. The feeling of the community at large that the accountability of the executive is more appropriately addressed through those changes should also be welcomed by all members of the House.

Statistics show that in general it is the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and the senior opposition executive people who ask the majority of questions from the opposition side. The vast majority of questions are directed to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) or the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). Legitimate questions could be raised in many areas of public policy. That rostered arrangement on a Monday does seem to provide the scope for more breadth in the detail of issues that all members of parliament, particularly backbench members, can raise relating to matters to do with electorates and general public policy and portfolio areas.

Having witnessed this system working in the House of Commons, I believe it is certainly worth having the trial that the committee has advocated in its report. It is one, I am sure, which will help to maintain the right dynamics and ensure the relevance of the question time process in the parliament. The recommendation that the time be moved marginally will, overall, be beneficial to all members, but it will be particularly beneficial to the leadership on both sides of the chamber, given the other commitments they inevitably have during a sitting week. That is the sort of reform that should be encouraged.

There are other recommendations in the report, as I said, which relate to the role of standing committees. I welcome the enhancement that is proposed there. In regard to the hours, the reforms are certainly overdue. Very few people outside this place can understand why we have the sorts of hours we have now. I appreciate that there is a history of reforms in this area which have not always gone as far as members would like, but that is not a reason for not being serious about the reform of the hours and operations of the parliament.

Rather than be defeatist about that because of past changes that did not flow in the way the committee wished, we should be getting behind the report. It will be beneficial to the House as a whole, and it will certainly be beneficial to individual members of the House. I believe the committee's report goes a long way towards maintaining the very important role our House has in the democratic process in Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As a person who was not on the committee, I am pleased to have this opportunity to make a contribution. I have to admit to being a bit slow in making a written contribution, but there were reasons for that. I thank the honourable member for Bonython (Dr Blewett) for being in the chamber to hear these additional comments. That shows his interest in the subject and I am grateful for that.

PARA.TAB: The members of the opposition have a point of concern that I would like to record at the beginning. The documentation does not record a submission by the opposition. Apparently, we did make a submission, and the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) assures me that she personally distributed that submission to honourable members. That is a technical point, but we would like to see the record corrected.

My contribution is primarily to talk about the second chamber, which I endorse wholeheartedly. In fact, I would like to add to the concept, because I feel that the committee, in trying to come up with what would appear a revolutionary proposal, has possibly tried to weaken it a bit, when in fact it is quite a simple proposition, if we stop and look at it, in the context of a second debating chamber.

My view is that the thing we lack most in this place is debating time. The honourable member for Moncrieff referred to committee reports and such things. It is the greatest joke in the world to say in this place, `The report should be noted'. That means the rubbish bin, in the current context, and yet there are very serious matters dealt with in those committees and no doubt many honourable members would like to put something on the record about them. Let me say that the parliamentary debate in this place is substantially about putting things on the record. We know what the outcome is going to be in most cases, particularly in this place, and it is a case of honourable members having the opportunity to put things on the record. Speakers lists often are quite surprising. The pig levy bill will always get a very large speaking contingent, from both sides of the House, when some other matters, which one might think very technical and very important, attract a much smaller number of speakers. It is frequently the non-controversial bills that attract the speakers because it gives honourable members the opportunity to refer to matters and bring matters to the attention of the government. So I think the issue is debating time, and the second chamber would provide that, substantially.

Secondly, the second chamber should be able to be construed within our standing orders or our rules to be just that. I do not know that it has to have special committee relativity, notwithstanding that I support wholeheartedly the concept that all votes be taken in this chamber. In fact, I see a situation arising on occasions where during a debate an uncontested matter, because of a contribution of an honourable member, becomes contestable, and we will have to have a mechanism to bring it back in here. I do not think that is beyond our resources.

I believe also that there is no need to make the operations of the two chambers concurrent. When one raises the problems of party meetings and ministry meetings and so on, I see no reason why the second chamber could not be operating at that time. In the context of the Labor caucus, honourable members opposite would have to think about how they would record votes, considering that a vote might be tight and some people might be in that second chamber. But, because they do vote and have ballots, there should be a way around even that. In the context of the Liberal Party room that is not a problem because we do not vote. But those little things can be resolved. In setting the program for the two chambers, considering we would be sending to the second chamber the matters which were deemed non-controversial, that could be operating literally nine to five, Monday through Thursday, to make a simple analogy.

The whole issue is one of a chamber to extend debating time and, where practical, to make sure that the matters listed for the secondary chamber were matters that were of that nature, and where honourable members could have the opportunity to debate. It opens up even the question of how long we might have to debate but, when we consider all the reports and so on that might go in there, we would have quite a lot of extra matters coming onto the notice paper. Of course, that allocation of legislation is simply an administrative matter to be dealt with from time to time.

We can make an interesting comparison with the Senate. Because the constitution stipulates that there should be twice as many members of this chamber as there are in the Senate, we sit roughly the same sitting hours but get half the debating time of a senator. That is a simple fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —We make more sense.

—I am sure of that. I think that over time we have put ourselves in the position of demeaning our role somewhat through some of the circumstances that have arisen, and I think that in terms of legislation we would bring great credit to this parliament if we looked at a program that emanated to a degree from within the parliament. I make no apology for my arguments in trying to force legislation into this chamber as early as possible, and I have argued within our own forums that the first weeks of a session should be taken up with the tabling of legislation and the second reading speeches in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: We always talk about the debating time available to us but we never talk about the time to communicate with the community. None of us is expert on everything that comes before this place. We rely heavily on advice from outside the parliament and, too frequently, the problem is not the time we have in this place; it is the time we have to go and consult with the community and do those sorts of things.

I believe very strongly that we should require a process whereby in a government's program, subject to the decision of the parliament—in other words, if some urgent matter comes up, it can always be dealt with—the first thing we should do in every sitting period is put the matters on the record and then get on with the debates and the allocation. I think that too is important in the context of these recommendations.

I am also very concerned about some suggestions on question time. Honourable members would not be surprised that I am not very much in favour of the sin bin. I do not really think that would be very wise and, in fact, it would be a situation that might make it just a bit too easy for the Speaker when it is a prerogative of the parliament.

I believe that question time should be in the mornings. I have experienced it in the Fraser government. Fraser was very strong on the point that it set the tone for the day, that it got people into the chamber early in the day, and there are other good reasons. It should be followed by the matter of public importance and the matter of public importance should have a decent quorum associated with it. I do not know whether it is a matter of tactics, or what it is, but I think it demeans this place when people get up as the matter of public importance commences and walk out. In our own interests and for our own reputations we should think about that.

Furthermore—surprise, surprise!—I think that at least one MPI per week should be allocated to the government. What is more, it should be used wherever practical for ministerial statements, and I believe that the government should use it for that purpose. Surely they are matters of public importance and surely they should be put down in a constructive way and the opposition, of course, can respond. That should be made a rule. I would like to put the obligation on the government, if you like, but I would urge that it be used in that particular way.

These are the sorts of things we need to look at. I believe that general business Thursdays proved the point that we do not need lunch and dinner breaks in the chambers. I believe that we can all adjust to that.

I believe too that we should have a right, entrenched even in the law, for oppositions. I remind the House that we all get our turn at government and opposition, and opposition should have a right to at least request the suspension of standing orders in terms of a censure. A censure should be used sensibly but, on the other hand, it is far too important to have it struck out in a parliament. I do not think it should ever happen.

I also oppose the ministers' roster. I am not sure that that is necessary considering particularly the advent of parliamentary secretaries and extra debating time that would ensue. I think question time could be given an excellent focus. It is the time we keep the executive honest, and I remind honourable members that they can be of either political colour. I believe that the situation should not be changed or we would regret it as a House.
Private members business on Monday seems to make sense. These are some of the issues that I am touching on only briefly because the time is not available to me.

I would strongly recommend that we consider the second chamber as the second debating chamber. I recommend that we have television coverage. All these things change the way this place operates. We would get the debating time we need and we would get time for government business. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), I was not a member of this committee either and this is one of the rare occasions in this parliament that a person who is not a member of a committee or a delegation gets the opportunity to actually debate a report that has been tabled in this place. This is one of the issues, as the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) highlighted, that need to be addressed. We have a lot of important government and national business that is recorded in reports in this place which we never get the opportunity to consider in some detail. So that is one of many issues that I would like to comment on in this brief discussion this morning.

PARA.TAB: Having not been a member of the committee but, having been very interested in this issue since I came to this place almost four years ago, I wish to commend the chairman of the committee and all its members for the hard work that they have put in in producing this report. It is important to recognise that this is not a party political debate, this is not a partisan issue; this is members of this chamber on both sides seeking to achieve some major reforms of the procedures. I think absolutely every member of this place recognises that there is a need for major reform of the procedures of this chamber.

We have some ridiculous structures and times for debate. We are limiting our opportunities to do the job that we are here for, which is to put on public record and to debate matters of national interest and of concern to our constituents. We have to make sure that the government of the day—whether we are members of the governing party or members of the opposition—is able to listen to the concerns and views of our constituents. It is my view that, unfortunately, there is very little opportunity for backbench members on either side of this chamber to do the real job that they are here for—to represent their constituents' interests in the debates on legislation.

The other thing that needs to be recognised is that the business of governments in 1993 is far more complex and detailed than it was when a lot of these procedures were set up. We need to make some major reforms of the operations of this place to reflect the fact that there is a lot more legislation being put into this chamber and a lot more complex debate occurring or needing to occur on matters of government. We need to make those major changes to enable that to occur.

That is why I support the concept of the committee stage of legislation being shifted to a separate place—the honourable member for O'Connor called it a second chamber—and having it absorb that committee stage where there is agreement on both sides that it is a bill that is non-controversial.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be only five minutes a week!

—I think there would probably be more than that. If we actually look at the record of votes on legislation in this chamber, there is a bulk of legislation that does not attract opposition, although there are points of interest that are raised. So I think there would be an opportunity for much more debate and much more opportunity for honourable members to put on the record the views, interests or concerns of their constituents about particular matters of government business.

PARA.TAB: I do support the opposition on the matter of the overuse of the guillotine in this chamber. It is of great concern to me that, as a member of parliament, I am given the honour and the great responsibility of representing 80,000 people in the electorate of Moreton, who want to have their views heard. I recognise that the other 146 members in this place have a similar responsibility. So, when we have debate on very important pieces of legislation limited to 40 or 50 minutes, members of parliament are being denied the opportunity to do their job. We need to make some radical reforms to reduce or, if that is not possible, eliminate the use of the guillotine. I know there will be occasions when the guillotine will be required but they should be extremely limited. The guillotine has been very much overused in the four years that I have been here and it is something that we need to address.

I believe the second chamber reform would have the effect of enabling more time to be spent on debating those bills that often are the subject of the guillotine at the moment. The controversial and therefore vigorous debates where there are strong differences of opinion between government and opposition could then receive more time here as well.

I support the concept of a second chamber, although there is need for some changes to the committee's suggested format. If we support the concept in principle, I think we will then have the opportunity to reduce markedly the use of the guillotine, which will greatly benefit the process of democracy in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most courageous, Garrie.

—I thank the honourable member. I am now going to get nervous since it is described as a courageous effort on my part. I think there are many people on this side of the chamber who also agree that the guillotine is overused. We appreciate the fact that the government does have some requirements to get legislation through. The way in which the guillotine has been used to such an extensive degree in these last three years is a reflection of the fact that the business of government now is a very complex affair and that there are a lot more pieces of legislation needing to be debated.

PARA.TAB: I also agree with the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in that I do not believe that we need to have set lunch breaks or dinner breaks in the timetable. If honourable members look at the way in which Thursdays operate, it does not create any great difficulty that we do not have a lunch break. On second Wednesdays, we do not have a dinner break and this does not interfere with the operation of the debates in this chamber. I do not think we need to actually include the breaks in the timetable. This will allow several more hours each week for debates to continue.

My view is that the timetable needs to be amended so that we eliminate those set dinner breaks and lunch breaks; I do not think they are required. I also believe that there needs to be some flexibility in the timing of question time. I think where it is at the moment is too restrictive. It does prevent other activities from occurring around that time of day. I also share the concern of the opposition that maybe 3.30 p.m. is too late. I think that, if we eliminated the lunch breaks, we could in fact make some adjustment to the time of question time so that it was more reflective of the needs of the government, the opposition and the media who take a great interest in question time.

The other thing that I would like to talk about is the need for more time for consideration of reports. I mentioned this earlier. I believe that we do not get enough time in this chamber to debate reports. In the last parliament, I was on three standing committees. I felt that they were three very good standing committees; a lot of hard work was put into examining and considering major issues of national importance. After months and months of work—in fact, on a couple of occasions, it was two years of very solid work—we would come here and have 40 minutes to debate on the matter. Having spent two years travelling around the country, talking to a lot of people, putting a lot of effort into thinking about which way we should go, my personal contribution to debate would be five minutes. I would have five minutes to sum up all the issues that I had under consideration for two years. Now I chair a standing committee, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs committee, and when I present the report of that committee in a couple of weeks time, I am going to get 10 minutes to talk about something that we have spent seven or eight months working on. I just do not think that is reasonable. There is not an appreciation around the country of the enormous amount of work that is put in by honourable members.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon) —Order! The time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.
Bill presented by Mr Charles, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Industrial Relations (Membership of Associations) Bill 1993.
—Will the government support it?

—Who knows? This bill is for an act to ensure that individuals shall have, as well as the right to belong to industrial associations, the right not to belong to those associations and for purposes connected therewith. The objects of this act are:

SPEECH.PARA: a)to ensure that employers are free to belong to, or not to belong to, representative bodies of employers;
b)to ensure that employees are free to belong to, or not to belong to, representative bodies of employees;
c)to ensure that independent contractors are free to belong to, or not to belong to, representative bodies of employers, or representative bodies of employees; and
d)to make provision incidental to the operation of the Industrial Relations Act.

Australia is a democratic society and with both rights and responsibilities of its citizens defined in statute or recognised in principles underlying the common law. Among those societal values which we hold to be inalienable are the rights of free speech and freedom of association.

PARA.TAB: Our labour law, our industrial relations legislation, recognises the right of employees to form associations for industrial purposes concerned with their employment. We call these associations unions. That same legislation recognises the rights of employers to form associations for similar purposes.

This bill addresses a major inequity which has existed in practice, if not in law, since Federation. That inequity is the right of individuals to make a choice about whether to join a union or a representative organisation. States and federal law and courts have always upheld the rights of employers to form organisations and the rights of employees to form and join unions. For a long time, both state and federal governments have countenanced the concept of the closed shop in industrial relations. The closed shop requires all employees of an industry or an enterprise to belong to a trade union.

The Industrial Relations Reform Bill 1993, which left this House for the Senate earlier this week, contains a clause which states that an employer must not terminate an employee's employment for reason of union membership. However, the legislation nowhere states the contrary, that an employer shall not terminate an employee's work by reason of that employee's non-membership of a union or an association. The government's reform bill also makes it an offence to induce an employee to stop being an officer, delegate or member of an organisation or association. It fails, however, to provide symmetry by saying that it should also be an offence to induce an employee to join a union or association.

The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), during the committee stage of debate on government and opposition amendments to the reform bill, committed himself to carefully examine opposition proposed amendments which would, for the first time, guarantee in statute the end of the closed shop. During debate on the reform bill and during the committee stage, I foreshadowed this bill which I introduce today. This is the second time that my private member's bill has been introduced in the House of Representatives, the former occasion being on 6 December 1990. In the last parliament, that bill did receive a second reading debate on 16 May 1991 but, as is usual with the government in these matters, the bill was not allowed to proceed to the third stage or to a vote.

A research poll in 1992 found that 87 per cent of Australians thought that trade union membership should be voluntary. There is a vast difference between union membership in the public and private sector, with the public sector propping up the entire system. I believe in the right of unions to exist but I also believe that they should compete fairly, based on services which they provide to their members and in a voluntary and not a compulsory sense. This bill in its several parts is designed to ensure that membership or non-membership of an organisation does not affect employment; that is, it gives full effect to the concept of voluntary union membership and voluntary membership of associations.
I wish to thank Robyn Webber, Director of the Chamber Research Office, for her invaluable assistance in updating my 1990 bill. I commend the bill to the House.
Bill read a first time.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! In accordance with standing order 104A, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Mr L.D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the victims of the Soviet-engineered Ukraine famine of 1932-33 should be solemnly remembered on its 60th anniversary; and
(b)this anniversary underscores the hardship and inhumanity of life under the repressive regime of the Soviet Union;
(2)condemns the systematic disregard for human life, human rights and human liberty that characterised the policies of the Government of the Soviet Union during the Ukraine famine of 1932-33;
(3)observes that the man-made Ukraine famine is a graphic illustration of the unacceptable alternative to democratic pluralism and social justice; and
(4)therefore is of the opinion that Australia should seek to help Ukraine as it transforms its society.

I was pleased when approached by one of my constituents, the President of the Ukrainian Council of New South Wales, Jurij Dechnicz, to move a motion that is very similar to one passed in the US House of Representatives, following a 1984-85 decision by that body to establish a commission on the Ukraine famine. It came before that house on 12 October of this year, and a motion was passed with wording similar to this one. In the Ukraine itself on 7 February, there was a momentous decision by the central committee of the Ukrainian Communist Party, recognising the crime of the Ukraine. In the period from 10 to 12 September in the Ukraine, there were days of sorrow in remembrance of the victims and there was a declaration of a national day of mourning.

PARA.TAB: Due to early postwar migrant settlement in Merrylands and Birrong, three of the 10 largest municipal concentrations of Ukrainians in Australia in 1993 are in the three municipalities which constitute my electorate. The surrounding municipalities of Bankstown and Fairfield have similarly large concentrations. I have been fortunate in the last few years to play an active role in a number of matters raised by the Ukrainian community.

These matters cover a range of issues, including charities to support the Chernobyl children; diplomatic representation in this country; the reality of a trade imbalance in our intake from the Ukraine; and sister city relationships. I am pleased to note that one of these three municipalities, Auburn, has been very active in establishing a tie with a Ukrainian city. Also, there has been the establishment of a friendship society within this parliament.

The reality of the famine, which was largely precipitated by government action, was underlined by the 1959 census in the Soviet Union which, for the Ukraine, indicated a situation of 4.7 million more women than men. That sort of thing does not happen by accident. That situation was caused by the war, the terror instituted by the Soviet government, and the famine. That massive imbalance in population was demonstrated in that first census after the Second World War.

I would like to examine the history of the famine. In 1926, 21 per cent of the total harvest in the Ukraine was forcibly taken by the central Soviet government. In 1930, the government increased that percentage to 30 per cent with a bumper harvest. The problem was that the central government authorities failed to recognise that that particularly large harvest was abnormal. It was also attributable to extraction of all stocks, reserves and seeds.

In 1931, when the total harvest in the Ukraine dwindled to 18.3 million metric tonnes, the central Soviet government pressed ahead and succeeded in extracting 91 per cent of what was a much lower total harvest to meet its targets. That led to a very strong movement of people to the cities and into central Russia. It was to lead eventually to extremely repressive moves by the central government.

So in 1931 and 1932 the area under cultivation dwindled greatly. There were massive losses in the actual amount of crop collected. This did not really stop the central government. It did not set it back. In 1932, at the Kharkov conference, Molotov and Kaganovich stamped on all local opposition. That opposition, it is fairly important to note, occurred even within the Ukrainian Communist Party. I will come to that at a later point.

The central Soviet government refused to accede to any of the concerns which were being expressed by the local population. It ignored the starvation that was spreading throughout the Ukraine and strongly pressed ahead with its measures. Thus, on 7 August 1932, the government implemented a piece of legislation which was related to the fact I mentioned earlier about people drifting out of farming areas because of the starvation situation there.

That measure basically attempted to further restrict people's movements. On 20 November 1932, the government used emergency measures to retract all wage payments that had occurred. It reclaimed more grain and requisitioned seed and forage. The next month, internal passports were instituted which required the registration of individuals. That, of course, was a measure that was to be very much criticised in the following decades.

Finally, on 17 March 1933 measures were introduced to prohibit collective farmers from moving to factories or mines. This was to deal with the massive problem caused by the high requisitioning of crops. Basically the government took most of the crop, and the amount left for farmers kept dwindling the whole time, with the result that farmers were being hit by hunger and the farming situation was deteriorating further. But the government failed to look at the reality of that declining crop and to adjust accordingly.

On 14 December 1932, with a degree of opposition from the Ukrainian Communist Party, the central Soviet leadership accused the Ukrainian Communist Party leadership of what it termed `nationalist deviation'. The membership of that party declined from 520,000 in June 1932 to 470,000 in October 1933. Events led on 7 July 1933 to the suicide of Nicholas Skrypnyk, perhaps the leading Ukrainian communist, as the central authorities said that the measures instituted by them were being undermined, supposedly by a Ukrainian nationalist leadership, and that really the Ukrainians were responsible for these failed measures.In an article on this matter, Victor Swoboda has said:

SPEECH.PARA: terror of 1929-33 was not directed against non-communists alone. Any manifestations of national communism were also punished. When the Ukrainian communist leaders repeatedly appealed to Moscow to alleviate the 1932-33 famine by reducing grain delivery quotas from the Ukraine, the central committee of the Soviet party refused, accused the Ukrainian leadership of nationalism, blamed it for the non-fulfilment of the quotas and a new wave of OGPU terror was unleashed. Between June 1 1932 and October 1 1933 75 per cent of officials of the local Soviets and 80 per cent of the local party secretaries were dismissed, and by late 1934 half of the rank and file were purged. Most were shot or exiled.

As I said, the central leadership had over a period of years continually increased the requirements on the Ukraine, which was, and still is today, the breadbasket in that region. That is a major economic reality of the independent Ukrainian state. The central leadership failed to take heed of, or deliberately went ahead despite, the very grave results its actions were having on the population. I referred earlier to the population imbalance that was evidenced in the 1959 census. It is claimed with a fair degree of certitude that between seven million and 10 million Ukrainians died during this period. Victor Swoboda further commented:

The speed of the collectivisation without the necessary machinery and the exorbitant demands for grain from Moscow culminated in the catastrophic famine of 1932-3. A Soviet law authorising the OGPU to shoot on sight anyone who attempted to steal `socialist property' was applied throughout the Ukraine, sometimes against starving children.
A similar motion to that I have moved was supported in the US Congress. To put this in some kind of context, I quote from the statement of one of the movers of that motion, Congressman Rohrbacher:

Let us all, as we look back at this crime of 60 years ago, as this resolution suggests, vow to one another that we will not remain silent as people are sent to their death, whether it is in communist China or whether it is in fascist right wing regimes that perhaps wave American flags when the American ambassador arrives on the scene.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in seconding the motion, and I reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to congratulate the honourable member for Reid (Mr Ferguson) on moving this motion before the House this morning. I must say that I am particularly heartened by the fact that a member of the left faction of the Australian Labor Party has moved such a motion decrying the failed policies of communism and socialism 60 years ago in the Ukraine. I would like to generally support the motion. For those who might be listening I think it is appropriate that I should read its terms:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)the victims of the Soviet-engineered Ukraine famine of 1932-33 should be solemnly remembered on its 60th anniversary; and
(b)this anniversary underscores the hardship and inhumanity of life under the repressive regime of the Soviet Union;
(2)condemns the systematic disregard for human life, human rights and human liberty that characterised the policies of the Government of the Soviet Union during the Ukraine famine of 1932-33;
(3)observes that the man-made Ukraine famine is a graphic illustration of the unacceptable alternative to democratic pluralism and social justice; and
(4)therefore is of the opinion that Australia should seek to help Ukraine as it transforms its society.

It is appropriate to consider, as did the honourable member for Reid, the appalling situation in the Ukraine during the period in question. When I was approached to speak on this motion, I must confess that I had little knowledge of those horrible events 60 years ago—in my electorate of Fisher we have a very small Ukrainian community—but when I looked at what had occurred I was horrified. After a previous term in politics and many years practising law it takes quite a lot to shock me, but when I looked at the facts of that sad period of Ukrainian history I was totally appalled. What happened is a case study of the failure of the policies of socialism and communism.

PARA.TAB: Communists and socialists love central planning. The honourable member for Reid highlighted how edicts kept emanating from Moscow to be imposed on the local community. Pleadings by local communists on behalf of the people of the Ukraine fell on deaf ears. The only response received from Stalin, Molotov and others was that the Ukrainian people were simply manifesting a form of nationalism which was to be stamped out at all costs.

The history of the grain harvest in the Ukraine is indeed a history of the failure of the collectivisation of farms. The inefficiencies which occurred as a result of collectivisation moved the situation very much towards the famine of 1932-33. Prior to the famine, there had been a good harvest, but the central authorities kept imposing ever higher quotas that were unattainable, while the Ukraine was constantly criticised over its failure to meet these quotas.

I understand that the basis for the insistence by the central authorities on obtaining so much grain from the Ukraine was that the Soviet Union needed to purchase capital equipment from overseas, and in order to do so needed to export more agricultural produce. Therefore, the quotas which were imposed on the Ukraine were constantly increased to a stage where they were simply not able to be met. Over a very short period, the total quota of grain demanded by the central authorities from the Ukraine was increased by a massive 2.3 times. Initially, there was an incentive given to peasants to join collectives because their quotas were three times lower than those for farms which were not collectivised.

It is also interesting to note that the Ukrainian harvest was only 27 per cent of the entire harvest of the Soviet Union, but the central authorities demanded that the Ukraine supply 38 per cent of the total grain procurements of the USSR; that helped to create a tragedy. When one looks at the response of the central authorities to the understandable failure by the Ukraine to meet the quotas, it appears to be a very similar situation to the Holocaust which occurred in the Second World War.

Because the farmers were not used to operating on a collective basis, a very large percentage of the harvest was lost in harvesting. I have statistics here that are constant exhibitions of the horror that was imposed on the Ukraine during that period. The Communist Party sent out large numbers of people to the Ukrainian countryside to forage for grain to be seized. In fact, at one stage it had 40,000 of its members in the countryside, but that number increased to 112,000 as the party sent people out to try to extract grain, from ordinary Ukrainian peasants, to meet Moscow's very unreasonable quotas. Indeed, even the seed grain was seized. One does not have to be a mental giant to appreciate that if one takes the seed grain it is going to be absolutely impossible to sow anything like the amount of grain that is required.

So we have this situation where the grain crop declined and the amount of cultivated land was reduced. Then there was the reduction in coal output which reduced the availability of fuel. There were other problems with the railroads in the Ukraine and the metallurgical industries and the result of all of this was that the economy of the Ukraine fell into a very grave crisis.

The communists called a conference. They brought along people from the Ukraine and people from the central government but, as was indicated previously, the sum total of that conference was that Moscow said, `We don't care how you extract this grain from the people of the Ukraine but you must do so'. There was a great tug of war over the harvest. People were going out there seizing the property of individuals to meet Moscow's unreasonable quotas. There was a reign of terror throughout the countryside. The Communist Party of the Soviet Union gave authority to shoot anyone who attempted to steal what it described as the socialist property of collective farms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous.

—It is outrageous and it is a tragedy. Even peasant children suffered this horrendous fate. All grain was to be grabbed and starvation stalked the countryside. As happens in many communist and socialist societies, the media, such media as remained, were prevented from reporting what occurred. Even cannibalism occurred in some parts of the Ukraine during this period. The honourable member for Reid has pointed out, quite accurately, that people were stopped from moving to other parts of the Soviet Union and other parts of the Ukraine and they were not allowed to get other jobs.

PARA.TAB: I would like to read an extract from a book by V. Tendriakov entitled Death. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: cattle died for lack of fodder, people ate bread made from nettles, biscuits made from one weed, porridge made from another . . . A year of hunger moved through the country . . . in the little park by the station, dekulakized peasants expelled from the Ukraine lay down and died. You got used to seeing corpses there in the morning; . . . Not all died; many wandered through the dusty mean little streets, dragging bloodless blue legs, swollen from dropsy . . .
That was what happened in the famine. Ten per cent of the population of the Ukraine starved. While Hitler, of course, killed six million Jews, five to seven million people in the Ukraine perished.

PARA.TAB: The hypocrisy of the ALP is interesting to note because during this period and during the period subsequently, luminaries in that party were constantly trooping to the Soviet Union and praising the so-called benefits of socialism and communism. I think that is a great tragedy. However, it is a credit to the honourable member for Reid that he has come into this House and raised this matter of very great concern.

We need to devolve power, we need to decentralise power, and that is indicated in the debates before this nation today. We find that the government in Canberra wants to take all power as seen in the area of Mabo and republican debates, and centralise it in Canberra. We can see what happened in the Ukraine in the 1932-33 famine when there were central controls imposed at that time from Moscow.

What one needs to do is to move power away from the centre and have that power exercised in local areas where local needs are understood. It is clear that the Soviet authorities were not interested in the terrible events that they caused in the Ukraine.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman The Hon L.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)noting the serious and widespread damage to property in the recent floods in Victoria; and

(b)observing that many farmers, small business operators, families, landlords, employers/ employees, community groups and local government authorities whose property has been seriously damaged by the floods have been unable to receive adequate or appropriate assistance from existing State or federal natural disaster programs—
(c)is of the opinion that a major and urgent review of the adequacy, effectiveness and relevance of federal and State natural disaster relief policies, programs and procedures must be undertaken; and
(d)calls on the Government to initiate an appropriate review without delay.

I seek an urgent review of state and federal natural disaster relief procedures and programs for all Australians who have been affected by natural disaster and for those who will inevitably and unhappily be affected in the future. In particular, I seek the review as well as urgent, additional help for the people and communities in the north-east, central highlands and Goulburn Valley of Victoria.

PARA.TAB: On 3 October 1993 a flood described by a state emergency coordinator as the worst natural disaster since Ash Wednesday swept into cities and districts of Wangaratta, Benalla, Myrtleford, Bright, Oxley, Euroa, Violet Town and Shepparton. Final estimates of damage to farms, homes, shops, factories and public assets have not yet been able to be calculated, but an estimate prepared by Emergency Management Australia, formerly known as the Natural Disasters Organisation, reveals that 10,000-plus people were affected, 6,500-plus homes, shops and factories were damaged, 6,500-plus people were evacuated, 4,000-plus kilometres of fencing were destroyed and 5,000-plus livestock were destroyed. An estimate at this stage of $200 million of total damage is yet to be confirmed but the figure is obviously very large.

Crops and land damage have not yet been fully assessed but, in the Myrtleford area, 20 per cent of tobacco crops alone were destroyed. Hops and other crops were also devastated. The flooding was a catastrophe of unparalleled proportions. Some communities have recovered quite well; all are trying valiantly to overcome the aftermath and you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would know the great spirit of the people who live in regional parts of Australia and how courageous they are in adversity. I would like to pay tribute to all emergency workers, volunteers and relief agencies from churches, Red Cross, CWA, service clubs, local government and government organisations who helped and are still helping so many of the victims.

However, cities such as Benalla are still in very serious difficulties although they are recovering. It is a pleasure to visit them and to see their brave faces. I know that my friends on the other side were there the other day and I thank them for going there. The October floods devastated the central business district of Benalla and many farms in the area. The social fabric of this community has been severely threatened because of the massive devastation.

In the Myrtleford and Bright areas many hectares of valuable farmland have been devastated—some of the most valuable and productive farmland in Australia. Some farmers and their families have been left with a lunar-like landscape, with craters, rocks and debris strewn over what was rich farmland. The plight of tobacco growers, already the victims of state and federal policies to reduce smoking through excise but which totally ignore the need for a decent fair go for them to help cope and adjust to those government policies, is a matter of very great concern.

So we have farmers, small businesses and landlords who need special assistance and help, but so far many have not been able to bridge the gulf that exists in the state and federal programs. Despite the valuable assistance which has been given or promised to date, in particular by the state government, and which I would like to thank both Commonwealth and state governments for, there is clear evidence that the existing guidelines, that both governments work under and that have been used by state and federal governments in the past and in the present, are inadequate and need urgent review.

So I urge federal and state governments to immediately provide special assistance in the form of grants to enable farmers and small business to re-establish; to introduce more flexibility into aid programs, for example, to permit farmers and small businesses to apply the low interest rate loans that some of them have been offered towards repaying or reducing existing high interest loans; to agree to organisations such as skillshare and other relevant agencies being funded to enable the unemployed to help tackle some of the flood damage that is there.

Federal and state governments should be involved, in my view, from day one of the major disaster. I recognise the constitutional responsibilities of the governments, but they should be involved nevertheless from day one together, as partners. There is only one successful team, Mr Deputy Speaker, and that is a united one, one sharing all the challenges and all the responsibilities.

The federal government should amend its legislation to unshackle the Minister for Defence and permit the minister to make a declaration of major disaster. Under present federal law, such a declaration can only be made by the federal minister if there is death,

SPEECH.PARA: injury and major property damage. In our case, in north-east Victoria, thankfully, no deaths occurred but huge damage has. The federal minister says he cannot make a major disaster declaration because the criterion in his act, death plus damage, has not occurred.

PARA.TAB: Disaster insurance needs to be reviewed. Many people miss out because of the act of God. Others can claim on their insurance because they are `lucky', because something else caused the water to enter their building. We should establish a national natural disaster insurance scheme so that everyone can have protection from the consequences of natural disasters. We should have a parliamentary committee re-examine all existing state and federal natural disaster insurance and programs.
I seek leave to introduce into Hansard a summary of Australian disaster events since 1967, which I believe is in a form appropriate for incorporation.
Leave granted.
