TALK.START.PARA: —We should act now to tackle this problem. Emergency cash grants should be available to small business and farmers. Improvements are needed in providing immediate disaster recovery advice, for example, how to disinfect homes, treatment of carpets, et cetera. Lengthy delays in implementing scheme mechanics must be eliminated. In our case, several weeks elapsed before grant applications processes were introduced. Rural financial loans do not respond in every case to the real needs of small businesses and farmers. There is a need to recognise that special assistance is required. Volunteers helping disaster victims should not be precluded, as some were, I understand, from claiming special social security benefits because the application was late because they were out helping others and did not go in and claim for themselves first.

PARA.TAB: Local government needs much more support and needs speedier and more flexible approvals for carrying out the massive rebuilding and restoration program of public property. Funds should be allocated, in my view, on a replacement cost basis and not on an historical restoration cost basis. Immediate seeding grants should be made to flood recovery committees. Uniform language should be used in the insurance industry so that people understand better the insurance that is offered to them. More education should occur anyway on what can and cannot be insured in Australia. More funding is needed to address medium- and long-term social problems, for example, the housing for elderly people affected by the floods, counselling for people involved and stress management. Reviews of flood and disaster warning systems are also required, in my view urgently, to eliminate some inadequacies that emerged.
I am very happy to be supported by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), who will second my motion and also make a contribution. His electorate was also very seriously affected.

I would like to make a plea in the last few seconds that I have that, whilst I expect there will be some froth and bubble in this debate about who is at fault, which government, which level of government, the final outcome of this debate will be that all sides of politics in this parliament will agree to work together to form a committee that will put politics aside and review the disaster guidelines and provide the assistance that is needed by so many worthy Australians who are in desperate plight now.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Does the honourable member for Murray second the motion and reserve his right to speak?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—I welcome the opportunity to speak here today on the motion moved by the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman). I appreciate the concern which drives the honourable member for Indi to move this motion, supported by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd). Going to the flood-ravaged areas of Victoria at a time close to the peak of those floods, and again during the subsequent wash-up, gave me a clear understanding of the needs of the people of Benalla, Myrtleford, Shepparton, Numurka, Nathalia and the other flooded areas in the Echuca and Wodonga regions. It gave me the opportunity to speak to the people of the flood-affected areas whilst they were dealing with the event and subsequently when they were trying to come to terms with it, both emotionally and financially.

PARA.TAB: I know that the honourable member for Indi has also experienced the immediate and the after-effects of the flooding and is acting in the interests of his constituents when he puts this motion to the House. I think it is a concern that is shared with the people of that area by the honourable member moving the motion and by all members of the House.

For the past few years I have been involved in organising delegations from the New South Wales flood mitigation authorities to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to discuss flood problems in New South Wales and the role the Commonwealth may play in helping to mitigate flooding. In 1990 I organised for a delegation to meet New South Wales parliamentary Labor Party members whose electorates had flooding problems so that they could help in pushing for greater assistance.

The vast majority of the New South Wales electorates with a substantial flooding problem are Labor electorates, and so it is a problem that affects not just Liberal Party or National Party electorates. My electorate of Page has some of the most serious flooding on the east coast of Australia. Lismore suffers the most dramatic flooding. Floods regularly inundate the main commercial centre, causing damage worth hundreds of thousands of dollars to business and interrupting agricultural activities in the surrounding rural areas.

Most honourable members would be aware that I was a publican in a former life. The hotel that I own at the moment, which is a recent building in Lawrence on the Clarence River, becomes an island during flooding on the Clarence. In the previous hotel patrons would stand knee-deep—or thigh-deep—for their daily drop. On one occasion I recall serving a beer to a chap who was sitting in a boat in the bar. Everything surrounding that hotel was under water—cane farms, dairy farms, beef properties, homes—and the loss of personal effects and production capacity of the agricultural areas was massive.

The residents always have an amazing resilience. Floods do seem to bring the community together, and although they may have suffered financial loss the community seems stronger as a result. On the Clarence flooding is something the residents have come to terms with. It happens regularly, so they just deal with it in the best possible way they can, but the recent flooding in Victoria was something different.

A 100-year flood, as the terminology suggests, does not happen very often. If it happened in my electorate base of Grafton, the town would be devastated. Levy protection there has given a false sense of security that leaves residents vulnerable. If we had the same type of 100-year flood that Victoria suffered, almost every home and every business would be inundated and the loss of personal property would be inestimable. It was this type of flooding or, more appropriately, the frequency of flooding which caused so much trouble in Victoria.

Flooding of that magnitude just cannot be planned for adequately, and this government recognises the need to make sure every avenue of assistance available to the people of the flood-ravaged areas is delivered as soon as possible. That is why the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and the honourable member for Murray—the former Deputy Leader of the National Party—together with myself and a number of other members of this House travelled to those areas, along with the then member for Indi, and that is why I made a point of taking the Prime Minister's rural and regional task force on the first visit to that area to determine how effective government programs had been in providing assistance to the people in need.

It is reasonable to say that whatever is done can always be done better. I think we can do better as a government. If presented with the same circumstances now, I am sure the program delivery from the federal government agencies would be better. As chairman of the rural and regional task force, I have recommended a number of measures which should be implemented by the government. I will outline those recommendations.

The federal government should allocate additional rural counsellors, perhaps on a temporary basis, in the flood affected regions to help local families return to stability and profitability. I believe that is partly being addressed through the appointment of a temporary officer at this stage. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) should investigate the possibility of introducing special disaster provisions, such that retrospective benefits may be paid to those who have been affected by natural disasters. This is also, I believe, being addressed through the Department of Finance.

Personal counselling services should be seen as an important part of the recovery process for those affected. Therefore, a commitment to providing adequate coun-selling services to those in need is essential. This may also be done through rural counselling schemes. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) should look towards the jobskill and LEAP programs for proposals that will assist the flood affected communities. I think that is also being explored.

The Commonwealth should investigate the possibility of producing a readily available emergency information guide that would be suitable for people in these types of disasters, with details of what to do, et cetera. A meeting between the Murray-Darling Basin Commission and other relevant bodies should be set up so as to minimise further difficulties experienced during the summer months with the growth of algae in the local waterways around Benalla, due to the increased levels of nutrients which will be deposited in the waterways.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy should investigate what assistance and funding could be directed to assist in the restoration and repair of damage caused to land and vegetation in the flood affected areas under the national landcare program. The Commonwealth should also look at ways to enter into discussions with the Victorian state government in order to ensure that the people of the flood affected areas receive the necessary assistance they are entitled to under national disaster relief arrangements.

I am sure the honourable member for Indi will recognise the importance and worth of these recommendations. I am confident that many of the concerns will be addressed. These recommendations, along with the report, will be given to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) today with a request that they be implemented without delay.

I think the benefits from the Department of Social Security is one of the honourable member's main concerns, and it is a realistic concern. People whose lives have been shattered by floods or any other natural disaster are hardly going to have a visit to the Department of Social Security at the forefront of their minds when they are getting their lives back in order. However, at present if they do not apply early they miss out.

As far as the national disaster relief arrangements go, that does put a threshold on state expenditure before Commonwealth funding comes in. I believe that type of mechanism is appropriate. It puts the onus on the state to prioritise the importance of disasters. It does this in monetary terms. As the major land and infrastructure managers, it is the states which are in the best position to assess the damage and prioritise it. Whether that is best done in monetary terms, as it is now, or whether some other mechanism could be found to do that effectively, I think should be explored.

Under the present arrangements, the federal government is automatically committed to massive funding if the states place importance on it. If, for instance, the $200 million mentioned by the honourable member for Indi were the figure that was spent under the NDRA, the majority of that would be federal government money. Of the $200 million, under the funding arrangements, in the vicinity of $120 million would be federal government money. So the question is: how should we prioritise? That is up to the states. It is done by the states in monetary terms at the moment. I think it is worth examination to see whether there is another appropriate method that could be used. At present, the priorities are with the states and it is their responsibility. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the mover of this motion, the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman), and also the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), who visited the area along with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), for their concern over this devastating natural disaster which was caused by the freak rains in the north-east of Victoria on 3 October. The important point for many people in the electorate of Murray and elsewhere in that part of Victoria is that that disaster is continuing day in, day out in their lives.

PARA.TAB: There were three segments to that particular disaster. Firstly, there was the north-east sector, which experienced very heavy rains, torrents of water, erosion, and the loss of stock, fences and many roads and bridges. Secondly, there was the city of Benalla, which was the main urban area affected. I am told that, so far, about 2,700 personal hardship grants have been made, which indicates the number of houses, particularly in Benalla, that have been affected. There have been 500 grants made to farms and homes in smaller towns, which shows the impact on those towns.

Thirdly, there was the electorate of Murray, where the floodwaters spread out over the plains of northern Victoria in one of the most intensively irrigated and farmed areas of Australia. There were no stock losses there but, if we take both the north and north-east areas, close to 1,000 farms have been affected, and about half of those severely. In the electorate of Murray alone, I would say that there has been a loss of income to farmers of at least $100 million, apart from any of the other losses. I know that the majority of those people were dairy farmers, but it has been indicated that many orchardists, tobacco growers, graziers and cropping farmers were also affected. Many of these people unfortunately have no future, or else their future is at risk because of the devastation to them and the fact that they have no cash flow now and are not likely to have any cash flow for some time.

The area devastated was three times that affected by the Ash Wednesday fires, the last great disaster of Victoria. That was of course not nearly the size of the area of the 1990-92 floods of Queensland and New South Wales, but the lost production would have been at least as great, because of the intensive farming in the area. The response of the Victorian government was swift, and I commend it for that. It introduced a state of emergency that allowed the Army to come in, and I commend the Army for the work it did, as I and others have commended all the other people such as the state emergency services, local government, state and federal departments, the thousands of volunteers, and even the CSIRO for the brochures it put out concerning how to cope with or re-establish a home that has been damaged.

Of course, the natural disaster relief arrangements were automatically triggered, because of the longstanding Commonwealth-state arrangement. There are two elements to that. Firstly, there are the personal and household grants, which are dollar for dollar, Commonwealth and state, from the first dollar. So far, there has been about $2 million worth of those personal hardship, temporary living expenses and rehabilitation grants, amounting to about $11,000 for each one, that have been distributed; and that amount could double. There has also been some provision of special benefits.

Secondly, there is the element of business, both farm and town business, and the availability of the $100,000 four per cent loan. For community and voluntary organisations, the same procedure applies. So far, about 42 farms and 25 businesses have had their claims processed and approved, and over $3 million has been allocated. But those loans will have to go to hundreds of farms for them to have the impact that they should have. I note that the Victorian department of agriculture has provided $50,000 to help with financial consultants so that more of those applications can be successful.

Generally there are no grants for businesses affected, with the exception of the farm home. But farm homes do not generally go under floods, because the farmers have the equipment and the ability to make sure that they do not go under. In other natural disasters, there have been some grants for transport assistance for livestock and fodder. That money is not being provided in Victoria, and I believe it should be. There are also, as we have indicated, the special benefits. There is the question of the tax office, and of landcare, which the honourable member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) will address more completely; but all of us would support the importance of overcoming the erosion situation.

The purpose of this motion is to emphasise the need for a review of the Commonwealth-state arrangements. The previous speaker has indicated some very important points in relation to that, as did the mover of the motion, the honourable member for Indi. The biggest problem is the bitterness that is created and is there now—I know it is not new, because the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), who is at the table, is aware of this from the flood that he had to cope with a couple of years ago—in the business sector, which sees only loans being available to it, and very difficult to obtain loans at some stages, and grants being available to householders. Generally speaking, businesses cannot insure for a flood. So we have got people who are bankrupt, people with no cash flow, their livelihood at risk, able to get loans only; whereas there have been grants for householders, which is very important, but their livelihood is not at stake.

It has been argued that this loan at four per cent is a concessional loan and that, over the five-year period of that loan, it about equals the $11,000 or so that is available for grants. I disagree with that argument. If the Commonwealth makes money available at about one per cent to the states and four per cent is charged, there is a normal lending margin, so there is nothing concessional in that. The obvious thing to do to bring equity to this, in my view, is to include the interest charge in the natural disaster arrangements and provide those loans at no interest. There is a precedent for this: in the exceptional circumstances provision of the rural adjustment scheme, where the Commonwealth and the state agree, no interest is charged, and I believe that would restore equity and a feeling of equity and fairness between the householder and the business person.

The critical reality of the difference of treatment and the failure, at least as perceived by the people in north and north-eastern Victoria, is that there has been established a small business and farming flood trust fund, of which about $200,000 has been donated by business, by media people in the area and by individuals. That is separate from the Salvation Army appeal, which was also very significant, but for personal and household assistance. It is providing long-term assistance, for example, re-establishment of pastures on properties and so forth. That is what is needed, and the fact that that had to be set up shows the shortcomings of the existing arrangement. I do commend those people involved. I also make those points again about loans at no interest and including more clearly the self-employed and the business sector in the rehabilitation and temporary living grants, which quite often are refused to them.

Special benefit was provided very quickly by the Department of Social Security. I commend it for that and for the brochure it put out, but that is only available for two weeks. Here we are seven weeks later and there are people with no income, and I make two points. The first is that it should be available for a longer period. The second point, which has been made by previous speakers, is that there should be retrospective ability to apply.

On provisional tax, the Taxation Office says it will look sympathetically at readjustments because of the flood. I would like to see that stated more positively so that those affected know that next April they can make the guesstimate of what it will be and not have a penalty tax applied later on.

The next point is infrastructure. Generally that is reasonable, and Victoria is up to about $21 million now with roads. But we have a problem. A community facility such as a cemetery is classed as a grant for any maintenance, but a football club room or a showground is not; it is available only for a loan. I believe community facilities should be in the grants sector.

The final point is levee banks. There is a tremendous problem here. They are within the natural disaster arrangements, so there is no argument on that. But no Victorian department will accept its responsibility so that people can go ahead and restore those levee banks, because of the legal liability that goes with it. That certainly has to be sorted out. I strongly support the motion that has been put forward that there is a need for an urgent review of the Commonwealth-state natural disaster arrangements with the lessons learnt from this particularly devastating flood. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, I think that it is worth while pointing out to the House, and indeed to those who may be listening through the broadcast, that this is one of those occasions where, on all sides of politics, we collectively work together for the good of all our respective constituents. It is worth while pointing out that I represent the electorate of McEwen, which is adjacent to the electorates of Indi and Murray. The electorates which the three of us represent in this House all suffered damage caused by this flood.

PARA.TAB: This is not just your normal sort of flood. I know it has been said before, but I think it is important to stress that this is a flood of quite unusual characteristics. For example, in the Strathbogie Ranges, many of the higher areas are well-known aquifers where the water comes down the dry land as salinity later on. During this quite enormous rain, water entering the aquifers on the high ground of the Strathbogies actually burst out of the side of the hills. The water flow was so great that the area underground could not cope with this flow of water and some hillsides literally burst open with water.

King Valley is in my electorate; it is a lovely part of Australia. On all of the hillsides and the ranges around King Valley, ugly scars can now be seen. There has been enormous physical damage to the land. Things have happened there which frankly should never happen, in general terms, even in a flood. There are hillsides which are heavily forested. Of course, we all understand that, if we put trees on hills, we hold the soil together: we stop the degradation of the soil. In the King Valley, there are areas where heavily forested hills have literally been torn away. The forest is still there but there are enormous scars, which come down the hillside. It is beyond belief what has occurred there.

The floods were so heavy in Benalla that they peaked at 1.2 metres above the highest recorded level. The locals say that they have never seen anything like it in their lives. The water literally came off the Strathbogie Ranges as a flood, as a wave of water, and just swept all before it.

Like everyone in this House, I am worried about the way the national disaster relief funding operates. What can be said to a farmer who has lost 100 dairy cows? That occurred in the King Valley. The farmer is looking at about $1,000 per cow replacement. He probably will not have the cash in his pocket to buy the cows. He is looking at a loss of income at the peak of the season. He was coming into the season; he had got his cows all joined; he was starting to milk; he was looking for a good cash flow. What happened? He lost 100 cows. He has now got to find $100,000 to replace his cows. He has got to get joined cows otherwise he is not going to get milk for the season. What do we offer him? We offered him a loan. The guy may already have a lot of loans. Nobody came along and said, `Can you afford the loan; can you get a cash income back?'. No. We just came along and said `Yeah. We will offer you a loan at 4 per cent'. Frankly, I find that a bit of a nonsense.

Again in the King Valley there is a case of a hop farmer. When hops grow, quite large posts are put up and the hops grow up them with trailing vines. It was a very good hop farm. All of the farm has gone. The topsoil has gone; it has just vanished. The farmer has got a clay base, where once he had hops growing on some of the best horticultural land in Victoria.

It is important to stress that this is damage that I have never seen before in my life. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) is right. I mention the landcare program and the need for us, as a federal government, to put in quite considerable funding to repair the damage. I point out that there are some farms in the area that used to have top horticultural land. The farmers are now looking at a metre or two metres of unproductive clay and silt sitting on top of their productive land. These are people who can no longer grow crops. They have got to get rid of the silt or turn it back over and get the land into productive value. We are not giving the sort of assistance that will enable these people to become cost effective and independent again.

Part of the recommendations we are making, as my colleague has mentioned, is for landcare funding. If I can stress anything to this House and to the government it is that we must get the land back into production and get more work done. We have areas where rivers have literally gone in different directions, where the banks have vanished. We now get these great masses. The best way to describe them is to say that they look like New Zealand rivers. It is unbelievable damage.

Unless we get landcare funding to start repairing this quite enormous environmental damage then I am quite fearful that many people in this area, frankly, will not survive. It is beyond the capacity of individual farmers to tackle the magnitude of the damage which has occurred to the environment. It is not just damage done to productive farmland but also to crown land and a host of other areas, and the government has a responsibility there.

I also join with other members in stressing that the social security department really has to have a good look at the way it operates in these areas. It is a nonsense to expect people in the immediate aftermath of a disaster like this to put their mind to going and seeking their entitlements through the social security department. It is inhuman and fundamentally wrong that when a person eventually goes to the department and puts in an application for the assistance to which they are unarguably entitled, and which the department does not deny their entitlement to, to then say to them, `I am sorry, you cannot have it backdated'.

It is a fundamental problem with the act. The act has to be looked at. We as a government have to make sure that the department has more flexibility in providing immediate cash outlays to people who are faced with this problem. I think also that LEAP and the jobskill program could be utilised very successfully here. They are all areas of fairly high unemployment. There are a large number of young people there who are quite anxious to start work. In fact, many of the unemployed there did work during the flood and many are working voluntarily on farms by assisting with fencing and other things like that.

If we can utilise LEAP, get additional funding in for LEAP, and additional funding for jobskill, we can pick up many of the unemployed and get them working on landcare programs, on farm restoration works and on fencing, trying to get that land back into production again.

I join with the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman) in his concerns for tobacco growers. They already have quite enough problems on their plate because of both state and federal government changes to the quota system on the import of tobacco leaf. I share with him the largest tobacco growing areas in Victoria. They are small holdings; very small holdings. They are farmers who know nothing else. They are often Italian. They know no other means of farming than cropping. They bought their farms on the basis that they had a quota off their farms going into a marketing board. Maybe the state was silly to allow this sort of farming to occur but nevertheless it is there, it is fixed into place and their farmland and their farms are valued on the basis of that quota and that marketing system.

When we change the quota system next year many of these people, frankly, are not going to survive. They already have this problem with the quota system changing and now we are not giving them sufficient relief to help them restructure and get back into other forms of agricultural production.

I also share the concern of the honourable member for Murray on the question of interest on loans. It really is a nonsense and yet I note the disaster agreement, which I have got a copy of, allows the states to add to the relief monies on cost or the cost of providing the money. I do not accept for a moment that it is going to cost four per cent of a loan to a farmer to provide that money. I really agree that there should be some arrangement where there should be no interest paid. What is the use of it, when they have already got debt on a farm, to get another debt and then charge interest on that debt? We are just basically saying to farmers that we do not really care.

I also accept that businesses are the big losers. The non-farm businesses are the major losers. They really get nothing and yet in Benalla businesses have written off their entire stock and they have had nothing given to them. I believe that is a very major problem. I regret that I have only got 10 minutes to speak and I note the yellow light is on.

I really think there is a need to look at this whole system and I am pleased that on both sides of the House that we have total agreement here. I can certainly say to the gentlemen on the other side that I will be doing what I can to assist those people and get money into their pockets so they can survive this quite astonishing and major disaster.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neville Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)acknowledges the population drift from inland Australia to coastal and northern regions;
(2)should enunciate policy directed at stemming this flow; and
(3)deplores the lack of empathy shown by this Government to the residents of regional and rural Australia.

The last release of the 1991 census figures and the last 12 years of quarterly interstate migration figures should send a chill down the spine of every Australian. There are two clear trends: the first is a continuing drift of population from the inland regions to the coast, and the second is a general migration northwards.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the first of these, there has been negative growth over the last five years in the Western District and in the Wimmera of Victoria, the far west of New South Wales and the south-west of Queensland. It is almost as disturbing to see that the Mallee and Gippsland of Victoria, the northern, north-western, central western Murrumbidgee and Murray areas of New South Wales, and the Darling Downs, Fitzroy, central west, Mackay, northern and north-west regions of Queensland are all growing at slower rates than the state averages. In other words, these areas are slipping behind.

Equally unnerving is the fact that for the last 50 quarters—I stress that this refers to the last 50 quarters, so it is not just a flash in the pan aberration—net migration figures from New South Wales and Victoria have been negative, whereas the recorded net migration gains to Queensland over the corresponding 50 quarters have been phenomenal, so much so that in the March quarter of this year 17,000 people net transferred to Queensland. If that trend continues, 1,000 people a week will be crossing the border.

The growth areas of the last five years are the Sunshine Coast, the Gold Coast, the Wide Bay-Burnett and the Cairns area of the state, with a spill over into the Richmond-Tweed area of New South Wales. While I concede that this northern push has elements of capital city migration in it, nevertheless the trend shows an unsettling disillusionment with life in many parts of Australia. I do not intend to dwell too heavily on this facet, other than to say that the trend was worse in the dying stages of the Kirner government in Victoria, the Bannon-Arnold government in South Australia, and was going the same way for nine of the last 10 quarters of the Dowding-Lawrence government of Western Australia. The trend shows that people are not insensitive to financial mismanagement, to public confidence and that they vote with their feet. Nevertheless, the more worrying trend is the slow denuding of Australia's inland and country regions. Years of struggle, government indifference and heavy indirect taxation on primary producers are taking a heavy toll, and this is reflected in the towns serving the inland areas.

It is a national scandal that 60 per cent of our population live in our five largest coastal cities. We celebrate the great Australian country and outback spirit in song, folklore, verse and literature, and yet the reality is that it is slowly diminishing. There has been a lot of rhetoric about decentralisation and regional development but little done about it. In fact, the uncaring side of government is, if anything, accelerating the process.

Let me quote a few examples from my own state's initiatives. On 9 July this year the state government announced the closure of nearly one-third of Queensland's railway lines. As one might have expected, there was outrage throughout the state. I might be a cynical soul but I believe that there is great cause for cynicism. The transport minister over the previous year assured councils of these areas in writing that the lines would stay open. Then on 25 July, in the face of the outrage, the Premier announced a review task force but, before the task force could release its findings and to the great anger of those serving on it, articles appeared, leaked by one of the ministries, on 9 October saying which lines would close. On 15 November yet another set of lines was to stay open, to be mothballed, or to be given conditional continuance.

It is a bit of a replay of the daylight saving debate in Queensland. The Premier was debating the pros of the case in the populous south-east Labor heartland while the Deputy Premier set out to woo the bush with the no case. At best, it was a two-bob each way exercise; at worst, it was a cynical manipulation, and so it was with the rail service.

In the federal dimension, albeit at arm's length, Australia Post has euphemistically changed the status of post offices. Some are APOs and others are licensed post offices. While only those with more than six staff will remain under the direct control of Australia Post, others will effectively have to franchise their services and survive on selling stamps and on other sales, providing mail services and post-office boxes, et cetera. If this is not sufficient to sustain them then, obviously, they will close or be tucked in the back of some store, a pale reflection of a once very proud service. In all this, the government walks away with clean hands while even the minimum requirements for communications in the country are not being met.

While I admire Telecom's technical achievements, its spirit of service could do with some finetuning. Many provincial centres the size of Bundaberg and Gladstone in my area do not even have a business centre. If this is the case in a provincial city, imagine how much more difficult it is accessing those few centres that do remain from country areas. This is in addition to the closure of the radio inspectors' offices of the Department of Transport and Communications, as my colleague the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) highlighted earlier in the year.

DEET offices at places like Lismore have also been closed. Then there are the nitpicking Medicare rules which say that something as simple as freezing a sunspot off a hand now has to be subjected to a pathology test. For many country people that will mean a trip to the doctor, pathology tests in Brisbane or a provincial city, and then another trip to the doctor. If it was a cost saving measure, what a farce it has become and what an impost it is on country people.

The state government has closed no fewer than 25 courthouses in recent years. After they were closed the role of the clerk of the court had to be assessed. The government admitted that the decision was wrong and then it had to put in facilitators. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy was reduced by 900 employees, 174 of which were in the agricultural branch, many of them meat and stock inspectors.

Two-man police stations were reduced to one-man stations and there is very little police presence in provincial and country areas at the weekends. I will not bore the House with the details of the Queensland Ambulance Service, because that could fill a whole debate. However, I will say that when I paid courtesy calls to ambulance centres during the campaign I did not find one happy centre.

The other matter which cries to heaven for vengeance was the expenditure by the state government of $45 million of trust funds raised by country ambulance committees. It can be imagined what that did to the morale of country communities. The list goes on like the litany of saints, sadly without any inspiring or religious dimensions. In all of this, the human face of government has been removed from a myriad of large and small country towns. It is about more than just the removal of a government office; it is about access, equity, facilitation and caring. It is little wonder that the challenge of isolation, be that relative or total, is becoming unattractive.

How can we arrest this? That could be the subject of a whole debate, but there are a number of principles, both at the human level and at the regional development level, that could be addressed. Some years ago, when the Queensland department of industry development had offices in Melbourne and Sydney, I asked what it was that attracted people to Queensland and to country areas. Was it the work force or the industrial land? The answer was no, it was the quality of life, culture and educational facilities. So that is one of the starting points.

There are three initiatives currently under way: the IC inquiry; the Kelty task force; and, more recently, the regional and rural task force of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). What a pity that this task force was not a bipartisan committee of this House rather than just a political hack organisation. I hope, however, in fairness to that task force, that it will not mirror the former country task force, which was little more than a vehicle for the vilification of those who disagreed with Labor policy.

Let me outline the steps that need to occur. The quality and access of government facilitation must be improved. Greater emphasis needs to be given to educational and cultural activities. An employment generation focus and, above all, a commitment need to be delivered through a sense of ownership. Regions need to be devised based on the interdependence of a provincial city and its hinterland. Regional practitioner organisations, such as development boards, must be properly funded by state and federal governments. It is only through a sense of ownership of a mixture of government operations that programs will be implemented. (Time expired)
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Fitzgibbon)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—I think everybody would acknowledge that population drift is nothing new; it is very much a fact of life in Australia. As we know Australia today, it has been developed by people from different societies who have moved to Australia for a range of reasons. Population drift has been going on continuously and is something that we have become accustomed to. People move to different areas for different reasons. Many people are forced to move because of their particular economic circumstances; they see opportunities elsewhere and they move to where the economy is generating these opportunities. Of course, many of our ancestors were forced to come here for no other reason than that perhaps they lived in very deprived circumstances and were perceived to have broken the law.

PARA.TAB: It is mostly economic opportunity that creates the climate for people to move. In the early days it was land or gold that moved people to various regions of Australia. Today we have a totally different economy and different reasons for people to move. The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) talked about the drift from the inland to the coastal areas. With an economy such as we have at present in which tourism is our greatest growth industry, it is natural that people are going to move to where the opportunities are. They will be moving north to Queensland, because the tourism industry is taking full advantage of the Queensland climate and it is only natural that people will drift to where the opportunities are occurring. On many a day in Victoria, when we look out and it is a bit cloudy and rainy, we might wish that we had the climate that Queensland has.

I do not think the fact that people are moving is of major concern. It would be a major concern if those moves are not regulated as well as they could be by government or if some country communities are having difficulties because of the shift of population and are not getting the support they need. We certainly recognise that and the economics of what is happening in Australia today. If small country towns lose a major industry, or even if they lose the school and the people from it, it might not be very long before the doctor or the chemist follows suit and then the people do not have the necessary services. There is a limit to how much subsidy can be put into certain regions and we must continue to allow economic forces to dictate to a certain degree where people wish to go.

The honourable member also says we should enunciate policies directed at stemming the flow. I think the National Party for many, many years, when it was a partner in the coalition, used the power of numbers it had to persuade many Liberals to provide subsidies in order to facilitate the stemming of the flow, or to direct people to particular parts of Australia. That era is over, and I am sure the honourable member for Hinkler would recognise that, because behind those tariff walls we developed an economy which lasted us for about 25 years and then it ran right into a big brick wall.

Today we have to become part of a world economy and we have to develop the policies which relate to that. That is certainly occurring at the moment, and it is also part of why we have the drift of people. But you cannot stem the tide. There is no way in the world that bureaucrats and governments can make decisions expecting to stem the tide of change, because it will continue regardless of what governments try to do, particularly in an economic sense.

We have seen some dreadful decisions made in the past in trying to adjust the economy and stem the tide—as the National Party people like to call it—by creating subsidised operations which have had detrimental effects not only eventually to the communities but also to the whole nation, when we have had to restructure the whole show. People do suffer then because the restructuring comes much faster than expected after the natural progression of change has been held up for five, 10 or even 15 years. When it does hit, such change hits regions very hard, as I know from the restructuring that is going on now in my electorate of McMillan, where behind very safe tariff walls we had industries and state electricity operations which were very fat and very soft and did not have to compete.

Today it is totally different, and I know there are people from my area moving to Queensland and good luck to them, I say. If they can move to Queensland and find opportunities, in the long term, of course, it will be good for those families but it is a very difficult phase for anybody to go through. So we cannot expect to stem the tide. We have to realise that the opportunities are in other parts of Australia at the present time and we must assist those people as best we can to make the right economic decisions for their families and for their futures.

The honourable member for Hinkler deplores the lack of empathy shown by the government to the residents of regional and rural Australia. I would say that the dead opposite is the case. Those who do not face up to reality, of course, cause the problem. As one might expect, the Australian people make their decisions at election times and call upon those who have the policies that they see will rectify the problem. So it is obvious that the people of Australia since 1983 have considered that the policies put forward by Labor governments will best serve this nation and their best interests, in contrast to our coalition opponents who have had their go for a long time and created a lot of the problems in Australia. I think it is probably an overstatement by the honourable member for Hinkler to declare that there is a lack of empathy.

I understand that today the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) will be making an announcement in relation to rural health. A large national health unit is to be established in my electorate of McMillan, which will be the centre of a major program to encourage and to develop programs to bring the health services of Australia in the modern era to rural Australia. That unit will be working in with the Monash-Gippsland university, with other universities around Australia and with remote areas of Australia as far away as Alice Springs. It is proposed that that health unit will bring to Australians the sort of delivery that is required to have health workers who are prepared to be trained and to work in country and regional areas. It will be a major initiative to assist rural Australia and one that demonstrates that this government certainly does look at those sorts of policies and develop them.

The restructuring over the years has been designed to lift off that veil of inefficiency and to develop an economy which faces and moves out into the national and international scene. We recognise the ongoing need for policy development, and we are doing that through studies, as has been mentioned. The Kelty task force has been moving all over Australia in relation to these issues. It has just been announced in the last week that the McInsey organisation will be doing extensive studies in four or five concentrated regions of Australia in order to further develop policy. The Industry Commission is also working on those issues. To say that there is lack of empathy is ridiculous because, whilst we recognise now that changes are taking place, there is further work to be done and we are expecting that a lot of effort is going to be put in in the next six months at the Public Service level, the government level and the community level in order to further develop policies which recognise that Australia has to develop its natural resources without subsidies.

It is interesting that the preceding occupant of the chair, the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), the mover of this motion, represents an area which has Gladstone and power stations, while I represent the Latrobe Valley. One of the major issues in Australia is the need to look at those natural resources and how to use them effectively, because our competitors around the world are also moving in those directions. There is no point in building a Victorian power station ever again where the intention is to transmit its power hundreds of miles to a smelter while expecting to compete in other parts of the world in the production of aluminium.

The honourable member for Hinkler, of course, has a major advantage. He has a power station and a port; he has everything on the spot. So if there is a place in Australia where that sort of development should take place, the honourable member's electorate is probably one of the best situated for the development of natural resources.

I would just hope that the honourable member does not make the same mistakes as the National Party did in the past and that his colleagues do not decide to shift things away from where the natural resources are, as they have done in Victoria. The Victorian taxpayers have now coughed up something like $1,000 million over 10 years to try to subsidise a program to build a smelter hundreds of miles from a power station. This was done for political purposes, and not for good, sound economic reasons.Such a concept does not do the community any good; it does not do the local communities any good and it is a thing of the past. If honourable members opposite ever want to get re-elected, they need to wake up to the fact that the Australian people no longer believe in the airy-fairy idea that they are going to get any benefits in the long term from subsidies.

The Labor government has a great record in this area of development of regional Australia, and it will continue. There will be moves. We do not disagree that there will be population shift, but we must do it correctly. When the population does move, we must provide acceptable services to towns in regional Australia over the periods when they are having difficulty—services the same as those expected in the cities of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with a great deal of pleasure that I rise to second the motion of the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) in regard to population drift from the inland of Australia to our coastal regions and to the major metropolitan areas. I represent the electorate of Riverina, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, and this drift is something that I am very alarmed about. Of course, before that I represented the seat of Riverina-Darling, which extended from the South Australian border up to the Queensland border.

PARA.TAB: It often amazes me that we have a continent that it takes about three or four days to drive across, yet most Australians live in urban or semi-urban environments within 200 kilometres of the eastern coast or in the south-west corner of Western Australia, taking up much of the good rural lands of Australia. In June 1990 it was found that 71 per cent of Australia's population lived in the state and territory capitals, plus six other large cities of 100,000 people or more. In fact, I think about 85 to 90 per cent of Australians are urbanised.

The result of that has been that many smaller communities in rural Australia have started to fall apart. When one goes into those areas, there is nothing more melancholy than a shuttered-up building, whether it be a business or a private residence. The trouble has been that governments, both state and federal, really have given no incentive for this to stop. There are no policies to keep people in rural areas.

I heard the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) this morning saying we had to get into manufacturing, that Australia would be recognised for its manufacturing now as we get away from the farm and from the mine, but I would like to remind the Prime Minister that 64 per cent of our overseas trade is still based on mining and farming. Where do we find most of these miners and where do we find most of these farmers? In rural areas. While ever we have the ACTU ruling the roost, particularly with the new industrial relations legislation, there is no way that people, particularly in rural areas, are going to employ workers in the manufacturing sector if they do not have to. From my reading and from talking to people in my electorate, one would have to be a masochist to employ someone under those conditions.

Just recently the government has set up a regional task force that Mr Kelty is running. He is the secretary of the ACTU. He has been around to my electorate, and on the face of it the task force looks pretty good. I asked Mr Kelty whether he and his committee would come to Leeton because of the Letona cannery problem. I understand they are very busy and cannot get there at this time. Perhaps they may get there at another time. At the bottom, the reply says:

SPEECH.PARA: This meeting was organised by the respective regional development organisations and the issue of future job creation in the region including the food processing industry were canvassed.
The Letona cannery does have jobs which will be lost, and it is no good talking about job creation when jobs are going to be lost. It just seems to be a waste of time to me.

PARA.TAB: In setting up this committee, the government really is being a little bit hypocritical, having increased excise on fuel. That one step alone has disadvantaged everyone living in rural Australia. It is a disadvantage to all Australia, of course, but mainly to those in rural areas. That one step alone has put back decentralisation by years and years.

On top of that we have had a drastic reduction in expenditure on roads. In some areas of rural Australia the roads are the only links because rail systems are being removed. Mining and farming areas need support. They need roads; they need rail; they need hospitals; they need banks—all these things that are gradually being put under threat in the drift of population towards the coast and to the major metropolitan areas. Governments need policies that will move people out of the major metropolitan areas into the country. Moving part of the CSIRO to Wagga was investigated but, because of one thing or another, the people would not go to Wagga. They are areas where governments can help.

We cannot afford to allow major metropolitan areas to continue to grow, mainly because of pollution, because of the quality of life. I do not have time to go into detail but Sydney, for example, will have to spend $10 billion on replacing sewerage infrastructure over the next 18 years. For Victoria the figure is $2.9 billion and, for South Australia, $73 million. And so it goes on and on. We have to do something about this drift to the coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —Possibly the major factor in the social, economic and environmental life of Australia is the transport system. This is true of all industrialised countries but particularly Australia, given the country's huge size and low population density. Transport determines land use, the shape, size and density of urban areas, the types of dwellings we live in, the location of jobs, the levels of air and noise pollution, accident levels, patterns of rural development, the price of goods and the competitiveness of exports. It affects the efficiency of the whole economy and the social interaction and the wellbeing of virtually everyone.

PARA.TAB: There have been numerous reports, seminars, announcements and legislative changes by state and federal governments over the last 25 years about the costs of urban sprawl and the need for high housing densities to reduce this sprawl, but all to no avail. Sprawl has continued unabated because the solution that it proposes is virtually unrelated to the problem. The overwhelming determinant is the transport system and as the system has moved to a largely private car based system then lower urban densities have been generated. There has been no land use policy related to transport and no mechanism to implement such policies even if they existed at either state or federal level of government. City motorists suffer extreme congestion and parking difficulties. Public transport services cover only a minority of urban areas and are generally regarded as unreliable, congested and often unsafe, and the urban environment steadily deteriorates.

State ministers wail endlessly about debt on the railways and close as many lines as they can, particularly in rural areas. The mix of private cars with huge buses and trucks on the roads is producing increasing numbers of accidents. We almost seem to have reverted to late 19th century England where the mix of huge road going steam buses and small vehicles and an inadequate road system produced an horrendous accident rate. This eventually led to the Red Flag Act and a speed limit of four miles per hour.

The New South Wales government seems to have almost abandoned any form of transport policy and in recent years has simply thrown the issue open and advertises, asking if anyone out there has any proposals. Local government, as a reaction to the many traffic problems, is spending millions of dollars handing out placebos to their residents, building all manner of hoops and jumps in a forlorn attempt to solve the problems of ever increasing traffic. The causes of all this anarchy and dissatisfaction are many but the fundamental cause is the lack of any relationship of cost to usage in the transport system.

The present transport system is a result of subsidy upon subsidy and distortion upon distortion. Transport infrastructure has been used as a means of job creation, welfare distribution and vote buying as are many road projects. When the New South Wales government decided some 30 years ago to introduce a subsidised school transport scheme, it cost a mere $3 million per annum. Today it is costing over $300 million per annum. In other words, the cost of it would build 20 new high schools per year. It has distorted school choice and is responsible for enormous peak hour traffic generation.

In the lower North Shore of Sydney almost 50 per cent of the total peak hour traffic is related to education facilities. We have never resolved the need for a national transport policy and standards with our federal system of government. Whilst gains have been made in recent years the ports of Australia are, for example, to some extent museums to this failure, as is much of the railway infrastructure.

It is an historical fact that roads have generally been free to the user in spite of their enormous costs. For example, the Gore Hill freeway in Sydney cost $43 million per kilometre for construction alone. It provides magnificent luxury off-peak travel for a handful of the Australian population. If people want a better road the procedure has been to organise a lobby effectively and they will get one at no direct cost to themselves.

There are no effective mechanisms to determine funding between proposals, be they urban, rural or regional. Road funding has been largely by grants, and railways largely by loans, totally distorting the modal split of road versus rail. Even private toll roads generally receive massive subsidies by way of grants, loans and free land, with toll charges purely arbitrary.

The recent trend of building private toll roads also promises even more anarchy and traffic congestion in the future. Private toll roads create special interests whose economic wellbeing depends on high levels of traffic congestion. It will be in their interests to oppose strongly any proposal to reduce over-dependence on cars or to reduce congestion. Therefore, they can be expected to oppose any expenditure on public transport or any attempts by government to provide rational road pricing policies.

Government economic policies relating to private cars generally promote over-dependence. Capital charges by federal and state governments mean that usage costs are relatively minor, hence distorting people's decision making. It would be much less distorting to eliminate sales tax altogether, for example, and replace it with a revenue neutral fuel tax of approximately 4c a litre. This would dramatically reduce the age of Australia's car fleet, create jobs, provide safer and less polluting vehicles and allow us to move towards relating cost to use.

In rural areas, use is primarily related to fuel charges but in urban areas parking is the major determinant. Here again, most urban parking is heavily subsidised one way or the other. Retail organisations spread parking costs over all consumers, thereby transferring the subsidy from those who use public transport or walk to the shops to car users. Local state and federal employers often provide heavily subsidised parking.

Local government massively subsidises parking stations, almost always ignoring land costs, therefore creating a transfer of funds to motorists from non-car owners. A constructed parking space in the inner and middle areas of Sydney costs, for example, in the order of $20,000 to $30,000, including land. Australian cities now have about 30 per cent of their total land given over to roads and parking.

Many studies have shown the hidden cross-subsidies between classes of road users, with overwhelming evidence that private cars heavily subsidise buses and trucks. The construction of new highways, with 450 millimetre deep concrete heavily reinforced, let alone the rapidly rising road maintenance costs, gives some indication of the extent of heavy vehicle subsidy.

All these distortions and subsidies in turn affect sea and air transport in relation to land transport. These modes have many distortions and subsidies of their own. For example, in relation to Sydney airport, the costs of airport development pale into insignificance alongside the wider urban consolidation and environmental costs of the airport on the metropolitan area. However, these costs are not passed on to airline users or the airline industry, who thereby benefit from a huge subsidy.

All this chaos will continue until governments and the public accept the principles that transport decisions must be made on a full cost-recovery basis and that all charges should relate to user benefits. That is not to say that subsidies should not be provided, but they must always be transparent and, preferably, given directly to recipients without distorting the transport function.

No-one pretends that road pricing is easy. Countless reports the world over on road cost recovery and user charges show the difficulties. Nevertheless, a consensus is emerging that shows that light vehicles subsidise heavy vehicles and that rail and sea transport would substantially improve their economic position with even reasonable road cost recovery.

The situation is not helped by motoring interests which endlessly mislead the public by claiming that the motorists are excessively taxed. These claims are usually made by comparing levels of mainly fuel taxation and state charges to annual expenditure on road construction and maintenance. However, construction and maintenance are only the tip of the iceberg. When the costs of road accidents, hospital costs, 30 per cent of the national health system, noise and air pollution, policing and legal costs, environmental costs, distortions of land use and many other factors are considered, there is no doubt that petrol is hugely underpriced.

Many of these costs are again difficult to quantify but, both here and overseas, studies show that petrol needs to cost well over $2 a litre to approach full cost recovery. Nevertheless, the present situation of having the cheapest petrol in the world with one of the longest road systems and the least number of vehicles to pay for it, means that the road system will continue to be hopelessly inadequate. We will continue to have dinosaur car engines made here which cannot be exported, accelerating urban sprawl, among the world's highest consumption of oil, and a worsening balance of payments with increasing fuel imports.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, let me say that I have an interest in this matter in that I am a member of the Fitzroy football club. I am a donor and a sponsor of that club. My grievance is against the way the game of Australian football is being managed by people who want to take it away from those who own it, the ordinary men and women and children of Victoria and Australia.

PARA.TAB: Australian rules football is an industry worth about $2 billion a year. It is not just a game; it is big business. But, of course, that business is not owned by the commercial people who now want to take over control of the game. As I stress, it is a game which is owned by ordinary men, women and children, by ordinary families who put money into it. It has been hijacked. No longer do ordinary club members—those who go on a Saturday in Melbourne or other states, who stand in the rain, eat a pie and sauce, drink a tinny, follow their team and enjoy themselves—have control, or rights of control, over this great game. The hijacking is complete.

About a year or two years ago, the AFL decided it would get rid of the Footscray football club. It tried very hard to get rid of the Footscray football club and it failed. More recently, it tried to get rid of the Fitzroy football club and, at this stage, it has failed. It is also trying to get rid of the Richmond football club and the North Melbourne football club. Of course Hawthorn, the premier club of Victoria, is also in financial difficulty. Hawthorn must now be on the chopping block. The AFL wants to run a commercial business with a game which is owned by ordinary people. It is time this was stopped; it is time that football was returned to the people who own it.

Let us have a look at the sorts of people who have taken over football in the last decade—people such as Dr Edelsten, Bob Ansett, Lindsay Fox, Alan Bond, Christopher Skase and, dare I mention the name, John Elliott—before I get accused of blackmailing or attacking the Labor Party, which I am not. These are the sorts of people who have moved into and have taken over the grand old clubs.

I went to my first game of Australian rules football when I was so young that I do not even recall how old I was. It was at the Brunswick Street football oval, the original old Fitzroy football club home. It was a great thrill for a kid to go with his dad and watch his local heroes. I recall that I used to eat dim sims in those days. They were heroes; they are heroes to many kids today. Yet this joy of youth is being taken away from them because of the commercialisation.

The AFL is actually a private company; it is the Australian Football League Ltd. It is a company which is limited by guarantee. It is, theoretically, owned by the 15 clubs which now constitute the AFL; it is managed by a person called Ross Oakley. Oakley is so concerned about football that he rips off a salary of $400,000 a year. The late Alan Schwab was paid $300,000 a year. This is $700,000 of public money. This is money quite often put in by low income people and it is being ripped off by those who now administer this great game.

Of course, another example is Sydney where, quite foolishly in my view, Victorian people have tried to introduce a game alien to the state. It is a state which has always had a very low spectator base. The former South Melbourne club, now called Sydney, is in such a financial mess that it is being subsidised by Victorian football goers. I am led to believe that the present manager/coach, Ron Barassi, is being paid a salary package in excess of $300,000 a year. Close to $1 million is being paid out on just three people involved in this game, for their own self-interest, I would suspect, against the wishes of the vast majority of football supporters.

But even worse than that, more recently—and this is where my real grievance comes into it—the AFL, without notifying clubs of potential rule changes on the transfer of players, did a deal with the Brisbane football club so that one of Fitzroy's best players, Alastair Lynch, could negotiate a deal with Brisbane without having to tell his own club. After the deal was made, the AFL announced the rule changes so that Fitzroy lost Alastair Lynch on a package which is publicly reported to be $1.2 million.

This is what we call a sport in this country. There are an awful lot of clubs that are not in a position today to compete with paying a single player a contract package of $1.2 million. Alistair Lynch is one of the best footballers I have seen in my life; he is very skilful and a great footballer. But I worry about which direction the game is going when the controller of the game, the AFL, does a deal under the counter with Brisbane to try to boost Brisbane's capacity to take top players from clubs that are struggling in Victoria and then allows that to happen legally down the track. It stinks, quite frankly, and it does nothing whatsoever for football.

Even worse than that, in order to get rid of clubs, the Australian Football League has done a deal whereby when a team like Fitzroy travels to play a club such as Adelaide, which has an enormous support base—it has a membership of around 38,000—the Adelaide members who attend on membership tickets make no contribution towards the central funding; none at all. So Fitzroy goes over there and Fitzroy does not get one penny of the gate receipts, not a penny, whereas, when Adelaide comes across and plays Fitzroy in Melbourne, it gets a share of the gate receipts.

One sits back and watches the way this game is being administered and one says, `I am an owner of the game. I am just an ordinary bloke out there in the streets and me and my kids go on a regular basis', yet what I believe about the game, and what most Australian football supporters believe about the game, is that we are totally cut out from it. Why should these other owners of the game, as I call them, have the privilege at a home and home game of sitting in plush surroundings behind glass? I have been to some of these lunches the owners of the game now have, with starched tablecloths, silver service and waiter service. They sit back before the game starts with an excellent three-course meal and top wines. They sit up there in their plush facilities paid for by ordinary families, have these great lunches and then sit behind glass and enjoy the game.

They do not pay for their lunches—not at all. It comes out of the money which ordinary people put into the gate down below while these people sit up in their new facilities, with their three-course meals on tablecloth and with silver service, and look down at the poor people below who stand out in the rain and enjoy the game. They look down at them and they do not understand that they are the people who pay for these privileges.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they are mostly corporate sponsors.

—The honourable member has never been to a Carlton football club lunch. He should not talk about corporate sponsors. He should see the people who go to some of these lunches. I got an invite once and I turned up and I was horrified. I have not been back since. It is a rort; it is an absolute rort. It is commercial. The game no longer is the people's game, and that is my beef, that is my big grievance. It is a grievance that people like Oakley and the AFL people are ripping money out of this system. A $400,000 salary? It is an absolute disgrace that they take this money off.
—Are you sure it is $400,000?
—Let Oakley come out and complain about it. One cannot get the financial statements out of the AFL. It is a private company.

PARA.TAB: The next beef I have, the next grievance, is that, if it is owned by the people—and the game is owned by the people—why cannot the people who pay the money, the supporters, get all of the financial details of how the AFL works? They should be published; they should be public knowledge and they should be available for everyone to scrutinise.

The Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett, said only last week, `Let Fitzroy go'. It is a nonsense, because if Fitzroy goes, North Melbourne goes, Richmond will go and Hawthorn is at risk. It is not just one club. The AFL is trying to make this game a commercial game owned by people, a purely profit seeking game, when it is a game which I own, we all own, and we should be worried about it. The honourable member should be worried because his constituents are not getting a fair deal either. It is his constituents who go through the gate, his constituents who put their money through the till and his constituents giving these people the benefits.

Why should Brisbane get a $4 million subsidy from the AFL; why should Sydney be subsidised by the AFL? If the AFL is not sensible enough to structure the game so that these clubs do not need subsidies, why should ordinary families be paying for it? Why should Barassi walk away with $300,000 a year, paid for by ordinary family supporters, to try to run Sydney, when we have some very wealthy people in Sydney who supposedly own the club? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to grieve today on behalf of rural and regional Australia and its growing estrangement from urban Australia. Canberra is the centre of the nation's national government and therefore it is well worth examining what attitudes and values pervade the place that has such an influence on the daily lives of my constituents. It has to be said that Canberra is an increasingly remote place. It is increasingly a world of its own with very few links and very little dialogue with mainstream society, especially the distinctive world of the countryside. It is little wonder Canberra's decision makers have next to no grasp of the needs of rural regions. The decision makers have hardly been scratched by the recession and the latest budget, with its huge increases in fuel and other taxes, only serves to strip away more resources from the countryside to bolster Canberrans' living standards. Canberrans and the Public Service mandarins who inhabit the place and dominate its social life and culture enjoy services and facilities rural Australians could only dream about, and the federal government is driving open the gulf wider and wider every year.

PARA.TAB: The costs of running the Public Service have jumped by six per cent this year, a year in which the rest of us have been lectured by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) about the importance of having to pay extra taxes to wind back the public debt. We see with our own eyes new Public Service buildings springing up around the place after Labor's election win. If the rural sector could just lay its hands on a small proportion of this largess, it could solve a lot of basic problems in the bush. But years into the rural crisis we are still fighting the same issues, working out how to improve the lot of the farm sector and rural business, and how to defend and preserve the interests of the rural community against forces which are diminishing its standing, its resources base and, more importantly, its morale.

I do not pretend these are easy times for any people in the community, be they metropolitan or rural dwellers. I do not want anyone to think that governments can achieve miracles. Forgetting Canberra for the time, I do not believe we can invent some fantasy world where every rural community will be flush with services and never have need again. We are dealing with the real world. We have to do the best we can and keep alive our hopes that we can always do a little better if we work harder in the bush. That, after all, is what we are about in country areas.

The message we have to get across to the nation and to the various governments of the day is that the countryside is unique. It is something altogether different from Canberra, from Sydney's sprawling west or from Melbourne's eastern suburbs, which all seem to dictate the political and policy debate. In rural electorates like Gippsland, 42 per cent of households earn an average annual salary of $25,000 or under, compared with a Victorian state-wide average of 24 per cent.

The National Party seats, the prime rural areas of the nation, have populations amongst the poorest in Australia. In fact, the poorest 14 electorates in Australia, out of a total of 147, are all rural or regional. The federal seats of Mallee and Murray in Victoria, for instance, are among the seats that have the highest proportion of families on low incomes. Mallee has over 23 per cent of its families earning less than $16,000; Murray has over 21 per cent. Those percentages are approaching twice the national average.

If honourable members are interested in looking at the nation's priorities, let us compare these figures with those for Canberra, the seat of decision making. While about only six per cent of Canberra's families have incomes under $16,000, the average figure for rural Victoria is 20 per cent. Canberra residents have average annual incomes of well over $50,000; rural Victorians on average earn around $22,000 less per year.

Canberra also has one of the highest growth rates in Australia with its population surging by 23 per cent between 1986 and 1991, but rural seats such as Wannon in western Victoria, Mallee, and McMillan in central Gippsland have growth rates of minus 1.4 per cent, 1.5 per cent and 3.7 per cent respectively. Bendigo and Ballarat have average growth rates of around seven per cent only.

One-third of all families in the national capital have yearly incomes above $60,000 but the average for rural Victorian seats is less than 10 per cent. Enough is enough! Somewhere, something has gone terribly wrong and, if country people think we have a problem getting the message through to Canberra, then maybe here is the reason.

We must also understand that economic recovery, generally speaking, will be slower in rural regions than elsewhere. In view of the very limited commercial infrastructure in rural regions and its heavy dependence on commodity prices, the regional economy cannot expect a rapid return to health. This is a very different situation to the situation that the cities face with their wider and deeper commercial infrastructure. Cities have a vastly bigger pool of demand and may, in the future, recover quicker. We cannot and Victoria's rural areas are dealing with an altogether different labour market problem as well, in common with Australia's country areas.

The average rise in unemployment across rural regions was just under two per cent between March 1992 and March 1993, but two-thirds of Victoria's 30 local government areas, the vast bulk of them rural, had an average rise of 4.6 per cent. Many rural areas are therefore still in an unemployment free fall and a huge slice of those who are jobless face a very long term of unemployment or else they will just drift off into the cities, further weakening the countryside's economic base in the future.

As we face this massive labour market and demographic problem, let us look at what is happening in Canberra. A week ago the federal government proposed that unemployed artists be paid jobsearch subsidies and allowances for up to two years without any work tests whatsoever. The plan makes a mockery of efforts to help the rural unemployed. There are 4,500 farmers on jobsearch allowances. Of these, 25 per cent, or 1,000 to 1,100, are located in Victoria. They are being forced to seek off-farm work and forgo re-establishment grants under the rural adjustment scheme just to qualify for benefits.

The rural community fought tooth and nail to have unemployment allowances extended to the farm sector and now the government is giving them as a handout to city based artists. The sight of unemployed artists receiving the dole while free to pursue their own artistic interests is too much to swallow, but it is a sight like this that we have to get used to. We will have to get used to a few other things Canberra is cooking up as well in the future at the expense of the rural community.
