I have presented a pretty despairing picture of life in rural Australia. We do face more challenges on more fronts than I can remember before. That is no cause for throwing in the towel; far from it. This is where rural communities come into their own. This is where the National Party and farm organisations come into their own and face the test for their right to exist and claim leadership of the rural sector.

The communities and towns we represent have been through two world wars, droughts, depressions and every other challenge one can imagine, and they have survived. Every year brings fresh challenges to country towns and cities right across Australia but all rural communities have learned to fight back all the harder. Their self-help ethic, their sense of civic responsibility and the ever-present optimism of their community leaders are great prizes and they will ensure rural Australia forges on towards the 21st century.

If we ever needed reminding of where the great strength we have to have to keep pushing on against the tide comes from, we probably saw it all before our very eyes earlier this month when the Unknown Soldier returned after 75 years to be buried in his own soil in the Hall of Memory in the Australian War Memorial. We do not listen to what is being said about how we are all meant to be working to manufacture a new identity or whatever. We have got it all, symbolised in the one unnamed man entombed in marble. When it comes time, as it sometimes does for many in rural areas, to wonder whether the race is worth the candle and whether to battle to hold on against those who do not care or who do not understand that it is worth it, then there is a simple and timeless reason why we keep pushing on. The rural community may be hard pressed but it represents the traditional core of Australia at a time when tradition is ridiculed. It hangs on and it will hang on a good bit longer than those people and special interests which have currently turned their backs on the countryside.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks today address the fundamental role of government in promoting innovation and science and technology and industry. The Business Council of Australia has defined innovation thus:

SPEECH.PARA: change that adds value to the business by meeting customer needs better. It is intrinsically outcome and output focussed.

Innovation encompasses all those activities necessary to produce commercial products and processes: that is, technology, development, design, quality, marketing and sales, training, management and so on. Innovation is critical to economic growth. It is only through firms understanding their customer demands better and developing an ability to respond quickly and accurately to those demands that sustained competitive success will be assured for Australia.

PARA.TAB: Australia's scientific and technological capabilities are among its greatest resources. I note that, since the Nobel prize was instituted, Australia has had three Nobel winners in the sciences, and that the east Asian countries, vastly larger in population, have produced only six Nobel winners in the sciences. Obviously, the skills of Australian scientists and technologists do not translate into innovation unless they are applied in a commercial context. For too long, we Australians have accepted the European model of innovation. In this model, pure research—mostly funded by government—is developed by applied researchers and is commercialised in industry.

Federal government programs now reflect a new approach to innovation that takes account of the economic success of Japan and certain east Asian countries. The speed and cost effectiveness of the innovation processes adopted by these countries have been a major factor in their economic growth. Under the so-called Asian model of innovation, the identification of commercial opportunities leads technologists to set research requirements which define the necessary R&D programs; that is, the commercial opportunities determine the R&D, and not the other way around.

Reflecting this approach, the federal government has pursued a number of strategies, including programs such as the partnerships for development program for information industries and the factor F program that supports the pharmaceutical industry. These programs have put Australian researchers in direct contact with leading companies such as IBM and the pharmaceutical company Merck, Sharp and Dohme. These programs have helped Australian researchers direct their work to meet the needs of major world markets, and the programs have been essential for the success of leading Australian companies such as the Computer Power group and Amrad.

A notable characteristic of Japan and other east Asian nations is that they have placed innovation and research and development to the forefront of their national priorities. Indeed, they have been able to reach, within their own countries, basic agreement by their political parties on their country's policy formulation and the direction of innovation and R&D. That is not so in Australia. Honourable members will recall Fightback, the document that the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) rightly described as `a 700-page suicide note'. To the consternation of his colleagues, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) still stands by Fightback, without the GST.

Fightback says nothing about the role of innovation in generating economic growth. Fightback proposed funding cuts that would cause terrible damage to industrial innovation in Australia. These cuts would include a $50 million per annum cut to tax revenue forgone through the 150 per cent tax incentive. In effect, Fightback proposes tightening the eligibility criteria for the concession. By contrast, under the Keating government, support for industrial R&D through its tax concession increased by $20 million last year, to over $400 million.

Secondly, Fightback proposed the termination of the national procurement development program. An Australian firm, Interscan, has signed a contract in excess of $5 million to supply its premier product, the microwave landing system, to the government of Taiwan. This contract was won against strong competition from the United States of America and Europe. The microwave landing system was developed at the Civil Aviation Authority with the assistance of a national procurement development grant.

Thirdly, Fightback would have cut $17.7 million from the national industry extension service program, which is a federal, state and territory network of business, information and advisory services. The program helps Australian manufacturing and service enterprises to become internationally competitive through enterprise improvement.

In contrast to Fightback, the Keating government has provided an additional $20 million over three years to these programs to greatly enhance the ability of small and medium sized firms to make the most of their technological capabilities. The manifesto of the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia on science and technology was released in March 1993. The strategy is in line with the ideology of Fightback. This policy document has not been abandoned. It is still there. It is an outdated policy that ignores the role of multinationals in innovation, technology transfer and marketing. It is a Jurassic Park model of innovation.

While we have much to learn from the Asian economies, we also have much to offer. The high standard of technical capability of our engineers and research and development professionals is a strength for building, trade and investment opportunities. The promotion of our technological capability is essential to developing Australian export potential. This is a challenge that must be met by all Australians.

Australia has one of the highest economic growth rates in the OECD. This is supported by a growth rate of business R&D of 13 per cent, almost twice the OECD average. In 1990, Australia's expenditure on research and development was $US4 billion. In the same year, Singapore's research and development expenditure was approximately $US320 million. Based on UNESCO data, it is estimated that in 1990 the expenditure on R&D by the ASEAN countries, in total, was less than $1 billion, a quarter of the R&D expenditure of Australia.

The R&D expenditure of the ASEAN countries has grown dramatically since 1990. Singapore plans to spend two per cent of GDP on R&D by 1995 and Malaysia plans to reach this level by the year 2000. To change the perceptions of our Asian neighbours, in April this year the federal government announced a new $60 million package to boost Australia's economic, trade and research links with Asia. The package includes programs to expand our business networks in Asia, broaden Australia's image in Asia, and foster better understanding of Australia in Asia, just to name a few of those initiatives.

I heartily commend the government's policies on innovation and links with Asia. As the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development ((Mr Griffiths) told this House last week, exports to Asia over the last decade have jumped 378 per cent to reach $17.7 billion in 1992. The minister's forthcoming industry statement will build on this success.

I issue a challenge to the opposition to join with the government to develop a bipartisan approach to this very important and critical issue of innovation in this country. In other words, it should try to emulate what countries in Asia are doing, in a bipartisan way, to ensure that this country is in the forefront in exports and economic growth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan Ms J.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak here today on behalf of many parents in the Pearce electorate, and I am certain that I speak on behalf of many parents in Australia, who have voiced their grave concerns at a social security measure that they see as a threat to the integrity of their families. The measure is the youth homeless allowance. On the evidence, they are right to be concerned. The government has a duty to act. The youth homeless allowance stands as a warning on how a well-intentioned palliative can itself become a cause rather than a remedy of social dislocation.

PARA.TAB: It was argued that homeless young people should receive an allowance from the taxpayer rather than turn to crime and prostitution. The consequence, however, has been to make homelessness a superficially attractive option for children and to some parents. The human dimension is too easily forgotten. This should have been foreseen and, in fact, was foreseen by the former member for Richmond in May 1986 when the first amendments were made to the Social Security Act to make available the youth homeless allowance. However, it should have been foreseen by many others that a 15-year-old receiving $102 a week and living independently would consider that he or she has gained adult status and be the envy of many of his or her peers.

Any parent would know that adolescents can and do rebel. This is a natural part of the road to adulthood and coping with it is a natural part of parenting. The last thing that so many families need during this process is a taxpayer funded incentive for a child to leave home prematurely. For every child who does leave home, there are many others who threaten to do so and, in the minds of their parents, now have the means to make good their threat. Welfare benefits were never intended to erode family cohesion and the basis of discipline without which we cannot become self-respecting adults. It is particularly important that, as young adults, we learn that with rights come responsibilities and with freedom comes discipline. Social welfare payments were never intended to allow parents to abandon difficult adolescents by throwing them out of the home, in the knowledge that the state will pick up the tab. When this happens, the state, of course, must take action but resources would be better deployed to try to prevent such family breakdowns.

I make this speech today with concern for the officers of the Department of Social Security who must administer this policy. I have been assured that a great many applications for the allowance are refused, particularly in cases where young applicants refuse to allow contact to be made with their parents, or where children simply do not want to obey the house rules.

There is too much anecdotal evidence, however, that indicates that, of the tenfold increase of 10,000 children receiving the allowance, many come from homes where there is no real abuse and where parents want to provide for them. The actual numbers of young people applying for this and the cost to the country were also foreshadowed somewhat by the former member for Richmond in 1986.

On evidence, the worst aspect of the administration of the allowance is the right to privacy. This is a sensitive area where children ought not automatically be given the same rights as adults. Although an independent adult authority is supposed to be contacted when a child demands that his or her parents not be informed of that child's application for this allowance, this does not seem to be a fail-safe process.

The right to privacy can be the right to tell lies that cannot be refuted. If it is exercised, however, because of real abuse in the family home, then it is equally wrong that the DSS officers are prevented from contacting state police and welfare officers. The system, in effect, allows for crime to evade investigation. Has anyone stopped to consider that, if a 15-year-old is fleeing a home where abuse is occurring, then other children may remain there and be subjected to the same abuse? The social workers from the department are only able to establish whether a child is homeless. They have no brief to interact with state authorities or to initiate family reconciliation. Counselling can be an abused word but it is terribly necessary to assist those families where there are genuine problems but equally genuine possibilities for solutions.
We will have become a warped society if we think it acceptable that children as young

SPEECH.PARA: as 12 are paid $102 a week to live independently, if parents who wish to provide for their children have their role usurped by the state, if other parents are encouraged to abandon responsibility, and if government agencies promote the concept of premature adulthood.

PARA.TAB: It is becoming clear that many responsible people in the department know that the system needs tightening up, and we had in October an admission from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) that a review was being undertaken to make the granting of the allowance more stringent. This, however, is too important a matter to be left to an in-house inquiry. A review must talk with state welfare bodies, with youth workers and with parents, who should be given the opportunity to state how the granting of the allowance has damaged their families and the welfare of their children.

In the International Year of the Family, Australia should respond by making a fresh start in the validation of the family and directing greater policy emphasis toward prevention of family breakdown rather than the repair of its consequences. This task involves a new approach to taxation as well as to welfare policy. More resources need to be allocated to lessen the number of family breakdowns and sole parenting. Dysfunctional families do not always need welfare payments but they do need education and they do need counselling. Sir Robert Menzies said 50 years ago that the family was the foundation of sanity and sobriety. His words are even more relevant to our current uncertain times, since it is by sharing and commitment within the family that we learn to relate to the wider community. It is a great loss for any young Australian to be deprived of the opportunity to develop as an individual within a forgiving environment. The future of Australia depends on skills learnt primarily within the family to solve problems, to promote harmony and to reconcile viewpoints.

Seven out of 10 Australians say that family life is the source of their greatest satisfaction. Unfortunately, sentiment is not always matched with commitment, when we have 300,000 single-parent families caring for 500,000 children depending on sole-parent pensions. The case for the importance of a strong family unit could rest on the economic argument alone. In a practical sense, the problem is that two-parent families have had a sevenfold increase in relative taxation since the 1950s with less benefits. Then, total tax on average weekly earnings was less than 10 per cent; now it is 23 per cent. There is a shrinking pool of two-parent families carrying an increasing burden. Of far greater importance is the human heartbreak and the social dislocation of a growing number of children and adults who no longer have the safety nets, the role models and the support of a cohesive family.

As we move toward the International Year of the Family in 1994, the evidence is abundant that this legislation does nothing to elevate the role of the family in our communities. Sadly, there are young people in our midst who need the kind of assistance this legislation provides. The government, though, must now act swiftly to reform the youth homeless allowance. A shift of emphasis is also needed to provide the necessary support to prevent family breakdown rather than reacting to a problem that has become the cause of great pressure on the family. This was made very clear also by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) when he addressed this legislation on 1 May 1986. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the government really wants to do something about the young homeless in this country, it ought to do something about supporting families for a change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Swan Mr W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I too rise to support families because as a member of this House I am very concerned about some recent statements by a member of the Senate, Senator Julian McGauran, who I think has abrogated responsibility to families and to children with some of his statements. I think it is fair to say that I am ashamed that a member of the Senate in recent days has behaved as irresponsibly as Senator McGauran has. He has behaved like a Scrooge with cheap politicking that could well spoil Christmas for many children in our community.

PARA.TAB: In our society there is nothing more precious than the innocent joy of celebration of Christmas with children. The giving of gifts, the singing of carols and the gathering of families at Christmas are a very important part of a child's upbringing. I believe that Christmas should be above petty, cheap and dirty politics and I believe that in recent days Senator McGauran has spoilt Christmas for thousands of Australian children. As a member of this House, I am ashamed that Senator McGauran could play politics with the joy of Christmas experienced by so many children. I think it is fairly obvious that Senator McGauran has never been to a kindergarten and probably has never visited one in his public life. If he visited kindies and preschools in my electorate, he would find a high quality of care and centres that operate on basic values of decency and honesty.

The recent guidelines, produced by the Commonwealth government with the support of the child-care industry and now adopted by the federal government, reflect the values of decency and honesty. Senator McGauran has set out on a deliberate campaign of lies to frighten people and to spoil Christmas for kids. I would like to quote from the guidelines mentioned by Senator McGauran. Principle 25 says:

SPEECH.PARA: Experiences provided by the program should cover a wide variety of areas including music, art, movement, literature, drama and the natural environment, as well as many types of play such as water play, block play, woodwork, pretend play, food preparation and sand play.

Is Senator McGauran opposed to this guideline? Does he want kids to be locked up all day in a child-care centre watching television? Of course he should not. The fact of the matter is that the guidelines simply outline a very sensible and diversified program for the education and upbringing of our children.

PARA.TAB: If we look at a number of the guidelines we find no reference to the allegations made by Senator McGauran. Senator McGauran has alleged, for example, that boys will not be allowed to play with trucks and that Christmas carols will be banned. If Senator McGauran were to visit many of the centres in my electorate he would find children at kindy singing songs like Little Red Wagon, The Wheels on the Bus and so on, which are all very important parts of creative education in our child-care centres, and they are definitely within the guidelines.

The guidelines have been developed to encourage diversity and creativity. There is no mention in any of the material of the allegations that have been made by Senator McGauran. So it is fairly obvious to me that Senator McGauran has not had the benefit of the balanced program provided to our current generation of kids in kindy or he would not be behaving the way he has in the last few days.

These guidelines have the broad support of the industry. They are nothing more than guidelines. What they simply put forward is best practice in kindergartens, and that best practice is currently the practice covered in many of the institutions throughout this country. As with any aspect of our society, there is always room for improvement. We have guidelines so that we can make the education of our children even better than it currently is.

In this vein, I would also like to talk about the work performed by another very important organisation in our community, and that is the organisation of nursing mothers. The Nursing Mothers Association of Australia and, in particular, the work of its Queensland branch, is very valued in my electorate of Lilley. The Nursing Mothers Association of Australia is a large and well-established organisation, with something like 14,000 members in a network of 526 locally based support groups throughout Australia. The Nursing Mothers Association provides breastfeeding information and counselling through something like 1,700 trained volunteer counsellors, who also provide general support for mothers in their parenting role.

The Queensland branch of the association is the second largest branch of the national organisation. In Queensland, it has the largest telephone counselling service; it has about 110 groups operating throughout the state, with about 352 counsellors and 134 trainees. Apart from the essential core of paid staff at national headquarters, the work of the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia is essentially carried out by volunteers spread throughout this country. The Nursing Mothers Association of Australia endorsed the following statement from the joint World Health Organisation/UNICEF meeting in Geneva in October 1979:

SPEECH.PARA: Breastfeeding is an integral part of the reproductive process, the natural and ideal way of feeding the infant and a unique biological and emotional basis for child development.

I am pleased to report that the work of voluntary counsellors and women such as Georgina Bloomfield, Bronwyn Carnell, Heather Chisholm, Marie Grey, Cathie Parminter, Anne Conway, Sherrill Sherwood, Frances Price, Jan Ayre, Julie Davis, Leigh Lance, Kathie McKeown, Jennie Barnard, Rosemary Lyall, Bev Steward, Joy Tomlinson, and many others in my local area is now being fully supported by the Commonwealth and state governments.

PARA.TAB: This group has been the beneficiary of a grant under the national women's health program of some $38,000, approved over 12 months ago. That grant was used to establish a resource centre for counsellors and other health professionals as well as for mothers with young babies. Unfortunately, however, that funding for the Queensland branch ceased on 29 July 1993. No more funding is available under this program until March next year.

Fortunately, following strong representations to the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, and the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley, the Queensland branch of the Nursing Mothers Association has been successful in receiving an interim grant of $12,000 under the community organisation support program, so that it can continue its work until March of next year.

I believe that both these grants reflect the priority that this government attaches to the work done by the Nursing Mothers Association of Australia. In a society which is becoming much more complex and depersonalised, the back-up of the Nursing Mothers Association provides an absolutely essential support for our families: our mothers and fathers and their children.

In recent years, the Nursing Mothers Association has also been active in supporting women who choose to combine child rearing with a career. Recently, the Nursing Mothers Association in Queensland published a booklet which targeted the needs of working women. The existence of the association means that a woman can simply pick up the phone and reach a trained counsellor nearby who can give her information on a myriad of breastfeeding topics. That is the value of the Nursing Mothers Association.

I believe that, if it were not for the existence of voluntary organisations such as this, the bill to the Commonwealth and state governments in other health related matters would be far greater. It is the work of volunteers and organisations such as this that makes our community a much more compassionate and caring one, and we should pay tribute to the work done by the hundreds of volunteers in organisations such as the Nursing Mothers Association.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrews Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Beazley) has conceded in some speeches in recent weeks what many people around Australia involved in education have been saying for some time, that the government's education policy is a mess. Throughout its period of office this Labor maladministration has poured money into higher education. Together, as the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) pointed out in his One Nation address, schools and universities have accounted for virtually all the growth in education and training since 1983. The number of 15-year-olds to 24-year-olds with university degrees has risen by 43 per cent over the period, while the number with trade qualifications has fallen by 11 per cent. And whose responsibility is this? It is the government's, of course.

PARA.TAB: Yet our Prime Minister can tell us ingeniously that vocational education is the cinderella of the Australian education system. In the same speech delivered in Perth in October, the Prime Minister told his audience that the vocational sector lacked the resources and prestige of universities and often acted as an `add-on to a generalist school-level education'. He continued sadly that `this dismissal of vocational education' which persisted in some quarters had cost Australia dearly.

Yes, but who dismissed vocational education? Was it not the same Labor government which was hell-bent on driving the Dawkins plan for making all the world a university, with his so-called unified national system of welding universities with the colleges of advanced education which had performed a vocational function with great efficiency? The Dawkins plan was driven by Labor's old chip on the shoulder mentality, where one deals with an institution that is perceived to be elitist by allowing mass access to it. This is called `satisfying demand'.

While increasing the opportunity for, and the level of, education for all Australians is imperative, the trouble is that one can never satisfy demand, as the government has now belatedly recognised. In his address at the University of Melbourne earlier this month, Minister Beazley noted that Australia's public investment in higher education is unmatched internationally. He pointed out that, while the OECD average expenditure on higher education represents 2.6 per cent of governments' budgets, Australia invests 4.5 per cent of government expenditure in higher education; Germany spends two per cent: and Japan just 1.1 per cent. To the minister, this appears to be an achievement, but it may well be a dubious achievement—indeed a pyrrhic victory.

To the rational man or woman, I would have thought that it would have been obvious that if the wonder economies of the world such as Germany and Japan are spending proportionately less than half of what we are on higher education—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are both in recession.

—And we are not, minister? The likelihood is that we have put all our money on one horse, and the wrong horse at that, if we are talking economic performance. Labor has sold students a pig in a poke. A survey by the Australian National Opinion Poll Research Services found that over 50 per cent of students hoped for a professional career. There is just one problem with this. Professionals account for only 14 per cent of the work force.

PARA.TAB: Conversely, while only two per cent said that they would seek blue-collar work, 22 per cent of the work force is employed in labouring and related work. Eighty per cent of the students believed university degrees were held in `very high regard' by employers but only 13 per cent saw TAFE qualifications as highly regarded by employers. Only 15 per cent said that they intended to go to TAFE and only seven per cent said they planned to complete an apprenticeship while only one per cent said they wanted to enter a traineeship.

Whose fault is it that students look down their noses at blue-collar work? It is indeed ironic and sad that a Labor government—and what a poor substitute or excuse for a Labor government it is, Ben Chiefly would be turning in his grave—has convinced people that the only prestige is to be found in the megalithic universities that they have created.

What is the matter with the honest labour of the workmen and the craftsman who creates visions with his hands? Perhaps in this educational snobbery there is some neo-regency teak table or a neo-something argandy light trickle down effect. We are looking towards a social justice that requires that every family have an empire French mantle clock.

The solution to this conundrum for this inept government is the usual one, a publicity campaign with the government trying to undo the damage by sending out 645,000 booklets to every year 10, 11 and 12 student in the country to convince them that there is more to life after school than university. It is just a little bit late.

Minister Beazley, to do him justice, is resiling from the middle class cringe displayed so abundantly in the educational policy of his predecessor, the present Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). Minister Beazley sent out a clear signal in his Melbourne university speech, and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: There are only so many places and it is not realistic for all year 12 leavers to aspire to enter a university. The vocational education and training sector must also be valued as a useful destination for a larger proportion of school leavers in view of emerging labour requirements.
The minister went on to say:
I do not accept that it is the responsibility of government to meet all so-called `unmet demand' for higher education; indeed it would be irresponsible for a government to seek to do that.
He pointed out that the highest level of unmet demand was in Victoria where the participation rate is well above the national average. He said:
Supply generates demand where it is effectively a free good.

The assumptions that have driven Australia's education reforms in the last few years have been shown to be misplaced. In an EPAC study by Dr Leo Maglen of Monash University he makes a convincing case that education is not the investment in human capital that it was thought to be. Dr Maglen says that it is not education that makes future workers more productive but rather that productivity comes from on the job training and experience. Education he says is no more than a filtering mechanism which sorts trainees.

PARA.TAB: Expanding post-compulsory higher education then may have no direct effect on productivity and economic growth. In fact, if it outstrips the growth in jobs usually associated with that level of education it merely results in credentials creep, an ever rising educational standard that is out of kilter with the work done. To some extent education does provide a competitive advantage in obtaining employment but once higher education becomes widespread that advantage diminishes and the earnings differential also diminishes.

While disadvantaged groups theoretically have greater educational opportunities, there is no evidence that this has been converted into improved economic outcomes and significantly changed income distributions. The study concluded that the `more is better' policy was wasteful and resources should be targeted at primary and secondary education for it is only here that there appears to be a link between education, skills and productivity. Dr Maglen argued that there should be more employment related training programs on the grounds that this has a much more direct impact on productivity than general education.

After 10 years in office the Labor government has only just realised that the overhaul of vocational training should have been its first priority. The reality is that the number of apprentices has dropped by 20 per cent since 1989 and industry has halved its intake of new recruits. The manufacturing sector lost 24 per cent of its apprentices between 1989 and 1992, the wholesale and retail trades lost 28 per cent and the construction industry lost 18 per cent.

Vocational education and training in this country is still sitting among the cinders. That is why some $20 million allocated for training for the long-term unemployed in the current financial year has not been spent to create as much as one single new job skill or LEAP position. Why is the government sitting on this money which could be alleviating the sorry plight of at least some of Australia's one million unemployed? Even if these funds were allocated today, given that many of the places are provided by local government, it is unlikely that the places would be taken up before the end of January because of the Christmas break. Only the government can answer that, and I ask the minister for education to explain why the $20 million today remains unspent. In the meantime, vocational training and education is still waiting for the prince to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments today on the Industry Commission's draft report on public housing. I have 15 or 16 major public housing estates in my electorate as well as other constituents living in public housing. Public housing is an issue of primary concern for constituents in the electorate of Melbourne, so there is a great deal of concern about the contents of the draft report of the Industry Commission.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, it should be acknowledged that the Industry Commission does actually determine that public housing is the most effective way of delivering housing to people in need and is more effective than alternative schemes such as vouchers. We perhaps should be grateful for that finding, given some of the other findings that the Industry Commission has made elsewhere. However, when one actually gets down to the detailed recommendations, the more traditional Industry Commission approach starts to surface. Particularly apparent is the use of analytical techniques and assumptions that really have relevance, if anywhere, only to business and industry and certainly not to the delivery of social policy. I will go through a few examples as illustration of this.

First, the Industry Commission recommends greater transparency and accountability in the delivery of public housing assistance to public tenants. I cannot really speak with any great degree of knowledge on the situation in other states, but I certainly know a fair bit about the circumstances in Victoria. It seems to me that in Victoria there already is perfectly adequate transparency in the nature of assistance provided to tenants and no lack of accountability on the part of tenants for the assistance that they receive.

I am concerned that if we are to pursue this neoclassical, ideological approach—I suppose I could call it that—to its logical extent, then on issues like the basis on which tenants can apply for priority, for example, disability, particular crisis circumstances in their families and whatever, it may be suggested that the rest of the world has a right to know the details about such issues on the basis of this principle of transparency. It is also a worry that the existing stigma that tends to attach to people living in public housing will be exacerbated by increased emphasis on these notions of transparency and accountability.

The second recommendation, which again is illustrative of the tendency of the Industry Commission to approach such issues with an economic rationalist industry approach rather than a social policy approach, is that the functions of management of property and management of tenancies should be separated in the provision of public housing. For example, in a major public housing estate the functions of owning and administering the estate, buying or selling the property, ensuring that it was maintained and the like, would be done by a property manager in one department of state government. The functions of administering tenancies—being the landlord for the public tenants—would be administered by another department, a welfare department, rather than the current situation which is that these two functions are combined within a single housing related department. The name keeps changing in Victoria but the basic approach remains the same.

This recommendation reflects the current obsession amongst the economic rationalist community for taking public sector organisations and cutting them up into little bits whenever there is some degree of dissection potentially available and trying to separate the various functions. That may in certain circumstances have some degree of logic, but certainly in this situation it has no logic at all. If it were implemented, what would occur is that the property decisions would be more market driven and hence people would tend to drift further out into the outer suburbs, where amenities are less and land and property are cheaper; the need for a return on investment to government would dominate decisions further; tenancy problems would go down the list in order of priorities; and the classic area which would be of great concern is the ability of tenants to get reasonable maintenance on their properties.

If one goes around the housing estates of inner Melbourne and talk to tenants, one of the first complaints that one will be hit with time after time is the inordinate amount of effort that is required to get very simple maintenance done. This was so under the previous Labor government. The situation is worse now under the current Liberal government and, if the responsibility for maintenance was in the hands of a property manager one step further removed from the tenancy manager with whom the tenants were dealing, the situation would only get worse.

We then have the recommendation from the Industry Commission that rent rebates should be based on equivalent market rent values. I concede that there is a need for some form of benchmark to ensure that there is some degree of equality of assistance being offered to people in different circumstances so that we do not find some people getting substantially more assistance than others who in effect are in the same circumstances, and that therefore some market reference does have a degree of significance. However, it is extremely dangerous to take this principle too far, because for obviously reasons it is difficult to find any market that is comparable, for example, with a 20-storey high-rise block of flats in an inner Melbourne suburb. There are no 20-storey high-rise blocks of flats in the private sector. There is nothing that is directly comparable with the housing stock that is being leased, and it is extremely difficult to determine the boundaries of any market that one may wish to use as a basis for comparison—what the area would be, how far one would take it, what the different groups of people in the market actually constitute, and whether it forms a market that is suitable for the basis of comparison.

Another recommendation by the Industry Commission would in effect lead to the dismantling of the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement which, in spite of some weaknesses, has served this nation well for many decades. The recommendation is in effect that the Commonwealth would provide money via the states for rental assistance only, subsidising rent for low-income people, and the states would retain the responsibility for capital investment in public housing. This would be a recipe for a very substantial reduction of investment by the states in public housing. It would mean that the Commonwealth's commitment to public housing would go straight into the pockets of private landlords, and it would also mean that in the longer term we would have a much more wasteful use of public money because there would be no public asset left at the end of the day after the expenditure of this money. By contrast, the approach that is currently in place does mean that we have a durable asset which continues to benefit new generations of public tenants as a result of the money that is expended by the Commonwealth.

There is a further recommendation focusing on the importance of pushing out from public housing public tenants who have had a change of circumstances and who are now in a better income situation. Clearly we do not want to have a situation where millionaires are living in public housing with assistance from the public purse, so there is some need for some pressure of that type. However, we should be very mindful of the need to avoid creating yet another poverty trap, a disincentive for people to get further employment and earn further income, because of the risk that they may as a result lose their home and have to move out.

Equally, it is very important that we do not allow public housing estates to be turned into ghettos where only people on social security benefits are living. It is very important that there is a good social mix of people, including people who are in the work force. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 1.45 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106 the debate is interrupted and I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That grievances be noted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —As violence against women continues in Australian society, I would like to draw the House's attention to and pledge my support for White Ribbon Week. White Ribbon Week is being held for the first time in Queensland from 6 to 11 December. It is part of the ongoing men against sexual assault campaign. Such a week urges men to speak out about violence against women. The symbol of a white ribbon marks the anniversary of the massacre of 14 women at Montreal University, with such a remembrance beginning in Canada in 1991 and in Melbourne and Canberra in 1992.

PARA.TAB: It is hoped that about 100,000 men will wear a white ribbon in Queensland during this week in 1993, with half of the funds raised from sales being given to violence against women programs. I know that my local domestic violence group in Toowoomba, the so-called Doves group, joins me in commending this week to all Australians and urges all men in all walks of life to wear a white ribbon for this most important week.

TALK.START.PARA: —The neglect and abuse of historic federal government properties in Sydney have rightly been raised by the New South Wales Heritage Council as being a disgrace. The recent demolition of Navy houses at HMAS Watson, the proposed sale of land next to the Macquarie lighthouse at South Head for development, and the continued dereliction of the facade of the Sydney GPO, all suggest that the federal government has departed from its heritage protection policies and that the Australian Heritage Commission has been largely a joke.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Heritage Commission seems powerless to pursue its role of conserving the nation's heritage, particularly from the indifference or malevolence of other arms of federal government. The case of the Sydney GPO demands special attention. The facade may be both protected and obscured by its current ugly scaffolding, but it is reported that the remainder of the structure is in general decline.

Australia Post has proposed and has now withdrawn a twin-tower development of 32 and 40 storeys abutting the GPO, but it is believed to have further plans for another tower as tall as the American Express tower adjoining the GPO. All these landmark heritage buildings were paid for and are maintained by public funds. The federal government is responsible for them and must act to preserve and enhance their structures and building surrounds in keeping with their great heritage value.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am stunned that there are no members from the government on the opposite benches in here to make members' statements. Perhaps they are so embarrassed by Kellygate that they cannot be bothered to come in! I refer to an article that appeared in the West Australia yesterday in which two of the new Liberal members, the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Evans) and the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Cameron), were said to believe that the Australian Labor Party may have written their seats off through Kellygate because of the small amounts given to their seats through the gratuitous handouts of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly).

PARA.TAB: Honourable members are underestimating their own talents to win seats. In the local government capital works program in last year's budget, as the honourable member for Stirling may well know, $7 million was allocated for the city of Stirling. This was job creation funding for the city of Stirling which, admittedly, has a high level of unemployment, but the city of Wanneroo, which has almost an equal number of people unemployed, received absolutely zilch.

So one can see that that local government capital works program was used in a very effective way last year to drive money into marginal Labor seats to help try to keep those seats—unsuccessfully, in the case of Stirling and Cowan—in the federal election which was held earlier this year. In the dying moments, I might just add that the record holder for the Kelly grants was the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley), who for every single winning vote received $1,845.44. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just one week after I was elected to this House, a couple from my electorate made an appointment to see me with regard to their granddaughter, a partially deaf five-year-old living in Zimbabwe. The little girl needs ongoing speech therapy, attention she is deprived of in Zimbabwe due to an acute lack of therapists. Her parents naturally turned to Australia and the child's grandparents. They desperately hope to immigrate, and they have passed all but one immigration prerequisite—the child is partially deaf. The grandparents have guaranteed that the little girl's therapy costs will not be a burden on the Australian taxpayer, but that does not count. Neither does compassion.

PARA.TAB: In my many talks with immigration authorities, I have found them to be friendly, efficient and professional, but cool to compassion. I understand that it is necessary to be that way. I also understand that there are millions of people desperate to come to this beautiful country, but I do not believe that nature's beauty alone makes a beautiful country. Beauty is also the compassion of its people and its government. We have shown compassion before to tens of thousands of refugees from despotic regimes around the globe. Why cannot we then offer a glimmer of hope to one little girl suffering in Zimbabwe? I appeal to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) to look for a heart and personally intervene in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just heard the greatest load of nonsense from the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) that I have ever heard—even for a performance by an opposition member. We are talking about the local government capital works program and, I guess, the insinuation is that that too was based on Labor marginal seats. Of course, what the honourable member for Moore failed to tell us is that it was based on a percentage of unemployment—not on overall numbers. Of course, if Wanneroo has got more people than Stirling, which I presume it has, then it might have had a lower percentage of unemployed.

PARA.TAB: Let us knock this nonsense on the head once and for all. If this was about marginal seats, it was a pretty sloppy exercise because the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) was the minister for local government at the time. He has a very marginal seat in New South Wales and yet the councils in his electorate got not one red cent from this program. Let us put an end to this nonsense. I have also got a marginal seat and yet only one of the six councils in my electorate got any money. What absolute nonsense!

This is yet another fishing expedition by an opposition which is totally incapable of any substantial debate about substantial issues. It brings up issues like Christmas carols in child-care centres and teak tables, and all this other nonsense, because it has got nothing more useful to contribute to the public debate in this country. What a pack of nongs! The opposition is totally incapable of any substantial contribution to the public debate so it goes on with this nonsense, these lies and these spurious accusations of bias. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), who just spoke, agrees that the government's child-care guidelines are indeed nonsense. I would like to condemn the government's social experiment which is being committed on Australia's toddlers and preschoolers. Labor's national child-care accreditation system is an attack on mainstream family values.
—Hear, hear!

—I am pleased that the honourable member agrees with me. His brother, Senator Julian McGauran, in fact first raised this matter. The government seeks to socially engineer Australia's culture and its approach must be rejected. Australians were disgusted by media reports that the government's guidelines want to ban Christmas carols. I have also had many complaints at my electorate office about the requirement that young children are to play with politically correct trucks.

PARA.TAB: Australia has a Christian heritage; Australia is a Christian society. It is absolutely wrong that a few bureaucrats, plus people on the Labor Party side of politics, are endeavouring to produce a politically correct generation in their own image. Australians are disgusted by the government's policy, and I believe that the government ought to be condemned and Senator Crowley should be sacked.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the last government speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland), the only government speaker as the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing) has said. He was trying to write off the fact that the funds that are being provided to local governments through the sporting grants were, in fact, a load of rubbish because of the way we were approaching it. The fact of the matter is that there is $30 million worth of taxpayers' money that has been passed out to electorates via the Minister's office.

PARA.TAB: There are procedures of accountability and quite frankly that gets to the heart of the problem that we have. We have continually asked in this place for some evidence of the needs base upon which the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) has made these grants and we have asked for the information on the grants to be tabled so that we could be satisfied that an appropriate method had been provided for allocation of these funds.

The fact of the matter is that twice as much money was provided to government seats as was provided to those of the opposition. One only needs to look at the individual seats to see that the funds that have been provided to marginal Labor seats do look significantly different to those in other areas. My main concern is the accountability issue. If the minister tabled the information so we could see that it was done on an effective needs basis, we would be quite satisfied. Until she does so, we have every right to continue to raise the matter and to believe that it has been done on a party politically biased basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —This nonsense about child care absolutely takes the cake. What could be fairer than to have an accreditation system whereby parents whose children are looked after in child-care centres funded by the taxpayer have an assurance that their children will be looked after with quality of care? We have got this nonsense about banning Christmas carols. There is no such proposal to ban Christmas carols or to force children to play with politically correct toys. All we are saying is that there should be a wider choice, and that there should not be stereotypes imposed on children by anyone's particular values.

PARA.TAB: Surely it is reasonable that if there are children of different backgrounds in a particular child-care centre that maybe a range of Christmas carols or songs could be sung, rather than one particular type based on the Anglo-Saxon tradition. That is all we are saying; we are not saying that anyone is banned from doing anything. The opposition is stooping even lower on this issue in this House than it did with the ridiculous allegations in the Senate, because it has not got anything substantial to contribute to the public debate in this country. The opposition is really clutching at straws. Banning Christmas carols in child-care centres: what absolute nonsense!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a rarity for me to join this part of the debate and I am pleased to be making a statement today. I want to correct the West Australian's reporting of the Kellygate incident that has been going on in the last couple of days. Unfortunately, the West Australian has got its facts wrong regarding the seat of Cowan. It mentioned that $30,000 was actually moved into the seat of Cowan. That is in fact incorrect: not one cent was actually given to the seat of Cowan. It is a marginal seat for Labor and was previously held by a member of the Left faction. I am afraid Labor forgot to support its Left member and gave the seat away too early. This is a typical example of how factionalism runs the Labor Party and I believe that it did not support its previous member too well by giving not one cent to the seat of Cowan.

PARA.TAB: As the new member for Cowan, I see a lot more activity within the electorate regarding its member of parliament going out to see and talk to the community. I can assure the electors of Cowan that their representation is at a higher level, and if the scheme starts again I hope they will in fact get some subsidy.

TALK.START.PARA: —In today's 90-second statements, as for the last fortnight, the opposition has focused on the really big issues: the dog kennels, the sports grants or some other really riveting topics. I want to talk about the situation of the improving economy and refer to some of the positive statistics that have come out in recent weeks. The ANZ Bank job vacancies series has shown a 21 per cent increase in the year to the end of September. That is the fourth consecutive month in which those figures have risen. The Bureau of Statistics job vacancies series for August similarly has shown an increase in job vacancies of 39 per cent compared with the same period a year ago. Substantial improvement in the job market is an issue in which the people of Australia have a little more interest rather than whether or not dog kennel of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has been heated.

PARA.TAB: A couple of other important statistics have recently been released. The National Australia Bank's survey of business conditions released in October shows increased business confidence and an expectation by businesses that they will increase employment significantly in the next year. This growth in jobs and the economic growth of our nation has occurred while we have maintained an inflation rate of three per cent or lower. That is an achievement that the government can be proud of. It is an achievement that provides real and lasting benefits to the Australian community and focuses on some of those things that are a little more important than the trivia the opposition has sought to parade in this place in the last two weeks.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three matters I want to refer to very briefly. Continuously in this place we hear speeches about how dreadful the world economy is and that is the only reason the Australian economy is bad. We get a little homily from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the rare occasions he walks into this place. In fact, nearly 70 per cent of our trade is with Asia, which is growing at an average rate of about six per cent. The growth rate in China, the country with the biggest population in the world, is stated this week in the Australian newspaper as 14 per cent. So in fact the countries that we trade with and that our economy is linked with are not languishing, as alleged by the Prime Minister, but are growing at rates that have been seen very seldom in the last 50 or 60 years.

PARA.TAB: The second matter I want to touch on is with regard to Telecom and the yellow pages. They are brutalising small business throughout the country and have resulted in a large number of people becoming bankrupt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2.00 p.m., in accordance with standing order 106A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House of the death today of Condon Bryan Byrne, a former senator. Condon Byrne represented the state of Queensland from 1951 to 1959 and 1968 to 1974. As a mark of respect to the memory of Condon Byrne, I invite honourable members to rise in their places.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members having stood in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. I refer him to July's national fiscal outlook which argued for structural repair to the Commonwealth and state budgets, and I ask: is the Treasurer aware that a blow-out of nearly $600 million in the South Australian Labor government's debt reduction target was announced today? Is he aware that this blows out South Australia's estimated debt from $7 billion to $7.57 billion by 1996? When was the Treasurer informed of this blow-out in South Australia's debt and what will its impact be on the national fiscal outlook?

—For the first time we have put together a national fiscal outlook statement which is now compiled annually in conjunction with the states. I would expect that next year a revised national fiscal outlook statement will be published. The Commonwealth's obligation in relation to the national fiscal outlook statement is, in the first instance, to coordinate its production and then to look at what contribution the Commonwealth can make through its budget to improve the national fiscal outlook.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members will recall that when the report was produced earlier this year it revealed a gap which needed to be filled. That is why the Commonwealth, in this year's budget, decided to take very decisive action both on the expenditure side and on the revenue side to ensure that the Commonwealth was doing its part in terms of reducing the size of the Commonwealth budget deficit to around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97.

In this context I am intrigued that the opposition has finally discovered fiscal policy, because for most of the period since the budget the honourable member for Mayo and other members of the opposition were doing their level best to try to wreck the fiscal policy of the Commonwealth and, by extension, the fiscal policy of the nation as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to a point of order. The question was quite specific in relation to when the federal Treasurer was made aware of today's announcement of a blow-out of a further $600 million in South Australia's debt. The question was quite specific—when was he made aware of it—and it is consistent with standing orders that he should answer that.
—The Treasurer was asked a question also as part of your original question about the national policy and the Treasurer is answering the question.

—Mr Speaker, you are absolutely right. The honourable member did make the mistake of prefacing his specific question with references to national fiscal policy, and I am making the obvious and legitimate point that, had the opposition had its way in relation to the government's budget proposals, the budget deficit in 1996-97 would be not $500 million as he claims has been the deterioration in South Australia, but $3.5 billion. The opposition was in for a $3.5 billion wreckage job as far as the Commonwealth budget was concerned, which would have had implications for the national fiscal position as well.

PARA.TAB: It is not the Commonwealth's job to supervise the budgets of state governments. Indeed, I would have thought that the Liberals would have been the last to suggest that we should. We have a system now, through the Loan Council, where we have a much better look at, and a much better set of, arrangements for ensuring that the states are more publicly accountable for their budgetary management and their debt position.

We have a quite specific arrangement with South Australia—as we have with Victoria, as we have with Tasmania—in relation to the debt reduction objectives of those states. The Commonwealth entered into an arrangement earlier this year with the state government about how its debt management could be organised over the years ahead in the context of the sale of the State Bank and in the context of some budgetary assistance which the Commonwealth had provided.
It is for the South Australian government to account for its plans and its success in relation to handling its debt strategy. It is for the state government to account for those matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have they told you about the blow-out?
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo!

—It is not for me to be giving a running score on how the state government is going through its budgets or forward estimates and about how its debt strategy is being handled. What is important is that, in the context of its particular budget this year, it should have made progress towards achieving those debt reduction targets. Indeed, in this year's budget of course it did make that progress. We will be looking, as future state budgets are brought down in South Australia, to see that it continues its progress in accordance with the debt reduction strategy which it has laid out with and for the Commonwealth.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Has he seen reports that the Western Australian parliament has overnight moved to extinguish all native title in that state allegedly because of the actions this government was going to take? What are the government's intentions in this matter?

—I direct my question to the Treasurer. Can the Treasurer inform the House of recent developments regarding the outlook for business investment spending in Australia? Is there evidence to support claims of growing confidence on the part of overseas and domestic investors?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I think it is an appropriate one, given that the Bureau of Statistics yesterday released its September quarter survey of private new capital expenditure. The survey reveals that in the June quarter private new capital expenditure grew by two per cent in seasonally adjusted terms.

PARA.TAB: Moreover, some commentators who have expressed their scepticism as to the importance of these numbers seem to have failed to look behind the aggregate figures and to analyse their composition. If they had, they would have noted that investment in plant and equipment increased by a very solid five per cent, whilst expected new capital expenditure for 1993-94 rose six per cent since its revised June quarter estimate. This follows a significant upward revision in the actual level of private investment in 1992-93 from 1.6 per cent to, again, a very solid 5.4 per cent.

This data released yesterday is just one of a series of data which is being systematically released by the bureau, indicating what I think is a strengthening economy. This morning's release of manufacturers' sales figures shows that they are estimated to have grown by two per cent in real, seasonably adjusted terms in the September quarter; whilst expected sales for 1993-94 have been revised up by four per cent since the June survey.

Again, we have more information released today on company profits, where company profits have recorded their ninth consecutive quarterly increase and are now at the highest level since this particular series commenced in 1985. Part of the reason why we have this indication of strengthening business investment is due not only to business perceptions of the economy but also to the underlying conditions within the economy—inflation at a 30-year low, interest rates at a 20-year low and the specific action the government has taken through its general investment allowance, the special investment allowance and the new company tax rate of 33 per cent. This demonstrates that the government's initiatives in One Nation, the investing in the nation program and subsequently have been important in encouraging business to make its investments.

I am releasing today the fifth quarterly report of the Development Allowance Authority, which reveals that a total of 56 projects were registered during the quarter. This brings the number of total projects registered to 121 and the total capital value of projects registered to date in the order of $27 billion, with plant accounting for $22 1/2 billion. We have seen the DAA systematically going through the applications every quarter, registering a new large number of investment proposals and today cynicism and scepticism oozes out of every pore of the opposition whilst it grizzles about the fact that the economy is doing better and there is clear evidence that investment is beginning to pick up.

Investment has been one of the missing links in the Australian recovery. But, as many commentators are now coming to understand—and in the next six months the penny might drop even as far as the opposition is concerned—we are now beginning to get not only the hard data but also increasing anecdotal information: for instance, the $100 million investment announced yesterday by Siemens AG.

All of this is evidence of the fact that the Australian economy is picking up and, most importantly, becoming a more competitive place in which to invest. These more positive signs are a galling piece of reality as far as the opposition is concerned but something from which we can take some heart and something which gives additional substance to the fact that we have seen jobs growing—70,000 jobs since the beginning of this financial year—which I think does mean that there are some better prospects for those people who are still unemployed in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his recent announcement of the appointment of a task force on urban design and his statement that he wishes to `put a bit of poetry into the souls of our town clerks and shire engineers'. I ask: does this mean the task force will concentrate on the regulatory approach for minor matters rather than the major determinants of urban aesthetics such as the government's road pricing policies and the anarchical activities of state and federal government instrumentalities? What are the terms of reference for the task force? When will it report? Will the Prime Minister take action to ensure that one of Sydney's longstanding monuments to ugliness and Commonwealth bureaucracy, the derelict facade of the Sydney GPO, is restored?

—Let me say, as somebody who has added a little bit of poetry to urban planning and urban design, that I am very pleased to take the question from the honourable member for North Sydney. North Sydney is one of the most difficult areas of any of the capital cities. The fact is that the honourable member, as mayor of North Sydney, has sought to try to enforce some codes of behaviour and aesthetic disciplines on the municipality of North Sydney—
—You never go across the bridge.

—Order! The Prime Minister might just wait for a moment. The honourable member for Mayo is constantly interjecting when ministers are speaking. I would remind him, as I would remind all honourable members in this place, of a warning that I have given in the past about the standing order relevant to naming members who are in some way offending the standing orders without the need to warn, and I hope he takes the hint.

—In an area that was basically a residential area, which changed over time to a built-up area, the honourable gentleman, as mayor, sought to lead a movement to preserve those parts of North Sydney as open space public recreation areas in a way which enhanced the aesthetic beauty of the area and, at the same time, tried to fight some of the more outrageous development proposals over time, and with a substantial degree of success. This is an issue in which he has had a continuing interest. So too have I, and so has my colleague the Deputy Prime Minister, for a long period of time.

PARA.TAB: I think our point—and the point of the task force—is that there is too little choice in housing in this country. It is not simply that we are hostage to the quarter acre lot; it is mostly that that is all we are offering. While we are seeing more medium and higher density in some of the inner city areas of the city now—most particularly in Sydney and Melbourne; and Melbourne now has quite a boom in inner city higher density developments—by and large this is not generally on offer. What has been on offer is a higher density which is not aesthetically pleasing, which is not comfortable to live in, which is not efficiently built and which does not do anything for the aesthetics of particular precincts.

One of the problems is that with the establishment of local government acts in this country the focus in planning—or in approvals—is on engineering and on health and if approvals meet engineering standards and they meet health standards what a building looks like or how it serves the community remains somewhat secondary to the overall outcome. In fact, there are no aesthetic codes to my knowledge which impact upon a development or which require a developer to work within an area or to have some regard to the precinct.

The study that is now being undertaken is to look at some of those things to see whether or not we might be able to do as some European countries have done—that is, construct aesthetic codes that also work in a total way with building and health standards so that when a municipal council, or officers of a municipal area, look at a planning decision or a development application, they look at it on a total basis with regard to the precinct and the impact of the development on the surrounding area.

I am quite happy to provide the honourable gentleman with the terms of reference. I think it is quite an interesting study. I do not know that one has been undertaken in Australia, even though there has been some academic work written on this subject over time.

It is a matter of some pleasure that we are seeing a change in housing style in Australia and a move towards greater densities in the inner cities, where more people can enjoy the public infrastructure which is already in place. With that, hopefully we will see a move towards higher quality, more aesthetically pleasing buildings. Nevertheless, there is still a propensity to put up packing case architecture cheaply without any regard to the neighbourhood.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are happy for you to be the judge, Paul, on all these things!
—The honourable member for Flinders!

—Well, this is something we all have opinions about. As a consequence, we will not see a lot of junk built in our cities, but our cities being nicer places than comparable cities as a consequence of having some care and attention to how they look.

PARA.TAB: As far as I know, there is no impetus to any of this view coming from within state governments—more is the pity—and I think they are now starting to focus some of their interest on it, as is the Commonwealth government. I look forward to the outcome of this work and to see whether something useful may come of it because I am quite sure we could engender a cooperative attitude between the Commonwealth, the states and local government. At any rate, the honourable gentleman has made his interest in the subject abundantly clear over time and, as a consequence, the area of the federal seat of North Sydney and the immediate area are so much the better for his having been around.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services inform the House of the effectiveness of the federal government's strategy to provide special assistance to people with a disability to give them equal access to the labour market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: HOUSING, LOCAL GOVERNMENT AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Capricornia for her question. The question went to assistance being provided through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service.

PARA.TAB: I say by way of preface to the honourable member that we recently published the Burdekin report dealing with the issue of mental illness. In responding to that report, I have tried to make it clear that, if we are going to deal with the issue of mental illness more effectively in this country, then we are going to have to change attitudes and culture so that we are able to overcome some of the prejudice and some of the stereotypes that are associated with mental illness.

One of those prejudices was that we would not expect people who had had a psychiatric illness, people who had been mentally ill, to be rehabilitated or to be able to make it back into the work force. I discovered that the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service did not particularly concentrate on providing a service for people who had been psychiatrically ill. So about a year ago the government established something like 11 units of the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service around the country particularly focusing on the needs of people who had been psychiatrically ill. It is to the results of those units that I want to refer.

A total of 72 per cent of clients who complete the program provided by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service get jobs. That is a success rate of around 78 per cent, with a very difficult client group in an extremely tight labour market. We are also finding associated with that group something like a 70 per cent reduction in rehospitalisation. That is, the number of people who have had a tendency to move between the community and go back into hospital is very substantially reduced where people have been through that process of rehabilitation offered by the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service.

There is particular significance, in view of the government's interest in employment and the green paper, for these results. They show that a case management approach, as it has been developed and, I think, practised highly successfully, can be of very considerable assistance to those who are out of the work force and to the long-term unemployed. I commend to my colleague the Minister for Employment, Education and Training the results of these pilot studies because I think they are of very much broader significance. If we are going to be able to have success—I think we have demonstrated through projects such as JET that we can have considerable success with people with serious disabilities being able to return to the work force—a case management approach is extremely important.

I conclude by making the point that in these experiments the results have been quite arresting, quite outstanding. They certainly provide a great deal of food for thought, as the government will be considering over the next few months both the issue of mental illness arising out of the Burdekin report and also the green paper and its subsequent white paper on employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In completing the answer to the shadow minister for sport, I will just make a simple point: even if any of his accusations happen to be true—and they will be checked—one has to remember that no money is provided until the facility is built.
