The reason for that, quite simply, is that those opposite hate sport, they hate the community infrastructure program—and they want to get rid of it. So, before I conclude, as we have only heard today all the negative, so-called, accusations from the opposition, I would like to quote from a few letters that I have here from some of the positive programs. One that I have here I am sure the honourable member for Indi would like to hear about, even if the rest of those opposite would not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145, relevance. The minister has indicated that she is now going to talk about matters which are completely outside the span of the question which was asked of her. The question asked what role was played by certain persons in the application, in a specific instance. For the minister to now talk about references in other matters which are unrelated to this is simply irrelevant. I ask you to ask the minister to come back to the question or to sit down.

—Order! Resume your seat. Consistently in the last two weeks the minister has been questioned on a particular program for which she has responsibility. In the course of that questioning she has gone to a number of specific examples. The last question asked of an example. The minister is giving a response to that particular question, and I would gather from what she has just said that she is concluding and is to illustrate that further. The minister in conclusion.

—In conclusion, I will quote from this one letter—for the interest of the honourable member for Indi at least. This letter is from the city of Benalla. It is about a grant of $170,000 to the honourable member's electorate. The letter, from the town clerk, states:

ANSWER.PARA: This funding will now enable a much needed community facility to be constructed for use by a wide range of regional sporting and recreational activities.
It is just one of the many constructive and supportive letters that we have received from around this nation on what is a very good and a very useful community program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, could you ask the minister to table all the papers that she was quoting from, in accordance with the standing orders?
—No. Your point is relevant to that particular document. The minister was reading from something because she indicated that. Is it confidential?
—Yes, it is written to me.
—That is the end of it.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is no debate on that as an issue, and in fact I again point members to—
—But it doesn't mean anything, Ros; it means nothing.
—I warn the honourable member for Mitchell.

—I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen reports suggesting that there should be no limit on the extent of foreign ownership of the Australian print media? Does he believe such a policy would be in the national interest? Can he say whether the government would entertain such a policy under any circumstances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—You don't want to hear about it.
—The Prime Minister might resume his seat for a minute.

—I am happy to hear about it, but I put to you, Mr Speaker, that the honourable member for Perth has not drafted his question in accordance with the standing orders in the second and third sections. They were deliberately loose in terms of compliance with standing order 144, which relates to the announcement of government policy and also to opinion. In those terms he should be ordered to redraft it or the question should be ruled out of order.
—There is no point of order. The question was in order.

—There has been a restriction on the ownership by foreigners of various parts of the Australian media and banking—a number of restricted areas of commerce. Prime amongst them has been the print media. The government has taken the view—even though these assets in the main have not generally been for sale over the last couple of decades with the Herald and Weekly Times and with John Fairfax and Sons—that this was a matter of national interest. As a consequence, as I said yesterday, the government, when considering Mr Black's interests, agreed to make it clear that Mr Black could have enough of the voting stock, and the stock of the company, to indicate that he could control it and to give the group, therefore, the cohesion and commercial direction which it had lacked for some time in the flux created by the takeover of John Fairfax and Sons by Mr Warwick Fairfax.

PARA.TAB: We had a major inconsistency in the parliament yesterday in the evidence or in the published views of Mr Black and the Leader of the Opposition. When considering this question of what the Leader of the Opposition had promised him in relation to the allowable limits of equity for John Fairfax and Sons by Mr Black's interests, Mr Black said this:

ANSWER.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition had already promised that if he was elected he would remove restraints on our ownership.
That was in his book. On the Sunday program he said:
The opposition's view was as a matter of policy we should be allowed to raise our percentage and they gave no indication they had any ceiling in mind.
He went on further to say:
I wrote in my book about Dr Hewson's position which was that this was not an issue with him.
That is, the question of equity was not an issue with him and he was, in agreed phraseology—that is, between the Leader of the Opposition and Mr Black—
. . . very relaxed about what our level of ownership would be in the event that he won the election.
That is, very relaxed about whether Mr Black could have control.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday in the House when addressing the parliament on this question the Leader of the Opposition said:

ANSWER.PARA: There is absolutely no commitment . . . I have never given Conrad Black a commitment to go to 100 per cent.
When asked by Mr Lee:
What about 50 per cent?
the Leader of the Opposition said:
Or to 50 per cent, or to any specific number.
Someone is telling an untruth here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Misleading the House.
—It is either Mr Black or the Leader of the Opposition.
—If the Prime Minister has a substantive motion to put, I suggest he put it.
—The Leader of the Opposition misled this House yesterday. He came in here and told the parliament a direct lie; a direct lie.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think I can handle that. The Prime Minister might withdraw that last statement.
—A direct untruth.
—No, Prime Minister, you will withdraw.

—I withdraw. This man was up debating yesterday the question of Fairfax stock. He had gone to Mr Black and promised him any level of equity, saying he was very relaxed about it. He then tried to deceive the House by saying he had made no particular commitment on level; he only made it very clear to Mr Black that he could have whatever percentage of the stock he wished. No level: that is, definitely control of the company about which Mr Black said he was very relaxed. He said he was exceptionally relaxed. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I wrote in my book about Dr Hewson's position which was that this was not an issue with him.

What was not an issue with him? The degree of Black's control of John Fairfax and Sons. `Not an issue' means control of the stock of the company. Whether we are talking about 50 per cent or 100 per cent, it means effective control, and it was not an issue. He said he was very relaxed about the level of ownership.

PARA.TAB: Then yesterday in the House the Leader of the Opposition deceived the parliament by saying, `Oh, I did not talk about a specific limit'—as though in not talking about a specific limit, he was in any other way indicating that complete control of the company could go to Mr Black.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The Prime Minister used the phrase about the Leader of the Opposition that he was deceiving the House. I submit that is unparliamentary and he should withdraw.

—I am sure that the Prime Minister is aware of standing orders relevant to the point which the Leader of the Opposition himself raised. I would just caution the Prime Minister about raising a particular issue. If he does wish to pursue that further, there are forms of the House which he can use.
—In his interview on the Sunday program Mr Black said:

ANSWER.PARA: I think a better rather than an inaccurate or evasive section of the book is to present the facts as I do.
Then he indicated as follows:
I would be quite happy to say under oath or in any other way—to present the facts and to present them under oath.

TALK.START.PARA: —He sounds truthful.

—He sounds truthful! Everything that he has said so far has been, as far as I am concerned, accurate. Mr Black made it very clear to me that the Leader of the Opposition had made a commitment to give him control of John Fairfax and Sons, yet this performance in the House yesterday misled the House on the basis that the Leader of the Opposition sought not to give Mr Black control of John Fairfax and Sons. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Filing

—No, I will not, Mr Speaker; look, it is not unparliamentary.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Name him! Name him!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Hang on; hang on. Honourable members should just calm down for a minute. —I will withdraw. But if the opposition thinks it will gag the parliament by seeking to have words withdrawn, it can think again. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order.
—Mr Speaker—

—You have trapped yourself, John Hewson; you have trapped yourself. You are the man who made the grubby commitment to Mr Black. The government has made a commitment to 25 per cent—
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order—

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I ask on what basis you ruled `duplicitous' as being different from `lie' and why you will not ask the Prime Minister to withdraw that word which he distinctly used a few minutes ago.

—You might recall that, at the time when I asked the Prime Minister to do so, the word used was in specific reference to an honourable member of this place. My understanding is that the Prime Minister used that word in a broader sense. I say to the right honourable member for New England that I am listening very carefully because of the sensitivities on both sides that have been displayed in this place over the last couple of days, and it is on that basis that I have made my ruling.

—I am drawing my answer to a conclusion. The conclusion is this: the government has allowed the interest in John Fairfax and Sons by Mr Black to go to 25 per cent, with a process of complete probity and with a limitation of no greater than 25 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Mr Speaker, when the Leader of the Opposition appears before the Senate under oath and the question is directed to him as to whether he was relaxed in the control of John Fairfax and Sons, and then when Mr Black gives his testimony under oath, we will see that the Leader of the Opposition raised a charge against this government, and against me in particular, when, in fact, it was he who had made the commitment to Mr Black.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I made the point before that there are procedures before this parliament by which the Prime Minister can move a substantive motion—
—There is no point of order; resume your seat.
—Mr Speaker, there was an MPI yesterday and this man did not take that opportunity—
—There is no point of order; resume your seat. The Prime Minister will conclude.

—Mr Speaker, for days in my absence the Leader of the Opposition charged that I had made an improper arrangement with Mr Black when, in fact, the Leader of the Opposition had agreed to pass complete control of the company over to Mr Black. He is the guilty man—the person who has made the deal that would just shovel Australian national interests to one side.

PARA.TAB: The House should take note of the evidence that will be given to the Senate committee and be very clear about what the Leader of the Opposition says under oath juxtaposed against that which Mr Black has already made clear he is prepared to say under oath.

—Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

—Yes, I was in an answer to a question about native title.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Bennelong, the Leader of the Opposition and the Prime Minister will cease interjecting across the table. The honourable member for Flinders has the call on a matter of personal explanation.

—Mr Speaker, in answer to a question at question time today, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) implied—in fact, he referred to me in his answer—that I had spoken to Mr Cash, a minister in Western Australia, about the Senate's timing of its consideration of the Native Title Bill. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The damage done to the national fiscal outlook by the Treasurer's failure to ensure structural budget repair.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have noticed that it is the habit now of the government to ensure that the appropriate minister refuses to respond to matters of public importance. Today it is the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) who is to respond instead of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins). But yesterday, very significantly, when the MPI was proposed by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) on the matter of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) not only allowing for an increase in ownership of the Fairfax group by Mr Conrad Black—a foreigner—but also doing so on the condition that the Fairfax newspapers provided more balanced reporting, the Prime Minister refused to respond to that matter of public importance. In a cowardly way, he waited until question time today, got a backbencher to ask a dorothy dix question about it and then spent 10 raving minutes abusing, denigrating, breaching standing orders and inventing positions of the coalition.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the Prime Minister is culpable on this issue and will always be held culpable because not only did he increase foreign ownership but also he increased that foreign ownership on the basis of a condition: that the Fairfax newspapers should provide more so-called balanced reporting. That, frankly, is a measure of the morality—or should I say a measure of the immorality—of the Prime Minister in public affairs in this country; that is a measure of his imperial grandeur, regardless of the consequences for the nation and regardless of the consequences for the people of this country.

This matter is relevant to the matter of public importance before the House today. I will explain why. One of the characteristics of the Prime Minister is his tendency to say things which are untrue. He has been doing that this afternoon. On 12 February 1991 in this very chamber the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: There are very few governments in this country that manage their financial affairs more soundly and tightly than the Labor Government of South Australia.

That is absolutely risible. It is yet another example of a Prime Minister who can never be trusted to tell the truth. This is a man who, when he became Prime Minister, said that he would resist the temptation to gild the lily and has since poured all the gold he can find over any flower that blooms. The fact is that he is a Prime Minister who will never be trusted by the people of this country. The fact is that he is just one of a group.

PARA.TAB: We had the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) yet again demonstrate that she is not worthy to hold the office of minister of the Crown in this country. It is a matter of shame to the Labor Party that it should continue to prop up such a totally incompetent minister. Indeed, she is one of the most incompetent Labor politicians in this country. Another is the Premier of South Australia.

Many honourable members will be amused to hear that this very morning the Premier of South Australia blew a hole in the government's national fiscal strategy. Way back in April of this year, Mr Arnold produced a report called Meeting the challenge in which he outlined how he would reduce the state debt of South Australia to $7 billion by 1996. But Mr Arnold, not being any more truthful in his activities than the Prime Minister, gave what I think everyone would agree was a quite extraordinary interview at a press conference yesterday. Remember, he stipulated back in April that his debt target would be $7 billion by 1996. He was asked yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: What's your target 1997 in real terms?
This, of course, is a year later than 1996. He said:
Our target in 1997 is about $7.8 billion.
I take it you meant $6.8 billion because you were hoping to reach $7 billion the year before that.
Well I think the figure is about $7.8 billion after the three years.
This went on until the journalist asked, `Do you really mean $7.8 billion? Is it nominal? Is it real?'. He said:
Yes, actually I think you're right. It was $7.8 nominal and $7 real. No I'm sorry . . . in my mind . . . my mistake.
He went on and on with this blithering nonsense which ended up with him saying:
Oh well I'd have to come back and see those figures.

In other words, he did not have a clue what his deficit reduction strategy was. But today the Premier of South Australia released the South Australian Treasury's forward estimates. Do they show that he has been telling the truth over the last few months since April, that the South Australian government will reduce the debt to $7 billion by 1996? No, they do not. The figures show that the real debt by that time will not be $7 billion but nearly $7.6 billion.

PARA.TAB: In other words, today we learned that there has been a $600 million blow-out in the South Australian government's debt reduction strategy—exactly the same amount of money as `Pork-barrel Paul' poured into the South Australian budget during the last federal election. In other words, the $600 million that went to South Australia from Canberra is chewed up today by the South Australian government blowing out the debt by $600 million by 1996.

Mr Arnold was immediately thrown on the defensive, rushed off and tried to explain this misleading information. Firstly, he said that state Treasury told his office last week that the debt would blow out by $600 million in 1996. But this information was passed on to him not last week but on Tuesday of this week, the day before yesterday, late in the afternoon after his notorious press conference.

However, we do know that the federal government and the federal Treasury knew last week all about this blow-out in the state government's debt. That information was transmitted to the federal Treasury last week and no doubt it passed that information on to the Treasurer and to the Prime Minister. So we can conclude that those people in Canberra had been sitting on this information, and only a fool would believe that Mr Arnold did not know his debt figure had blown out by $600 million last week. The reason why this debt will blow out has to be described as little short of extraordinary. He says that debt has been redefined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and that redefinition has `taken place in very recent times. This happened after the August budget'. They were his words this morning.

The fact is that this question of the redefinition of debt by the Australian Bureau of Statistics was decided at a Premiers Conference—and I thought this man was the Premier—in May 1991, to be applied from 1 July 1993. There was even a press release that went out from the Treasury on 11 July 1991 explaining how this redefinition of debt by the Australian Bureau of Statistics would take place.

So for Mr Arnold to come out today and say that there has been a redefinition of debt very recently is for Mr Arnold to not tell the truth. Mr Arnold is not telling the truth about this blow-out in state debt. This is a blow-out of $400 per head for every man, woman and child in South Australia, and Mr Arnold apparently was not told about it by his office for a whole week. Nobody is going to believe that; nobody on earth.

So the miserable saga goes on. Mr Arnold claims that the reason for the blow-out in state debt is also the State Bank sale price has apparently been overvalued. It has been made clear to Mr Arnold for months now that his determination to suck $160 million out of the State Bank to fund his election bribes will, of course, reduce the value of the State Bank. One would think if he knew anything about money, business or economics he would have taken that into account. But apparently he did not. His claim today that the State Bank cannot be sold for as much as he originally proposed is simply a nonsense.

The fact is that throughout the whole of this saga we can conclude one thing about Mr Arnold: Mr Arnold is not telling the truth. Mr Arnold is telling South Australians porkies about the size of the debt of that state. The sooner South Australians get rid of him the better, because then at least in that state we can have honest government—even if we have to wait two years to get honest government at the national level as well.

The State Bank, of course, has been the great saga of South Australia. It has caused devastating damage to the state, and its collapse is entirely the responsibility of the state Labor government. The Prime Minister went to Adelaide on 8 November and while he was there he claimed that the present South Australian government had no responsibility for the collapse of the State Bank. The fact is that eight out of the existing 13 ministers were in the cabinet between 1989 and 1991 when 200 questions were asked in the state parliament about the problems of the State Bank. Those eight out of 13 ministers appointed the board of the State Bank and they also approved a doubling of the capital of the bank to enable the bank to go on the absurd spending spree that it ended up embarking upon.

Of course, at the end of all this, the state government then had to indemnify the whole exercise—to provide indemnity of $3.15 billion to bail out the State Bank. But the bailing out of the State Bank is not finished yet because, out of that $3.15 billion, there is only $113 million worth of indemnity left. There is only $113 million left to finance two years of substantial losses by what is known as the `bad bank' over the next two years, and also to finance the Remm centre disaster to which the State Bank lent $740 million—which the bank values now at $205 million and is more likely to be worth something in the vicinity of $100 million to $150 million.

So what we know about the State Bank saga is that a further bailout of the State Bank is almost inevitable. A fifth bailout of the State Bank of South Australia is almost inevitable because $3.15 billion is not going to be enough. The federal government should continue to monitor very closely the impact of all of these things on the finances of South Australia. As a matter of fact, I think it is possible that it is, but the federal government is deliberately covering up these issues in order to help the Arnold government skate through to the next election.

Do honourable members remember what the federal government did during the Victorian election campaign when the Victorian government exceeded its Loan Council limits? The federal government knew all about it; the Treasurer knew all about it. He deliberately did not include those figures in the budget papers. But he knew what was going on in Victoria and he was prepared to cover up rorts by the Victorian Labor government to help it through an election, which of course it lost.

The federal government is covering up for Arnold as well. It is covering up for Labor in South Australia. It is covering up for its mates. The simple fact is that a fifth bailout of the State Bank is almost inevitable. The state government has passed information to this government about the blow-out in its own medium-term debt strategy, and the federal government is deliberately covering up that information, and has done for at least the last week, in order to help the Arnold government across the line.

The fact is that in the end nothing is going to save the state Labor government in South Australia. No cover-ups by the Prime Minister, no cover-ups by the Treasurer and no degree of confected argument by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer is going to do anything to save the Arnold government in South Australia. Those people have ruined South Australia, just as the federal government is imposing ruin on this country through debt and unemployment. The electorate of South Australia will take it out on the Labor Party on 11 December. I very much look forward to casting my own vote for the Liberal Party on that day. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who has had a look at the terms portrayed in the matter of public importance and who has listened to the speech just made would have to wonder whether there was any relationship. There was not. The honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) gets up and talks about truth and honesty in government. A couple of weeks ago, I came in here and had to straighten him out on one of his own press releases in which he sought to misrepresent the fact that millionaires paid less tax than people on incomes of $40,000 to $50,000 a year. Having done that, there was no apology or anything from the honourable member for Mayo.

PARA.TAB: It is all right for him to get up here and spit a few untruths. In fact, I notice that a new word called `Downerism' is getting about Parliament House. It is not unlike the word spoonerism. If a couple of letters are transposed in a sentence we get the word `spoonerism', but the word `Downerism' means that if something is repeated often enough it must be true. To add flourish to it, it helps if those words can be repeated. I remember after the budget the words `vicious' and `vindictive' were used. In fact, I think the same words kept coming up in about six or seven different interviews on Media Watch. `Downerism' is up and running around Parliament House and out there in the electorate.

If we look at the terms of reference of the matter of public importance, we see that the honourable member for Mayo did not even touch on the subject. This government has the best record of any government in recent times in looking after the budget deficit and the fiscal strategy. In this year's budget it sought to bring the budget deficit down to around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97.

What was the opposition's role in that? I think it was signalled fairly early by the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) when he said when we get back to parliament it is going to be war in the trenches in terms of what those in the Senate are going to do. With a very responsible budget in terms of looking at the fiscal outlook, what was the role of the opposition to oppose it? In actual fact, if honourable members want endorsement of the federal government's strategy on the budget deficit, we have only to look at the 3 September edition of the Business Review Weekly. On page 23 it quotes Mr David Beers:

One of the leading ratings agencies, Standard & Poor's, is stunned by the negative reaction in Australia to the budget. "I kind of wonder what people are talking about," comments David Beers, director of the agency's international finance department in New York. "From our standpoint, which is rating bonds, we don't entirely share the pessimism about this budget. We think it is important that it has taken some steps to bring the deficit down to a more sustainable level over a period of time. The comments that people are making are of apocalyptic proportions, as they often are in Australia, about things that are relatively on the margin," he says.
Beers says that from the bond market's perspective, the projected reduction in the Australian budget deficit was perhaps the most important initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: Later on he made this statement:
It is often forgotten that the government has a pretty good record during the past few years of reducing spending as a proportion of GDP.

Indeed, he is dead right. In fact, it was the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when he was Treasurer—we will all remember this—who achieved the first budget surplus since the early 1950s. In the 1987-88 budget the surplus was 0.7 per cent of GDP, in 1988-89 it was 1.7 per cent and in 1989-90 it was 2.2 per cent. So during the good years, the growth years in Australia, the government actually ran budget surpluses—the first postwar government to do so.

PARA.TAB: Let us compare those achievements, now that we are midway through our current term of office, with the budget deficit of 3.4 per cent that the coalition government achieved in 1977-78. This year, this government introduced deficit reduction legislation which, as I have already pointed out, was opposed by the opposition, yet today it proposes a matter of public importance relating to the damage done to the national fiscal outlook. The simple fact is that in the budget this year we went about repairing the national fiscal outlook. I did not hear one word of criticism, one word in anything the honourable member for Mayo said during his 15-minute speech anything the federal government had done wrong in this regard.

It is not as though we are the only country in the world that is taking steps in this direction. The United Kingdom government has set itself a fiscal target of reducing the public sector borrowing requirement to 4 1/2 per cent of GDP in 1996-97. With regard to the United States, we all read about and saw on television the trouble that President Clinton had in getting his budget deficit reduction strategy through the House of Representatives and the Senate. His aim, of course, was to get the budget deficit down to 2.6 per cent of GDP by 1996-97. So the figures of 4 1/2 per cent in the UK and 2.6 per cent in the United States do not even come close to what we are going to do. As I said, ours will be about one per cent. In fact, over four years, the budget deficit will be cut by $8.5 billion, from a prospective deficit for 1996-97 of $14.9 billion to $6.5 billion—all done without help from the opposition.

The public sector will directly contribute $17 billion to the improvement in national savings over the three years to 1996-97. Of course, that was all glossed over by the honourable member for Mayo, who did not lay a single glove on this government about anything. If one listened to what he had to say, it seemed he was more content to roam around South Australia. I have been in this place long enough to know that, whenever a state election is in the offing, people in this place think they can get up and make a few statements about that particular state. I suppose the second speaker in this discussion from the opposition side will also be from South Australia and will get up and make some mindless comment about how bad things are in South Australia. I notice there are a couple of opposition members from South Australia in the chamber. It will be very interesting to hear what they have to say. I doubt whether their comments will be much different from what we have already heard. This is a national parliament. I thought the attack today was going to be on the national government. Of course, there was not a word about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Provincial thinking.

—Provincial thinking and opposition thinking. Of course, until today there was not a question from the opposition about the economy. One of the gauges as to how well the economy is doing is how many questions are asked in this House by those opposite about the economy. The one question asked today by the honourable member for Mayo about the economy was the first question we have heard for at least three weeks. When there are no questions asked about the economy, we know it is doing pretty well. It is not a bad barometer.

PARA.TAB: This is not about the federal government; it is nothing to do with the federal government. Our record stands unchallenged by the honourable member for Mayo who spoke for 15 minutes here today and said absolutely nothing about the federal government. It is all about good old South Australia. It will be interesting to hear what the second speaker has to say because not much more juice can be squeezed out of that lemon; the honourable member for Mayo has been over it already. It will be very interesting to turn on the television up in my room and see what the second speaker has to say.

Let us go back to just after the budget when the honourable member for Mayo had to get on TV. We all remember how he floundered on television when there were a couple of questions about the fact that he wanted to see a lower budget deficit. He agreed with the government about a lower budget deficit but he opposed the means to achieve it. When he was asked on national TV, `Well, how are you going to achieve it?' we got the inevitable answer, `Well we're going to cut government spending'. The question that automatically flows from that—`If you're going to cut government spending, where are you going to cut it from?'—was met with a stony silence.

I have read out the sorts of savings that we are talking about in reducing the prospective budget deficit from $14.9 billion to $6 1/2 billion. If the opposition is going to make those sorts of savings by cutting government spending—remembering that government spending as a percentage of GDP has been cut by the government back to the 1950s levels—it would be very interesting to get a list from the honourable member for Mayo of the sorts of spending cuts that he would introduce to come within cooee of getting where our budget reduction strategy would be in 1996-97.

It is this government that has brought together for the first time a coordinated effort by the federal government and state governments in having a national fiscal outlook. The national fiscal outlook seeks to coordinate the budgets of all the states and the federal government to achieve a common goal, and that goal has been achieved by this government. That will stand as one of our proudest achievements because that will go on into the future.

Another very important area is national savings. It was this government that set up the inquiry under Vince FitzGerald to have a look at national savings and report to the government. The report made the key point that movements in public sector saving are an important determination of national savings. The government accepts that proposition and has done something about it. The FitzGerald report also highlighted the need for coordinated efforts among the states and the Commonwealth in identifying the scope for efficiency savings through pursuing budget quality—through a coordinated benchmarking by program area.

Once again, it is the national government working with state governments to try to improve the budgetary situation for all governments in this country with a common objective. That common objective is to make sure that we improve national savings and that we do not put too much of a call on public savings when the recovery gathers pace into 1996-97. The government's budget strategy does that by giving the economy a $16 billion stimulus this year to aid recovery and make sure that recovery keeps going and accelerates through the year to a prospective three per cent annualised in the second half of the year. We believe that in the out years the economy will be expanding.

The budget deficit is being run this year for a very good reason, but by 1996-97 we will reduce the call on public savings by the federal government because by then the recovery will have gathered pace and there will be a need not only to repair national savings, but a need then for the private sector, as it expands, to have access to these funds.

Let me just go through the speech by the honourable member for Mayo on the matter of public importance. His references to untruths, gilding the lily and all those things are fairly hollow, given his personal performance and that of some of his colleagues. In this matter of public importance today he raised a national issue and did not lay a glove on it. He did not speak about it. He spent the first five minutes of his address to this House talking about the MPIs from yesterday and the day before—and who was speaking on them.

When we hear that sort of rambling at the start of a matter of public importance we understand that there is not much behind it. We listened to the honourable member for Mayo—I kept listening and had my pen out, ready to write down what he would say about what the federal government has done—but he did not lay a glove on us; he did not talk about the federal government. It was all about South Australia. That is the opposition mentality.

Because the honourable member for Mayo did not address the subject of his matter of public importance, and given the point I made today—that it was not only the government's view but that of Standard and Poors—it can be seen that there is nothing behind this matter of public importance. The government's budget strategy is the right one for Australia. It has been endorsed and passed, and it will do the job.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall The Hon R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a sandbank in a heavy tide erodes, so the government in South Australia has declined since the announcement of the failure of the State Bank. That decline has seen a number of important departures—an exodus—from a number of vocations in South Australia. For instance, former Premier Mr Bannon will study at Flinders University next year. It may be that he should have undertaken that study before he took on the stewardship of South Australia as premier. The Managing Director of the State Bank has departed South Australia for other states—and was barred from returning for the recent Australian Grand Prix.

PARA.TAB: These events have had a great effect on South Australia and the national budget because the federal government, in a desperate attempt to shore up the declining Arnold administration, has made available $600 million to in some way bolster the enormous public debt. The question now arises about the stewardship of the present Premier, Mr Arnold. How much did he know at the time—we know he was forewarned—and what has he done since? What is the quality of his current administration? Is he separate, as he claims, from what went on in the past and from the standard of failure of his predecessor?

Let us look at his management and see what he has done in relation to a number of people involved in this exodus from positions in the South Australia government. Mr Guerin, during the days of the failure of the State Bank, was Mr Bannon's chief executive officer. After the bank collapsed it was decided to place him at the head of the MFP. He held that position for a sufficient time for it to be stated about the incoming director of the MFP:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Ross Kennan admitted yesterday he was "absolutely dismayed" by what he found when he took up his $300,000-a-year appointment as chief
executive officer . . . Breaking his self-imposed three-month media silence after sizing up this task, Mr Kennan described some earlier MFP-inspired proposals as "in a word, desperate".

PARA.TAB: "There was so much ethereal thinking . . . God, bloody poppycock", he said.

SPEECH.PARA: That was a result of Mr Geurin's administration. What did Mr Arnold do with Mr Geurin then? He agreed to part-finance a new Centre for Public Policy and Management at Flinders University—and he put Mr Geurin in charge of it. What do honourable members think about this? This man oversaw the failure of the State Bank while in the premier's office, went to the MFP to give it guidance—and his successor said he had never seen so much bloody poppycock—then was choofed off by Mr Arnold to teach South Australians to manage and develop public policy. This was Mr Arnold in his new responsibility.

PARA.TAB: What is being done generally by the Labor Party? A few weeks ago I brought up in this House the question of the appointment of Dr Bob Catley—the failed member for Adelaide, who was defeated at the last election—as adjunct senior lecturer at the Faculty of Arts and Humanities at the University of South Australia, a new faculty to be part established by funds, as I understand it, directed by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans). That too has an impact on the federal budget. That appointment was recommended in the document I have in my hand. It prompted me to raise a question in this House, because the job had not been advertised before the recommendation of Dr Catley's appointment. I raised that question on a date early—

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this month.

—No. It was early last month. Subsequent to my raising the question here, an advertisement was put in the paper. This is the management of Labor in South Australia. There was a recommendation to appoint him officially in the records of the meetings, but when the appointment was protested his job was advertised. Where does it stand? This is the demonstrated quality of management in South Australia, followed with these sorts of appointments, desperately and quickly made, before the government is defeated a fortnight hence. Another example states:

PARA.TAB: A former Labor MP will be appointed head of the Environment, Resources and Development Court, State Parliament has been told.
State Cabinet has approved the appointment of former Newland MP, Ms Dianne Gayler, as Commissioner of the Court—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I draw your attention to the terms of the MPI before the House. I really think that this has very little, or nothing indeed, to do with the terms of the MPI.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —Order! There is some degree of relevance in what the minister is saying because the member is swaying somewhat from the MPI. I think he should bear in mind what the contents of the MPI are during this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —This MPI refers to the fiscal responsibility of the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth has put $600 million in to prop up the Arnold government. I submit the connection is direct. Let me finish my quote about the expenditure of state money:

PARA.TAB: Ms Gayler was an MP between 1985 and 1989. She has held the position of policy director of the Environment Protection Authority for about six months.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the quality of administration of the Arnold government. The Premier lost count of his debt, as the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) illustrated. He forgot that he had $577 million more in debt. He prevaricated and was made to more or less apologise for his defect. There is a strong leak from the Labor Party in South Australia that the government is awaiting the announcement of the policy of the state Leader of the Opposition in South Australia. It will present it then to officials of the federal Treasury to examine to help the Arnold government put a political slant on its reply—because that government is incapable of examining its own accounts, let alone the policy of its opponents.

PARA.TAB: If that is to occur, if federal money is to be spent on paying federal officials to examine the political policies of an opponent to the Arnold government, it will be a disgrace. I want an undertaking from the honourable member who will follow me that that will not be the case. I want a public repudiation of the report that the state government will use federal officials in the pursuit of its political objectives in the state election it will lose.

We know that South Australia is desperately looking for a change. I noticed in the premier's announcement of his policy yesterday that he has promised all South Australian residents a lifetime driving licence. I wonder how they will use it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I ask what on earth the issue of lifetime driving licences in South Australia has to do with the matter of public importance, which states:

PARA.TAB: The damage done to the national fiscal outlook by the Treasurer's failure to ensure structural budget repair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the minister's point of order. The honourable member for Boothby should bear in mind that he should at least—if he is speaking about things in South Australia—relate them back to how they affect the issue before the House under this matter of public importance.
—I have not had a chance to finish my remarks.

—Order! The honourable member will not argue with me. He will resume his seat. I am telling him that he needs to bear in mind a linkage between this matter of public of importance and the matters he is talking about here. Please continue.

—Thank you for the opportunity, Mr Deputy Speaker. You have already taken 30 seconds of my remaining time. I am telling you that the conditions of commercial and business activity are so bad in South Australia that of course there is an enormous impact on my state and the federal coffers. This is because of the lack of funds and return on taxation from a state that has been so decimated by a state Labor government. I was about to say that of course South Australians will need their driving licence as they leave South Australia. (Time expired)

—As the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs (Mr Bilney)—who is at the table—has quite correctly pointed out, it is a disgrace to this federal House of parliament to raise provincial issues about a state government just before a state election. Let us take a little quote from a wise person of the past. Cicero said that orators are the most vehement when they have the weakest cause, as men get on horseback when they cannot walk.

PARA.TAB: It could be true that the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) and the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) are nothing more than filibustering marauders. We have in Port Adelaide a black and white flag—a very proud black and white flag. Fortunately, it is not the skull and crossbones of those on the other side.

This is an incredible motion put up by a party which has no policy on how to raise any revenue whatsoever. Not one policy does the opposition have on how to raise revenue other than what it has proposed to admit to. Those opposite are still committed to the GST—the 15 per cent tax on all goods and services. How can opposition members talk about tax and budgets when they have a $22 billion hole in their future programs.Let us have a look at what they have said in recent times.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Following on from the points of order of the minister at the table, I take the opportunity to do as he did and that is to remind you of the subject of the matter of public importance. I point out to you that the content of the speech by the current speaker bears no relevance to the subject of the matter of public importance. I ask you to suggest, as you did to the honourable member for Boothby, that the honourable gentleman return to the subject of the matter of public importance.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott) —I think the honourable member for Port Adelaide was actually talking about revenue collection as taxation measures, and that is what this particular matter of public importance is about. So I think it is relevant. I am sure the honourable member for Port Adelaide is well aware of the need to stay relevant to the matter of public importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us take the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mayo. He makes the point that he accepts the fact that the level of taxation in this country is far too high. In fact, he says the tax levels in Australia are over twice as high as eastern Asia. As the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) has pointed out in this House, if we want Asian levels of spending we would have to cut revenue by between $10 billion and $20 billion per year. Where will opposition members cut those taxes? What spending cuts are they contemplating? Will it be: age pensions, family income supplement, family allowance, tax cuts, or education?

PARA.TAB: Those opposite want to get provincial. The honourable member for Boothby and the honourable member for Mayo have a very clear policy. They are going to announce a policy to the South Australian electorate, to the people, six days from the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The comments that you made to the honourable member for Boothby related to a point of order made by the minister at the table which was based on the fact that the speech made by the honourable member for Boothby was not relevant to the subject matter of the matter of public importance.
—Order! I think the honourable member is making somewhat of a speech. What is the point of order?

—Part of the basis of the point of order made by the minister at the table was that the subject of the speech made by the honourable member for Boothby was of a regional nature whereas the matter of public importance is not. I now note that the—
—The honourable member for Hume should get to his point of order because it is quite clear what he is doing.

—My point of order is that the honourable member now speaking is going to a subject matter which does not relate, under his own claims that he made earlier, to the matter of public importance. I ask you to live up to the claims he made a few minutes ago that this debate not be of a regional nature.
—Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. The honourable member for Port Adelaide can continue.

—This is nowhere more apparent than in the reply of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) to the budget. He committed the opposition there to vote against tax measures that were not only part of the budget but are integral to the government's deficit reduction strategy. By opposing the increase over two years of the petroleum excise and the change to wholesale sales tax rates—except of course on luxury cars—and removing the existing concessions for those able to accumulate long service leave and annual leave, the Leader of the Opposition would increase the deficit in 1993-94 by almost $1,400 million and by over $3 billion in 1996-97. In other words, the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow Treasurer would increase the deficit in each of the next four years and leave the deficit in 1996-97 over 50 per cent higher than the government proposes. Perhaps the honourable member for Mayo, the shadow Treasurer, could explain how that will result in lower interest rates.
—Why don't you blokes defend Mr Arnold?

—The honourable member for O'Connor goes through the roof in this House. There has to be something in the attic to do that. For goodness sake, the honourable member should keep quiet. Maybe the honourable member for Mayo might like to identify the spending cuts and the tax increases he proposes should be introduced to fill the deficit hole that the economic vandalism of the Leader of the Opposition will create.

PARA.TAB: The strategy of this year's budget has been based on the enhancement of growth in the short-term through a mild fiscal stimulus this year and a progressive tightening of fiscal policy in the ensuing years. There is a medium-term strategy of deficit reduction and it is crucial to our prospects of sustained economic growth. Without it, the deficit would continue at high levels, thus ensuring a higher level of government demand for domestic savings and damaging the balance of payments outcome as we continue to finance our activities with other nations' savings. It would also generate increased interest rates, so providing a growing disincentive to economic growth. In a nutshell, that is the opposition's policy.

The government's deficit target of around one per cent of GDP by 1996-97 requires discretionary measures to raise $9 billion by that year. However, in the aftermath of the budget the government made a number of amendments which will reduce the amount of $9 billion by some $360,000 million in 1996-97, thus leaving us with a deficit of 1.2 per cent of GDP compared with 1.1 per cent originally contained in the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they opposed it.

—And they opposed it. In the current year the amendments have cost the budget $68 million, which does not change the deficit from 3.8 per cent of GDP. All this makes the actions of the opposition in parliament quite scurrilous. Those opposite have abandoned all pretence of fiscal rationality by opposing the raising of $3 billion in tax and opposing a large number of expenditure cuts while simultaneously—listen to this one—attacking the government on the ground that the deficit is too high. Opposition members are behaving like petulant brats who are determined to spoil the party for everybody else because someone else won the first prize.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. The honourable member's suggestion that people on this side of the House are `rats'—

—I did not say `rats', but I will withdraw the remark. The point is that those opposite cannot be forgiven—we will not forgive them and the people of Australia will not forgive them—for their reckless disregard for the welfare of this nation. Despite the opposition's unsuccessful efforts, the budget has put Australia on a prudent path to a lower structural budget deficit and higher national savings. Over four years, this budget will cut the structural budget deficit by $9 billion. Surely, that is what this matter of public importance is about, not some provincial argument about a state election in a couple of weeks time.

PARA.TAB: The filibustering and the provincial attitude that the honourable member for Boothby and the honourable member for Mayo demonstrated in the MPI lessen the importance of such matters and show how not to deal with them. The opposition takes a populist approach by opposing all revenue issues. The clear senselessness of its approach was there for all to see when the honourable member for Mayo fronted up on the 7.30 Report. While he wanted to lower the budget deficit and did not want any tax increases, he was completely incapable of explaining where the expenditure cuts were to come from. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the fifth report from the Publications Committee sitting in conference with the Publications Committee of the Senate. Copies of the report are being circulated to honourable members in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Report—by leave—adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the following report: report 327—Finance minute on report 325.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Report 327 contains the Finance minute—or formal response—on report 325, The Midford Paramount case and related matters, together with committee comment on the Finance minute and, in particular, comments made by the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, DPP, in an appendix to the Finance minute.

PARA.TAB: The inquiry into the Midford Paramount case and related matters investigated the failed prosecution of a Wollongong based shirt manufacturer, Midford Paramount, and revealed significant failings in Commonwealth administration. This of necessity resulted in a report to the parliament which was critical of both the Australian Customs Service and, to a lesser extent, the DPP. While the committee may have anticipated that these agencies would not agree with all of its recommendations, it did not at any time foresee the gratuitous comments that would be offered by the DPP in the Finance minute.

The DPP's comments, if read in isolation, would present a reader with a false view of the committee's inquiry and report 325. Therefore, to ensure that the parliament and other interested parties are presented with a balanced view, the committee has prepared this report.

The DPP's criticisms appear to be based on selective quoting and a failure to read the entire report, contain simple errors of comprehension, and demonstrate a lack of understanding of basic fundamentals such as public accountability, the role and functions of parliamentary committees and the presumption of innocence. The committee is disappointed at the comments made by the DPP for they indicate that the director has learnt little from the Midford case or the committee's inquiry. Given the breadth of the committee's inquiry, it is significant that the DPP chose to make no comment on the vast majority of the report even though he did not confine himself to findings relating to the DPP.
Needless to say, the committee is firmly of the view that report 325 stands on its own merits as a thorough and balanced document. I commend this report to the House.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Delegations to the Republic of Colombia and to the 30th Commonwealth Parliamentary Conference

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Republic of Colombia, September 1992, and the report of the Commonwealth of Australia branch delegation to the 38th Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference, held in Nassau, the Bahamas, in October 1992. I also seek leave to make a short statement in connection with the reports.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table these reports of the Australian parliamentary delegation which visited Colombia from 26 September to 3 October 1992 and attended the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference held in the Bahamas from 4 to 10 October 1992. The delegation comprised Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa, President of the Senate as leader of the delegation; Mr Wilson Tuckey, MP, deputy leader; Senator Bruce Childs; Senator Gerry Jones; and, for the CPA conference, Senator Shirley Walters. Mr Kieran Schneemann, delegation secretary; Mr Fred Peppinck, senior adviser to the President; Mrs Jenny Tuckey; Mrs Judy Childs; Mrs Rita Jones; and Dr David Walters comprised the rest of the party.

PARA.TAB: The visit to Colombia was the first by an official Australian parliamentary delegation and reciprocated the 1989 visit to Australia by a parliamentary delegation from Colombia. The delegation visited Bogota and the old Spanish fortress city of Cartegena. Unfortunately, a visit to Cali to look at agricultural research had to be cancelled at the last moment. The delegation met with the President of Colombia, Dr Cesar Gaviria Trujillo. In fact, I have to say that I was amazed at the informality when he first came into the room. I think we were wondering whether or not the President had arrived, he was so informal and relaxed. But that added greatly to the discussions we had which were very informal, but otherwise very productive.

That meeting was in addition to meetings with a number of ministers, and in all meetings there was free-ranging and frank discourse on economic growth, foreign investment, drugs and security, and Colombia's increasing Pacific focus. In most meetings we were able to refer to, and provide copies of, the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on Australia and Latin America and indicate that Australian public and private enterprises were awakening to the potential for expanded trade and joint venture operations with Latin America.

Opportunities for exports from Australia that were apparent to me have been drawn to the attention of people within my electorate and my state. I am hoping that they are progressing. There were some quite surprising opportunities in terms of what Australia might provide and what Australia might learn, particularly in the area of produce of the sea and of course aquiculture.

The Colombians expressed disappointment that we had not yet established an embassy in Bogota, but the delegation records its appreciation of the excellent job which was being done by the Honorary Consul for Australia, Dr Dario Cardenas Navas.

The delegation was surprised by the relative strength and increasing sophistication of the Colombian economy. While Australia and Colombia have cooperated closely as members of the Cairns Group, it is also clear that Colombia can become a formidable competitor in both the agricultural and mining sectors. We were also extremely interested to meet people who have been to Australia and picked up our technology in the solar area.

I think most of us have visions of places like Colombia as lush tropical jungles. But, quite surprisingly, we were told by a gentleman we met who is actively involved in this area that there are in fact very large areas which he called the `Australia of Colombia'. These areas are quite arid and offer subsistence living to the people who live there. Technology of the type available in Australia in the solar area—even simple windmills—is being used to lift the living standards of those people. We had discussions with this gentleman and others who had been to Australia and recognised Australia as a leader in that area.

We would like to thank our hosts in the Colombian parliament—the then President and Speaker—for the warmth and generosity of their welcome. I would like to thank Ambassador and Mrs De Stoop who accompanied the delegation, and also Ms Maggie Pinsent for the excellent translation work done for the delegation. I would also like to record my personal thanks to our principal guide from the Senate's public relations department, a young lady whom we all got to know by her Christian name, Ampoora. I cannot add from memory her rather lengthy surname.

The delegation also attended the 38th Commonwealth Parliamentary Association conference in the Bahamas. Prior to the conference, the Bahamas had been subject to two major upheavals. In August the Bahamas had its first change in government for 25 years, and four days after the elections Hurricane Andrew badly devastated a number of the Bahamas islands. In recognition of the need for costly reconstruction programs by the Bahamas authorities, the CPA executive committee proposed the cancellation of the traditional conference tours, which had been focused on the quincentennial of the arrival of Columbus in the New World. The funds were redirected to assistance to people who had been disadvantaged or had suffered injury or loss of property in the hurricane.

The conference heralded a different format from that presented in previous years, with greater emphasis on panel discussions within a single conference theme. This was one of the major recommendations of the report of the working party on the CPA and the future, which had been chaired by Senator Kerry Sibraa since its inception at the New Delhi conference in 1991. Senator Sibraa presented the report of the working party to the General Assembly and it was accepted in its entirety. The chairman of the executive committee expressed the association's thanks for the work done by Senator Sibraa and his colleagues.

The draft constitution, which had also formed part of the working party's report, was presented to the General Assembly. But the proposal was lost when it did not receive the required two-thirds majority of the votes cast, although it did receive over 50 per cent support. I do not think that particular proposal is lost. The simple fact was—and Australians participated in this process—that there were some concerns about the potential effect of the constitution expressed by nations from different parts of the world. I am sure it will come back to the next conference in a slightly amended form.

The conference also saw the appointment of Mr Arthur Donahoe as Secretary-General to succeed Dr David Tonkin. Senator Sibraa also retired as a member of the Executive Committee (Australian Region) and was replaced by Mr George Gear.

Again, the Commonwealth Secretary-General, Chief Emeka Anyaoku, addressed the conference on developments in the Commonwealth, making particular reference to Commonwealth efforts in South Africa and the increasing focus on election monitoring. Chief Anyaoku also attended the now traditional Australia-New Zealand function in honour of the host branch.

The delegation would like to express its thanks to the Australian High Commissioner to Jamaica and the Caribbean, Mr Peter Rodgers, and Mrs Rodgers as well as the fine support work done by Ms Virginia Brueckner. I also thank officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Parliamentary Library and the Parliamentary Relations Office for helping with the delegation's program. I thank Kieran Schneemann and Fred Peppinck, the workhorses of the delegation, who looked after so many of the more administrative details. As officers of this parliament, as usual, they did a wonderful job.

There are considerable opportunities for closer exchanges with Colombia on education, social policy and federalism. Our parliamentary ties are both close and warm and the bestowal of the Extraordinary Order of the Grand Cross—in gold—by the Colombian Congress on Senator Sibraa was a reflection of the high esteem in which the Colombian parliament holds the Australian parliament. I have left this particular paragraph until last because that bestowal was certainly the highlight of the visit. Australia can be very proud of the serious manner in which the Colombian Senate attended the presentation of this order.

The Senate was full—all members were present—and a choir from the military academy rendered both the Australian and the Colombian national anthems. In fact, the singers had a better knowledge than I of the two verses of the Australian national anthem. It was sung with great ability. The delegation was very proud to be present because this presentation was a very true recognition of Australia.

The delegation was also very pleased to hear how concerned and interested Colombia is in maintaining its embassy in Australia and is also concerned that some day Australia reciprocate. Colombia is very interested in Australia and recognised the delegation in the highest possible fashion through the presentation to Senator Sibraa. I was very proud to have been present. I commend these two reports to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pity that the change in Australian society is such that, if one dares to disagree with some of the politically correct thoughts, one is branded a racist. If one says something out of the mainstream about Aboriginal affairs, multiculturalism or Asian migration, open debate is inhibited and one is immediately attacked for not agreeing.

PARA.TAB: I make passing reference to the fact that a couple of weeks ago I asked a question of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) about Aboriginality in this legislation, the Native Title Bill. The question was not answered and, quite frankly, I was subjected to 10 or 12 minutes of abuse.

I totally reject any allegation that I am racist; but I do believe that we should have one law for all Australians. I believe in equality for all Australians before the law. I am totally opposed to any form of prejudice or apartheid. I believe equally strongly that, as a caring and compassionate society, we must look after the needy and those suffering disadvantage in our society—a situation in which Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders find themselves. They are disadvantaged in housing, health, education and employment; their life expectancy is lower and they are disadvantaged in infant mortality, disease and infection. But I do believe that, in the interests of equality, all Australians should be looked after on the basis of need, not race, skin colour or creed. Unfortunately, Australian society is going down the wrong track of institutionalising discrimination.

Democracy in this country is alive and well. We are very fortunate to be among the few countries where democracy is practised. The vast majority of the 174 member countries of the United Nations do not exercise democracy at the same level that we do.

I say quite definitely and specifically that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are, in many ways, in dire need. I refer briefly to the disgracefully high level of diabetes among Torres Strait Islanders. Equally, it is a great shame and a disgrace that, three years after ATSIC was created, the Torres Strait Islander health policy has not yet been created, let alone implemented.

Also, help is desperately needed for the small children in the Macleay Valley in my electorate. Something like 94 per cent of Aboriginal children between the ages of three and six years have been identified as having the disease otitis media—glue ear—which means they have hearing difficulties. This means that the six-year-old kid starting school is about three years behind in socialisation and language development. When these kids start school they cannot hear, so they cannot understand what is being said and they cannot learn. Therefore, one has a continuation of the stereotype that Aboriginal people are dumb, stupid and cannot learn. That is not the case. This situation is artificially created by a medical condition which we tend to ignore. So we have to go much further.

Life expectations of Aboriginal men and women are much less than other Australians. Aboriginal men and women have a life expectancy of 20, 25 to 30 years shorter than other Australians. It saddens me desperately when I stop and reflect that most Aboriginal males born the same year as I are already dead and gone. It is a sad reflection on our society.

I have had the opportunity of speaking with a great many Aboriginal people and organisations in Queensland, the Torres Strait, New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, Tasmania and the Northern Territory. Time and time again one is told by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that they do not believe that we will cure their problems just by throwing money at them and, quite frankly, I agree. We have to go beyond just throwing money at the problems in the hope that they will go away.

I do not know the accurate figure, but we already spend $2 billion on Aboriginal affairs—$1.3 billion from the Commonwealth, the rest from the states. That is $2 billion in entitlements of Aboriginal people over and above that of other Australians to health, education, unemployment benefits, pensions or so on.

I firmly believe that the road to success for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people is education. We need to have an incredible emphasis on education, and I do not mean just teaching kids the three Rs. I have been to Lockhart River in North Queensland, to Thursday Island, Badu, Yorke and Darnley, and quite a number of other Aboriginal areas around Australia. It needs to be education in the wider things; in health, for instance—not just in ordinary, perceived academic education. It has to go much further than that. The present legislation really presents a situation where we all need education. It is not clear. I believe it will create more problems than it will cure.

The present legislation is not understood by the vast majority of Australians, either of Aboriginal or European origin. It is being rushed through this House. It was introduced on 16 November—only last week—with three days debate this week, and it will be put through this House and carried, of course, on the numbers tonight. I do not believe that this is enough time for the people of Australia to consider what is in the bill.

Certainly there has been nowhere near enough consultation with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. I understand that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) talks to five people as his advisers. They seem to be—and I do not say this in a pejorative sense—professionals from the Aboriginal industry, and I do not know how many of them are on the public payroll. But Aboriginal people all around Australia are complaining about the lack of consultation. I refer to that three-day meeting at Eva Valley with 300 Aboriginal leaders from around Australia: they have not even been consulted, as far as I understand it.

I ask: why the rush? If we accept that there have been 200 years of injustice, it is up to us to get it right. After 200 years I do not think we can possibly attempt to believe that we can solve this in that amount of time. As a parliament we have to act with responsibility, and rushing the legislation through is irresponsible.

We have to get it right this time; we really do. Getting it right means no relaxation of the Racial Discrimination Act, except as needed to validate past grants. Getting it right means that compensation should be paid on a non-discriminatory basis, and that is certainly on just terms with the amount determined by a court if there is any dispute. Getting it right means acceptance that native title exists, and this is central to the coalition policy.

Getting it right means that governments will be responsible for compensation payments for extinguishment of native title—not individual Australians, not land-holders. Getting it right means that settlements can include, in addition to or as a substitute for cash, substitute land title or interest in other land, or the provision of services and facilities and any other benefit agreed with the claimant. Settlements need to be flexible to meet the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Getting it right means provision for all governments—state, federal and territory—to legislate to validate past land titles and prevent invalidation of existing titles. Getting it right means acknowledging that states and territories have the right to set their own deadlines for lodging compensation claims. Getting it right means that government funded assistance should be available on an equal basis, not only for native title claimants and compensation claimants but also for the respondents. Natural justice certainly demands that.

Getting it right means having the Commonwealth reimburse the states and territories for compensation payments made for extinguishing native title associated with validating past grants. Getting it right means that Commonwealth legislation should be put through to enable the states and territories to confirm the Crown's ownership of mineral and petroleum deposits.

Getting it right means protecting the existing rights of public access and enjoyment of public places, foreshores, beaches, national parks, recreation reserves and stock routes for all Australians. Getting it right means providing equally for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander aspirations, national development, jobs, economic use of land and further development of Australia's mineral, pastoral and other industries. Getting it right means fairness, justice and equality for all Australians.

I must say that in my opinion present day Australians should feel no guilt. I personally reject the guilt industry. The government of the day and individuals over the past 200 years have done dreadful and horrible things. There is no excuse for that. The standards of behaviour in Australia at those times were no different to the standards of behaviour elsewhere in the world. That is not an excuse. The fact should be that none of us, white Australians or Aboriginal Australians, should feel any guilt for the past. The sins of the fathers should not be visited on the children. In terms of feeling no guilt, I have shot no-one. My Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander friends have never speared anyone. None of us should feel any guilt.

Essentially, we cannot live in the past; we have to go forward and we have to go forward together, not in antagonism. We have to go forward together in harmony and, dare I say it, with a degree of love for one another. This is the way we have to go.

There are moves among some Aboriginal organisations—among some active people—that there should be a separate nation state. I do not believe that that is in the interests of Australia. It is totally remote from reality, and I for one reject it. At the same time I must say that I have no particular doubt at all about the justification for providing some form of government for the Torres Strait which may be similar to Norfolk Island. I have no quibble or quarrel whatsoever with that.

Many Australians, both Aboriginal and white, have been misled by the rhetoric of the Prime Minister. Of course, his rhetoric is crafted by his own desires and his own ambitions. He wants to see himself as the great statesman, the great legislator, the great bringer of justice to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and the father of the republic. In reality, he is only the great destroyer.

I believe in Australia, and I take great pride in our country, in our nation and in areas of activity such as the parliaments. I take pride in what our forefathers did in putting this nation together. I think our system of federation is spot-on. It has worked very well for nearly 100 years, since 1901—and our federal system is effective, and it works. Brand me as a states `righter', but I am opposed to centralising more power in Canberra. I believe that power should be decentralised. I am opposed to the creation of the new, complex system of bureaucracy which will be created to deal with administrative and legal problems.

Some Aboriginal people will be left out in limbo. I realise that I must finish very shortly to enable my colleagues on both sides of the House to have adequate time. But it should be pointed out that where there is an Aboriginal community, and a minority of people living there are from that area and, because of injustices in the past, other people have been moved in, those people who have been moved in cannot claim native title where they are living now because they do not have that long-term association. They cannot claim native title where they came from because they have been moved from there, so they are in limbo. I believe that this legislation does not address that particular point.

The final point I want to make is that there has been very limited mention of the land compensation fund. I believe that Australians everywhere have the right to know what is going to happen. We have been told that in February there will be a social justice bill. Who knows what will come out of that? Australians have the right to know. It has been suggested already by the responsible minister that compensation could take hundreds of millions of dollars. I do not want to be a scaremonger, but I have heard rumours and reports that it could be not hundreds of millions but many, many billions of dollars over the next 10 to 20 years. The matter of compensation has to be dealt with and made public. When we are considering this legislation, the overriding care of all of us should be that we get fairness, justice and equality for all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on the Native Title Bill. The calibre of the debate surrounding this bill is a reflection of the importance and magnitude of what the bill represents for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and for the peoples of Australia in this, the International Year for the World's Indigenous People.
