PARA.TAB: The Native Title Bill recognises that native title existed and the traditional terra nullius doctrine was, indeed, invalid. It is regrettable that what our forebears did not understand they pushed aside, refusing to acknowledge the intrinsic relationship between the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and their traditional lands. Their relationship with the land was not the traditional European concept of land ownership. It was not the way of Aboriginal people to sell their land for a fast dollar, nor was it their way to sell off valuable productive agricultural land for housing development because it was worth more.

To the Aboriginal people the land was part of them and played a vital role in their way of life, their society and their culture. The Aboriginal people do not take their land for granted as modern society does today. The land played the role of guardian to our early inhabitants, providing them with food and shelter. It looked after them and they looked after it for thousands of years. Their land usage practices may be described today as sustainable agriculture or environmentally friendly practices. Within clan areas, most, but not all, were nomadic, taking advantage of particular areas depending on climatic cycles and thus the productivity of nature. That was until white settlement 200 years ago.

I do not intend to give members a history lesson but merely wish to emphasise the special relationship the Aboriginal people had with their traditional areas. My electorate of Richmond, now one of the fastest population growing electorates in New South Wales, once sustained coastal Aborigines, who lived on plentiful fish supplies and bush foods. It is difficult to envisage this now travelling through the bustling towns of Ballina, Byron Bay, Murwillumbah or Tweed Heads. Time, together with what could be described only as barbaric and inhumane actions by Australia's early settlers, changed this relationship forever. The establishment of settlements and missions, combined with rapid early development on the eastern seaboard, ended the lifestyle of the Aboriginal people. They were moved off good lands to make way for farms and highways and were relegated to remote areas, areas that they were unable to live off, hence the beginning of dependence on white society.

It was not their choice; it was a decision forced upon them. It physically changed the relationship the Aboriginal people had with their traditional lands but did not sever the emotional, spiritual or cultural links that had been forged by over 40,000 years. This dispossession has never been recognised by legislation at either a state or federal level. Many of the social, cultural and physical problems currently facing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community have been attributed to this dispossession.

The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) commented that the solution, as he saw it, was not to throw money at problems and that we have to move beyond that. This Native Title Bill does just that, so I cannot understand why he does not support it. The Native Title Bill recognises native title, defining it as:

SPEECH.PARA: The rights and interests that are possessed under the traditional laws and customs of Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders in land and waters.

If honourable members think for a moment about that definition, they will realise that it really is a significant statement. It is the first time the intrinsic relationship between Aboriginal people and their traditional land has been recognised in legislation. That recognition is extremely important not simply to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, but to all Australians.

PARA.TAB: This public and legislative recognition of native title and its importance will go a long way towards rectifying many preconceptions that exist in our community regarding Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. We as a government must ensure the Native Title Bill is properly understood by the community at large. The record has to be set straight in no uncertain terms.

Unfortunately, the high profile fear campaign assisted by the media culture has gullibly been swallowed by many in the community as being discriminatory against our non-Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander population. On Tuesday the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) stated that there was only one criterion that was relevant in determining whether the legislation deserved to be supported. That was, simply: is it in the interest of all Australians, indigenous or non-indigenous? The answer is unequivocally yes.

The recognition of the rights and interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in land and waters under their traditional laws and customs is in the national interest. A prolonged failure to recognise this inherent right would only perpetuate the bigotry and divisiveness that exist in our society.

The Leader of the Opposition says he will vote against the Native Title Bill because it is bad legislation and creates enormous complexity, delay, uncertainty and division in Australian society. The division in this country is being perpetuated by such statements. The Leader of the Opposition said it is bad because `it assumes a mistaken view of the root cause of Aboriginal and Islander disadvantage'. If dispossession of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community is not the root cause of their disadvantage, then what is?

The Leader of the Opposition then had the gall to say it was bad because it constrains future opportunities for national development. The Native Title Bill is not, as the opposition would have us believe, a `land grab' or a `free-for-all'. It is simply a recognition under common law of the traditional rights and interests of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. It is not a vehicle that will open Australia up to farcical land claims, nor is it a bill that will end Australia's mining or agricultural operations. There are many examples of mining operations on traditional Aboriginal land where the local Aboriginal people and the mining company enjoy a very harmonious relationship.

The legislation is quite specific in its guidelines and how it will operate. It took guts to recognise the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in this legislation. It had, after all, previously been recognised only by lip-service and token gestures by successive state and federal governments.

The Native Title Bill will create a platform on which we will be able to build a unified Australia. It will come as no surprise to honourable members on this side of the House that it took a Labor government to address this issue. Labor governments over the years have set the social, economic and political agenda, making the tough decisions and facing the issues head on. Only a Labor government would have the vision to undertake such a commitment to do what is right. I refer the House to a quote from former Prime Minister Ben Chifley:

I try to think of the Labor movement, not as putting an extra sixpence into somebody's pocket, or making somebody Prime Minister or Premier, but as a movement bringing something better to the people, better standards of living, greater happiness to the masses of people.
We have a great objective—the light on the hill—which we aim to reach by working for the betterment of mankind not only here but anywhere we may give a helping hand.

SPEECH.PARA: Those words are as relevant today as they were in 1949. Nobody is suggesting that the problems facing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community will disappear by this legislation, nor is anybody saying that the entire Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community would like to return to its former lifestyle. The key word here that the opposition has overlooked is `perspective'. The recognition of native title will bring the rights of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community into perspective—a perspective that will allow governments, now and in the future, to begin to deal with the problems of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community more effectively than ever before.

PARA.TAB: The Native Title Bill will be remembered as a stepping block towards a successful reconciliation between black and white Australians and towards a truly unified Australia. It will be remembered as an achievement to the rights of indigenous people, not only in Australia but across the world. Australia is not the first nation to deal with the native title issue, and it will not be the last. Two of our nearest neighbours—New Zealand and Papua New Guinea—have also dealt with the issue.

This Native Title Bill, I believe, compares very favourably with the New Zealand situation. The bill is quite specific. It recognises native title and puts into place a mechanism that can establish the existence or non-existence of such title. Some 150 years after the signing of the Treaty of Waitangi, the issue of native title in New Zealand is still unclear. The Treaty of Waitangi was signed by a crown representative and over 500 Maori chiefs in 1840. There were two versions: one in English and one in Maori. Only 39 chiefs signed the treaty in English; the majority signed the treaty in the Maori language.

The treaty in English ceded to Britain the sovereignty of New Zealand and gave the Crown the exclusive right to pre-empt such lands the Maori people wanted to sell. In return, the Maori people were guaranteed full rights of ownership of their lands, forests, fisheries and other prized possessions. The treaty also promised them the rights and privileges of British subjects, together with assurances of crown protection.

It is clear the Maori text failed to convey the proper meaning of the English version and the treaty negotiations failed to clarify the difference. The Maori chiefs signed the Treaty of Waitangi, which they believed guaranteed them and their tribes the right of undisturbed possession of the land they owned in return for handing over supreme political power to the British Queen. As they understood it, the chiefs ceded the right of governance, not the power or sovereignty over the land.

The New Zealand government has established five principles by which it deals with issues arising from that treaty. The principles are consistent with the Treaty of Waitangi and with the observations made by the courts and the Waitangi Tribunal, which was set up in 1975 to deal with issues arising from the treaty. The problem lies in the original treaty. Unlike the Native Title Bill, the Treaty of Waitangi was not clear in what it meant for New Zealand's Maori people.

Papua New Guinea has also dealt with the issue, but under contrasting circumstances to that of Australia and New Zealand. Papua New Guinea achieved self-government in 1973 and independence in 1975, when it ceased to be an Australian external territory. Ninety-seven per cent of the total land area in Papua New Guinea is customary land, that is, land owned under traditional or customary title by nationals. Only 3 per cent of the land has been alienated from its traditional owners, the bulk of which is owned by the government. Only a fraction is owned by private leasehold.

Land owning groups in Papua New Guinea are typically clans or sub-clans which are defined by lineage, with the patterns of entitlements within groups varying to some extent in different areas. Basic ownership rights seem principally a function of effective possession and control, established formerly, and sometimes currently, by force, if necessary. Historically, effective possession and control of land passed back and forth among different groups involved in tribal warfare.

In Papua New Guinea, disputes over ownership of customary land are frequent and extremely difficult to resolve, as there are over 700 tribes in the country, which have few or no records of land ownership. No interests in customary land are presently registered, although two abortive attempts have been made to introduce a registration system in that country. The complexity of the customary ownership issue was never addressed adequately by the two land title acts in that country. According to section 81 of the Land Act 1962-73:

SPEECH.PARA: A native has no power to sell, lease or dispose of native land otherwise than to natives in accordance with native custom. A contract or agreement made by him to do so is void.

This is subject to section 16 of the Land Act, which permits the government to purchase or lease customary land if the native owners are willing to dispose of it otherwise than to natives in accordance with native title.

PARA.TAB: The Papua New Guinea government also has powers in relation to compulsory acquisition for prescribed public purposes and in accordance with prescribed procedures. Section 56 of the PNG constitution prohibits non-nationals from acquiring freehold interests. Government land is normally made available and allocated for development through 99-year leases in that country. Interests in vacant land are advertised, with all tenders reviewed by the Papua New Guinea Land Board, which makes a recommendation to the Minister for Lands. If the minister disagrees, the matter is referred to the National Council Executive. The complexities Papua New Guinea faces in relation to customary ownership and land tenure are far greater than exist in Australia over native title and current land tenure.

I raise both of these examples as a comparison with what Australia and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities will be achieving with the passage through both Houses of the native title legislation. The native title legislation makes the recognition and determination process of native title clear, with the formation of the Register of Native Title Claims, the National Native Title Register and the National Native Title Tribunal. These bodies, together with state bodies, will ensure that claims and determinations are dealt with fairly and equitably. There will also be avenues for compensation for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, as well as a land acquisition fund, which will form part of the Native Title Bill's social justice strategy.

The Native Title Bill will also give us an opportunity to put the past behind us and look to the future. It will finally acknowledge the intrinsic relationship the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community has with its traditional lands. With the passage of this bill, as some members of the opposition have agreed, we will be able to look forward to a unified Australia, to a better future for our indigenous people. For this reason, I commend this legislation to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The decision of the High Court of Australia in Mabo v. State of Queensland (No. 2) is undoubtedly a landmark. It raises for resolution many questions relating to the rights of the indigenous peoples of Australia and the relationship of indigenous peoples to other Australians. The decision presented a unique opportunity for achievement of greater unity among Australians.

PARA.TAB: The actual decision is more limited in scope than some of its supporters make out. The basic proposition for which the case is authority is this: where an identifiable group of indigenous people has had a traditional connection with particular land, and the group has maintained that connection from the time of European settlement, the native title held under the law and customs of the group, by reason of that connection, will be recognised at common law, unless the title has been extinguished. Although there are arguments about the reasons members of the High Court gave for reaching the decision, I believe the basic principle for which the case stands is correct.

The High Court has been subjected to criticism for engaging in judicial law-making in its decision. Many of the critics have demonstrated a lack of understanding of the functions of the High Court. Others have really been criticising the decision of the majority that this was a situation where the court was able to overturn a longstanding assumption in relation to the law rather than a situation where the court should leave the matter to the legislative process. For my part, I reject the criticisms. However, this is not the occasion for explaining my reasons.

In early May this year the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) appointed a task force from the shadow ministry to develop coalition responses to the High Court decision. I was pleased to be included. I relished the challenge of the undertaking and have participated in the endeavours of the task force with some enthusiasm.

The task force has sought to consult widely. It has met representatives of various interest groups, some on several occasions. The task force has also visited remote parts of Australia to consult indigenous communities. Among places visited were the Torres Strait islands, including the Island of Mer; Cape York; the Gulf of Carpentaria; and in Western Australia, the Kimberley and the Gascoyne. The communities were all most hospitable. Their understanding of Mabo and their aspirations in respect of it varied enormously.

The working out of a response to Mabo was never going to be easy. That has been recognised on all sides from the time the decision was handed down. It is understandable that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders would seek to maximise claims to native title under the judgment. It is understandable that the mining industry would seek to ensure that native title claims would not inhibit prospecting, exploration and mining. It is understandable that pastoralists would seek to minimise the impact of native title on pastoral leases. It is also understandable that people not directly affected would be expected to have a range of views in relation to native title, from total support to total opposition.

It was also evident from the outset that the resolution of Mabo would involve the Commonwealth, on the one hand, and the states and territories, on the other hand. The Commonwealth has legislative power and responsibility in relation to the affairs of indigenous people. Power arises under section 51(26) of the constitution which authorises the Commonwealth to make laws for the people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws.

The High Court has interpreted this power as encompassing more than mere power to control or protect people of a race if such a need arises and more than a power to control or protect people of a race in their dealings with others. The power enables the Commonwealth not just to protect the people of a race but necessarily extends to the making of laws to protect the cultural heritage of the race.

The Commonwealth also has power under the external affairs power, section 51(29), and a responsibility to fulfil Australia's obligations under the International Covenant on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination. This responsibility has resulted in the Racial Discrimination Act 1975. Under article 1(4) of the convention and section 8 of the act the Commonwealth, in effect, has power to take special measures in certain circumstances to ensure that the human rights and freedoms of people of a race are of the same nature as those of other people of other races.

As against this, responsibility for administration of land has historically been a responsibility of the state governments and more recently of territory governments. This historical position is reflected in the absence of direct legislative power in the Commonwealth on the subject. The states and territories have each developed their own land administration regimes. The administration of the waste lands of the Crown, as crown land used misleadingly to be described, was organised under the land acts of the colonies and since federation has been an important part of state legislation. The Torrens system of land title registration has replaced the common law system of title in the most developed areas of all states and territories and a related system of registration is used for the agricultural and pastoral areas not under the Torrens system. Each state and territory has developed its own regime for regulating mining. There are basic similarities between the systems, but there are significant differences between the different jurisdictions.

The provision of land for the use and benefit of Aborigines has had different histories in the different states and territories. Aborigines have been provided with extensive lands in Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland and the Northern Territory, but this has been done in different ways. In the Northern Territory and South Australia, it is under land rights legislation. In Queensland, it is under a system of deeds of grant in trust known as dogits. In Western Australia, it has been through setting aside land for Aboriginal use by way of reserves or under trust. In New South Wales, there is a fund for the acquisition of land for Aborigines but they hold comparatively little land. In the Australian Capital Territory, Victoria and Tasmania, there is either no Aboriginal land or virtually none.

The optimum approach to the resolution of Mabo would take into account the constitutional and historical responsibilities of the respective governments. The Commonwealth has a role to ensure that the rights of indigenous people are respected and that their cultural heritage is, in the process, appropriately protected. The states and territories have a duty to continue to provide efficient and economic systems of land management. The optimum result would be one under which the Commonwealth actions in protecting the rights and culture of the indigenous people do not unnecessarily intrude into or burden the land management regimes of the states and territories. The optimum result would also be one under which the maintenance by the states and territories of economic and efficient management of land use does not prejudice the rights or heritage of indigenous people. A sensitive balancing of interests is required.

To achieve the optimum result, a number of things would have to be done. First, there would have to be cooperation between the Commonwealth government and the state and territory governments. Secondly, there would have to be wide consultation with the various interest groups. Thirdly, there would have to be detailed negotiations in which the interests of all affected groups were taken into account in an effort to achieve maximum consensus. It would require patience, skill, tolerance and sensitivity.

It could never have been thought seriously that the task of achieving the best result in the interests of all Australians would be easy. The initial reactions of the different governments and the different interest groups presented, as a starting point, polarised positions. Identifying appropriate representatives of interest groups also presented problems. But the challenge was there for the Commonwealth government. For all Australians, it was imperative that the greatest possible effort be devoted to achieving a result which all Australians, or at least as many Australians as possible, could support. It was always inevitable that there would have to be compromise to achieve any sort of result. However, the compromise should not have penalised any interest groups.

Among the biggest obstacles to be overcome was the need to avoid the issues becoming politicised. If party politics intruded into negotiations of such a sensitive nature, achievement of the optimum result would be impossible. A suitable model was available. In 1990-91, the Commonwealth government and the federal coalition agreed to adopt a bipartisan approach to Aboriginal reconciliation. This resulted in legislation—the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation Act 1991—which continues to this day to be supported on a bipartisan approach.

What has happened in the resolution of Mabo has not been done on a bipartisan basis. It has not been done on a basis of cooperation between the various governments. The consultations and negotiations have not been conducted on the basis of taking into account all interests. On the part of the Commonwealth, it has not been done with patience, tolerance or sensitivity. The results have been that Victoria has introduced its own legislation and New South Wales has tabled its own version.

As members have stood in this House speaking on the Commonwealth Native Title Bill 1993, members of the parliament of Western Australia have been debating the Western Australian Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Bill 1993. The two governments—the Commonwealth and the Western Australian—are engaged in an unseemly testing of constitutional power, an unseemly clash of legislative resolve and an unseemly race to proclamation. The Northern Territory government is, at the same time, expressing disquiet at the terms of the Commonwealth bill. Above it all, the federal coalition opposes the Native Title Bill.

What may be foreseen is that the uncertainty and division will grow. If this bill is passed, it will be challenged as unconstitutional. I do not accept the confident assertion yesterday by the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) that the bill is valid. There are reasonable arguments that parts of it are invalid. Assuming that the Western Australian bill is passed—and that seems likely—it seems as if that also will be challenged. If both bills are passed substantially in the form in which they are being debated, and survive challenge on the basis of basic legislative power, very complex questions will also arise as to the extent to which the Commonwealth legislation will, by virtue of section 109 of the constitution, prevail over the Western Australian legislation.

This is a very sorry state of affairs and causes me profound disappointment. Even if an optimum cooperative result were achieved, there would be a continuing need in the working out and implementation of both Commonwealth and state legislation for a bipartisan and sensitive approach. The prospect is that the working out and implementation of such legislation as survives challenge will be conducted in an atmosphere of division and confrontation.

Most of the blame for this result can, in my opinion, be placed on the Commonwealth. Most of the responsibility for ensuring that there was an appropriate national response was with the Commonwealth. Because the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had such a dominant role in the negotiations for the Commonwealth, he carries particular culpability. The Prime Minister has spurned a bipartisan approach. The Prime Minister peremptorily terminated negotiations with the states—negotiations which showed every sign of being fruitful. The Prime Minister has, since then, sought to go it alone. In this bill, the Prime Minister seeks to impose a solution on the states. The bill constitutes a repudiation of our federal system of government.

I would like to think that it is not too late to try again. Regrettably, it looks increasingly likely that returning to the negotiating table is no longer an option. In those circumstances, one can only hope that reason and restraint will be exercised by all in whatever is to follow. I join my colleagues in the federal coalition in opposing this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am proud to speak in support of the Native Title Bill—perhaps the most important single piece of legislation to have come before this House in a decade and longer. I have had a long but somewhat intermittent interest and involvement with Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, some of it being encouraged by my mentor H.C. Nugget Coombs who was the first chairman of the Australian Council for Aboriginal Affairs. In an earlier incarnation in the Victorian Legislative Assembly, I was shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs in 1973-74. I was then and have remained an enthusiast of Aboriginal art, as a collector, long before these works became fashionable, and have read many Aboriginal legends. I have also visited many important Aboriginal sites.

PARA.TAB: Bruce Chatwin's wonderful book The Songlines, published in 1987, is an attractive introduction to Aboriginal creation myths which, as he writes:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . tell of the legendary totemic beings who had wandered over the continent in the Dreamtime, singing the name of everything that crossed their path—birds, animals, plants, rocks, waterholes—and so singing the world into existence.

The Aboriginals had an earthbound philosophy. The earth gave life to a man; gave him his food, language and intelligence; and the earth took him back when he died. A man's `own country', even an empty stretch of spinifex, was itself a sacred icon that must remain unscarred . . .

In theory, at least, the whole of Australia could be read as a musical score. There was hardly a rock or creek in the country that could not or had not been sung. One should perhaps visualise The Songlines as a spaghetti of Iliads and Odysseys, writhing this way and that, in which every `episode' was readable in terms of geology . . .

By singing the world into existence, the Ancestors had been poets in the original sense of poesis, meaning `creation'. No Aboriginal could conceive that the created world was in any way imperfect. His religious life had a single aim: to keep the land the way it was and should be. The man who went `Walkabout' was making a ritual journey. He trod in the footsteps of his Ancestor. He sang the Ancestor's stanzas without changing a word or note—and so recreated the creation . . .

White men made the common mistake of assuming that, because the Aboriginals were wanderers, they could have no system of land tenure. This was nonsense. Aboriginals, it was true, could not imagine territory as a block of land hemmed in by frontiers: but rather as an interlocking network of `lines' or `ways through' . . .

Most of Outback Australia was arid scrub or desert where rainfall was always patchy and where one year of plenty might be followed by seven years of lean. To move in such landscape was survival: to stay in the same place suicide. The definition of a man's `own country' was `the place in which I do not have to ask'. Yet to feel `at home' in that country depended on being able to leave it. Everyone hoped to have at least four `ways out', along which he could travel in a crisis. Every tribe—like it or not—had to cultivate relations with its neighbour.

So much for Bruce Chatwin—honourable members will now notice the change in style. Aboriginals were excluded from the 1901 constitution. As recently as Australia's sesquicentenary celebrations of 1938, Aboriginals were listed under the heading `fauna' in at least one official publication. They were not even included in census returns until after the referendum of 1967, when voters gave the Commonwealth parliament power to legislate for them.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, Aboriginal customary land rights were not recognised by Australian courts which adopted the concept of terra nullius; the concept that after British occupation, if Aboriginal inhabitants anywhere lacked an organised society comparable to that of the occupiers—which of course they rarely did—the right to confer title became the exclusive monopoly of the Crown which could treat the land as if it were unoccupied.

I am deeply concerned by the degree of misinformation and misplaced anxiety caused by some irresponsible and alarmist reactions to the 1992 High Court of Australia decision in Mabo v. Queensland. The concerns were misplaced. It needs to be stated over and over that there is no possibility of existing land tenure in Australia's cities and settled areas being disturbed, wild ambit claims by some Aboriginal groups notwithstanding. I regret that the recent Mabo speech on television by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) referred to the fears of dispossession by white landowners without taking the opportunity to emphasise that they had no basis.

What did the High Court decide? It rejected the concept of terra nullius and recognised the validity of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander land tenure under tribal law and lore before 1788 and its continuation since under very limited circumstances. Those limited circumstances require continuous occupation by Aboriginals. This applied in the Murray Islands, the subject of the Mabo case, where the facts were not in dispute. Even the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) says that if he had been sitting on the High Court—an unlikely prospect to be sure—he would have found in favour of at least some of the plaintiffs.

Where occupation has been interrupted, the land has been subject to a Crown grant and alienated, for example Parliament House, farms or houses generally, held by freehold or leasehold title, the Aboriginal claims are no longer valid. The validity of Aboriginal claims to unoccupied crown land, where no title has ever been issued or ownership claimed, remains uncertain. Of the seven High Court judges, three thought there was a moral claim by Aboriginals in the absence of occupation, three thought there was not and one judge did not rule on it. However, as he rejected all the Mabo claims, he could be regarded as one of the `not' supporters.

It is true that some ambiguity has arisen between the passage of the Commonwealth Racial Discrimination Act 1975, binding on the states, and the Mabo decision of 1992 where the states had made Crown grants over land where Aboriginals may have been able to claim native title. To the credit of the opposition, it must be said that on two matters it is correct. First, as I understand it, the opposition accepts the Mabo judgment and does not seek to overturn it by referendum or legislation. Secondly, it accepts that the Racial Discrimination Act of 1975 is a fixture and will not be overturned. So far we have no disagreement.

The question is what the next stage is; the consequential legislation necessary after the Mabo judgment. To put things in context: every country settled by colonists has had to come to grips with the land rights of the original inhabitants. They have dealt with them in a variety of ways: slaughter, absorption, starving out or treaty. We are facing up to the central issue 205 years after white settlement. The idea is hardly an innovation. The US Supreme Court recognised the Indian tribes as nations in their equivalent of the Mabo case in Johnson v. McIntosh in 1823, although the process of executing treaties took more than 50 years.

New Zealand's Treaty of Waitangi dates from 1840. Canada began to recognise Indian land claims in the 1860s but, again, the process of concluding treaties was protracted. In the 1850s, the British Colonial Office warned settlers in Australian colonies that the justice of Aboriginal land claims would need to be recognised and negotiated on. We have taken 140 years to follow this advice.

It must be emphasised that the High Court's Mabo approach is not very different from the common law doctrine of adverse possession; that where an occupier squats on a piece of land without challenge for 15 or 30 years, depending on the jurisdiction, he or she is entitled to title as against another owner. Admittedly, that adverse possession does not run against the Crown.

The quality of the Mabo judgment was outstanding. The present High Court is of international standing—and I can be quite bipartisan. Of seven justices, four were appointed by Liberal governments. It has been a characteristic of the High Court from its earliest days—as with the US Supreme Court in cases ever since Marbury v. Madison in 1803—to apply the principles of the common law, as they interpreted them, in a spirit of justice in areas where the circumstances of the case required it and where the legislature was silent. This occurred in our High Court with the harvester case, the engineers case and the Egon Kisch case, to mention only three.

The people who suggest that the High Court is acting in a novel way and acting illegitimately in declaring the law, reveal a profound ignorance of the court, its history and function. I also draw attention to the role of the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in the Jamaican death sentences case, as recently as October 1993 when it acted in exactly the same innovative way. In Mabo v. Queensland two justices, Deane and Gaudron, have been attacked because in their joint judgment they used the term `unutterable shame' when describing crimes committed against Aboriginals.

They used the phrase in one sentence. The context was this: quite early after settlement, the attitude of some early governors was quite sympathetic towards and cooperative with Aboriginals and there was some, admittedly limited, recognition of Aboriginal land tenure. A century later a much tougher line was taken. The Aboriginals were sometimes described as `vermin' and there was some sympathy for our very own `final solution'. There were campaigns to extirpate them. There are people still living who were involved in the massacres of Aboriginals as late as 1928 in Western Australia. This does seem to be a matter of `unutterable shame'.

We have to face up to the question of the moral responsibility of the white European community for the Third World conditions in which many Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders live. They of course have to take some responsibility themselves too; but they have a dramatically shorter life expectancy than whites, they have high rates of infant mortality and they have a susceptibility to illnesses which are no longer regarded as life threatening for most Australians. That is not to say that we should become paralysed by guilt. We have to examine our collective moral responsibility in context. If we say: are we entitled to feel pride in the achievements of Australians, in the wonderful and heroic things that have been achieved, even where we were not personally or directly involved, I would say yes, we are.

Australians generally felt a strong sense of empathy at the return of the unknown Australian soldier from World War I, a sentiment expressed in the speech of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 11 November. I shared that feeling at Villers-Bretonneux at the exhumation ceremony which I attended on 2 November. I did not fight on the Somme in 1918, but I felt pride at the courage of those who did and paid with their lives. So my feeling was both legitimate and vicarious. But, if we are entitled to feel legitimate, vicarious pride at good and great things in our past, what of the bad things, the dark stains? Surely it follows that, if there has been genocide of Aboriginals, forcing tribes off their land, poisoning their waterholes—events which we have tried to eliminate from our collective memory, matters that are shaming even to recount—we ought to feel an affliction of the conscience. Pride and guilt are opposite sides of the same coin: we cannot have one without the other. But it is part of our rather slow process of national maturation, of recognising or redefining who we are. I am not into a guilt trip, but I do understand the context of our history, its tenderness and harshness, its shining lights and dark shadows, its pain, grief and bloodshed.

The bill deserves an urgent passage. It is not a perfect bill. We could all think of ways in which it could be improved. I should add too, before I close, that there have been some very important speeches in the course of the debate, including speeches from honourable members of the opposition—the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Dr Wooldridge), the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent), the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) and the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall)—who indicated, I thought, very real sympathy not for the form of the bill but for the principles behind the bill. We can all think of ways that the bill can be improved, but it deserves speedy passage, because I think at this stage what would be intolerable would be to have a further period of delay. But the speedy passage of the bill should be followed by careful consultation with the states to ensure that there is a national approach to the issue of native title which does recognise the striking differences in land tenure in each state, both a product of geography and history. To have eight jurisdictions in this complex area—six states and two territories—would be intolerable.

I close by imploring the two Greens in the other place, if they are listening to this on their crystal sets, to let the bill pass and then play a constructive role in making sure that the legislation works and brings about justice for all and a mood of national reconciliation—a fresh start in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. After 205 years it is long overdue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whatever the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) tells us, it is certain there is nothing certain about his native title legislation. We have heard a great deal about the concerns of key representatives from mining and pastoral industries—all extremely valid concerns—but there is one area of significance which seems to have been overlooked, and that is the concerns of the fishing industry. It is a major industry in Western Australia and Australia-wide. It may not be an industry that contributes the kind of wealth generated by the giant mining companies in our state, but it is without argument one of Australia's most important and thriving industries.

PARA.TAB: The government's Native Title Bill asserts that the legislation would extend to each external territory, to the coastal sea of Australia and of each external territory and to any waters over which Australia asserts sovereign rights under the Seas and Submerged Lands Act 1973. After all, the concept of terra nullius applied to the ocean in the same way as it applied to the land mass. Furthermore, amongst the bill's many definitions, native title is defined as the communal, group or individual rights or interests of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders in relation to land or waters. Rights and interests are further defined to include hunting, gathering or fishing rights and interests.

We have been told that native title is derived from traditional laws and customs of indigenous Australians. One of those traditional customs, of course, is fishing. There has been as much talk about sea rights as there has been about land rights in recent years. No doubt this debate will come to the fore again in light of the legislation being discussed in the House in the present few days. This issue has already been highlighted in a report by the Sydney Morning Herald in June this year which described the desire of the Meriam people to claim sea rights following their success in the High Court with the Mabo case.

On 16 June the West Australian newspaper reported on an address to the Indigenous Peoples' Sea Rights Conference by a law professor from the University of Western Australia, Richard Bartlett. Mr Bartlett warned that `Mabo style native title rights over Aboriginal fishing grounds could be easier to prove than land claims'. Another participant in that conference, Mr David Allen, from the Northern Land Council in Darwin, was reported by AAP as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the response to such recognition will be even more aggressive than the response over native title to lands . . . Not only would commercial fishing interests be affected but it would touch the hearts of all recreational fishermen. There is, in the inland continent of Australia, a deep tradition that the sea and its resources belong to no-one, and that in a curious way the sea is the ultimately enduring terra nullius.

On 22 October, the Business Review Weekly took up the matter in an article entitled, `Sea Rights: Mabo's Second Coming', saying that the commercial fishing industry, which has been largely overlooked in the Mabo debate and which is already under pressure to reduce quotas, licences and conserve fish, was fearful of the notion of indigenous groups exploring their rights to saltwater country. It also referred to the Northern Territory Aboriginal Land Rights Act which allows Aboriginals to fish within two kilometres of their land and provides for sea closures, which have seen amateur and commercial fishing interests unite to fight the applications for closures. The draft report from the Resource Assessment Commission of December 1992, entitled Coastal zone inquiry, stated in its fourth chapter:

. . . the relationship of Australia's indigenous people to the coastal zone is qualitatively different from that of other Australians. It is a relationship based on a tradition of long ownership, stewardship, utilisation and cultural significance.

I do not propose to argue on that point; rather, I support the traditional usage rights of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and I support Richard Court's Western Australian Land (Titles and Traditional Usage) Bill 1993, which passed through the Western Australia parliament last night.

PARA.TAB: Referring back to the report, I am interested to observe the revelation that approximately 120,000 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people currently live within 20 kilometres of the Australian coastline—roughly half of Australia's total indigenous population. In Western Australia, more than 20,000 indigenous Australians live within 20 kilometres of the coast—or 16 per cent of the total population. In the metropolitan areas of New South Wales and Queensland it is true that most of these people are not living traditional lifestyles, although they may well argue that their traditional bond with the land and sea has been maintained. Here I refer to the Dreamtime legend or dreaming tracks which encompass beaches, reefs, oceans and estuaries as the linchpins of special myths about hunting, fishing and gathering. These practices may have ceased in the metropolitan zone and closer regional areas, but as any indigenous Australian would tell us the dreaming is forever; the myths are permanent.

What is not certain is whether those practices alone can constitute a basis for a native title claim. A more concrete example, however, would be that of the people of northern Western Australia. A great deal of that area is earmarked for land rights claims already. These people continue to rely on the coastal estuarine environments. These areas are of cultural and economic importance as traditional hunting and fishing traditions endure, and the groups' rights of traditional usage should be protected.

There are other examples. In New South Wales, the Aboriginal Legal Service has already lodged a claim over parts of the state's south coast, and it has foreshadowed more of the same on the northern coast. The Utemorrah claim, which recently went before the Western Australian Supreme Court, seeks sea rights for the deepest oceans beyond the farthest reefs in the north-west of Western Australia.

According to statistics provided by the Western Australian Fisheries Department and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, the Western Australian fishing industry in 1992-93 had a total gross production value of more than $366 million—a very healthy share of the nation's $1.4 billion fishing industry. In Western Australia the fishing industry—involving fish in the strictest sense of the word—was worth $22 million. This sum is small fry when compared to our lucrative crustacean, shellfish and mollusc production values of more than $230 million and $33 million respectively. Other forms of aquaculture, including pearling, contributed around $81 million.

What strikes me as potentially alarming is that two of the most valuable of these species—abalone and rock lobster—can be harvested from those reefs which exist in relatively close proximity to the shore. Some key locations are the Abrolhos Islands, Geraldton, Jurien Bay, Cervantes, Lancelin Ledge Point and Fremantle. In general, however, the area stretches from the Murchison River in the north to Bunbury in the south-west. In addition, salmon catches, which are used mostly for canning, yield around 2,000 tonnes per annum with a value of around $1.8 million and constitute a significant proportion of inshore and beach fishing.

Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders may well have hunted and gathered at some point in history from the same areas in which these commercial ventures now base themselves, collecting a rich and diverse range of marine species to complement their staple diet. This tradition is still strong in the Torres Strait Islands, in particular, with many of these people already involved in commercial fishing activities. Again I argue, where the custom is still being practised, the groups' rights of traditional usage ought to be preserved in the legislation, as is the case with the Western Australian legislation proposed by Richard Court and passed last night.

The pressing question which is weighing heavily on the minds of some fishermen is whether these traditions, along with the Dreamtime legends, reasonably constitute the ongoing relationship with the land or sea deemed as being a necessary foundation upon which to lay claim to native title. I am aware that one of Western Australia's most prominent organisations in the fishing industry, the Western Australian Fishing Industry Council, also views the matter with concern and is hoping to clarify the uncertainty as soon as possible.

What is certain is that many indigenous Australians have already expressed their concern, as evidenced in the Coastal zone inquiry report, about the competition between commercial and subsistence fishing and commercial entry to traditionally owned marine estates. Just what the effect of native title legislation will be in this situation is unclear. If widespread sea rights similar to those found in the Northern Territory's legislation were founded, it would be a blow to commercial fishermen and charter boat operators, who could stand to lose their livelihood if they were lawfully excluded from the area on the grounds that access to these important resources were being granted on a non-discriminatory basis. It would also anger a great many of the recreational fishermen of Australia.

While the Prime Minister stated in his second reading speech that the Native Title Bill would ensure the validity of legislative regimes governing offshore economic activities such as commercial fishing ventures and petroleum exploration, he has not gone as far as to say that those industries themselves would be protected. He has stipulated that environmental and health controls and fisheries regulations will persist to keep native title land fully within the reach of Australian law, but he does not say that the rights of existing commercial fishermen will be protected. Many of these controls are imposed by way of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, which right now can enforce exclusions from fishing areas at any time without compensation.

It was never envisaged that this legislation would be used for any purpose other than to meet scientific, biological or environmental access requirements. The fishing industry certainly never envisaged that it may eventually add weight to native title claims, including exclusionary access by Aboriginal groups. The effect of combining this act with the possible claims arising under the native title legislation, which only may confirm existing rights, is a significant worry for the fishing industry, which feels it could be about to lose out in a big way—a loss that could be without compensation; all in all a double whammy for recreational and commercial fishing.

No doubt the real test will come as sea rights battles emerge. Native title legislation can only evoke the same kind of anger from fishermen and associated exporters that it has from mining leaseholders, and pastoralists in some cases. I also argue that Australians are just as passionate about the ocean, perhaps even more so, as they are about the land. It is as integral in our lifestyle as the great Australian dream of owning a family home on a quarter-acre block in the suburbs. I am not simply referring here to a family trip to the beach but to the richness of the ocean's resources.

According to the Business Review Weekly, recognition of sea rights would involve `a conceptual leap for white Australians accustomed to the notion that the sea and its resources are common property over which no-one has priority or exclusionary rights'. I agree strongly that there is a widely held belief that the ocean and its resources are there for the use and enjoyment of all Australians. Where traditional usage of the ocean continues, it should be respected and protected. But, as in the case of mining and pastoral industries, the importance of key industries should be acknowledged to ensure a brighter economic future for Australia. In addition, by leaving land management, including coastal management, in the hands of the states it would be more beneficial for Aborigines to play a greater role in marine resource conservation and management. This would satisfy one of the main concerns—that indigenous Australians, as traditional users of the land, are not consulted on matters pertaining to fishing and tourism.

In conclusion, as a Western Australian member of the House of Representatives, naturally I have a considerable amount of concern about the effects of the native title legislation on the opportunity for Western Australia to participate fully through its mining and pastoral industries in the economic recovery of this country. There is an overwhelming opposition in Western Australia to the intent, to the thrust and to the nature of the native title legislation, as proposed by the government. Richard Court's answer to the native title decision by the High Court was to propose his own legislation—legislation which is being supported by mining, pastoral and other industries within Western Australia as being a sensible answer to the problem of managing the effects of the Mabo native title decision by the High Court and other aspects of land management within the state.

I can only urge the Prime Minister on behalf of my constituents, who include a number of commercial and recreational fishermen, that it is imperative that his legislation should not be used to override the legislation of the Western Australian parliament. Land management is a right of the states. I can only tell him that if he tries to override the legislation in the Western Australian state parliament, he will get one of the biggest fights of his political life and, in my view, it will probably be one of the great conflicts of modern political history. If that is the case, it will be a tragedy for Australia—a tragedy of immense proportions. I can tell the minister who is present at the table, the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker), that in Western Australia there is overwhelming support for the Western Australian legislation and overwhelming opposition to the legislation of the Prime Minister and the party of which he is, of course, a member.

TALKER.NAME: Mr WALKER
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State)

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians have much to be proud of: we live in a beautiful country blessed by a stable democracy and we have a caring social security system. We like to believe that we are the lucky country—a land of opportunity and a fair go for all. However, there has been a cancer eating away at our national psyche for the past 200 years that needs to be excised if we are to face the world as the 21st century dawns and honestly proclaim that we are a harmonious multicultural society where concepts such as equity and justice have real meaning.

PARA.TAB: This parliament unanimously created a council for reconciliation with indigenous Australians, recognising the historic truth that our Aboriginal people have been subjected to dispossession, degradation and deprivation and that a process of acknowledgment of rapprochement had to occur if the sins of the past were to be purged.

I know there are some, including those in the opposition, who seek to deny the truths of history and label those who would try to right the wrongs of the past as the guilt industry. A mature nation needs to reject such attitudes. Australians have traditionally got behind the underdog, and the Keating government has taken the opportunity presented by the High Court's Mabo decision to substantially progress national reconciliation.

This bill is fundamentally an act of recognition—recognition that Aboriginal people were forcibly dispossessed of their land; recognition that genocide, persecution and discrimination did occur; recognition that the result has been inequality and injustice for our indigenous people. Ultimately, it is about recognising the social truth that only through acknowledging our Aboriginal people's very special attachment to this land can we begin to constructively eradicate that cancer in our collective soul.

This bill, like all land law statutes, presents as long and complicated but, in essence, it achieves four simple objectives. The first is to give ungrudging statutory recognition and protection to the native title proclaimed to exist by our High Court. The second is to validate titles purchased in good faith by all Australians and corporations in ignorance of native title but rendered invalid by the Mabo decision. The third is to provide an effective but principled framework for future dealings with native title. The fourth is to create a specialist tribunal to deal in an efficient but sensitive way with claims for native title.

For the past 14 months the government has laboured mightily to secure consensus within the Australian community regarding this legislation. Given the gulf of self-interest between the major stakeholders, this was probably an impossible dream but human decency demanded that an honest effort be made. Much has been achieved but I regret that we are not able to convince the opposition, and its mates in the ultraconservative rump of our community, to join with us in building this new relationship between indigenous and non-Aboriginal Australians.

Instead of the peaceful path of reconciliation, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has chosen to take the politically opportunist road of conflict and division. His actions degrade us all because they limit Australia's potential and sully our international reputation. It is sad that this opportunity to display our political maturity has been marred by a weak, beleaguered leader, more interested in appeasing redneck interests in his party room than serving our national interests.

My distasteful job in this debate is to respond to the opposition's disgraceful and un-Australian amendments to a bill that cries out for bipartisan support. I suppose that we should have realised just how low and despicable the Liberal's approach would be when the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) was appointed shadow spokesman on Mabo. Appointing a man who had publicly reviled our High Court judges for making the decision, and calling for a referendum to reverse it, was not a positive step towards consensus or reconciliation. His jackboot style and intellectual limitations had a most negative impact on the negotiation process. The Opposition's final policy of total opposition to this bill and abdication of responsibility to state governments would come as no surprise to those who listened in horror while the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) labelled Mabo the `guilt industry' and proclaimed Aboriginal people as lesser human beings because they had not invented the wheel. We could only expect the worst from the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), who was supported by his leader in an unprecedented attack on the integrity of our High Court and in making most offensive remarks about Aboriginality. Indeed, the debate has been characterised by the most odious racist comments from the Liberal Party politicians since the abolition of the White Australia Policy.

We had a former Liberal Prime Minister, John Gorton, declaring Aborigines to be thoroughly inferior to whites. Marshall Perron, another Liberal leader, also maintained Aborigines to be unworthy because he believed they were unhygienic. Former Liberal leader Bill Hassell stated that the Mabo decision was illegitimate, illogical and racist and that native title represents racial discrimination—a view echoed by many opposition frontbenchers, including the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) and the honourable member for Barker.

Decent Liberals, like Ian Viner and Ian Macphee, distanced themselves from their former colleagues. Fred Chaney condemned the Liberal Party for failing to recognise that Aboriginal people are entitled to some respect and for regarding them as a subspecies. He accused his former colleagues of treating Aboriginal people like kangaroos: seeking to move them on whenever there was a competing use.

At the end of the day, it was inevitable that the opposition would oppose this bill root and branch, and would do its best to have it defeated in the Senate. We know that the real reasons relate to the opposition's inherent attitudes of class superiority, its leadership crisis and its desire to appease extreme elements within the mining industry. However, this debate requires us to examine the few phoney reasons that the Leader of the Opposition has advanced in his amendments.

His first amendment argues that there is no need to recognise or protect native title because the High Court has already done that. That is a fatuous proposition because the High Court has periodically changed its opinion on vital issues. Its judgments are not set in cement. Anyway, what has come over the Leader of the Opposition and his redneck crew, who only two weeks ago were crowing in this House about the doctrine of the supremacy of parliament and demanding that we legislate to remove uncertainty in the mining industry? This bill is necessary to express the view of the legislature on a permanent resolution to this great issue and to provide the act of public recognition so necessary to the process of reconciliation.

The second amendment argues that the Racial Discrimination Act suffices to protect the interests of native title owners from state and territory governments. It has always been possible for state governments to extinguish native title, if they do so in a non-discriminatory way. The real question here is whether they should be allowed to do what Richard Court's government seeks to do, and that is to extinguish all native title in a racially discriminatory fashion. This is the sort of final solution strategy dear to the hearts of the extreme Right. Indigenous Australians should never forgive the Liberals for opting to complete the process of their dispossession which the High Court so graphically condemned as the darkest aspect of the history of this nation.

This amendment represents hypocrisy of the worst kind, particularly in the light of the admission by the Leader of the Opposition that, despite his media protestations to the contrary, the Racial Discrimination Act would be amended if he ever became Prime Minister to ensure the validity of past titles. This amendment is unadulterated cant and deserves to be treated with contempt by this parliament.

The third amendment argues that land management is entirely a state responsibility. That argument certainly has no validity in fact, nor have the courts ever given it support. Anyway, there is no suggestion in the bill that the Commonwealth government is invading the states' land management responsibilities. Ours is a co-operative scheme. Many of the specific powers of the Commonwealth government have the incidental effect of constraining the way states manage land. The most obvious example is the Racial Discrimination Act.

In the Mabo decision, the High Court allowed the Racial Discrimination Act to intrude into the land management responsibilities of the Queensland government by invalidating a Queensland act extinguishing native title in the Torres Strait. The Franklin Dam case is another example of the Commonwealth government successfully intervening to modify land management in Tasmania. Moreover, Australia's ratification of the international conventions on racial discrimination and the covenant on human rights give us ample scope under the external affairs power to pass this bill. Under this measure, land management will remain a state responsibility but the states will manage native title land according to the principles and guidelines established by the Commonwealth parliament.

The fourth amendment is the most dangerous of all for Australians because it proclaims the false proposition that federal laws are unnecessary to facilitate the validation of past grants. The opposition's about-face on this issue over the last week has been truly breathtaking because, for the past 14 months, along with the mining lobby and the states, it has been vociferously demanding Commonwealth validating legislation and predicting dire consequences if we did not get on with that job. Well, what has changed? What Damascus Road revelation has turned these small-minded conservatives around on this point of law? In three days of debate we have not heard one word of explanation.

The government's legal advice is that only the federal government can guarantee retrospective validation of past grants. The government's legal counsel are convinced, as are many other eminent lawyers in this country, that the Court bill breaches section 10 of the Racial Discrimination Act and is accordingly invalid. The Leader of the Opposition acknowledges the likelihood of that eventuality because he promises to amend the RDA if the Court bill fails.

If this bill is lost in the Senate, there would follow a period of great uncertainty and inertia in resource development while the Western Australian act awaits hearing in the High Court. That could take many months, even years. No responsible bank would lend multimillions of dollars for new mining projects while grave doubts existed about the validity of the security. Financial markets could become very nervous about the status of existing securities.

Having listened ad nauseam to the mining lobby about sovereign risk, loss of jobs and companies moving overseas, I am stunned that it has now grabbed on to the opposition's coat-tails and decided to gamble all on the validity of the Western Australian bill. Perhaps it believes that our bill will pass anyway. I would imagine that it is now having second thoughts as the Greens hold us all in suspense, indicating that they do not favour this bill because they believe it is pro-mining and disadvantages Aborigines.

The Greens want us to embark upon an exercise of further consultation with Aboriginal communities around Australia. Having once spent two years on such an exercise, I can tell them that, once initiated, that exercise could end up taking a long, long time. CRA with $1.75 billion at stake on the Cape York peninsular must be beginning to get concerned as to whether it can convince its financial backers that secure title can be achieved. MIM should be feeling concerned about its $300 million investment in the McArthur River mine. Indeed, virtually all prominent mining corporations in the north of Australia will have a king-sized headache if this bill does not become law.

Having dismissed the Leader of the Opposition's puerile policies, I must now turn to this bill's greatest challenge—to gain the support of the Western Australian Greens. Like all dedicated environmentalists, I have a great deal of goodwill for the Greens but I must say that, while I do not doubt their sincerity, Aboriginal people must be filled with anguish by their tactics. Some time ago a very decent Liberal came to me with a draft of what the Greens now call their holding bill. I explained then that the bill would be a disaster for Aboriginal people because of its fatal flaws. It is in reality a Trojan horse.

The first fatal flaw is that it prevents laws passed after 1 July 1993 from extinguishing native title, but not laws already on the states' statute books. Some months ago an attempt by the New South Wales government to use its Crown Lands Act to convert all crown leases to freehold title was narrowly defeated in the upper house. Nothing in the Greens' bill would stop Richard Court taking executive acts permitted under his government's existing laws to convert all unused crown land to freehold, so extinguishing all native title in Western Australia.

The second fatal flaw is that it is arguable that a Commonwealth bill which would simply validate, as opposed to modify, the Western Australian Land Titles Act passed through its parliament today is, in effect, a Commonwealth acquisition and must be paid for under the just terms and provisions of our constitution. If this view is correct, the Greens' bill would provide an irresistible incentive for Richard Court to wipe out native title because the Commonwealth government would be paying for the compensation.

The third fatal flaw is that the Solicitor-General has expressed the view that the Greens' bill is of doubtful constitutional validity because it would not attract the support of either the race or the external affairs powers. No doubt the legal advisers of the states would be giving them the same advice. The Greens' holding bill should be consigned to the dustbin. Instead of bagging the Aboriginal leaders who are horrified by their position, the Greens should start listening to them.

We all know that this bill represents a compromise. Miners, pastoralists, state governments and Aborigines all had to give some ground in the lengthy negotiations to produce the bill before the House. However, it was a principled, balanced, workable compromise; an honourable settlement that all Australians will be able to look back on with pride. We do not pretend that this measure is a panacea for the problems of indigenous Australians. It is going to have little immediate effect on those Third World conditions in health, education, housing and employment; that is Australia's shame.

However, like Michael Dodson, I passionately believe that social justice for indigenous peoples will not be achieved by paternalistic authorities simply throwing more goods and services at Aboriginal people, but by the provision of inalienable rights. The High Court's recognition of native title has stirred up a hornet's nest in the bastions of privilege in our nation because it represents a change in thinking that has entirely recast the social landscape of Australia.

The human dignity inherent in owning land, so treasured by Australians, can be shared by black Australians. The recognition of their unique identity will inevitably lead to their children enjoying a better life of choice, a better life of opportunity, that has been denied by the pernicious doctrine of terra nullius to previous generations. In achieving dignity for Aboriginal Australians, we also provide for the dignity of all Australians who will find it a lot easier to hold up their heads in pride after this bill becomes law.

So I would urge the opposition to review its position. Those opposite should seek to take a bipartisan approach to this issue—an issue which, above all others, deserves a bipartisan approach. They should not relinquish responsibility to state governments around this country, but accept, as their predecessors have done in 1975 and at other times, the responsibility that the people of Australia gave this parliament in 1967 by a majority of over 90 per cent—the highest winning percentage that a referendum has ever had.

I would also urge the Greens in the Senate—I know there is a great deal of pressure upon them; I know there is a great weight on their shoulders—to listen to Aboriginal people. If they truly believe, as I think they do, that the interests of Aboriginal people should be advanced and improved by this measure, I urge them to listen to the people who are talking to them, such as the leaders of the Aboriginal communities. I know there are a few Aboriginals within Australia who have a different point of view—there will always be a few individuals in any community with a different point of view—but the overwhelming majority of Aboriginal leaders are telling them to get on and pass this bill. I urge them to do so.
Debate interrupted.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —I declare the Native Title Bill 1993 an urgent bill.
—The question is that the bill be considered an urgent bill.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the time allotted for the remaining stages of the bill be until 9 p.m. this day.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not speak at any length—we are not permitted to speak at any length—but I will point out these salient facts. Thus far we have had an extensive debate on the Native Title Bill, and we will have further debate. Already, twice as many people have spoken in this debate as there are members of the Western Australian upper house.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the House will resume his seat for a moment. The honourable member for Mayo will withdraw that comment.
—What comment?
—The honourable member for Mayo will withdraw the comment of hypocrisy that he made across the table to the Prime Minister. Correct?
—Mr Speaker—
—You have been asked by the chair to withdraw the comment.
—I withdraw it just because—
—There is no because anything. I call the Leader of the House.
—Mr Speaker, can I seek your indulgence?
—I have called the Leader of the House. There is no indulgence. Resume your seat.

—As I pointed out, there are very material differences between the situation here and that in Western Australia. Firstly, we have had three days of debate here as opposed to one evening's debate in the Western Australian Legislative Council. Secondly, this is not the House of review; this is the legislative house where the government programs its legislation. The bill will proceed from this place to the Senate where it will reside until at least the middle of December and be extensively discussed.

PARA.TAB: In the house of review in Western Australia, the Liberal Party keeps justifying its massive malapportionment on the grounds that it has a voting strength of 3 1/2 to 1. It justifies this weighting of rural districts in Western Australia by saying, `We know how to use a house like this. We stand back independent as a house of review. We allow our house of review to deliberate at leisure, unencumbered by guillotines, to consider what is produced by the majority in the governing house—the governing chamber'.

There are very specific reasons why the Liberal Party, for the first time in the 100 years existence of the Western Australian Legislative Council, moved a guillotine in that place as opposed to its Legislative Assembly—basically because it has no confidence in the legality and constitutionality of its bill. One of the reasons why we are able to complete this deliberation here is that the government has no amendments to move to its lengthy legislation in the native title area.

That contrasts with the Legislative Assembly in Western Australia where the government moved 20 pages of amendments in an attempt to establish some vague level of confidence that, at the end of the day, it might come up with a potable product. Of course, that government has been unable to do that and is, therefore, utterly embarrassed. The last thing it wants with a non-potable piece of legislation is the Legislative Council to pick it apart.

We all know that one of the members of that Legislative Council has been suspended for four days and, therefore, is not voting on this occasion. In all probability, were he there we might indeed have some degree of deliberation in that house of review. The great constitutionalists opposite always tell us about this beloved deliberation—until it is inconvenient for them to do so. After 100 years of justifying its rotten boroughs in the Western Australian Legislative Council, with its 3 1/2 to 1 malapportionment, the opposition's colleagues in Western Australia are finally and totally exposed for the rottenness they have displayed in this area.

The opposition will get another hour or so to debate this bill. Already twice as many people as there are members of the Legislative Council in Western Australia have spoken on this bill in this chamber. There has been very substantial deliberation in this place, and there will be more deliberation in the Senate before this is concluded because we have confidence in this bill; the Western Australian government has no confidence in its legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWARD
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Opposition Business)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition completely opposes this declaration of urgency, and we oppose most of all the stench of hypocrisy coming from the other side of the parliament. We oppose the hypocrisy of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of this country who had the unbelievable gall at question time today to say that we were trying to gag question time. That was the most blithering piece of hypocrisy we have heard in this parliament today.

PARA.TAB: Only a couple of weeks ago that man got up in this parliament and wanted us to believe that the Native Title Bill was of monumental importance to the future unity of the Australian community. He laced his second reading speech with exhortations to national unity and to national decency. He asked that all Australians come together and recognise the importance that the Mabo decision represented in the life of this country. He invited all of us to have a sense of our oneness as members of the Australian community.

I think that is the most hypocritical part of this whole debate, because if ever there has been a man who has headed a government, who has been a wounder and a wrecker rather than a healer and a builder, it is the current Prime Minister of Australia. He is the most divisive leader this country has ever had. He is the man who has the urge to spoil all of the parliamentary form, and he is doing it again and again.

Today he is denying at least eight people on this side of the parliament the opportunity to speak on a piece of legislation. This is the man who talks about unity and decency; this is the man who talks about Australia being a decent place in which to live. If ever there was a person who has tried very hard not to make it a decent place in which to live, it is the current Prime Minister of Australia. By this motion and by his whole handling of this issue—and it comes to a climax with the jackbooted tactics in the parliament tonight—he has further divided the Australian community rather than bring it together.

We do not have to look any further than a succession of opinion polls on Mabo to realise that his handling of Mabo is rejected by the great majority of the Australian community. On two occasions a poll has shown that that is the situation. Yet the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) has the nerve—and this is the most galling piece of hypocrisy in the exercise—to say that the Western Australian parliament is running for cover; that the Western Australian government is worried about the constitutionality of its legislation.
