The Prime Minister ought to worry about constitutionality! If he was so dammed certain of the constitutionality of his bill, why is he retrospectively extinguishing rights of the Western Australian parliament? If he is so certain that his bill will successfully run the gauntlet of the High Court of Australia, why is he retrospectively wiping out rights and wiping out powers of the Western Australian parliament?

The Western Australian government has presented a fair and reasonable bill. If he does not want to believe us on that, he ought to at least believe the word of Sir Ronald Wilson, a former justice of the High Court, a former head of the Uniting Church, the head of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, and the deputy chairman of the Council of National Reconciliation.

The final parliamentary atrocity of this little guillotine exercise is that the Leader of the House will not effectively allow any committee stage of debate on this bill. He will not allow any kind of rational examination. It is typical of the jackbooted parliamentary tactics that he and the Prime Minister have used throughout the entire eight months since the last election. If ever there was an example of the authoritarian streak which is the characteristic of this Prime Minister's approach to Australian politics, it has been demonstrated by his divisive and disruptive handling of this issue and by the jackbooted, arrogant tactics he has used to get the legislation through this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KEATING
TALKER.ROLE: Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —After nearly nine months of discussion, a draft outline of the government's bill, a discussion paper, a draft outline of the legislation, drafts of the legislation circulated, three days of debate and yet, despite that, the opposition has the hide—when seeking to have a Senate committee bail the bill up, and to have an extended debate—to try to suggest that the remarks I made today about that outrageous piece of law in Western Australia, about the outrageous non-consultative tactics of the Western Australia government and its decision to try to ram this through the upper

SPEECH.PARA: house which has never guillotined a bill, through a malapportioned chamber—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —There are the rule of law men; they are all interested over there in the rule of law until the High Court says something that does not suit them, and then they want to put the High Court asunder. They are the rule of law people, except when the law does not suit them.

PARA.TAB: On this side there has been consultation with the community, with the Aboriginal community, with the mining community and with the farming community. A draft outline of the bill has been produced, copies of the draft bill have been distributed, and there have been three days of debate in here. We are not going to be part of the obstructionist tactics in here of the opposition, and that is why it will bear the guillotine. But when the bill goes to the Senate, we will also bail up the opposition there.

Today we had a discussion about appearances before Senate committees. The Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has great faith in Senate committees and he has told us how he will appear before a Senate committee, but now he will not appear because he would have to perjure himself were he to appear before such a committee. He has since announced, after question time, that he will not now appear before the Senate committee on the Black-Fairfax matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. The Prime Minister just suggested that a member on this side of the House might perjure himself. That is an accusation totally unparliamentary and I ask it be withdrawn.
—No. There is no point of order.

—Mr Speaker, we are hearing about the rights of Senate committees and the commitment by this man, the Leader of the Opposition, to appear in front of one, except when it is made clear that, were he to appear, he has to either turn Mr Black into a perjurer or go and defend his remarks before the Senate committee. I hope he reconsiders and goes to the Senate committee that he has now set up. At any rate, let us make this point—

PARA.TAB: Dr Hewson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he has pulled out. Have you pulled out or are you going? Are you going? Are you going to the Senate committee?
—The Leader of the Opposition will have his chance in a moment.

—Mr Speaker, Mr Black's remarks are obviously still on record. Mr Black said he will testify under oath. The Leader of the Opposition said, `So will I', but now he is backsliding on the commitment to testify, and it could only be because he would live in fear of needing to perjure himself before the Senate committee to make his shabby case against the government stick.

PARA.TAB: Let us make this clear: no Senate committee and no faith you have in it can deny justice to Aboriginal people in this respect. There is no way you can slide and hide behind debates about guillotines to cover your shame of trying to denude the first Australians, the indigenous Australians, of the land that should be theirs, and no stinking, rotten, foul manoeuvre by the Western Australian government will see Aboriginal people robbed, pilfered or thieved of their land as you are complying in that so to do. That is why we will triumph with this bill of principle, and why the nation will embrace it for righting a wrong 200 years in the making. The stain of that wrong has to be finally put asunder by a decent decision with a good piece of Commonwealth law.

TALKER.NAME: Dr HEWSON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been fascinated to see the urgency with which the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) ran in here this afternoon to try to defend his indefensible position on this guillotine. You all know why he is here. Every one of you—particularly all those on the back bench who are not consulted as the rest of them—knows why he is here. You know that this issue is going to eat you. You know that the more the people of Australia understand what this man is on about, the more they are going to move against you.

PARA.TAB: Do not forget, I remember a statement you once made to me: the devil is in the detail. Well, the devil is in the detail of your legislation. You have come in here to actually admit that you are scared stiff that the people of Australia are going to find out the detail of what you are on about.

What you have done with this piece of legislation is scandalous—and you know it. You know what you have done. You completely rolled over to the left wing of your party to save yourself and sold out the interests of the people of Australia to try to save your political skin. You have put in place a bill that probably is going to prove to be unconstitutional. It is going to build the biggest bureaucratic, administrative and legal nightmare that this country has ever seen. You will rue the day you ever put this piece of legislation in place.

You are asking the people of Australia to sign off on a blank cheque that will cost them hundreds of millions—indeed, the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker), behind you, says billions—of dollars. An open-ended commitment for what? Because you want to go down in history as the man who could reconcile black and white Australia. The megalomaniac at the desk wants to go down in history as the one person who wanted to reconcile black and white Australia. He is selling out the interests of average Australians, he is selling out the miners, he is selling out the farmers and he is selling out those who want jobs—all for the sake of this man's megalomania.

He is driven by ego. Ever since this issue started, this man went out and consciously set out to divide this nation for his own political ends. We are seeing him in here today expressing the urgency that he now knows. He is now reading these polls. He is now starting to understand the reaction of the people of Australia as they understand more and more about the nature of this man's legislation and this man's agenda.
Mr Keating interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at your backbench. The people of Australia are starting to understand the magnitude of the agenda that you have asked them to sign off on. The only reason you do not want debate is that you are running scared on this issue. You do not want the details of this issue exposed. You do not want the average Australian to understand the full extent of what you are on about and what your agenda is because once they do they will hound you out of office. You have sold them out, and they are starting to understand that.

PARA.TAB: Just look at the polls over the last series of weeks and look at the reaction. I am talking about the Mabo polls, which are showing that people understand this issue, they see this as a significant issue, and they are getting more and more concerned about the extent to which this man, this hypocrite, this megalomaniac, is selling out the interests of the average Australian for his own political ends.

On this issue, the cruelest thing of all is that he has gone out and raised the expectations of the Aboriginal people in a way that he will never be able to deliver. He will never be able to satisfy their expectations. You go back to your Redfern speech, to the speech you made in New Zealand, and to some of the things you said and the extent to which you raised their expectations.

I do not know how the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) can stand behind you because he knows how much you have sold them out. You have sold out the Aboriginal people of Australia completely for your own political ends. You have raised the expectations of farmers and you have sold them out. You have raised the expectations of miners and you have sold them out. You have sold everybody out for your own political ends. And that is so typical of this, the most divisive, out of touch, imperial Prime Minister this country has ever seen.

TALKER.NAME: Mr GEAR
TALKER.ROLE: Assistant Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just seen here is Richard Court's lackey. All he has done is sold out to the Western Australian parliament, a parliament that passed legislation taking away rights given to Aboriginal people by the High Court.
—You're a Western Australian yourself.

—Yes, I am a Western Australian. I will tell you something: I am more of a Western Australian than Richard Court will ever be. What we have just seen here today is an absolutely disgraceful performance by somebody who pretends to be the alternative Prime Minister of Australia.
—Order! The minister will resume his seat. The time for this debate has expired, regrettably.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Beazley's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Dr HEWSON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Leader of the Opposition claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, I do.
—Please proceed.
—During the last debate the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said that I had changed my mind about appearing before the Senate committee because I knew that I would perjure myself. That is what he said.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No child might need to live in poverty, or something like that, right?
—Order! The Leader of the Opposition does not need help.
—I did a doorstop interview this afternoon when I was asked that specific question. In my answer to that specific question I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I have already said I am happy to go to the inquiry. I challenge the Prime Minister: has he got the guts to go to the inquiry? Has he got the guts to answer the questions? Has he got the guts to repeat the allegations he made against me? I doubt it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Show where you have been misrepresented.
—I just did.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Three electorates cover more than 60 per cent of australia's land mass; the three biggest electorates of kalgoorlie, the northern territory and grey. Many of the potential native claims—some have already been made—are in these electorates. The fundamental differences between these electorates and urban electorates are location, lifestyle and outlook.

PARA.TAB: Tonight, I remember my constituents, Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, and my heritage as a regional Australian. I think of the creation of a nation the world has come to know as Australia. I think of the Burma railway, the New Guinea campaign, Gallipoli and those people who fought there and at all other battlefields for Australia. I think of my children and my children's children and the children of Aboriginal heritage.

I do not underestimate the difficult and great task that confronts us as a parliament in advancing fairness and opportunities for all Australians, particularly Aboriginal Australians and the native title issue. My work on the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs and my work in the electorate of Grey have given me a wider experience over recent months. Five per cent of my electorate is Aboriginal land granted by the Tonkin and Bannon governments. That granting of land began 20 years ago. The Arabunna people currently have a native title claim on another 15 per cent of my electorate. Coupled with the World Heritage listing of Lake Eyre, honourable members might begin to imagine how many of these people who have lived in these regions for many generations might feel. Never—I repeat never—let it be said that a home on a pastoral lease is not someone else's home.

About five per cent of Aboriginal people are potentially able to be beneficially involved with the real intent of the High Court's native title finding. There is one main way that revenue can be created and that is from wealth creation by people creating real development. Access to land in the most sensitive way possible is the main basis of development. Revenue is the main resource from which benefits to Australian society can be sourced. Regional people—my constituents—understand this simple reality. My constituents have lived, worked and socialised with each other—Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal—for many generations. As regional Australians we are stereotyped and denigrated by many in the media and many of our political opponents. Yet we have been the closest to the Aboriginal people for many generations and we share in many ways some understanding of Australia's urban dominant culture. The comfortable cliches of the ignorant and the politically correct roll off the tongue as many confess that they have had little or no contact with Aboriginal people. In enterprise development, the education and health issues are offered some crocodile tears and almost forgotten.

I briefly touch on racism throughout the world. I recently plucked up the courage to ask a black African woman, who had recently emigrated to Australia, about racism. I think she helped me as much as anyone to understand whether I was racist or whether I was somewhere in between various shades of that description when she described to me the racism between tribes and between various groups in her own country. As far as she was concerned, as a black African woman, racism in Australia was negligible in comparative terms.

In my work on the standing committee, it has been my privilege to meet many Aboriginal people throughout Australia and share our mutual concerns. There are some absolutely outstanding and wonderful people and they can only be filled with a sense of positive confidence about our future based on their capacity, commonsense and respect for Australia.

There is a great irony to me that no land in urban Australia is under claim, where obviously some of the best land in Australia has been used for development and recreation by the overwhelming number of Australians. Could it be that once again regional Australia has been asked to carry the heaviest load? I give three simple examples. In the Northern Territory, where I understand that 40 per cent of the land is controlled by Aboriginal people, there have been 270 applications for mining and 43 applications have been approved. In the non-Aboriginal lands, there have been 3,000 applications and 2,000 applications have been approved.

In Western Australia recently, I had the privilege of travelling through the electorate of Kalgoorlie with the standing committee. The great thing happening in this little town was that the Aboriginal people had got together with the local authorities and were helping people home from the hotels. That was just a practical little thing and they could not get one dollar of government support. The only support they were getting was from the local government which provided them with a bit of petrol. In my electorate of Grey, I am reminded of the people of the Pitjantjatjara. All they were asking for one day was basic shelter for the elderly.

Not one Aboriginal constituent of mine has mentioned the native title issue to me in a positive sense. They have approached me about access to Aboriginal land by Aboriginals who are not regarded as part of certain lands. The only public Aboriginal comment I have observed in my electorate is from an Aboriginal who was strongly in favour of one Australia encouraging development for the benefit of all. It could well be that, in practical terms, one of the greatest impediments to Aboriginal enterprise development on their own lands is the indirect tax burden of fuel excise and all other transport costs.

In my maiden speech I proudly mentioned Benno Murray, 103 years of age, an Aboriginal constituent of mine and a veteran of Gallipoli and World War II. I acknowledged the earliest known inhabitants, the Pangkala people in my region and proudly mentioned some of the Aboriginal names which predominate in my electorate. The states are the traditional land title administrators. Many in this parliament would abolish the states. Reconciliation has been occurring for many decades, and for many Australians that will continue in the future. Many other Australians—non-Aboriginal and Aboriginal—have reconciled in their own personal way over the generations. The parliament, the executive and the High Court should never presume that in all their deliberations they provides the only answer. I hope that we would never be that arrogant. In the hearts and minds of Australians there is a fairness which makes us amongst the most tolerant democracies in the world. We should never underestimate or undermine the commonsense and goodwill of all Australians.

Our future is what we make it. I am an Australian. Australia is my country. I will always try to serve my country and seek to represent the regional view with the practical experience available to me. I am proud of my heritage in the knowledge that the future always has the potential to be creative. I, from humble beginnings, who can still remember life without electricity, access to only basic education and only one generation removed from the tent and the pug and pine, believe we have many challenges ahead of us which, with strength and practical commonsense, we can overcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am proud to be an Australian and proud to be part of a government which has embraced a strategy which enriches the lives of all Australians, the question of justice for all. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his second reading speech on the Native Title Bill talked about the basic facts of history. To deny them is to deny history. Our past is our present, and our present is our future. For us all it is a matter of acknowledging the past, being part of the present and, more importantly, looking to a future in which all Australians, irrespective of religion, culture or economic substance, are part of this great land and are treated equally.

PARA.TAB: To all of us who grew up in suburban Australia—as I did in the 1950s—Aborigines were unknown. We did not meet them, mix with them or know them. Only through our history books did we know something of them; but the history we were reading was British and there was certainly very little about Australia, other than that Australian history started with Captain Cook—which we now know to be false.

It was not until I went, as a young teacher in 1969, to Mareeba in North Queensland that I was able to see at first-hand that our first Australians were fringe dwellers in their own country. Racism there was rampant. Very few of the children attended school and very few Aboriginal people had any role in the community. That was a product not just of dispossession of the land, but also of dispossession of their identity—not being part of a community. Having lost the sense of identity and community, those people were pushed to the fringes of our society; and we turned against them and poked our fingers at them.

I also taught in the Northern Territory for quite a number of years. Those Australians who have not been there or to outback central Australia need to understand that the way some people are living shows us they are Australia's Third World. Part of the problem is land dispossession, people being moved at gunpoint to join others. As I talked to people I learned with horror about their history. While I, as a young student in the 1960s, had been taking part in all sorts of demonstrations, people in central Australia had been rounded up—not once or twice, but three times—at gunpoint and taken to Aboriginal settlements because it was believed that would be good for them. It is a very salutary lesson for all of us—and for me it was a salutary learning experience.

At the heart of that is the land—who one is, the language one speaks, where one comes from and where one is going. If the whole issue of Mabo does not raise these very central and crucial issues for all of us in the community, it has failed. The whole issue in the Mabo debate is the recognition that all Australians should be treated equally. We are all entitled to justice. After all, we are one of the richest countries on earth. Those of us who happen to live in towns and provincial cities throughout Australia have a high standard of living. Yet the very first Australians do not enjoy such benefits. Their health and education have slipped dramatically.

Mabo and the Native Title Bill do not endeavour to turn those things over and change them overnight but recognise that all of us have to know who we are and where we come from. Those of us who have grown up in families can trace our family trees; the Prime Minister went back to Ireland recently to his own family. For the 40 per cent of Australians who were not born here it is important to know where they come from. Surely for the first Australians it is equally important to know who they are and where they come from.

Aboriginal people of my age are only now beginning to know who their mothers are and where they might have been born. It is horrible. It is unimaginable for those of us who have been cocooned in Australian society that people—perhaps believing at the time they were doing the right thing—could have done such horrible things and dragged children screaming from their mothers and so on. We would not allow it now. We cannot change the fact that it happened; but we can accept that it happened and create a society in which it will not happen again and in which everybody will be treated fairly and equally.

In terms of the whole question of land and the kind of possession people have of it, we all need to understand that the way we possess land and the way we have possessions is viewed somewhat differently by very many in the Aboriginal community. I am reminded of a school in Alice Springs called Yipirinya, a school for children of fringe dwellers. They speak three languages. It started when a group of parents felt that children needed to be able to walk in both cultures. In my electorate, 40 per cent of the people I mix with every day were not born in Australia and their children are more than able to walk in two cultures and two languages. Why is it any less appropriate for first Australians to be able to walk in two cultures and two languages?

At Yipirinya school that is exactly what parents set out to do. They believed that language was important. I think all of us would acknowledge that. It enables us to communicate, be informed and imbue a part of culture which is important for all of us. At Yipirinya the children speak three Aboriginal languages and are taught by Aboriginal teachers. Having mastered their own language they move on to English—a step across.

Models such as that acknowledge that children can grow up bilingual. It is important for us to preserve such models and look at things in a very different light. People on the other side of this House sometimes seem to think it is perfectly acceptable for us to have community languages for people who come from Italy, Romania, Israel, Iran, Greece, Turkey, the Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia or any of the other 148 countries which Australians now come from. It is somehow acceptable for them to preserve their own language. The government provides funding for those community language programs.

However, it seems that our first Australians should not and must not preserve, develop and work with their own language. Language is part of the tie to the land. It defines where they live and the groups in which they move. Some languages, because they are spoken by very small groups of people, are very sophisticated. I can think of one language group which has 14 forms of address, depending on whom one is speaking to. Some of us would find this extremely difficult. We are not talking about the historical view of simple people doing simple things, but about people who have a very sophisticated understanding of their environment and whose relationships with each other, and those developed through their language, at times are incredibly complicated and sophisticated.

Tied into this legislation are all those kinds of things which are very much about Australia and Australians, about who we are and where we are going. We have heard a lot of talk about the relationship between Aboriginal communities and pastoralists, pastoralists and mining companies and of all of those groups to government and to the Australian populace in general. Somehow, it has always been deemed to be all right for pastoralists who acquired land in all sorts of ways to achieve respectability but that that is not all right for those people who were there and had land.

There is room in this great land for all of us—pastoralists, mining companies and certainly the very first Australians. There has to be room because we are all here as part of a great democracy which is committed to justice—justice for each and every one of us, irrespective of who we are and where we come from. It is somewhat frightening to hear people talk about the need for further discussions and debate. Indeed, it is said that perhaps some people do not understand the nuances of legislation. I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that almost all of the laws and legislation passed in this House often is not understood by the vast majority of the Australian populace and, I would hasten to add, sometimes not even by some of the honourable members in this House.

When I hear people suggest that groups should travel through northern Australia to discuss legislation with isolated communities, I wonder what kind of paternalism or view of the world they have. I find it quite extraordinary. It is also quite ridiculous, given that northern Australia is currently in the middle of the wet season. One would find it difficult to travel through that countryside at present. This is apart from the fact that the first language of very many people there is not English. Once again we see a kind of paternalism: it is all right for us to tell people what to do if they happen to be Aboriginals who obviously could not understand or would not know about the legislation. I would have hoped that the Australian community would have moved further down the track to raise issues of fairness, concern and justice.

This government speaks for all Australians. It consults with organisations and groups in the communities. We talk to people. We do not talk to each and every person we know. A member in this House represents on average 70,000 people. We do not discuss issues on every piece of legislation with each and every person in the community, but we do go out and talk to people. We have a sense of what people think, feel and know. The same thing has happened in consultations with this Native Title Bill.

At the heart of the legislation is a High Court decision. I find it quite extraordinary that people are now suggesting that we should be having a referendum on this High Court decision. We do not have referendums at the end of murder trials and we do not ask people whether they agree with particular court decisions. At times there have been court decisions which very few of us have agreed with. There have been some recent cases where judges have made comments about women and about the way women have been treated. While there were outcries, there were certainly no calls for referendums on those court findings.

If we are to be bound in this democracy by the rule of law, then we must abide by the High court's decision. It has ruled quite simply on the law of native title. For those of us who abide by the law, the law is the law. People who do not like this decision may not like other laws, but we have not heard them calling for referendums on those. This nonsense that somehow the rule of law applies in some instances but not in others seems somewhat absurd. I find it even more extraordinary that the people who purport to uphold the rule of law—the more conservative groups in our society—suddenly find that, when the law is not to their liking, it is somehow defective. They cannot have it both ways. At the heart of this Native Title Bill is the issue of the rule of law and, more importantly, the translation of that law into action. Quite properly, that is what governments and democracy are about.

We have had many discussions on the government's application of this law. Sure, not everybody is happy, but not everybody is happy every day of the week with the laws that are made. Honourable members, sitting in their offices, hear people complain about the laws as they pertain to a whole range of issues—social security legislation, the local CES office, a whole range of educational policies, health policies, defence policies or any other kinds of policies. But, quite properly, people are elected to make laws, they are elected on policy platforms and they are elected on questions of a philosophical basis.

This great party, at its core, at its heart, has always stood for a sense of justice, equality and equity. Nowhere are those principles more clearly shown and defined than in the translation of the High Court finding on Mabo into this Native Title Bill. It has shown that each of us in Australia has a role to play in questions of social justice and in determining the present and the future; that each of us needs to look to our past and to our history—not to deny it, not to pretend it did not happen, nor to feel guilty about it. It is not a question of guilt but simply an acknowledgment of the fact that these dreadful, degrading, outrageous, wicked things happened to individuals in our community. Many of us who stood by did not know they were happening or did not care or simply thought they would all go away. Those things do not change, but with this Native Title Bill there is an acknowledgment that they are part of our history. Social justice, the question of the acquisition of native land title, the issue that Aboriginals were the first Australians, that they are very much part of modern Australia and that they bring with them a very long history, a proud culture, a wealth of languages, music and art are all things which together make for a very diverse and very interesting Australia.

We pride ourselves on being enormously multicultural. What greater success can we have than bringing about a reconciliation of those very first Australians with modern and multicultural Australia so that, together, we can work to build a proud and just society. The economic benefits that European settlement has brought to enormous numbers of us through education, health programs and freedom enable us to participate in this great society and great democracy. Through this Native Title Bill we will see justice for all. It will be a first step along that path. All of us look back on a past of which we are not proud but which we can no longer deny. We look forward to a great future when Australians can hold their heads high in a just and free society in which the first Australians can be recognised for who they are and what they were—the first Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that we are debating tonight what the members of the Labor Party have said is—and perhaps it is—the most significant piece of legislation ever presented to this House. Yet before dinner we saw the extraordinary circumstance that the opposition and this House are to be denied full and frank debate on this matter. Worse still, we are to be subject to not being able to examine the bill clause by clause in the committee stage, which is what such an important bill demands.

PARA.TAB: It was also interesting to hear the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford) talk about how the High Court decision has to be accepted and about the futility of putting it to a referendum. Yet only a few years ago the High Court, in a similar case known as the Bushell case, found in favour of a veteran being able to receive certain pension entitlements because of a certain circumstance—and immediately the department and this government acted to try to reverse that court decision. So it is a lot of humbug for the government to come in here and talk in terms of a High Court decision.

It is also humbug for the government to suggest that the opposition is doing other than agreeing with the decision. We agree with the decision because, after all, the decision was that native title exists. In the amendment we recognise that there is native title. We also recognise, through that decision, that compensation has to be paid. That is quite all right. We also look at it from the point of view that it was a decision made for the Murray Islands in the Torres Strait and that it was a discrete case on which the judgment was made. To suggest that we can take that case onshore and apply it in that form is not nonsense, but there will be difficulties in implementation.

What we find wrong with this particular legislation is that it goes far beyond the Mabo decision and sets up an elitist situation in which many people in Australia will be disadvantaged. I speak here from the point of view that my electorate of Dawson has 3,224 indigenous Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders—the 17th greatest amount of any electorate in Australia. I also have in my electorate South Sea Islanders, who are not included in that figure. They are classed as ordinary Australians, and, at 3,500, number more than the indigenous people. These people have been denied and deprived for so long.

Over the last 30 or 40 years, Australia has seen a revelation in the manner in which whites and blacks in this country have come together. There has been reconciliation. The Aborigines have been able to retain their traditions and customs and yet act as Australians. Now we have this bill which, unfortunately, I believe is not going to do anything at all for those people who have been underprivileged, including my South Sea Islanders; they will not benefit from this bill.

I know that two claims from my electorate are currently before the High Court. They have the prospect of removing any certainty of investment and any certainty of tenure until they are heard. Those are two cases from my electorate alone. Goodness knows what the number is right throughout Australia.

Uncertainty was created by the decision in the first place. We have to admit that. I came across further evidence of uncertainty when at a seminar today I met a representative of one of the mining giants of Australia, Mount Isa Mines, who said that the company has the capacity to produce the gross domestic product of Australia in just one week. In other words, it provides one-fiftieth or two per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. It is also looking at the marvellous investments that could still be made if there were certainty, but it is plagued with this uncertainty.

One of the greatest and best mining companies in Australia has said that, with this uncertainty, there is no chance of people being prepared to risk capital, and so investments cannot be financed. It is interesting that this mining company is in the state of Queensland. We heard the Premier of that state, Mr Goss, loudly disclaim some of the earlier moves that were made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in this regard and force certain actions on him.

It is rather interesting that we have been told we have not got time to debate this bill in full. It has been only within the last month—even less than a month—that any definition has been given to the manner in which it might be transacted. The Prime Minister has made backflips of a standard for which he could have received an Olympic gold medal without much trouble at all. He has changed positions from one to the other, and now is saying, `Time for discussion has passed. Let's get on with it'.

It is interesting to look at some of the statistics that have been brought forward from very recent polls. Of the 1,200 people polled around Australia, 76 per cent said that people should be treated equally in terms of land title, with 20 per cent supporting different rights for native title holders. From these statistics we can see the level of concern among people about this legislation and the Mabo decision. Eighty-six per cent of those polled would be concerned if existing property titles of other Australians were put at risk; 85 per cent would be concerned if employment opportunities were reduced; 82 per cent would be concerned if economic development were delayed; 81 per would be concerned if mining investment were discouraged; and 78 per cent would be concerned if the Mabo decision resulted in large areas of Australia being claimed under native title by Aboriginal people. That is what the people of Australia are talking and thinking about. For us to think that after three or four weeks we know everything and are prepared to transact this now is beyond belief.

It is interesting that Mr Goss came into this argument roaring like a lion. But, although his state probably is second only to Western Australia in terms of how much it has to lose under this legislation, nothing is being said.

There is still talk amongst people that a referendum should be called on this subject. I happen to agree with that. We can talk in terms of equality and what we believe people think. However, I believe that a referendum would solve that once and for all.

I agree with the amendment moved by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) in that we do recognise native land title; there is no need for any further legislative action; and any legislative action should rest with the states, not the federal government. I have never believed in centralisation of these types of things.

I believe this legislation is an overkill for one particular reason: the government has a guilt complex and has tried to rush into this. It is not a guilt complex that I share. This legislation is an overkill and I am certain that further decisions of the High Court will be required to interpret it—and, goodness knows, there are a lot of people who have some doubts about the first decision. To say that we are going to commit further decisions to the High Court in this matter is beyond belief. It will be an absolute bonanza for the legal fraternity if these things are argued backwards and forwards.

In this debate a lot has been said by the government about Richard Court's legislation in Western Australia. I have to say that Richard Court has it right. He recognises native title and has moved to make sure that the leases already granted are validated. But he then turns immediately and says that, if a lessee leaves and a compensation claim is lodged, it will be taken through the courts and just compensation given. That is a fair flow which will give certainty to industry to keep going, knowing that the only impairment will be compensation paid at the other end.

This legislation fouls up that certainty. We now have a dual train of application that will stymie applications for mining or any other types leases into two courts, and it will be a month of Sundays before any decision whatsoever is made. If people took the hype out of this argument and looked at what was there, they would agree that perhaps we are looking at something that is more of an overkill than anything else and that we should be trying to improve and build on the past 30 years in which, as I have said, there has been great reconciliation with the Australian people. We should try to build on that.

Mr Speaker, as I understand it, within the context of this debate, people have taken the opportunity to cast racist slurs. I remember a question I was asked by a colleague of mine about Aboriginality. A lot of people want to know what Aboriginality is. Also, in the context of this bill, they want to know what tribality is—how long a person has belonged to a tribe and accepted the traditions of that tribe. As far as I know, the bill is entirely silent on that point.

Under the original application of `Aboriginality', as I understand it, if I were accepted by an Aboriginal community and were prepared to accept Aboriginal ways and live with that Aboriginal community, I could be classified as an Aboriginal. I believe that definition—not only of `Aboriginality' but also of `tribality'—is very important and should have been considered in the preparation of this bill. Instead, there will be great confusion, unnecessary delay and controversy as these things are decided through court channels.

In talking about racial implications, it is important to remember the claim made by the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) in his speech yesterday. He claimed that 99 per cent of the land owned by blacks in Queensland is reserve land, yet 90 per cent of the people on those reserves are not indigenous to those areas. Imagine what will happen with a claim for native title when the indigenous 10 per cent are recognised. What is going to happen to the 90 per cent who are not indigenous?

If people care to read the Notice Paper, question No. 717, which I put on notice, sets out in quite vivid detail the difficulties that exist within my own electorate where members of one tribe of Aborigines or Torres Strait Islanders are fighting against others. It is the old saying about `divide and rule'. Those problems exist in our present society. How much more racial will things be for the 10 per cent who have a land claim when 90 per cent do not? Goodness knows where this will end up. That sort of situation should have been looked at. There are also real problems in Ayr, where racial tensions are greater than ever.

Mr Speaker, because the time for debate has been cut short, we will not have any significant time in which to debate the major issues. However, I want to say that I am concerned about government funds being made available for the acquisition of land. I am worried about the level of compensation; there is no figure on that. I am concerned about access, not only to land, but also to sea frontages and offshore areas and about who will have access to them.

As I have said, I support the amendments because they are realistic. They put power back where it belongs—the states—and allow the Commonwealth to come in as an assistant and not a hindrance to what is proposed by them. I regret that time is so short that we will not have a full debate on this issue, but that is fairly typical of the lack of rights we have had in the House this session—with guillotines and loss of privileges to the duly elected representatives of people throughout Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the Native Title Bill affects the electorate of Kalgoorlie more than the rest of Australia put together. There has been no consultation with the Aboriginal people in my electorate, and there has been no consultation with me. Yes, it is true that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has consulted widely, but this consultation has been overwhelmingly with the Aboriginal industry. The so-called top leaders, lauded in the press and by the Prime Minister, mean nothing in my electorate where the real people live. My people were ignored. I want to read into Hansard a letter I received today from the chairman of the Yungngora Association in the Kimberleys. He writes:

SPEECH.PARA: There is some worry here regarding reports from the media that you may be expelled from the Labor Party for your decision to abstain from voting on the Federal Governments Mabo Legislation.

I am writing to you to offer our considered support in your abstaining from voting for the Mabo Legislation. Thank you for your commitment to our people in speaking out and opposing the Mabo legislation as we have requested. I have spoken to representative leaders of Biridu, Kadjina, Looma, Nelabublida, Warrimbah, and Yungngora communities which have also offered their support.

As our elected representative you have been the only consultation that we have had. You have visited Nookanbah and discussed the Mabo issue with us. We have had no such approaches by any other Government bodies or organisations.
On Saturday the 27th of November we are holding a meeting at Noonkanbah of concerned Aboriginals of the Fitzroy Valley and Gibb River areas regarding the Mabo legislation.

We have supported the Australian Labour Party for many years now and feel deprived of proper treatment by the ALP over Mabo. We are also concerned that our elected representative should be threatened with expulsion for representing the views of his electorate on matters of such significance. I will now be adding these issues to our agenda for consideration at the meeting.

Dickey Cox is a man of outstanding leadership. He is a man of authority in the Fitzroy Valley. His influence is real and the point of view he expresses is the point of view of the Aboriginal people in that region. I appreciate all the help I have had from Mr Cox and I am embarrassed that I find myself, through my own stupidity, in a position where I cannot do as I have so often stated I would. I know that this has caused embarrassment to Mr Cox and I deeply regret that. But, quite clearly, it is my own fault and no blame attaches to Mr Cox in any way, for I know that he has gone out into the community, seeking support for me.

PARA.TAB: I have painted myself into a corner whereby, if I do not vote for this legislation, I will be expelled under rule 7 of the Labor Party, thereby invoking all the plenary powers. While I am sure that Labor Party rules are like the law in general—the embodiment of everything that is excellent; it has no fault or flaw—I find that they are something of a movable feast. On the occasion of the ATSIC legislation I was actually asked by the then Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs not to vote; rather, I was to be given the opportunity to speak. It is the reverse on this occasion: I have the opportunity to speak but I am compelled to vote. I do not fear my expulsion; it would be a situation into which I got myself. However, it would be very embarrassing for people in Western Australia, some of whom have supported me for 20 years, and would hand a victory to elements in the Labor Party in Western Australia who, for a long time, have been seeking my expulsion. I do not intend to give them that privilege; nor do I intend to resile from this fight.

I believe that, at the best, this is silly legislation; at the worst, it is desperately dangerous legislation. The bill is certainly very complex and difficult to understand. Let me give an example which will show that neither the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) nor the Special Minister of State (Mr Walker) understand the bill. Both ministers have made reference to my having a conflict of interest because I hold shares in a mining company.

My shares in Cambridge Gulf are well documented; they were declared in my pecuniary interest schedule on 18 August, very shortly after I bought them. That mine has tremendous potential. I believe that it will provide employment to Aboriginal people in Wyndham and earn billions and billions of dollars in exports for this nation. But this mine is in the sea—a dredging operation—a fact that both ministers should have known because all ministers were briefed on this matter. Because that mine is in the sea it is not affected by this legislation because clause 25(i)(ii) limits the operation of this bill to the low water mark. There never was and never could be a conflict of interest. It is clear that either the ministers did not know this—which means that they did not understand the bill—or they were being reprehensible and irresponsible with the truth. That is something that they will have to decide.

Let there be no doubt, the complexity of this bill will inevitably lead to litigation and delays as we seek out who has title and who has not. I have anthropological and ethnological advice from Western Australia which says that it is possible, under the terms of the High Court decision, that nobody will be entitled to native title—not one single person would succeed. However, that would not stop the litigation and the inevitable costs that would flow from it—costs which would be borne by the taxpayers.Unfortunately, while we pay the costs of those who are litigating, people defending themselves will find it much harder to meet their costs. It is true that there is a clause in the bill which says that money can be made available for this defence; but, believe me, it will be very hard to get.

The objections from the Aboriginal people I speak to, I think, are fairly sound. They say that, under the present regime, they can negotiate with mining companies at their own pace. Now they will be hurried. There are schedules to be met. They say that some companies, unethically, will obfuscate, delay and force them into arbitration. I think this is quite conceivable; it could happen. There is no doubt that the process is going to be complex. It is going to set Aboriginal against Aboriginal, black against white, and black against black and white—there is no doubt about that.

I want to say here and now that I believe the High Court ruling was irresponsible. It was a ruling from a rogue High Court. But let us look at what was actually said. One judge, Mr Justice Dawson, got it right. He said that native title existed but it had no status in law. I think that was a very accurate description. Three judges said that it applied to the Murray Islands; three judges said it applied also to the mainland. So in terms of judges saying it applied to the mainland, there was a four to three decision saying it did not. Yet we have seen the government rush into legislation.

The common law is not about social justice; the common law is about the good governance of a country. If we make the common law a vehicle for social justice, we are going to run into enormous difficulties because what is just for one will be unjust for another. I believe common law should be changed only very gradually. It should be a process of evolution. But here we have a High Court that has stood it on its head. For 200 years we have had fixed law and the High Court stands it on its head. A responsible government would have said, `Thank you, your honours'—and then legislated to extinguish native title, as we thought it was already extinguished, and paid compensation.

`Shock! Horror!', I hear. The truth is that native title has been extinguished for most of Australia and for most Aboriginal people. It would be entirely equitable to extinguish it completely and agree to pay the compensation. If the compensation were paid according to the High Court terms, the payout would be negligible. The costs to the taxpayer would be negligible. There would be no time delay because things would go on without the inhibitions that will now obtain.

It has been said that I have supported Richard Court. In fact, what Richard Court has done is follow the recommendations I made long before the Western Australian parliament came to its decision. I think Court is in fact wrong to give any form of title. We should simply have stopped at eliminating it and paying the compensation. This is a view that has wide support from Aboriginal people because they do not want other Aboriginals making claims on their land. My communities are saying now that they are going to put into their constitutions bans on any more excisions on their properties. They are going to change their constitutions to lock up voting in their communities so that outsiders cannot interfere, because they fear the influence of other people.

They also fear the legislation for other reasons. They believe the money that the government has said it is going to allocate for its social justice pact—a sum so far undeclared; a sum which the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) says we will need additional taxes to pay—is going to be paid through ATSIC and, we are told, through other Aboriginal organisations, for which we read `land councils'. My Aboriginal people know that if this is the case they will not benefit from the money.

There is $2 billion a year going into the Aboriginal industry today. The Aboriginal people are not the beneficiaries of this money, and they know it. If there is to be any social justice in this nation it should be in the proper application of that $2 billion. This is what Aboriginal people want.

I have a few words to say about racism. Very early in my career in this House—in about 1982—I served on the Aboriginal affairs caucus committee. It was a fairly tedious task. We had a visit from some Aboriginal people from Sydney who were concerned about the Aboriginal Arts Board and what they saw as the illegal use of $2 million—there was $2 million missing. After listening for a while, I said, `If half of what you say is true, some of these people should be in gaol'; whereupon the chairman, former Senator Ruth Coleman, jumped up and said, `I'm sick of your racist statements. You can't put these people in gaol. They're Aboriginals'. I said, `I don't care whether they're Aboriginals. If they're crooks, they should be in gaol'. To a person, this Aboriginal group jumped up and said, `That's what we think'. That senator's statement was the most racist and the most patronising that I had heard in a long time. The word `racism' is bandied about today. It is used to humiliate and to try to stop people expressing a point of view. I have devised a description of a racist: a racist today is anyone who wins an argument with a multiculturalist.

This legislation is going to cause enormous conflict. If we had goodwill and reasonable people, it is possible that the bill could work. I remember when the Northern Territory land rights legislation was put through. The minister concerned assured people that not more than 10 per cent of the land would be claimed. Look at the map today. The truth is that there are no people of goodwill out there; there is no goodwill in the Aboriginal industry. They have an insatiable appetite and that appetite is for power; it is for sovereignty.

I stood for election in 1980. I toured the Kimberleys in 1979 and I was advised to talk to an influential Aboriginal person attached to the Kimberley Land Council. He told me he would go out and support me if I was prepared to back sovereignty—an independent black state in the Kimberleys. I told him where to get off. I read him the riot act and I said I would not have a bar of it. As it turned out, the state government had an election two weeks before the federal election. The Aboriginal people voted at the state election and they did not bother about the federal election. So the outcome was indecisive.

Aboriginal people say to me that they are frightened of sovereignty. They know. They hear these stories. They do not want a black state. They say, `We are Australians. We want to be part of Australia. We don't want what other Australians don't get'. That is not a view we get in the cities. These are Aboriginal people out there trying their damnedest to make things work. They are being inhibited by the operations of ATSIC.

I have criticised ATSIC before. It is a bureaucracy of monstrous size. When we scrapped the Department of Aboriginal Affairs it was monstrously overstaffed in Canberra. It had about 125 employees. Now there are over 600. What should have happened is that we should have put people out into the state capitals and then out into the provinces. We did not do this. We have created this monster bureaucracy which gobbles up money at an unprecedented rate and seems to actively deny Aboriginal people the ability to become self-sufficient.

I only wish that I was in the position of stormy Normie Foster in relation to this bill. If my vote would make a difference, I would cross the floor on this legislation. But, unfortunately, it does not make a difference. It is more important, I believe, that I stay within the Labor Party to counter those existing elements which I think are very destructive; those elements which I understand have been rejoicing in Western Australia about my imminent demise.

This is not the end of the story by a long way. We have not yet got this legislation through the Senate. It may be possible that, for once in their lives, the Greens will do something useful. If they can lock this up in a committee for any length of time, I believe public opinion will steamroll this bill and it will be consigned to the garbage bin of history where it belongs.

I feel extremely humiliated about the statements I have made. I have had to make these judgments and I make them on behalf of the people who have supported me, not on my own behalf. It is a humiliating experience. I think those who know me would have to concede that I am generally a person of my word. In this case, I have certainly proved to be less than that. It is with no pride at all that I will be sitting on this side of the House in the division.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—I agree it is a shame. It is a shame that I will have to live with. But it is for other reasons that I will be sitting on this side in the division. Also, if I am expelled, there will not be much of a voice to put the view of genuine Aboriginal people.
—They won't expel you.
—Actually, you do not know the machinations of the party. I want to illustrate how this situation came about—
—I am sorry, but the time allotted for the remaining stages of the bill has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Dr Hewson's amendment) stand part of the question.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question put:
That the bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the remaining stages of the bill be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF CSIRO SITE, PROSPECT, NEW SOUTH WALES

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) representing the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to parliament: redevelopment of CSIRO site at Prospect, New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed work, recommended by the public works committee, involves the redevelopment of a site at Prospect, New South Wales, for the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, CSIRO. The project is consistent with the CSIRO's accommodation strategy which aims to progressively consolidate CSIRO research activities on a limited number of sites within major regional centres to facilitate collaborative research, share scarce and costly resources, and reduce operating costs and overheads.

PARA.TAB: The project involves the construction of a 2,200 square metre, two-storey laboratory and administration building; a 500 square metre animal house and associated yards; a research laboratory-amenities building, and poultry sheds in a compound providing a facility for poultry research; a 250 square metre, 126-seat lecture theatre; extensions to the existing library and post mortem building; alterations and upgrading of existing buildings; and associated demolition, roadworks, car parks, landscaping and site services.

The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in July 1993. The committee tabled its favourable report on 17 November last recommending the redevelopment at an estimated cost of $11.6 million at August 1992 prices. In addition, the committee recommended that the government give consideration to transferring the Wool Research Development Corporation's equity in the site at Prospect to CSIRO. I thank the committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: UPGRADING OF MOUNT WELLINGTON BROADCASTING FACILITIES, HOBART

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) representing the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to parliament: upgrading of Mount Wellington broadcasting facilities, Hobart.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed work, recommended by the public works committee, involves the upgrading of Mount Wellington broadcasting facilities in Hobart, Tasmania, for the National Transmission Agency. The project is consistent with the aims of the National Transmission Agency to provide the public with ongoing access to reception of the television and radio services of the ABC and the SBS, and providing capacity for the introduction of new services.

PARA.TAB: The proposal involves construction of a tower consisting of a 70-metre tapered concrete shaft supporting a 60-metre steel frame upon which is mounted several transmission antennas and a protective fibreglass radome. The work also includes alterations and upgrading of the existing transmitter building, demolition of the existing broadcasting tower, ancillary towers and masts and related site rehabilitation works.

The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in August 1993. The committee tabled its report on 18 November last recommending the development at an estimated cost of $13.095 million in September 1993 prices. The National Transmission Agency has noted the committee's recommendations and provides the following comments. The NTA has discussed the use of VHF or UHF transmission with Tasmanian Television and on several occasions has offered the company an agreement to share facilities on the new tower using a VHF or a UHF channel. Tasmanian Television has so far declined to accept these offers. In addition, the NTA is also consulting with the company concerning sharing facilities at other NTA sites in Tasmania.

The NTA also agrees with proposals made by the Hobart City Council, and is developing an environmental management plan in consultation with its contractor for the Mount Wellington project, Telecom Australia's broadcasting division, which incorporates the principles developed and put forward by the council in discussion with the agency. The plan will take into consideration the effect upon the Fern Tree community of traffic and road maintenance problems arising from the upgrading work. I thank the committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL CENTRES AT BRISBANE AND MELBOURNE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) representing the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to parliament: air traffic control centres at Brisbane and Melbourne.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed work, recommended by the Public Works Committee, involves the development of air traffic control centres at Brisbane and Melbourne. The development is part of the Australian advanced air traffic system. The proposal involves construction of new air traffic control centres of about 7,500 square metres; associated roadworks, car parks, engineering services and landscaping; minor modifications to the Cairns air traffic centre; modifications and refurbishment of the existing area approach control centre in Sydney, including upgrading of power supply and airconditioning; and modifications to the area approach control centres in Adelaide and Perth. The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in July 1993, and the committee tabled its report on 18 November 1993 recommending the development at an estimated cost of $50 million.

PARA.TAB: The Civil Aviation Authority has noted the committee's recommendations and provides the following comments. The Civil Aviation Authority has made a commitment to the PWC and to the Australian Council for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled, ACROD, to consult and take account of ACROD's suggestions in the detailed design of the air traffic control centres for Melbourne and Brisbane. The CAA will also undertake to brief the committee on the detailed design of each centre following the awarding of the contract. I thank the committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARTIAL REFURBISHMENT OF STAGE 1, COMMONWEALTH CENTRE FOR AUSTRALIAN ESTATE MANAGEMENT, HOBART

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) representing the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to parliament: partial refurbishment of stage 1, Commonwealth Centre.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed work, recommended by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, is the partial refurbishment of stage 1 Hobart Commonwealth Centre for Australian Estate Management of the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services. The total area proposed for refurbishment is approximately 4,600 square metres of net lettable space, comprising five upper floors, floors 9 to 13, part of the ground floor, and the upgrade of base building services—mechanical, electrical and fire protection—including the removal of asbestos from the 14th floor plant room at an estimated total cost not exceeding $8.3 million. The project is expected to take at least 10 months to complete.

PARA.TAB: The refurbished accommodation is to be leased to the Departments of Social Security, the Arts and Administrative Services and Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, together with the National Media Liaison Service and the Merit Protection and Review Agency.The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in July 1993. The committee tabled its report on 16 November 1993 and has recommended the refurbishment proceed at an estimated total cost of $8.3 million.

In its report the committee made a number of recommendations which I will comment on as follows. Firstly, that floors one to nine be refurbished as part of this proposal. In August 1991 the government approved the development of cost estimates and detailed design for the refurbishment of the entire stage 1 building. Later investigations established that a refurbishment of the entire building was not viable due to insufficient tenant interest for vacant space.

In December 1992, a reduced scope of refurbishment work was agreed by the government, subject to tenant commitment, to occupy the refurbished space. Negotiations are continuing with several Commonwealth government agencies with a view to obtaining in-principle commitment to lease vacant accommodation in the stage 1 Hobart Commonwealth Centre upon expiration of their current leases in privately owned accommodation. Once this commitment has been obtained, Australian Estate Management will be in a position to seek funding for the refurbishment of floors one to nine. It is considered inappropriate to commit scarce funds and resources to refurbish the remaining vacant floors before first obtaining commitment from tenant departments.

Secondly, that the Minister responsible for the Department of the Arts and Administrative Services review the policy relating to the provision of office accommodation for Commonwealth departments. The management of the Commonwealth's real estate portfolio has undergone significant changes in recent years. In particular, the management of the Commonwealth office estate has been commercialised, with departments and agencies being responsible for the payment of rent for their occupation of Commonwealth owned office accommodation. Whilst the government has benefited through the freedom and autonomy granted to individual departments and agencies in their property decision making, it is recognised that there is a need to regularly review and assess the effectiveness of the property reforms.

As part of the 1993-94 budget deliberations, it was agreed that AEM, in conjunction with the Department of Finance, should review the financial and operational arrangements pertaining to the management of the Commonwealth's investment in real estate. The review will examine funding arrangements, reporting requirements, the impact of public sector reforms, the commercialisation process, the impact of private sector competition and optimum strategies for meeting the government's policy objectives.

The review is under way currently and has been staged to enable the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services to report to the government by the end of this year on the appropriateness of current funding and reporting arrangements for the office estate. Stage 2 of the review will be undertaken during 1994 and will examine all areas of the Commonwealth estate and the organisational structure of Australian Estate Management.

Thirdly, that Australian Estate Management conduct an audit to assess the effectiveness of the comprehensive energy management strategy. An audit will be implemented on all refurbished floors to measure energy usage commencing approximately 12 months after occupation. The data obtained from this audit will be used to assess the actual building performance against the predetermined energy targets.

Fourthly, that Australian Estate Management continues consultations with the Nursing Mothers Association. AEM is continuing consultations with the Nursing Mothers Association to ensure its requirements for nursing mothers rooms within the Hobart Commonwealth Centre are satisfied.

Fifthly, that Australian Estate Management re-examine the provision of toilets for disabled persons. The total number of disabled person toilets proposed is above that required by the building code of Australia.

Australian Estate Management will, however, re-examine the provision of toilets for disabled persons and determine whether the number could be increased. I thank the committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Punch The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PUNCH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) representing the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan), I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to parliament: rationalisation of inner Melbourne accommodation.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed work, recommended by the Public Works Committee, involves the rationalisation of inner-Melbourne accommodation, RIMA, for the Department of Defence. The RIMA project involves the refurbishment of buildings located within the Victoria Barracks precinct in St Kilda Road, Melbourne. The upgrading of accommodation within the precinct is one major element of a larger capital facility project directed at rationalising defence owned and leased property assets in the inner-Melbourne area.

PARA.TAB: The project involves major refurbishment of buildings A, B, C, D, G and H to provide approximately 30,000 square metres of good quality commercial office accommodation, fully airconditioned with communications and data reticulation to individual work spaces throughout. The proposal was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works in July 1993. The committee tabled its report on 17 November 1993 recommending the redevelopment at an estimated cost of $27 million.

The Department of Defence has noted the committee's recommendations and provides the following comments. Victoria Barracks is Commonwealth owned. In the case of the residual space to be accommodated by the defence element in the inner-Melbourne area, the selection of a preferred option will depend on the outcome of market opportunities available to Defence at the time of negotiation.

The prototype workstation layout has generally been well received. A number of lessons have been learnt since its introduction. Further analysis of the size and configuration is proposed to ensure that defence elements are accommodated without compromising work function or efficiency, but at the same time achieving maximum utilisation of space available. Discussion with relevant unions in regard to the utilisation of the workstation relative to individual buildings is proposed in the coming weeks.

A meaningful dialogue is being developed with the Heritage Commission to ensure that heritage sensitivities throughout the refurbishment program are respected. Defence has engaged a heritage expert to protect its interests and those of the commission throughout the development. Defence has agreed that it and the primary contractor will liaise with local Commonwealth Employment Service offices to encourage the use of locally registered unemployed tradespeople on the project.

Defence has also agreed to the committee's recommendation regarding the provision of recreational/leisure sporting facilities. Given the predominant younger, more athletic conscious work force, defence is keen to achieve an efficient working environment with due regard for recreational/leisure sporting facilities. However, it is unlikely at the time that all these facilities will be able to be met from within the $27 million cost budget. I thank the committee for its report and commend the motion to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER AFFAIRS

TALKER.NAME: Mr TICKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill follows on from the changes to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989 which were passed by the parliament during the autumn sittings earlier this year and more recently at the commencement of the current budget sittings. It gives effect to the remaining major changes to the act that are necessary to implement the totality of the reform package flowing from the commission's review of the operation of the act.

PARA.TAB: The amendments in this bill, together with those which have already received assent, establish a leaner, tighter and more effective organisation, with devolved decision making going hand-in-hand with improved accountability. As a result, ATSIC's ability to provide a vehicle for indigenous self-determination becomes even more firmly established. As we have seen in the last few weeks, that means ATSIC's evolution as an organisation able not only to manage Commonwealth programs for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities but also to negotiate on policy with an independent and forceful political voice. This bill provides, in essence, for:

SPEECH.PARA: major changes to arrangements for the Torres Strait, including the establishment of a Torres Strait Regional Authority (TSRA);
streamlining the financial provisions of the act, one of the effects of which will be to facilitate the further devolution of authority to regional councils;
strengthening the role of the Office of Evaluation and Audit; and
establishing an independent electoral review panel.

Honourable members will recall that, when the second package of amendments was introduced at the commencement of the current sittings, it was foreshadowed that a further bill encompassing these further reforms would be introduced during these sittings.

PARA.TAB: This third package of amendments, like those introduced earlier this year, flow from recommendations contained in the commission's report to me on the operation of the act.
