These amendments, which build on the reforms already agreed to by parliament, will further enhance the representative nature of the organisation, strengthen the role of the regional councils as the linchpins of empowerment for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples and reinforce the commission's established commitment to high standards of scrutiny and accountability. The reforms are based on the government's commitment to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-determination and our confidence in indigenous people managing their own affairs.

I turn now to the major provisions of the present bill and in doing so I draw to honourable members' attention that the bill is large and it is not possible to set out in great detail many of the changes. Those that are of a substantive nature I will deal with more fully.

The bill substantially widens the powers of the Office of Evaluation and Audit, increasing the ability of the minister and the commission to have examined the financial management of ATSIC funded organisations. It provides for an expansion in the functions of the Office of Evaluation and Audit to include the evaluation and audit of the operations of Aboriginal Hostels Limited, the Commercial Development Corporation, and the proposed Torres Strait Regional Authority, as well as the commission.

Additionally, the bill includes provision to enable the minister and the commission to direct the Office of Evaluation and Audit to investigate the operations of regional councils, in addition to the above bodies, and in certain cases, ATSIC and Torres Strait Regional Authority grant and loan recipients. Provision is also made for the Director of Evaluation and Audit to have greater powers to examine documents.

The bill also includes a number of clauses relating to the Director of Evaluation and Audit amendments, including provision for the period of appointment, remuneration and allowances, leave of absence, disclosure of interests, resignation, termination of appointment of the Director of Evaluation and Audit, aligning these with similar provisions for other full-time statutory office-holders under the principal act. Provision is also made for an acting director and for the director to be immune from personal liability in an action or other proceeding for damages in relation to anything done in his or her official capacity. These provisions are largely administrative in nature and serve to correct an anomaly in the existing act.

The bill amends the period of appointment of the chief executive officer by setting a maximum period of appointment rather than a minimum. This is in accordance with standard appointment provisions in most legislation establishing statutory appointments. It also requires the chief executive officer to report his or her interests to the commission chairperson rather than the full board of the commission.

The bill includes amendments relating to membership of advisory committees and the members of the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board. The amendments include provisions for the disclosure of interests at meetings, resignations, and termination of the members of these bodies.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments relating to Regional Council Administrators

PARA.TAB: Provision is made in the bill to set the terms and conditions for an administrator to hold office. This was omitted from the principal act and is largely an administrative matter. The provisions include full-time appointment consistent with the move to full-time regional council chairpersons, disclosure of interests, resignation, leave of absence, and suspension and termination of appointment.

Consistent with the government's commitment to greater self-determination and self-management, provision has been made for the commission rather than the minister to appoint administrators. Provision is also made for an acting administrator and for the commission to appoint a replacement administrator if there is a vacancy in an office of the administrator.

There are a number of amendments relating to the Commercial Development Corporation. These are largely technical in nature and tidy up the principal act to bring it more into line with current drafting procedures. The bill provides for at least one director to be an ATSIC commissioner, for the period of appointments not to exceed five years, and for the termination of appointment of a director of the corporation.

The bill includes provision for exempting ATSIC from the payment of excise duty which would otherwise be payable by the commission, or by any other person, on goods that are for use by the commission. The current arrangement whereby ATSIC is required to pay excise duty is inconsistent with other government agencies and it is only reasonable that the act be amended to bring the organisation into line with other Commonwealth departments and agencies.

It is important to note that AHL is not a statutory organisation established under the principal act but a company funded through ATSIC. The government considers that it is essential that AHL be subject to the same level of scrutiny and accountability and to the same administrative review mechanisms as ATSIC. Provisions are included in the bill to this end. Honourable members will note that the bill before them includes provision for division 2 of part XI of the Audit Act 1901 to apply to Aboriginal Hostels Ltd and that certain decisions of an administrative character made at the director level are made subject to the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

In the interests of privacy and in recognition of the very sensitive personal information that may become available to certain office holders within ATSIC, the government has agreed with the commission's proposal that section 90 of the principal act be extended to apply to the Director of Evaluation and Audit, a member of the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board, a regional councillor, a member of an advisory committee established under section 96 and an administrator. It will also extend the secrecy provisions to the Torres Strait Regional Authority when it commences on 1 July 1994.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Regional Council Estimates Processes and Reporting Requirements

PARA.TAB: The bill includes provisions to strengthen the annual reporting requirements of regional councils. As a result of the proposed amendments, regional councils will be obliged to provide to the commission an annual report dealing with the operations of the regional council during the year, the implementation during that year of the regional plan, details of grants made from regional council budgets during the year and any other matters relating to that year as the commission determines in writing. The annual report and regional plan are required to be made available for inspection and purchase by residents of the region.

Additionally, provision is made in the bill to require regional councils to have regard to their regional plans when preparing their draft budgets. This linkage is considered necessary because of the increased powers which regional councils will have over the disbursement of commission funds.

The bill makes provision for a number of changes to the power of delegation under the principal act. Some of the changes relate to administrative matters. I refer in particular to the proposal to enable the commission to delegate to the Director of Evaluation and Audit its powers for the appointment of consultants under section 56 and also to enable the chief executive officer power to sub-delegate functions or powers to a member of the staff of the commission. However, the more important aspect of the amendments relates to the enhanced responsibilities given to regional councils.

One of the key recommendations of the commission in its report to me was the need for greater empowerment of regional councils. The bill provides for the commission to delegate to a regional council its powers to approve funds and issue guarantees.

These powers are not unfettered. It is important that honourable members note that these delegated powers will be subject to any written directions by the commission and are accompanied by sanctions to protect the interests of the government, ATSIC and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. Provision is also made to empower the commission chairperson to suspend delegations to regional councils in certain cases.

Another of the key recommendations of the commission was the need to simplify funding powers of the commission. This bill spells out the new and simplified arrangements. I must reiterate to honourable members that it is neither the commission's nor the government's intention to in any way water down accountability requirements either to the parliament or to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people whom the commission represents. Indeed, the effect of the amendments is to enhance that accountability.

We are concerned, however, over the current complex and inflexible provisions and propose that they be amended to enable the commission to more successfully fulfil the functions imposed upon it by the principal act. As the government has stated on a number of occasions, true self-determination is fundamental to the success of the commission and it is in pursuit of this that these amendments are put before the parliament.

In essence, the changes enable the commission to make a grant of money or grant an interest in land or grant an interest in personal property or make a loan of money to any body corporate or unincorporated organisation. In certain cases this power extends to individuals. Regional councils and the Torres Strait Regional Authority cannot be recipients. This provision is accompanied by a requirement that such grants, loans and guarantees may only be made for the purpose of furthering the social, economic or cultural development of Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders.

For purposes of enhanced scrutiny the bill also requires the commission to formulate decision making principles about the giving of grants, loans and guarantees. Funding must only be made in accordance with these decision making principles. The chief executive officer must cause a notice of the making of decision making principles to be published in the Gazette. He must also ensure that copies of the decision making principles which are in force are given to each regional council and are available for inspection and purchase at each of the commission's offices.

One of the important technical amendments which the commission has suggested is the need to remove the direct link between the commission's corporate plan and the procedures for the engagement of consultants. The bill proposes that this link be severed. Instead, the commission will be required to set out the criteria and standard terms and conditions for the engagement of consultants by way of written instrument and to notify the making of the instrument in the Gazette.

In the second amending bill passed earlier in these sittings, wards were created for the purposes of electing regional councillors. This present bill includes consequent provisions which prohibit a member of the staff of the commission or a consultant to the commission standing for election, or being elected, as a member for a regional council ward.

The bill provides for simplification of the draft budget, and the estimates processes involved, for both the commission and regional councils. Consistent with the proposed streamlining of funding provisions, the bill reduces the number of elements required in the commission's estimates of expenditure. Equally important, the bill facilitates a greater devolution of funding to regional council budgets by enabling the commission to earmark elements of regional council allocations for particular purposes.

As I have mentioned earlier, both the commission and the government wish to maintain and enhance the accountability requirements. Included in this bill are amendments which strengthen the responsibility of the commission and regional councils. The bill provides for the commission to remove regional councils from office in certain situations. These include the regional council's failure to perform its functions, failure to comply with the draft budgets requirements, failure to meet the annual reporting requirement, or contravention of a delegation from the commission.

The provisions require that, before this power is invoked, the commission must provide the regional council with a notice setting out the reasons for its proposed course of action and giving 28 days in which to show cause why the regional councillors should not be removed. It is hoped that any dispute in connection with these matters can be resolved within the 28-day period and that it will not be necessary to remove the regional councillors.

Provision is also made for an appointment of an administrator to administer the affairs of the regional council where the regional councillors have been removed from office. It is my intention, as the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, to make election rules to provide for a by-election to be held within a period of twelve months from the date that a regional council is removed under the new section 123A.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Provisions relating to Torres Strait Islanders

PARA.TAB: This is perhaps one of the most significant changes proposed in the bill. The government is taking up the commission's recommendation that the Torres Strait region be dealt with separately from other regions and has included in the bill clauses establishing a Torres Strait Regional Authority. This authority will supersede the Torres Strait Regional Council. This clause of the bill is quite lengthy and I ask that honourable members study it carefully as it is a significant demonstration of the government's commitment to the empowerment of one of Australia's two distinct indigenous peoples.

In effect, this will give significantly greater powers and impose significantly higher levels of accountability upon the Torres Strait body. The Torres Strait Regional Authority will now have powers and functions similar to those of the commission in relation to indigenous peoples in the Torres Strait.

As I foreshadowed when I introduced the ATSIC amendment bill No. 2 earlier in the current sittings, this bill contains a further major reform in the establishment of an independent electoral review process. The review panel established by this bill will have two distinct functions: firstly, to review and determine the boundaries of the regions and wards and the grouping of regions into zones; and, secondly, to review and report to the minister on the electoral systems established by the act.

As far as the review of boundaries is concerned, the panel will call for submissions from interested persons and make draft boundary recommendations. An augmented review panel will then consider appeals against the draft boundary recommendations and make final boundary recommendations. The minister will be required to give effect to the final boundary recommendations.

The boundary review process is modelled on the redistribution committees established by the Australian Electoral Act and is designed to ensure that the panel and the augmented panel are not only independent and objective but are seen to be independent and objective.

Honourable members will recall that when I presented the first ATSIC amendment bill to the House in May this year, I stated that, consistent with the principles of self-determination and empowerment which were the basis for the establishment of ATSIC, the provisions allowing the minister to choose the chairperson and two other commissioners would be repealed. The effect of these proposals was that the commission would consist of 17 elected commissioners who would elect their chairperson. Honourable members will recall that these amendments were overturned in the Senate.

I note with great pleasure that, by amendment to this bill, the Senate has agreed to reinstate these provisions, albeit commencing from the zone elections to be held following the round of regional council elections to be held in 1996. From that time, the commission will comprise 17 elected commissioners who will in turn choose their own chairperson from amongst themselves. Whatever our views might be on the Native Title Bill, I am sure all agree that the chairperson, Lois O'Donohue, has been a magnificent Australian over recent weeks.

It is also with great pleasure that I note that the Senate has, on the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats, supported by the government and the Western Australian Greens, decided to include a preamble in the ATSIC Act. When the first ATSIC Bill was proposed in 1988 by my predecessor, Mr Gerry Hand, honourable members will recall that the government proposed that the act contain a preamble clearly stating the principles upon which the act was to be based. Unfortunately, the preamble did not survive the passage of the original bill through the Senate.

The preamble which the Senate has now agreed to is consistent with the proposed preamble contained in the Native Title Bill 1993. It describes the dispossession of the indigenous inhabitants of this country and the devastating effects of that dispossession. It goes on to outline the reasons why the ATSIC Act was enacted. I congratulate the Senate on its initiative to amend this bill to incorporate a preamble which was a notable omission from the original act.

This final package of reforms gives effect to the remaining aspects of the major changes to the act contained in the commission's review report to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs on the operation of the act. I am aware that the bill is quite a complex one, ranging from minor technical amendments to fairly significant changes. As a whole it fulfils the government's commitment to implement the commission's recommendations in relation to the operation of ATSIC.

I present the explanatory memorandum for the information of honourable members. I take this opportunity to thank the highly professional work of ATSIC officers—in particular, Mr Shane Hoffman, who is in the chamber tonight—over the past year in giving effect to these amendments. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Sharp) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill implements arrangements that have been agreed with New Zealand to facilitate obtaining evidence from New Zealand for use in Australian proceedings and from Australia for use in New Zealand proceedings, and to facilitate proof of each country's laws and official acts and documents.

PARA.TAB: At present, unless a witness is willing to attend voluntarily, evidence is obtained between Australia and New Zealand by means of a letter of request to the other country's judicial authorities or arrangements for evidence to be taken on commission. These methods are more cumbersome and expensive, and much less satisfactory, than obtaining the evidence of the witness directly in the course of the hearing.

The arrangements implemented in the bill provide for evidence to be given in the course of a hearing by requiring attendance of the witness at the court, or by evidence being given by video link or telephone. Broadly similar arrangements to those contained in the bill were implemented in 1990 in relation to a very narrow range of competition law cases. These 1990 arrangements are replaced by the new and broader schemes in this bill. These arrangements reflect the close relationship between New Zealand and Australia especially in, but not limited to, the economic area. There is a need for Australia-New Zealand legal cooperation to keep pace with developments in other areas. This bill provides for:

SPEECH.PARA: .Australian subpoenas to be served in New Zealand;
.enforcement of New Zealand subpoenas served in Australia;
.Australian courts to take evidence by video link or telephone from New Zealand;
.sanctions and administrative arrangements in support of New Zealand courts taking evidence from Australia by video link or telephone; and
.judicial notice to be taken of New Zealand laws and facilitated proof of New Zealand public and official acts and documents.

Complementary New Zealand legislation was introduced in the New Zealand parliament on 21 September 1993. The arrangements relating to subpoenas will apply in proceedings except criminal proceedings and family law proceedings. These exclusions were sought by New Zealand. The other arrangements will apply in all kinds of civil and criminal proceedings.

PARA.TAB: The states and territories were consulted in the development of these arrangements, and gave broad support to them. To provide flexibility for states and territories the arrangements for trans-Tasman subpoenas and taking evidence by video link or telephone will not apply automatically to state and territory courts. They will apply to prescribed state and territory courts, as well as to all federal courts.

The provisions of the bill relating to judicial notice of New Zealand laws and proof of New Zealand public and official acts and documents will apply to all Australian courts. Appropriate safeguards and protection are provided for persons who are involved in proceedings under the bill.

Under the bill an Australian subpoena can be served in New Zealand if leave for service is given by a superior court judge. In deciding whether to grant leave, the judge must take into account the significance of the evidence to be given or the document or thing to be produced by the witness, and whether it could be obtained by other means without significantly greater expense, and with less inconvenience to the witness. Safeguards for witnesses include:

SPEECH.PARA: .The subpoena must be served no later than a day specified by the judge and must be accompanied by a copy of the order granting leave, and an information notice setting out the witness's rights and obligations under the subpoena; and
.the witness's reasonable expenses of complying with the subpoena must be paid or tendered to the witness a reasonable time before the time for compliance.

In addition, a special procedure is provided for a person served with a subpoena to apply to it aside. An application to set aside may be made by fax to the appropriate court. It may be determined without a hearing if neither party objects, and must be conducted by video link or telephone if the person served so requests. The subpoena must be set aside if the person cannot reasonably attain necessary travel document or compliance would expose the person to criminal or civil sanction—exception a civil penalty under the Trade Practices Act. Grounds on which the subpoena may be set aside include hardship or serious inconvenience.If the subpoena only requires production of documents or things, it must permit compliance by producing the documents or things at a registry of the High Court of New Zealand.

PARA.TAB: The bill obliges persons in Australia who are served with a New Zealand subpoena in accordance with the bill and with New Zealand law to comply with it. Failure to comply without proper excuse is taken to be a contempt of the Federal Court.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Video link or telephone evidence from New Zealand

PARA.TAB: The bill enables courts to direct that evidence be taken or submissions made by video link or telephone from New Zealand where it is more convenient to do so. Such a direction may only be made where suitable facilities are available or can reasonably be made available. Courts are authorised to make orders for the payment of expenses incurred in connection with taking evidence or making submissions by video link or telephone.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Video link or telephone evidence from Australia

PARA.TAB: The bill authorises New Zealand courts to receive evidence or submissions by video link or telephone from Australia. In relation to the taking of video link or telephone evidence by a New Zealand court from a person in Australia, the bill:

SPEECH.PARA: .authorises a New Zealand court to administer an oath or affirmation to a witness in Australia;
.confers the same protection on persons participating in the proceedings as such persons would have a proceeding before the Federal Court;
.applies section 35 of the Crimes Act 1914, which relates to false evidence, to evidence; and
.creates offences relating to misconduct while evidence is being given in Australia by video link or telephone.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Judicial notice of New Zealand laws and proof of New Zealand public and official acts and documents

PARA.TAB: Under the bill all Australian courts are to take judicial notice of the content and commencement of New Zealand laws and of proclamations and orders made by the Governor-General of New Zealand. It also includes provisions to facilitate the proof in Australian courts of New Zealand public and official acts and documents.

The bill, especially its provisions relating to subpoenas and video link evidence, will make a significant reduction to the cost of litigation before Australian courts involving trans-Tasman elements and also improve the quality of evidence available to courts in such cases.The bill is expected to have little impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I table the explanatory memorandum for the bill. I commend the bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Williams) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: EVIDENCE AND PROCEDURE (NEW ZEALAND) (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill presented by Mr Duncan, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr DUNCAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is consequential upon the Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Bill 1993. It sets out transitional arrangements for that bill and makes consequential amendments to the Evidence Act 1905 and the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976. The bill is expected to have little impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.I table the explanatory memorandum for the bill. I commend the bill to the House.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Williams) adjourned.
Bill presented by Mr Sciacca, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SCIACCA
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The charter of the Department of Social Security is to deliver social security entitlements with fairness, courtesy and efficiency. With this in mind, this bill contains a range of omnibus amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 to further refine the government's carefully balanced income support programs administered under that act. The bill also provides for the implementation of a 1993 budget initiative.

PARA.TAB: The Social Security Act currently provides for the payment of mobility allowance to disabled persons who have jobsearch as part of their agreed activity plan but who cannot use public transport without substantial assistance because of their disability. This bill amends the Social Security Act to ensure that disabled persons undertaking jobsearch activities under a competitive employment, placement and training program will also qualify for mobility allowance.

Under the Social Security Act, a person does not have to make a proper claim for sole parent pension if the person is receiving a wife pension or a carer pension, the person's partner dies, immediately before the end of the bereavement period the person is qualified for wife or carer pension respectively and immediately after the end of that period the person is qualified for sole parent pension. However, this is not the case for a person in similar circumstances who qualifies for widow B pension. The bill corrects this difference by amending the act to allow a person to be granted a widow B pension without the need to make a proper claim in similar circumstances.

It is with much pleasure that I inform the House that this bill gives effect to a new international social security agreement between Australia and the Republic of Italy. The new agreement follows a review instigated by Australia and encouraged by Australian-Italian community groups and representatives.

The Social Security Act provides that, if there is a charge or encumbrance over a particular assessable asset of a person that is not used for primary production, the value of the asset is reduced by the value of that charge or encumbrance. This reduction is not allowed to the extent that the charge or encumbrance is a collateral security or was given for the benefit of a person other than the person or the person's partner. If the charge or encumbrance is over a mix of assessable and exempt assets, it is apportioned between those assets. Assets cannot be reduced by the value of unsecured liabilities and, if a secured liability exceeds the value of the unencumbered asset, the excess is not an allowable deduction.

Amendments were made to the Social Security Act in 1991 to allow more generous rules to apply to primary producers by providing that the aggregate value of primary production assets could be reduced by the aggregate value of their liabilities that are related to the carrying on of primary production. This means that the value of their primary production assets can be reduced by the value of their unsecured liabilities, as well as by the amount that a secured liability exceeds the value of the asset that provides the primary security. However, it was always intended that where a liability exists in relation to an asset that is an any part exempt for the purposes of the assets test, then the apportionment rule should apply. This bill gives effect to that intention.

The Social Security Act provides for certain assets to be disregarded in calculating a person's assets for the purposes of the pensions and benefits assets tests. One type of asset that is disregarded is a life interest unless it is a life interest in the principal home of the person or the person's partner or it has been created by the person or the person's partner. The intention in not allowing these latter types of life interests to be disregarded was to prevent people from gaining an unfair advantage under the assets test by converting absolute interests in property into a life interest.A recent decision of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal—SSAT—highlighted a deficiency in the legislation in situations where a life interest is created under the will of a deceased person who, immediately before their death, was the partner of the life tenant. The bill corrects this deficiency to ensure that these life interests will not be disregarded in calculating the value of a person's assets.

The Social Security Act currently allows the assessable period of a client to be taken into account when the client realises a `saved' non-superannuation investment. Amendments contained in this bill ensure that the assessable period of a non-client partner will also be taken into account. The Social Security Act will also be amended to clarify the existing definition of `retirement village'. This amendment aims at preserving the original intention underlying this definition. It ensures that accommodation primarily intended for persons who are at an age that is more than 55 years is treated in the same way as accommodation primarily intended for persons who are at least 55 years of age; that is, as accommodation in a retirement village.

This bill makes further amendments to the confidentiality provisions of the Social Security Act as part of an ongoing vigilance by the Department of Social Security to safeguard a person's privacy. One of the key amendments relating to confidentiality that is contained in the bill provides for the extension of the definition of `protected information' to protect the information that the department has no information about a person; for example, that the person is not a client of the department.

A further amendment tackles a loophole in the provisions. At the moment, it is not an offence under the Social Security Act for a person to disclose protected information if that information has been obtained by the person through innocent means; for example, if a person finds departmental papers about a client in the street and then tells another person about the details contained in those papers. This bill provides that, should a person obtaining the information know that it is protected information and intentionally record, disclose or otherwise use it, that person will be committing an offence.

A decision by the SSAT must usually be implemented by the Department of Social Security regardless of whether a further appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal is lodged by either the department or the client. If the SSAT decision is to be delayed in its implementation, one of the parties must successfully seek a stay order from the AAT. The department seeks a stay order when it is unsuccessful at the SSAT and appeals to the AAT in situations where implementation of the decision would be detrimental to the longer term interests of the Commonwealth. A client seeks a stay order where he or she is unsuccessful at the SSAT, intends to appeal to the AAT, and wishes to continue to receive advantages that would cease if the SSAT decision were implemented.

Problems arise where the SSAT has affirmed an original departmental decision. The decision on appeal to the AAT is then not the SSAT decision. Rather it is the departmental decision as affirmed by the SSAT. In several cases, the AAT has commented on this as a curious situation, because it means that there is no decision of the SSAT's own that it can stay. It is anomalous that departmental clients in a similar situation could be treated differently by the law depending on whether the SSAT and the department happened to be in agreement. This bill overcomes this anomaly.

The Social Security Act lists all situations where an overpayment can be described as a `debt due to the Commonwealth' and so be recoverable. At present that list does not include a debt that has arisen because of social security payments made pursuant to an AAT stay order granted at the client's request where the client ultimately loses at the AAT and, with hindsight, it is clear that the money was not payable. As a result, these stay order debts cannot be recovered. This bill amends the act to add these debts to the categories of recoverable overpayments.

The government decided in the 1993 budget context to abolish, from 1 July 1994, the administrative charge currently applicable under the Social Security Act in relation to certain debts. The administrative charge will be replaced with a penalty interest charge that can be applied to any debt owed under the act if, and only if, the person who owes the debt is not a current client of the department and refuses to enter into an agreement to repay the debt or if, having entered into such an agreement, the person defaults on the agreement. The bill also makes a number of minor and technical amendments as part of the ongoing exercise to ensure the integrity and accuracy of the Social Security Act.

Finally, the bill corrects an unintended consequence of an earlier amendment to the National Health Act 1953 so as to prevent a person who is a dependent of a mobility allowee from attracting concessional pharmaceutical benefits unless the person can attract those benefits otherwise than because he or she is a dependant of the mobility allowee. I commend this bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe The Hon N.P.

TALKER.NAME: Mr O'KEEFE
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill makes amendments to 16 acts administered within the transport and communications portfolio.The amendments do not introduce substantial new policy schemes, although a number of the amendments do introduce some new policy arrangements and initiatives. In addition, the bill makes a number of technical amendments to a range of portfolio legislation. These amendments correct technical drafting defects and typographical errors which have been discovered since the original passage of the relevant bills. These include deletion of duplicated words, mistaken references to other legislation, spelling mistakes and grammatical errors. The amendments in this respect are all minor technical matters which have no policy significance or impact. I will not address the minor technical amendments in this speech, but will refer to the more significant amendments individually.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1988

PARA.TAB: One of the conditions attached to the release of funds provided under the One Nation statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of 26 February 1992 for upgrading Australia's national intercapital rail network was that the Commonwealth receive appropriate recognition of these funds as equity in the National Rail Corporation Ltd. The bill amends the Australian Land Transport Development Act 1998 to enable the Commonwealth to receive this recognition. Under the amendment the Commonwealth will be entitled to shares in National Rail equivalent to the value of payments made in respect of certain nominated railway projects. The actual issue of the shares, however, must be agreed to by the shareholders of the company in accordance with the intergovernmental shareholders agreement.

The amendments correct a technical restriction in the ALTD Act allowing this equity recognition. The act previously allowed for the payment of grants. This is to be amended to allow funds to also be used for capital contributions which would entitle the Commonwealth to equity recognition, but only with the agreement of shareholders.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Australian National Railways Commission Act 1983

PARA.TAB: The bill amends penalty provisions relating to actions which intentionally or recklessly endanger the safety of a train and increases the maximum penalty that may be prescribed for offences against the by-laws or regulations from $500 to $1,500. In addition, the bill also amends sections 69 and 70 of the act which require the commission to provide to the minister reports of accidents that occur on railways `operated by the Commission' and provide that the minister may establish a board of inquiry to inquire into such accidents.

The precise scope of the phrase `railways operated by the Commission' is somewhat ambiguous, particularly where the operational control and management of a railway owned by the commission may be exercised by another railway authority under a contractual arrangement such as a lease, licence or running agreement. The amendments extend the safety reporting requirements under sections 69 and 70 to cover railways `owned or operated by the Commission' thus ensuring that in the event of any rail safety accident or incident occurring on any of the commission's railways the reporting and inquiry obligations will apply.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988

PARA.TAB: The main amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988 will enable Australia to give effect to article 83 bis of the Chicago convention when it enters into force internationally. The amendments will facilitate the oversight of leased, chartered or interchanged aircraft by enabling a contracting state to enter into bilateral arrangements transferring some or all of its obligations relating to the airworthiness and safe operation of aircraft registered with it to the state in which those aircraft are based.

These arrangements will permit closer and more effective oversight of the safety of such aircraft. As a corollary of these amendments, the Air Navigation Act 1920 is amended to provide for Australian ratification of article 83 bis. The amendments will also clarify the authority's ability to properly regulate foreign registered aircraft which are employed in domestic commercial operations.

The final set of significant amendments to the act will empower the authority to provide safety regulation and other services to other countries and agencies under contract. Such a move has the potential to be an important area of export activity for Australia. Moreover, it has the potential to assist harmonisation of air safety regulation in the Asia-Pacific region, whilst underpinning Australia's regional influence in the area of air traffic management.

On 1 July this year, the Commonwealth took over responsibility for issuing licences to pilots of ships transiting the compulsory pilotage areas in the Great Barrier Reef. This bill will insert a new part in the Navigation Act 1912 to enable the Commonwealth to license pilots operating in the Torres Strait. It will also provide for regulations to be made about a number of operational matters connected with pilotage, such as safe working practices and pilot liability. Some other provisions of the act already applying to ships' crews, such as dealing with abuse of alcohol and drugs, are being extended to include pilots.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992 and to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Levy Act 1992

PARA.TAB: The bill makes several technical amendments to the compensation act, the most significant of which:

SPEECH.PARA: .distinguish `company trainees'—who are in the direct employ of an individual employer—from `industry trainees' for the purposes of claiming compensation;
.allow employers to insure their liabilities with state insurance offices;
.rationalise provisions relating to compensation for travelling expenses incurred in seeking medical treatment;
.ensure that injured seafarers are not required to be examined by a medical panel; and
.increase compensation for funeral costs in line with recent amendments to the Commonwealth Employee's Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act.

The amendments to the levy act give effect to an undertaking by the former Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support to the scrutiny of bills committee. The undertaking related to limiting to the power to prescribe a particular rate of levy, to be paid by employers of seafarers, in the event that the industry fund ceases to operate and the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority assumes the fund's functions and liabilities.

PARA.TAB: The amendments provide that, before the minister advises the Governor-General about the making of a regulation in relation to the rate of levy, the minister shall consult the authority, which includes employer representatives, in respect of:

SPEECH.PARA: .the need to ensure the fund has adequate financial reserves for the purposes of its prudential management;
.reasonable estimates of present and future liabilities under the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992; and
.the cost of administering the authority in connection with the performance or exercise of the fund's functions, powers and obligations.

These amendments ensure that in assessing the relevant rate of levy to cover the authority's costs and liabilities in administering the fund's functions and obligations, the minister must take account of relevant financial matters before advising the Governor-General. As the rate will be prescribed by regulations, the specific rate of levy and the adequacy of consultation would be subject to parliamentary scrutiny and, if considered appropriate, disallowance.

PARA.TAB: These amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991 deal with two matters—numbering and protection of the content of communications. The ability to access and use numbers for telecommunications services is an important aspect of the government's reforms in telecommunications. To this end, the government transferred the responsibility for managing numbering from Telecom to Austel in 1991.

Consistent with the Telecommunications Act, Austel has produced a numbering plan which provides a framework for the allocation and administration of numbers. Within this framework, it is important that the providers of telecommunications services have the flexibility to supply innovative services and packages to meet the needs of consumers.

These amendments are to remove some unintended consequences of the current act that reduce this flexibility. For instance, the amendments remove any restrictions on the further allocation of numbers by persons to whom they have been allocated and remove any doubt that carriers and other persons can charge for numbers they allocate. Accordingly, the amendments ensure that a service provider who has been allocated a number by a carrier can further allocate that number to its customer. If that customer wants a particular number which the carrier or service provider has been allocated because, for example, it has a memorable sequence, the carrier or service provider can charge a fee. It was always intended that the legislative reforms to telecommunications in 1991 would not prevent such charging of fees for special numbers.

The amendments also provide consumer and competitive safeguards through enabling Austel to impose conditions on the use and allocation of such numbers. For example, Austel proposes to prevent fees being charged for the standard numbers allocated for the standard telephone service. It could also be used to enable customers to retain their existing telephone number, where feasible, when they elect to have another carrier provide that service.

Such conditions will be in the form of a disallowable instrument. These amendments have been prepared in consultation with Austel's Numbering Advisory Committee which includes the representatives of carriers, users and consumers. Austel is expected to continue to consult with its Numbering Advisory Committee before determining any conditions.

Section 88 of the Telecommunications Act protects the contents of communications carried by telecommunications carriers and the suppliers of eligible services. Section 88 creates an offence for unauthorised disclosure or use of any fact or document that relates to contents of communications carried, telecommunications services supplied or the affairs or personal particulars of a person.

The bill amends section 88 to provide greater consistency with information privacy principles 10 and 11 of the Privacy Act 1988, which place limits on the disclosure and use of personal information. The amendments will ensure that section 88 protects `information and documents' instead of `facts and documents'. The amendments also make it clear that the protection given by section 88 extends to non-factual information, such as opinions.

The amendments to the Civil Aviation Act 1988, which will expand the Civil Aviation Authority's ability to export a range of aviation related consultancy services overseas, will enable the authority to enter into agreements with other countries or agencies for the provision of consultancy services in relation to air safety regulation and other matters in which it has expertise. The amounts involved will depend on the contracts which the authority successfully negotiates with such countries or agencies. Being able to provide an expanded range of services to overseas countries and agencies should increase the authority's prospects of gaining a number of contracts in the region.The other amendments are not expected to have a significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I present the explanatory memorandum and commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that enervating performance by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr O'Keefe), I have something to say to all those people out there in listener land—the real people of Australia. I was about to wake them up, but we just went off broadcast.

PARA.TAB: Early this morning in my electorate of La Trobe there was an indication that there might be some concern about a media release put out yesterday by Senator Julian McGauran, citing the fact that the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley) had dumped on the children of Australia. After a day of telephone calls and visits to my electorate office, it is now clear that the thought police of the children of Australia organisation have now been put well in train.

A lady from Kilsyth called in to express her concern that if in kindergartens—several people believe the legislation relates to kindergartens—children are not allowed to sing carols a similar ban could be extended to religious instruction in schools. The window cleaner—a regular visitor to the office—was also very concerned that Christian practice and principles were being eroded. A lady from Upwey, who is totally against the legislation, asked what we were going to do about it.

She said that the majority of members, particularly those with Labor leanings, were horrified and had asked that the local member be told of their disgust. She said that children should be allowed to be children and not restricted to behaviour decided by bureaucrats. She wants a copy of the legislation as she does not believe what she is hearing. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: On gender, the booklet disapproves of centres where the staff do not encourage children to enter activities that are traditionally regarded as more appropriate for the other sex. PARA.TAB: For heaven's sake!

Times they are a-changing. But the move towards a sensitive, new age must be by natural evolution, not through Canberra brainwashing tots.
Meanwhile, Senator Crowley should insist that the council's infantile manifesto goes straight into the wastepaper basket of every kinder.

SPEECH.PARA: Honest to goodness. The honourable senator has created a furore in my electorate and, indeed, I suspect around Australia—and a well deserved furore it is. What on earth are we doing in this nation when we provide a booklet of rules, regulations and innuendo that smacks of the most highly engineered social document that I have read in decades? TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to the imputation made during question time today that there was something improper in the allocation of a grant to the Mount Gravatt Workers Club for the redevelopment of facilities at Dittmer Park. I seek tonight to put the facts before the House about this proposal and to reject absolutely any allegations of wrongdoing.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, Mr Speaker, the question raised sought to imply that there was something wrong about my involvement in the project. The fact is that I take my responsibilities very seriously as a local federal member representing the fine citizens of Moreton who have elected me twice to represent them in this place. I am actively involved in a wide range of committees, groups and associations working to provide facilities, services and programs to the people in the southern suburbs of Brisbane.

I am the chairperson of the establishment committee for the Mount Gravatt Workers Club. I am proud to be part of this exciting new development which will greatly enhance the facilities available to the whole community. There are 11 other members of this establishment committee, all from the southern suburbs area, including a number of important local community and business leaders who are not members of any political party.

The Mount Gravatt Workers Club has been working with the management committees of the Mount Gravatt Australian Football Club and the Mount Gravatt Soccer Club to create a single new club on the site of Dittmer Park and build excellent club, sporting and recreational facilities at this site. The application for a grant was made on the basis of demonstrated need in this inner urban area for facilities for youth and women, and to cater for the child-care needs of sports men and women utilising these facilities. The aim of the project is to broaden the facilities available at Dittmer Park so there is much greater utilisation by the whole community.

The grant application was made at the same time as an application was made to the Brisbane City Council for an approval in principle for the redevelopment of the project, approval which has subsequently been granted. The total cost of the project is over $5 million. The Commonwealth grant was for $200,000. The terms and conditions of this grant are that the department reimburse the club for expenditure already made on the specific proposals contained in the grant application.

Up to this time, $18,000 has been reimbursed to the club from the department for design costs associated with the proposal. The club has expended almost $40,000 in design and associated activities in preparation for the redevelopment. The awarding of the Commonwealth grant has also been a major catalyst for substantial support for the project from a number of quarters in the community. The discussions and planning for this new project have involved a very public, fully transparent process, including four public meetings held over the past 18 months at the site of the Mount Gravatt Australian Football Club. Further, the proposed redevelopment was on show for three days at the Mount Gravatt show held in late July which stimulated a great deal of public discussion and approval.

As the local member of parliament, I am very much in touch with the needs and aspirations of my local community, and am active in working with local organisations. I also convene the establishment committee for the southern suburbs employment network, a group of local business people, training providers, government departments and agencies in the southern suburbs of Brisbane working on strategies to stimulate employment in our area. Is there anything wrong with being involved in that?

I am also convenor of the southern suburbs senior citizens picnic and concert committee which plans and conducts a major public function for over 2,000 senior citizens in Mott Park each July in Senior Citizens Week in Queensland. Is there something wrong with being involved in that committee? I have also convened for the past 18 months an informal group of church and community youth workers investigating the need for youth counselling services in our area. As you can see, Mr Speaker, I am an active participant in a range of committees and organisations trying to identify the needs of our local community and serving the needs of Moreton. I am proud to be involved in that way.

The redevelopment project at Dittmer Park reflects a considerable need for facilities serving youth and the needs of families for a broader range of appropriate services in our area. Any imputations of improper behaviour or inappropriate funding are completely without foundation and are totally rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth Ms T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, we have all become accustomed to seeing newspaper headlines about the state of our health system, hospital waiting lists and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) staring each other down before these issues are discussed in caucus. In my state of South Australia we have newspaper headlines such as, `Waiting lists crucial to seats'. On 28 October this year in the Adelaide Advertiser respected journalist, Barry Hailstone, wrote:

PARA.TAB: There are 8,000 South Australians on public hospital waiting lists and their votes may well decide the outcome of individual seats.
If you have waited six months for a hip replacement at Flinders Medical Centre or the Royal Adelaide Hospital and you live in the marginal Labor seat of Unley—

SPEECH.PARA: which happens to be in the Federal electorate of Adelaide—
there may never be a better time to make your mark.

PARA.TAB: Under Medicare, SA public hospitals started off with 60 per cent funding from the Commonwealth. This has now dropped to about 40 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Michael Armitage, the state member for Adelaide and shadow minister for health, recently drew attention to the state of affairs at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital where beds have been closed due to severe cuts. Last year, 100 nurses were laid off and now the hospital is suffering from a shortage of nurses and further bed closures. Dr Armitage said there were concerns about the hospital's gynaecological ward being closed at weekends, forcing patients to be moved.

PARA.TAB: We can all feel concerned when reading these stories, but without feeling any emotion, particularly those familiar with this area. Recently, having spoken on the ABC to Keith Conlon about our home and community care programs, I had a number of phone calls from people in South Australia. Jan Quick, who is not a constituent of mine but of Wakefield, drove from Gawler to speak to me. I felt privileged to have spoken to her because it was one of those rare occasions when one feels that one has spoken to a very courageous woman who is having to be very brave. She later put her experiences to me in writing:

SPEECH.PARA: In March of this year I was diagnosed as having Ovarian Sarcoma Stage 3 bordering on Stage 4 with pelvic seeding. I had radical surgery followed by chemotherapy. From this point on until August I subjected myself on a monthly basis to the hell that is chemotherapy.

I chose to have the chemotherapy at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital in Ward M1 which contains the gynae-oncology unit. This hospital was, until last month, unique in the state inasmuch as it offered care from diagnosis to death. Put more bluntly it offered a hospice service. The cost containment forced on the Queen Elizabeth Hospital by an ill-informed minister dictated that this ward be closed each week from Friday until Monday morning. The problems of nursing patients with gynaecological cancer can be profoundly disturbing to both the patient and the nurse. Indeed it requires special skills to undertake this type of care. By reducing the ward of 7 shifts involves a loss of skills hard won.

I had chosen to die in this ward where I was known by the staff whose care cannot be sufficiently praised. However, thanks to the intervention of you master Evans, I will have to make alternate arrangements for it is not necessarily possible to die between 10am on Monday and 6pm the following Friday.

I could, of course, be transferred up to M2 or M3, which are maternity wards and where those gynae patients, not ready for discharge would be transferred. But I think I would prefer to die without the singing of new born babies cries in my ears and I am sure, for those giving birth, my death may well spoil their occasion.
Jan continues to speak in high praise of a younger woman who has chosen to give up her job to care for her. But she then continues:

This country makes no provision whatsoever for we country people with terminal or disabling illness. Two visits a day from the district nurse would have been irrelevant in my condition. The administration of medication alone was extremely frequent and needing ongoing titration. Meals on Wheels are not equipped to supply the high protein diet that is necessary to offset the devastating consequences of protein deficiency.

I have to say that I think the health service and after care is a total disgrace. I should have thought it patently obvious, even to the most limited of intellects, that if you have ongoing increases in medical technology eg. Liver transplants, heart and lung transplants, costs will inevitably increase.
Jan told me in conversation that she would be pleased to die on the steps of Parliament House to make her protest known.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about a serious matter in our community—mental health. The recent Burdekin report and other moves by the government on this matter are overdue and very welcome. I am particularly pleased to see that my colleagues opposite are taking a professional and not political approach to this matter. This problem needs the brains and cooperation of all of us. I, for one, am always keen to cooperate with the Liberal and National coalition parties in dealing with Australia's serious problem.

PARA.TAB: The changes brought about over the past half a dozen years in the field of mental heath are not uniformly good or successful. We all welcome the end of punitive imprisonment in psychiatric hospitals. However, it must be said that `release into the community' has been a failure for very many mental health patients. The sight of these poor people living in disgraceful circumstances, unwashed, poorly fed and badly tended is proof of this failure.

I notice that many hospitals have very large grounds. Can motel style accommodation not be provided on these grounds? Most of these destitute patients are not bed cases. They can often fend well enough during the day. However, a certain degree of professional supervision for cleanliness, regular meals and proper medication is obviously essential.

I can assure the House that the sight of these poor neglected people is distressing to other Australians and lowers public morale—not to mention the infringement of the rights of the patients themselves. They are Australians in need and we have a duty of care. I am convinced that the government should resist the situation where the drug companies set the cultural tone in the field of psychiatric care.

I have discussed this matter with Mrs Lou Holland, a constituent who has worked as a volunteer in this field for over 10 years. Her group, SOMA, is an unfunded self-help organisation which has done excellent work over the years. It proves that drugs are not the be-all of psychiatric care, and I commend it for its work.

A holistic approach, which gives due emphasis to diet, allergies, and ordinary medical attention to physical complaints, is now known to be contributory to personal wellbeing. The old method of a handful of tablets three times a day is a primitive approach. The government must broaden its attitude and not let itself be manipulated by the `god-doctor' attitude.

Sadly, there are still quite a number of very seriously ill psychiatric patients in Australia. Current medical practice is to control the symptoms by use of psychotropic drugs. The theory is to control the symptoms, place patients in the community and rehabilitate them. This concept is a failure for a considerable number of severe cases.

Without 24-hour a day supervision of the drug intake, the problems will include: failure to control symptoms, resulting in unacceptable behaviour and even suicide; unintended side effects; and failure to even be administered properly. It is neither decent nor professional to administer mind-altering drugs to people without proper supervision. Such supervision can be better organised by use of day clinics and non-coercive accommodation on hospital grounds. The cost of this can be discussed by the department of health and the Department of Social Security.

My own electorate of Lowe is in the inner west of Sydney and is the venue for many of these poor unfortunates to try to be `rehabilitated into the community'. This expression is a cruel joke on these people. It is obvious to anyone who looks that utter confusion is the daily lot for many of these people. It is obvious that they receive no care as to their personal or clothing cleanliness. Heaven knows what they eat—or their actual nutritional state of health.

I would hope that all honourable members can see that this is a social problem which needs immediate attention. It will not improve by itself. We do not want to see Australia decline socially. We have all seen films of degenerated cities abroad where the streets are full of the poor, the sick, the violent and the psychiatric. Unless we act decisively, this fate awaits our cities in the near future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter Mr R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —With deep regret I rise to inform the House that it has been mooted that the two pathology units presently operating in Tully are to be terminated by the federal government department of health. I would appreciate assurances from the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services (Mr Howe), representing the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), that this will not happen.

PARA.TAB: I remind the minister and the government that, to quote the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, the World Heritage listing cost this area 1,000 jobs. It was claimed that the state government applied for the listing, although I have my doubts about that. That application cost Tully another 1,000 jobs, making a loss of 2,000 jobs. The closure of the railway operations in the area probably cost it another 50 or 100 jobs. Whilst that is not the fault of the federal government, it is most certainly the fault of the ALP government in Queensland.

I deeply regret the attitude of the government, as well as the leadership on this side of the House on free trade in the sugar and the banana industries. This has undermined confidence in both of those industries, which has had an enormous detrimental effect on the development of Tully, so much so in the sugar industry that we now have an offer for the first time probably this century for the purchase of the cooperatively owned, farmer owned, mills of Tully.

It seems to me everything in this country will soon be owned by foreigners if this government continues to operate on the policies of the level playing field so much espoused by it and so much implemented by it in this place. Once again, I deeply regret that similar policies have been espoused on our side of the House as well.
Tate and Lyle have offered to the farmers almost exactly—and I quote from the front page of the Tully Times:

SPEECH.PARA: half the listed value of sugar shares in other mills in the state of Queensland
That is an insult to the farmers. It amounts to pretty close to what I would describe as a con.

PARA.TAB: The deregulation of the industry will leave the farmers in a situation where they have only one mill to sell to, which means that the mill enjoys a monopoly and can pay to the farmers whatever price it wishes to pay because the farmers have no other person they can sell the cane to. It is not a commodity that can be put on the back of a truck and carted up the road to the next mill because it is far too heavy to cart any distance at all.

So we will return this industry to what it was last century when North Queenslanders worked for slave labour wage levels for the foreign landlord. That is what will happen if this government continues to pursue a policy of deregulation of that industry.

The policy of this government allows European sugar, subsidised at 193 per cent—without any impositions upon it whatsoever—into this country to compete with our sugar producers. If that is a level playing field, I am certainly a Martian astronaut.

Switching subjects completely before I sit down, the recent Industry Commission report on the taxi industry was almost an entirely unbelievable document. It has suggested that the industry should be totally deregulated. If these recommendations are accepted, people who have paid an average price of $100,000 to $150,000 for taxi licences will have licences which are worth absolutely nothing.

The Industry Commission report says that this could lower the price of taxi services to consumers throughout Australia by five or 10 per cent. In return for this remote possibility we will completely destroy 30,000 Australians or, alternatively, find $2,500 million because that is the present value of taxi licences throughout Australia.

It is extraordinary that the commission would seriously countenance that the government should pay $2,500 million or, alternatively, that every single one of these people should see every single cent they have in the world thrown away. All the taxidrivers in the Kennedy electorate have invested almost every cent they have in the entire world—and a lot they do not have—in their taxi licences. Those licenses were purchased in good faith. This extraordinary document has come from a very important government body, a highly respected—I deeply regret to say—government body. I do not know how it can have the standing it enjoys. Its recommendations have been followed on so many occasions.

In the dairying industry the commission's recommendations have been implemented by the state government with the net result that in many parts of Queensland no milk is being delivered. Old people who rely very much on milk, which carries considerable important nourishment for them, cannot afford to go to town; they have no car, so they now simply have to go without milk. Deregulation has been a totally disastrous failure. To implement it in the taxi industry will be just another disastrous failure.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to follow such a great socialist, the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). I rise tonight because I did not have an opportunity today to speak on the motion of the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) before the House regarding regional and rural Australia. Basically, his motion indicated that the government had not done and was not doing anything for regional or rural Australia. As someone who represents rural and regional Australia, and a big part of Tasmania, I would like to address some of those issues.

PARA.TAB: I believe that market forces on a worldwide basis have a great effect on regional Australia. The decisions regarding prices of our commodities are set well beyond our shores in many regards, and that has great effects of regionalism. Today in the local press in my electorate a copper mine, which has been open for a hundred years, has set a date to close—in December 1994. The manager of that mine said that `the mine would stay open if copper prices stayed above US$0.70 a pound'. That mine, which has operated for a hundred years—and had three or four generations of Tasmanians working in it—is going to close. It will close because of the price of copper outside Australia. These are issues that I do not believe government has much control over.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about native title?

—In Tasmania I do not think that will affect our mining industry very much at all, but that is another debate and I will not be sidetracked onto that. GATT issues are important to this whole debate, and I do not think that has been touched on.

PARA.TAB: I would like to go to some of the programs which I have seen this government put in place to assist regional and rural Australia. Since this debate started with Queensland, the sugar industry infrastructure program is basically in place to assist the sugar industry. The Murray-Darling Basin initiative is helping that region with its own particular problems.

The farm forestry program is of major benefit to Tasmania in getting farmers into farming trees. This can create local jobs in rural and regional areas, and it is a great program. We need to work through a few basic problems. I understand that there is a bit of a taxation difficulty that we have to get through, but it is a program that this government is looking at.

The rural adjustment scheme is a program that has been used in my electorate to assist some people in rural areas to get off farms which have become uneconomical. It assists people to get off with some dignity. In the past we have not had those programs.

The rural assessment program is a program set up to access information through computers, faxes and other modern communications for rural and regional areas. In the Department of Tourism there are regional tourism development programs. The national ecotourism strategy is very important in Tasmania, combining our forest areas with tourism, and that is starting to develop very well. The rural tourism program is a major program in Tasmania. We now have colonial accommodation scattered right across the state using old accommodation going back to the early settlements. It is very good for jobs in our regional areas.

I have seen many of the DEET programs training young people in local areas to have jobs. There are a lot of labour market programs. Early in December I believe Bill Kelty and Lindsay Fox will bring down a report dealing with regional Australia. I look forward to that.

The government has acknowledged the drift of some parts of the population from rural and regional areas. I believe we will develop even more policies that will be focused on regional and rural Australia. I do not believe that governments in the past have focused on these areas as much as they could have done, and I believe that we will see a major plus in the future.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 5 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that (a) there is only one Medicare office in the Division of Cowan and (b) the closest Medicare offices to most electors of Cowan are more than a twenty minute journey by vehicle.
(2) Are the electors of Cowan entitled to an easily accessible Medicare office.
(3) Is it a fact that while the population of Cowan grew by 20 per cent between 1986 and 1991, there was no corresponding adjustment to the Medicare services available to the community.
(4) Will a Medicare office be constructed at the Warwick shopping centre, WA; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) (a) There are no Medicare offices in the Division of Cowan, although there are three offices within a kilometre of the boundaries of the Division of Cowan;
(b) No part of Cowan is further than 8 kilometres away from a Medicare office and therefore no more than a 10 minute journey by vehicle.
