TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 18 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has his attention been drawn to expressions of concern by non-government schools concerning the annual collection of school financial data.
(2) Will he review the new data collection rules to ensure they are not unfair or unreasonable in their effect on non-government schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am aware of the concerns of some non-government schools about the revised financial questionnaire for non-government schools.

(2) The questionnaire has always been subject to regular review and refinement. The purpose of the recent reformatting was to ensure an equitable distribution of funds in the non-government sector based on an accurate reporting of schools' financial data. The questionnaire as it now stands will give fair treatment to all schools. Nevertheless, my Department will monitor the impact of the changes to the questionnaire and make recommendations to me on any refinements which may be necessary in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Naval Air Station (NAS) Nowra management review team decide that facilities associated with the Naval Aircraft Commercial Support Program at Nowra, NSW, were non-core.

(2) Is it a fact that current Defence Instructions require the Assistant Chief of the Defence Force (Development) and the First Assistant Secretary of the Force Development and Analysis Division to make the decision on core/non-core classification.
(3) Is the core/non-core classification critical in determining candidates for the Commercial Support Program (CSP).
(4) Has an intermediate maintenance activity classification been issued to the CSP management review team with respect to NAS Nowra; if so, (a) when and (b) from whom was it issued.
(5) Are fleet intermediate maintenance activities for fleet surface units classified as core activities.
(6) Why are the intermediate maintenance elements for RAN aviation classified as non-core activities.

(7) Is it a fact that serving RAN officers who had access to commercial-in-confidence information in relation to a Defence in-house bid for workshops at NAS Nowra were subsequently involved in providing advice on opposing bids as employees of tendering contractors, one of whom was the successful tenderer against the RAN's in-house bid.
(8) Is the workload associated with the RAN's S-70B-2 helicopter maintenance poorly defined.
(9) How were the operational support and financial risks to the RAN associated with a fixed price contract arrangement assessed against the workload associated with helicopter maintenance.
(10) Were copies of the NAS Nowra in-house bid freely circulated; if so, in what way was the bidding process fair and above board.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The activity conducted within the NAS Nowra workshops (aircraft component maintenance) was given a non-core classification by Navy and this was agreed by the Assistant Chief of the Defence Force (Development) (ACDEV) and the First Assistant Secretary of the Force Development and Analysis Division (FASFDA) on 1 May 1992.

(2) Yes. On 1 May 1992, ACDEV and FASFDA agreed a Deputy Chief of Naval Staff proposed classification of core/non-core activities in Navy, which included a determination that the activities conducted in the NAS Nowra workshops are non-core.
(3) Yes. Activities designated `core' are not considered for commercialisation.

(4) No. Navy does not issue classifications regarding the level of maintenance performed in workshops in the context of the Commercial Support Program. The activity performed within the NAS Nowra workshops is however designated non-core.
(5) Yes.

(6) Some maintenance elements for RAN aviation are designated as core. For example, the activities performed by maintenance personnel on RAN aircraft squadrons are core because these maintenance personnel might be deployed to an area of operations. Similarly, some Service personnel in the NAS Nowra workshops form a Mobile Aircraft Support Team which is deployable to areas of operations. The activities performed by the Mobile Aircraft Support Team are also designated core, which meant that this part of the workshop activity was exempt from CSP review. For virtually all of the NAS Nowra workshops, however, the activities performed are not deployable, hence the classification as a non-core activity.

(7) No. Two former RAN commissioned officers are now employed by British Aerospace (Australia) Ltd at NAS Nowra. Neither had access to commercial-in-confidence material relating to the In-House-Bid which was lodged by NAS Nowra. The normal Departmental rules on post separation employment were followed when the officers left the Service.

(8) No. The workload is adequately defined and was properly specified in the Statement of Requirement released with the Aircraft Component Maintenance Request for Quotation (RFQ) to industry. In any event a significant proportion of the S-70B-2 maintenance activity does not form part of the scope of work contained in the contract between British Aerospace (Australia) Ltd and the Commonwealth. Parts were excluded from CSP review pending finalisation of Test Program Sets to be used to diagnose some S-70B-2 equipment and the acceptance into Naval service of facilities to test S-70B-2 T700 engines and Main Rotor Blade Dampers. On finalisation of the Test Program Sets and facilities for equipment testing, the remaining S-70B-2 maintenance activities will be tested for commercialisation, if designated as non-core.

(9) During the source selection phase of the review of aircraft component maintenance a very detailed analysis of technical and financial risks was conducted by the Source Selection Team. The Source Selection report was later reviewed by a Senior Navy Committee with One Star and Captain level representation. The Committee noted the exceptional quality of the Source Selection report, and agreed that the requirements of probity, propriety and thoroughness in the Source Selection recommendation had been met. Following review by the Senior Navy Committee, the Flag Officer Naval Support Command agreed the recommendation that British Aerospace (Australia) Ltd be selected as the preferred source.

(10) No. The NAS Nowra In-House Option was treated exactly the same as any other commercial-in-confidence tender bid with the normal safeguards against disclosure applied. Moreover all parties who had access to the In-House-Option bid during the evaluation process were given a directive which required the strict confidentiality and safe-keeping of the document. The bidding process was at all times fair and above board. Selection of British Aerospace (Australia) Pty Ltd as the preferred source will result in annual recurring savings of approximately $5 million to the Commonwealth. Moreover, the cost of the preferred source is 70 percent less than the previous means of conducting the activity (the status quo).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 21 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) How will the ongoing eligibility of recipients of income support under the New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS) be assessed.

(2) Is the Department of Employment, Education and Training developing a formula for assessing the eligibility for NEIS support on means testing the business income against income generated on a monthly basis.
(3) Will the Department liaise with managing agents of the NEIS network to ensure suitable means testing guidelines are developed.
(4) Have managing agents of the NEIS network identified many areas of potential cost saving which they have conveyed to the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)&(2) The details of how continued eligibility for income support under NEIS is assessed have not yet been finalised. Implementation will be in early 1994 following consultations with interested parties.
(3) Yes.

(4) I am advised that the Department has received no submissions from the NEIS Managing Agents' network identifying potential cost savings, although there have been some discussions regarding cost savings.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, upon notice, on 28 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 284, (Hansard, 27 September 1993, page 1175), on what date and in what form did the Government consult with the States and Territories regarding ratification of the 1989 Unesco Convention on Technical and Vocational Education.
(2) On what date and in what form did each State and Territory respond.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Federal Government consulted with the States and Territories regarding ratification of the 1989 Unesco Convention on Technical and Vocational Education by letter dated 9 December 1991. The Federal Government followed up this initial letter with telephone and facsimile inquiries to Queensland, Australian Capital Territory, Victoria and New South Wales concerning their respective State and Territory responses to the ratification of the Convention. These inquiries happened during the week ending 12 March 1993.
The Federal Government wrote to New South Wales clarifying the Constitutional position on ratification of the Convention by letter dated 21 April 1992.

(2) All States and Territories except New South Wales support the ratification by Australia of the Convention. South Australia responded first by a letter dated 19 December 1991, followed by Tasmania by a letter dated 7 January 1992, New South Wales (negative response) by letter dated 9 January 1992, and Northern Territory by a letter dated 29 January 1992, Australian Capital Territory by letter dated 23 March 1993 and Victoria through an oral response by telephone on 26 March 1993. Western Australia provided a response by letter dated 15 April 1993.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders: Monetary Assistance or Benefit

PARA.TAB: (1) What direct monetary assistance or benefit is available on an individual basis to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders under programs operating within the Minister's portfolio.
(2) Which forms of assistance or benefits are not means tested.
(3) How many persons received each form of assistance or benefit in 1992-93.

(3) Not Applicable
